**The Complete Works of Patriarch Lü**
**Volume 1: The Original Biography of Patriarch Lü**

*Preface to the Original Biography in The Complete Works of Patriarch Lü*

Patriarch Lü, in response to the Supreme Yang Emperor, declared, "Only when all sentient beings are delivered shall I ascend." Yet even after his ascension, he continued to transform and deliver the world. Thus, from the Tang dynasty to the present, his manifestations and transformations have been myriad. The world calls him "Immortal Lü," while he refers to himself as "The Returning Daoist" or "Lord of the Supreme Palace." Having ultimately realized the rank of Supreme Sage and Teacher, his numinous traces are too numerous to record in full.

This biography follows the original account in sequence, with occasional additions and annotations for reference.

As for the divergent accounts in circulation: some claim he was originally of the Tang imperial clan, surnamed Li, and named either *Huan* or *Qiong*, entering the mountains with his wife to cultivate together and changing his surname to Lü; others say he passed the imperial examinations and became a magistrate, or that he failed the examinations; some assert that at sixty-four he traveled to Chang’an and encountered the Supreme Yang Emperor, while others claim he ascended at sixty-four to pay homage to the Jade Emperor of Primordial Beginning; some hold that he was born on the fourteenth day of the fourth month, others on the fourth day of the eighth month. As for the year of his birth, some say it was during the *Zhen’guan* era, others the *Tianbao* or *Zhenyuan* eras—such variations abound.

Patriarch Lü once remarked, "Call me an ox, and I respond as an ox; call me a horse, and I respond as a horse. The world’s errors may be true or false—what did I have to do with anything before the Tang?" His words were truly enlightened.

When the Most High descended to be born, he took Li as his surname; when the snow-clad mountain first bore him, he emerged from a *qi*-womb. Dragons coiled around the chamber, and the five stars shone in the courtyard—such divine portents were precise and unerring. The births of immortals, buddhas, sages, and worthies have always been extraordinary. How, then, could I presume to fathom Patriarch Lü?

Compiled by Liu Tishu, styled *Wuwuzi*, of Yiling
Collated by his son Liu Yincheng, styled *Qinghui*, and nephew Liu Yuncheng, styled *Qingxu*
Revised by Huang Chengshu, styled *Yixingzi*, of Shaxian

*Eulogy*

The greatest divine power
Lies in loyalty and filial piety;
Benefiting self and others—
The grand Dao of a thousand autumns.

From ancient times to the present,
Karmic conditions are not trifling;
Freely brushed onto the page,
A portrait before one’s eyes.

Again—
A sword slashes through autumn,
Pure wind fills both sleeves;
The Dao resides in the Three-in-One,
The elixir perfected, cycling through the Nine.

Cangwu and the Northern Sea,
The imperial homeland of white clouds;
A single drop from the Gan River—
Its source distant, its flow long.

*The Original Biography of Patriarch Lü*
*(Collated from the *Complete Writings on the Dao*, *Marvelous Traces of Immortals and Buddhas*, *Comprehensive Mirror of Divine Immortals*, and *Complete Tang Poems*. Discrepancies are annotated beneath the text for reference.)*

Patriarch Lü’s personal name was Yan, his courtesy name Dongbin. His family had long been natives of Yongle County, Hezhong Prefecture. His great-grandfather, Yanzhi, served the Tang as Military Commissioner of Hedong; his grandfather, Wei, ended his career as Vice Minister of Rites; his father, Rang, was Prefect of Haizhou.

Born on the fourteenth day of the fourth month of the fourteenth year of the Zhenyuan era (at the *si* hour), his mother, as she lay in childbed, was enveloped in a strange fragrance, while celestial music drifted through the air. A white crane descended from the heavens and vanished into the bed curtains. At birth, his form was golden, his essence wooden—crane’s crown, tortoise’s back, tiger’s body, dragon’s jowls, kingfisher brows, phoenix eyes, a long neck with prominent cheekbones, a broad forehead and rounded frame, a straight and towering nose bridge, a face of pale yellow hue. A black mole marked the corner of his left brow, another beneath his left eye. His head was large, his feet bore hidden patterns like tortoise-shell creases.

From childhood, he was keen and quick-witted, memorizing ten thousand words a day and composing essays extemporaneously. In adulthood, he stood five *chi* and two *cun* tall, fond of wearing a Huayang cap, a pale yellow *lan* robe, and a black sash, his bearing reminiscent of Zhang Zifang.

At twenty, he remained unmarried, still in swaddling clothes. Master Ma saw him and remarked, *"This child’s bone structure is extraordinary—naturally a figure beyond the dust of the world. When you encounter a hut, dwell there; when you see a bell, strike it. Keep this in mind."* Later, all came to pass as foretold.

He later traveled to Mount Lu, where he met the Fire Dragon Perfected and received the *Celestial Concealment Sword Technique*. Thereafter, he wandered the world selling ink among the common folk, styling himself *Master Pure Yang*.

During the Xiantong era, he passed the imperial examinations at the age of sixty-four. Later, while visiting a wineshop in Chang’an, he saw a Daoist—green turban, white robe, long whiskers, and bright eyes—carrying a purple bamboo staff and a large gourd at his waist. The Daoist inscribed three quatrains on the wall:

*Seated or reclining, I always carry a jug of wine,
Lest my eyes ever recognize the imperial capital.
Vast as heaven and earth, yet nameless—
A carefree man of the world, a true husband.*

*True immortals who have attained the Dao are not easily met;
When shall I return? I wish you would follow.
I say my dwelling adjoins the azure sea—
It is the first peak of Penglai, apart from all.*

*Do not weary of chasing joy and laughter,
For pondering separation and chaos grieves the spirit.
Leisurely, I count on my fingers—
How many have known true peace in this world?*

Struck by the Daoist’s archaic and extraordinary appearance and the soaring spirit of his verses, Patriarch Lü bowed and inquired after his name. The Daoist replied, *"My compound surname is Zhongli, my given name Quan, my courtesy name Yunfang."* Patriarch Lü bowed again and invited him to sit.

Zhong said, *"Might you recite a quatrain? I would fain observe it."* Patriarch Lü thereupon presented a quatrain:

*Born to the Confucian path in times of peace—
The weight of office hangs heavy, while coarse cloth feels light.
Who in this world would vie for fame and gain?
I serve the Jade Emperor, returning to the Upper Clarity.*

Zhongli beheld the poem and rejoiced inwardly. They then rested together in a tavern. Zhongli himself rose to tend the stove, while Patriarch Lü, overcome by weariness, pillowed his head upon the table and dozed. In his dream, he journeyed to the capital as an examination candidate, passed the imperial exams, and began his career in local posts before ascending to the ranks of ministerial secretary, remonstrator, academician, and custodian of the imperial archives—every eminent office he traversed in turn. Promoted, then demoted; demoted, then promoted again. Two wives, daughters of wealthy families, were wed in his youth; sons and grandsons flourished, the household brimming with capped and gowned officials. For nearly forty years he served, then a decade more as sole minister, his power and influence scorching all. Suddenly, he was charged with grave crimes: his family’s wealth confiscated, his wives and children scattered, himself exiled to the southern frontier, left alone, destitute, and gaunt. As he stood astride his horse amid wind and snow, a deep sigh arose—

Then, in a start, he awoke. Zhongli was beside him, the millet still uncooked, and laughed, saying:
*"The millet is not yet done—
A dream has carried you to the land of Hua Xu."*

Patriarch Lü exclaimed, *"Master, did you know my dream?"*
Zhong replied, *"The dream you just dreamed—its rises and falls, its countless glories and sorrows—all spanned fifty years in but a moment. What is there to rejoice in gain, or grieve in loss? Only when one awakens to the Great Dao does one realize this world is but a vast dream."*

Patriarch Lü, moved to sudden enlightenment, understood that the path of officialdom was not worth clinging to. He bowed again and said, *"Master, you are no ordinary man. I beg you to teach me the art of transcending the world."*

Zhong declined, saying: *"Your bones are not yet whole, your will and conduct not yet settled. If you seek to transcend the world, you must pass through several more lifetimes."* With that, he departed in a flutter.

Patriarch Lü, disheartened and lost, resigned his office and withdrew into seclusion. Thereafter, Zhongli tested Patriarch Lü ten times:

1. One day, returning from outside, he saw that all his family had fallen ill and died. His heart held no grief—he simply prepared coffins with care. Soon after, the dead all revived.

2. Once, selling goods in the market, he agreed on a price. The buyer suddenly paid only half, yet he made no dispute. He did not even take the half, but left the goods behind and departed.

3. On New Year’s Day, a beggar leaned against his door, seeking alms. He gave money and goods. The beggar demanded more, hurling abuse. He bowed again and again in apology, until the beggar laughed and left.

4. Herding sheep in the mountains, he encountered a tiger chasing the flock. He pushed the sheep down a steep slope and stood alone before the beast. The tiger then turned and left.

5. Alone in a thatched hut in the mountains, reading, a girl of seventeen or eighteen appeared—her radiance dazzling, her adornments and voice pure and lovely. She claimed to be returning to her mother’s home, weary from travel, and asked to rest a while. Soon, she began to tease and entice him in every way, pressing him to share her bed through the night. Yet he remained unmoved.

6. One day, traveling in the countryside, he returned to find his household possessions plundered by bandits, leaving almost nothing for his daily needs.

He showed no sign of resentment, supporting himself by tilling the soil. One day, while hoeing, he uncovered several dozen cakes of gold. He quickly covered them again and took not a single piece.

7. Once, in the marketplace, he purchased several copper vessels and took them home, only to find they had turned to gold. He immediately sought out the owner and returned them.

8. A mad Daoist priest wandered the streets selling medicine, proclaiming, “Whoever takes this will die at once, but in the next life will attain the Dao.” After ten days with no buyers, he bought the medicine himself and consumed it without ill effect.

9. In spring, floodwaters surged, and his small boat was swept into the current. Waves tossed and churned, yet he sat unmoving, and in the end, he came to no harm.

10. One day, sitting alone in his room, he suddenly saw countless grotesque spirits and demons: some sought to strike him, others to kill him, yet he felt no fear. Then, several dozen night specters appeared, dragging a prisoner in shackles, blood and flesh dripping, wailing and shrieking, “You killed me in a past life—repay my life at once!” He replied, “A life for a life—what objection could there be?” He immediately seized a knife and rope to end his own life. Suddenly, a rebuke rang out from the void, and all the ghosts and spirits vanished. A man descended, clapping his hands—it was Ancestor Zhong. He said, “The dust of the world is hard to extinguish, and those with immortal potential are rare. My search for a worthy one surpasses even their search for me! Ten times I tested you, and you remained unmoved—you are certain to attain the Dao! Yet your merit and conduct are not yet complete. I will teach you the secret arts of alchemy, that you may aid the world and benefit all things. When your three thousand merits are fulfilled and your eight hundred deeds perfected, I will come to deliver you.” He asked, “In the work of metal transmutation, will there be any anomalies?”

The Ancestor replied, “After three thousand years, it shall return to its original essence.” Lü Zu’s voice grew somber as he said, “To mislead people for three thousand years—I would rather not.” Zhong laughed and said, “With such a heart as yours, the three thousand merits and eight hundred deeds are already fulfilled in this! This test alone suffices.”

He then recounted to him the history of his renunciation of the world and attainment of the Dao, adding, “The inscription of Master Ku Zhu said: ‘When you journey among men, you will meet one with two mouths—he shall be your disciple.’ I have roamed mountains and seas, yet never encountered a man with two mouths! Now, examining your surname, it truly matches the record of Ku Zhu. I dwell on Crane Ridge in Zhongnan—would you follow me there?”

Lü thus accompanied him. Beneath the radiance of stars and moon, all was still and desolate. Zhong took Lü’s hand as they walked, and after just a few steps, it seemed as though they rode swift horses, crossing mountains and rivers. In an instant, they arrived at the southern cave, where the gate was locked. Zhong struck Lü’s belt with a jade tablet, and together they slipped through the crevice—suddenly, all was bright and vast. Ascending a high peak, they reached the eastern gate of the great cave, where two tigers crouched in guard. Zhong rebuked them, and the tigers lay still, allowing them to enter. There were golden towers and jade terraces, rare birds and jasper trees, their radiance dazzling, the climate like spring.

They sat upon a serpentine stone, drinking three cups of *yuanhe* wine. Soon, a maiden in green appeared—her double buns adorned with golden bells, crimson robes and kingfisher sleeves, cloud-patterned shoes and jade pendants—exotic fragrance curling about her. She bore a jade seal and golden-scripted paper, saying, “The assembly of immortals has gathered in the Upper Palace of Penglai. They urgently summon you to the Heavenly Pond Assembly to discuss the *Divine Travels of the Five Primordial Lords*.”

As Zhong Ancestor prepared to depart, Lü Ancestor, fearing he might not return, composed a poem to send him off:

“To meet one of lofty Dao is rare indeed—
Yet now you journey east to grace the immortal altar.
A staff tipped with spring’s hue, a gourd of wine,
A crown of five-hued clouds piled high upon your head.
The sea-turtle’s child drinks deep, unknown to men,
The mountain-burning talisman eludes the gaze of ghosts.
When you depart, this body must wither with age—
I beg you, grant this poor scholar the Elixir of Bone-Transformation.”

Zhong replied, “Simply remain here; I shall not be gone long.” Then, facing southeast, he rode upon a cloud of purple and departed.

Lü Ancestor took up the plain silk scroll that had accompanied him, unfolding it to read and recite with delight. Ten days later, Zhong returned and asked, “You have dwelt in this solitude—do you not long for home?”

Lü answered, “Having resolved my heart to study the Dao, how could I yearn for the mountains of home?”

Zhong said, “Excellent! You do not yet grasp the subtleties of yin-yang convergence and separation. To abide in yin is merely to be *po*; to preserve yang is merely to be *hun*. If one can gather *hun* and unite *po*, merging yin and yang so that *hun* and *po* become one in truth, this is called a *zhenren*.”

Lü said, “*Hun* and *po* dwell in darkness—how profound the principle! How may their full measure be attained?”

Zhong replied, “When wisdom arises from the unseen and the spirit settles in perfect stillness…”

When the spirit has merged into unity, does it not then align with the true? The golden form and jadelike essence arise from utmost sincerity. Once the Great Elixir is perfected, the body becomes light as if to take flight.

Lü then asked about "Heaven and Earth." Zhong replied, "When Qian’s three lines seek union, Heaven conjoins with Earth, giving rise to the three yang; when Kun’s three lines seek union, Earth conjoins with Heaven, giving rise to the three yin. Within yang, yin is concealed—this is called *true yin*. When true yin ascends to Heaven, it is born through yang. Within yin, yang is concealed—this is called *true yang*. When true yang descends to Earth, it emerges through yin. Through their union and harmony, the Dao is attained, and longevity naturally endures."

Lü asked about "the Sun and Moon." Zhong said, "The moon receives the sun’s *hun*, transforming yang into yin. When yin reaches its extreme, yang becomes pure, and the moon’s radiance shines with crystalline clarity. Cultivating to this stage, accumulated *qi* refines into spirit."

Lü asked about "the Four Seasons and Five Phases." Zhong replied, "Within a single heart, the Five Phases reside; within a single day, the Four Seasons unfold. In essence, it is merely the interplay of yin and yang. Yang cannot complete itself without yin, yet in the end, there is no yin that does not die; yin cannot generate itself without yang, yet in the end, yin is exhausted and all becomes yang." The doctrines of the eight grades of scripture are fundamentally rooted in this.

Lü further asked about "Water, Fire, Dragon, and Tiger." Zhong said, "Within the body, there are sovereign fire, ministerial fire, and common fire. True fire emerges from water—dim and indistinct, yet within it lies something. Though unseen to the eye and unattainable by grasp, it is there. True water arises from fire—profound and obscure, yet within it lies essence. Though glimpsed, it cannot be detained; though detained, it cannot be held.

The kidneys are water. Within water resides *qi*, called *true fire*. The heart is fire. Within fire, fluid is born, called *true water*. This is the meaning of 'the dragon emerges from fire, the tiger is born at water’s edge.'

As water generates wood: when kidney *qi* is abundant, liver *qi* arises, cutting off the kidney’s residual yin. As *qi* passes through the liver, it becomes pure yang, storing the water of the true One—dim and indistinct, it is called the *true dragon*. As fire tempers metal: when heart fluid is plentiful, lung fluid is born, cutting off the heart’s residual yang. As fluid reaches the lungs, it becomes pure yin, storing the *qi* of true yang—profound and obscure, it is called the *true tiger*.

Drawing water from *qi* and *qi* from water, one obtains the *grain of millet*, returning it to the Yellow Court—this is the *Great Elixir*."

Someone asks about "lead and mercury." The master replies: "Lead’s nature is heavy and fond of sinking—this is kidney water, which moistens downward and readily fills. Mercury’s nature is light and fond of rising—this is heart fire, which flames upward and readily scatters. Using lead to restrain mercury, employing heaviness to anchor the light and flighty, the inner elixir coalesces!"

Another asks about "withdrawal and augmentation." The master replies: "After the winter solstice, yang ascends from the earth, and the earth withdraws its yin: *Greater Yin* withdraws to become *Terminal Yin*; *Lesser Yang* augments to become *Yang Brightness*. *Terminal Yin* withdraws to become *Lesser Yin*; *Yang Brightness* augments to become *Greater Yang*. After the summer solstice, yin descends from heaven, and heaven withdraws its yang: *Greater Yang* withdraws to become *Yang Brightness*; *Lesser Yin* augments to become *Terminal Yin*. *Yang Brightness* withdraws to become *Lesser Yang*; *Terminal Yin* augments to become *Greater Yin*.

Moreover, consider the sun and moon: the moon receives the sun’s *hun*-soul; the sun receives the moon’s *po*-corporeal soul. In the first fifteen days, the moon withdraws its *po* while the sun augments its *hun*—essence and brilliance fill, and light illumines the earth below. Without this, there would be no crescent waxing to first quarter, nor first quarter waxing to full moon. The moon restores its yin *po*; the sun gathers its yang essence. In the latter fifteen days, the sun withdraws its *hun* while the moon augments its *po*—light fades, and yin *po* settles. Without this, there would be no full moon waning to last quarter, nor last quarter waning to darkness. As sun and moon cycle endlessly, the nine and six transform—this is the image of withdrawal and augmentation."

Another asks about the "River Chariot."

He replied: "In the human body, yang is scant while yin abounds—all is but water, hence the recourse to the *River Chariot*. The *River Chariot* arises from the true water of the northern quarter, not through the forced transmutations of heterodox schools."

Asked about the wonders of "inner contemplation and sitting-in-forgetfulness," he said: "When dragon and tiger conjoin, yin and yang pair as mates. The Nine August Perfected Lords descend, leading a vermilion-robed youth; the Nine August Perfected Ladies ascend, leading a black-clad maiden. They meet before the Yellow Palace, where a yellow-robed crone receives them with a rising inflection, as husband and wife unite in joyous consummation. When the union is complete, the woman descends again, the man ascends, as husband and wife part. Once done, a thing is born, round as a pellet, its hue like red citrus. It is cast into the Yellow Palace and preserved in a golden vessel."

Asked, "Does such cultivation invite demonic trials?" he answered: "Do you know the ten demons and nine trials? Pressing needs of clothing and food—first trial. Entanglements of affection and love—second trial. Snares of profit and fame—third trial. Sudden calamities—fourth trial. Blind teachers and misguided precepts—fifth trial. Conflicting doctrines—sixth trial. Wavering resolve—seventh trial. Wasted years—eighth trial. Turmoil and chaos—ninth trial. The six thieves: first, the demon of wealth and rank; second, the demon of riches and honor; third, the demon of the six passions; fourth, the demon of love and attachment; fifth, the demon of hardship; sixth, when gods and buddhas become harmful—this is the demon of sages and worthies. Seventh, the demon of blades and warfare; eighth, the demon of music and women; ninth, the demon of feminine allure; tenth, the demon of goods and gain."

Further asked, "How may one verify attainment?" he replied: "At first, deviant influences are wholly extirpated, and external conduct is cultivated alongside internal practice. When gathering the medicine, the golden essence fills to abundance, and the yin *po* melts away. Next, the *Heart Sutra* wells forth, and sweet nectar flows from the mouth. Then, yin and yang clash and grapple, the belly roars like thunder. Then, as *hun* and *po* remain unsettled, dreams and sleep are fraught with terror. Then, minor illnesses arise but heal without treatment. Then, the cinnabar field grows warm at night, and the countenance is clear by day. Then, in darkness, one’s spirit-light appears of itself. Then, one embraces the infant and ascends the golden tower. Then, a thunderclap resounds, the joints open, and startled sweat pours forth. Then, the jade liquid is refined into congealed butter, and snow-like essence scatters down. Or blood transforms into milk, and one gradually shuns the rank and foul. Or the dusty bones grow light and turn to gold and jade. Then, one’s gait is swift as a galloping horse. Then, one is unmoved by external scenes. Then, one’s breath can cure illness. Then, inner vision grows luminous. Then, both eyes gleam like lacquer. Then, black hair regrows. Then, true *qi* suffices, and one is ever sated. Then, one eats little but can drink wine without limit. Then, the spirit-body glows, and essence and *qi* are radiant. Then, the mouth savors strange flavors, and the nose detects rare fragrances. Then, the eyes see for ten thousand *li*. Then, scars vanish. Then, tears, saliva, and sweat all cease. Then, the three corpses and nine worms are wholly expelled. Then, the inner will is lofty, harmonizing with the Great Void; worldly passions fade, and both mind and realm become empty. Then, *hun* and *po* no longer wander, and dreams end of themselves; spirit and essence are fresh, undivided by day or night. Then, the yang essence forms the body, and the numinous palace is fortified—cold and heat cannot assail, life and death cannot touch. Then, a sigh can dry external mercury. Then, spirit-light constantly arises whether sitting or lying. Then, in stillness, one hears celestial music—gold, stone, strings, and bamboo—sounds not of this world. Then, in inner vision, one may wander Hua Xu, where towers and halls gleam with splendor unseen in the mortal realm. Then, one perceives the foulness of ordinary people. Then, one’s inner gods manifest. Then, external gods come to pay homage. When merit is complete and conduct perfected, one receives registers and charts. Purple auroras fill the eyes, golden light envelops the body. One may see fire-dragons soar or phoenix-cranes dance, colorful clouds swirling, auspicious vapors in profusion. Heavenly flowers rain down, divine maidens descend. One leaves the mundane and enters sagehood, carefree and natural. This is the day when the great man’s merit is accomplished and his name established."

Hearing the esoteric formulas of the Perfected Ones from Zhongli in full, Patriarch Lü comprehended each in turn. Presently, a knock sounded at the door; rising to see, he beheld Qingxi’s Zheng Siyuan, along with the two Perfected Ones, Shi Hufu of Taihua, arriving from the southeast. They strode unhurried through the void, their forms suffused with golden and azure radiance, and after exchanging bows, sat together. They said, “We have just offered congratulations to Yin Siyi for his elixir’s completion and have come to call at your immortal gate.”

Shi asked, “Who is this attendant?”
Zhongli replied, “The son of Lü Rang of Haizhou in our dynasty. In youth, he studied the Confucian and Mohist arts but met with frustration in the capital. By chance, he encountered me in a Chang’an wineshop and followed me into the Dao, mastering the subtleties of yin-yang, refining form and spirit, and entering the wondrous.”

Zhongli then bade him bow to the two immortals. Zheng and Shi said, “Your form is pure, your spirit present; your eyes are bright, your essence concealed. If you seek to cast off the dusty net, may we see a poem?” They presented him with a golden brush, rosy stationery, divine glue, and a rhinoceros-horn inkstone.

He immediately offered this poem:
*"Through ten thousand kalpas and a thousand lives to this life,
Only now does this life’s body begin to sense its weightlessness.
Leaving home, parting from kin, casting off the clouds and mountains of the realm,
Refining po and hun with the essence of sun and moon.
I have seen the Perfected discuss the Nine Cauldrons—
Seeking the great elixir, I inquire of the Three Clarities.
Now that I meet the true immortals face-to-face,
My name is recorded at the gates of the Purple Palace."*

The two immortals sighed at his talent and elegant lines, each bestowing their secret teachings before departing. At that moment, spring birds trilled as Ancestor Zhongli inscribed at the cave’s mouth:
*"Spring’s qi fills the sky, flower dew drips;
Morning sun strikes the sea, mountain clouds return."*

Turning to Lü, he said, “My audience at the Primordial has its time; the feathered guests of the Ten Isles will journey to Jade Capital to report these merits, ascending the immortal ranks. I fear you cannot long remain in this cave. We shall meet again at Dongting in ten years.” Taking up his brush, he wrote in cursive on the cave’s stone wall:

"By day, the sun shines in lofty brightness;
By night, the moon glows in perfect clarity.
Yin and yang, soul and spirit,
Merge and ascend as one."

He cast aside his brush and declared, “As you wander the world, you must practice the Way of benefiting and saving others! When your deeds are complete and your merit fulfilled, we shall meet again.” With this, he bestowed upon him the *Lingbao Bifa* and said, “At first, within the stone cliffs of Zhongnan, I once obtained the three divisions of the *Lingbao Scriptures*: the upper is called the *Yuanshi Jin’gao*, the middle the *Yuanhuang Yulu*, and the lower the *Taishang Zhenyuan Yi*. Altogether, they number several thousand scrolls. I distilled their essentials into this *Bifa*, dividing it into sixteen sections and the three vehicles with their six meanings. It clarifies how within yin there is yang, and within yang there is yin—the Dao of heaven and earth’s ascent and descent. Within qi, water is born; within water, qi is born. The mechanism of heart and kidney communion operates through the eight trigrams moving the twelve hours, its crux lying in *Gen*; through the three fields mutually interacting, its crux lying in the *Niwan*. As for the initial practice, I merely use swallowing qi and rinsing saliva as an analogy. Yet the true oral instructions on qi reside in heart-to-heart transmission, not within written words.”

He then presented several grains of numinous elixir, explaining, “These are not the five metals or eight minerals of the mortal world, but a wondrous treasure compounded from rare substances. Though they possess substance, they have no form—like clouds, like fire, like light, like shadows—visible yet intangible. When ingested, they merge with a person’s soul and consciousness into one body, subtle and wondrous, unlike any elixir of physical form.”

Finally, he gifted a poem, which read:

“You are blessed with a spirit of heroic bone—
Thus I teach you the heart’s trance-state.
In the Crystal Palace atop the Hall of Primordial Containment,
I clearly point out the cavern of immortals.

O great man,
Having met the true formula,
You must hold fast with a heart fierce and resolute.
The Five Phases align as naturally as the *daogui*;
Grasp the inverted secret of Tortoise and Serpent.

The Three Corpses’ spirits—
You must strike them through.
Advance and retreat by the celestial mechanism of the Six Jia.
Know these three essentials, and the ten thousand spirits will submit,
Coming to harness the Fire Spirit, departing the Nine Gates.

When the nine-by-nine Dao reaches its consummation in true attainment,
The Three Realms and Four Palaces will celebrate the Return to the Origin.
Qi soars aloft, the spirit blazes in glory—
Penglai is but my family’s dwelling.
The assembled immortals feast amid celestial music’s clamor,
Twin lads usher in the ascending guest.

As my Dao-heart does not regress, I transmit this to you.
We pledge our oath, words sealed with blood.
When you meet others—
Do not speak recklessly.
When you meet fellow seekers—
No need for secrecy.

Do not fault me for repeating these words:
Disdain will surely bring retribution from the Dark Bureau.
Hand in hand we part—what is the feeling?
Today I compose this song anew for you,
Expounding every wondrous principle of the immortal path.
Yet will your heart truly believe it?

I speak to you with utmost clarity—
Cherish my words, ascend to the Great Canopy.”

When Patriarch Lü had heard this, the dust and filth of the world fell away entirely, and he pressed further, asking of the teachings on the "Three Origins, Three Purities, Three Treasures, and Three Realms." Master Zhong replied:

"The first is the Primordial Chaos of Supreme Non-Being, from which the Heavenly Treasure Lord is transformed. He governs the Jade Pure Realm, the Heaven of Subtle Clarity, its qi beginning as azure.

The second is the Crimson Chaos of Supreme Non-Being, from which the Numinous Treasure Lord is transformed. He governs the High Pure Realm, the Heaven of Yu-Yu, its qi verging on yellow.

The third is the Profound Stillness of Mystic Pervasion, from which the Divine Treasure Lord is transformed. He governs the Supreme Pure Realm, the Heaven of Great Redness, its qi verging on white.

Thus the qi of the Nine Heavens gives birth to the spirit."

The scripture states: *"Though their names differ, their root is one."*

Each of the Three Lords serves as a teaching master, the revered teachers of the Three Caverns.

As the transmission neared its end, two immortals suddenly appeared, clad in gossamer robes shimmering with rosy clouds, bearing in their hands golden tablets and sacred talismans. They announced: "By decree of the Supreme Emperor, Zhongli Quan is appointed as the Celestial Envoy of Selection for the Golden Towers of the Nine Heavens."

Having received the mandate, he turned to Lü and said, "I shall now ascend to heaven. You must remain in the world, cultivating merit and establishing conduct. One day, you too shall be as I am."

Lü bowed again and replied, "My resolve differs from yours, Master. I must first deliver all sentient beings before I shall ascend."

What boundless vow and power of compassion this was—truly a heart of mercy!

At that moment, phoenixes soared and auspicious cranes took flight, golden banners and jade regalia gleamed, and celestial music resounded in clear, ringing tones. The Ancestral Master Zhong, together with the two immortals bearing the decree, ascended upon clouds, drifting slowly away.

Having received the Dao of Zhongli, Patriarch Lü also obtained the Heaven-Concealing Sword Technique from the True Man of the Fire Dragon. With it, he severed in three stages: first, the afflictions of sound and short-lived vexations; second, the desires of form; and third, greed and wrath.

He once wrote a poem:

*"In years past, I met the Fire Dragon Lord—
A single sword passed to me, companion to this body."*

From mist the heavens and earth and mountains and rivers took form,
While stars and sun and moon halted their turning wheels at will.
Know that the original nature endures through countless kalpas—
Yet vainly in the human world it has passed ten thousand springs.

Last night, Zhongli spoke a single word:
The six celestial palaces would crumble to dust.

This poem was inscribed later, as he blended into the marketplace in remembrance.

On his first journey to the Jiang-Huai region, he tested the magic sword, slaying the great flood-dragon’s harm. Arriving at Dongting Lake, he ascended Yueyang Tower and drank alone. Suddenly, Ancestral Master Zhong descended, saying, “I have come to fulfill our former pact. The Supreme Emperor commands that your kin all dwell in the Jing Mountain grotto-palace, and your name has already been inscribed in the Jade Clarity Register.”

On the eighteenth day of the third month, he was led to pay homage to True Lord Ku Zhu and received the method of the sun and moon’s conjoined radiance. At fifty-three, he returned to Mount Lu to take refuge in the ancestral teachings. At sixty-four, he ascended to pay homage to the Primordial Celestial Worthy and the Jade Emperor. From then on, his appearances and transformations were manifold.

Only because his vows were vast did he drift through the turbid world, practicing transformation and delivering people. Even the most ignorant men and women, hearing his name, could not help but rise in reverence. He once said, “People vie to see me, yet cannot follow my words. Though they dwell with me day and night, what benefit is there? If a person can be loyal to their country, filial and kind to their family, faithful to friends, benevolent to those below, neither negligent of their own heart nor deceitful in secret, using skillful means to aid others and accumulating hidden merit to move Heaven—then people will love them, and ghosts and spirits will revere them. In this single thought, they are already one with me. Though they do not see me, they have seen me.

For the nature of humanity is this:
When the mind turns to goodness, it belongs to luminous yang, its nature entering the light and pure—this is the path to Heaven.
When the mind turns to evil, it belongs to turbid yin, sinking into coarseness and heaviness—this is the stairway to Hell.
Heaven and Hell are not ruled by any sovereign master; they are merely self-created by the human heart!”

In the early years of the Jianlong reign of Emperor Taizu of the Song, the Venerable Lü emerged from the rear palace gardens. Addressing the emperor, he identified himself as the August Thearch of Zhu Ling, who ruled the realm under the virtue of Fire. He spoke at length, though none in attendance could hear his words—his discourse remained secret and untransmitted. The emperor removed his cinnabar robe and jade belt and bestowed them upon him. In an instant, the Venerable Lü vanished. The emperor commanded his likeness be painted in the Tower of Supreme Purity, and Daoist registrar Chen Jingyuan disseminated the portrait among the world.

During the Zhenghe era, malevolent spirits plagued the palace precincts, manifesting even in broad daylight to steal gold and jewels from the imperial consorts. Only the emperor’s own chambers remained untouched. Lin Lingsu, Wang Wenqing, and other court Daoists were summoned to exorcise them, yet the disturbances ceased only to resurface. The emperor fasted with utmost sincerity and offered six memorials in prayer. One day, as he dozed at midday, he saw beyond the Eastern Florescence Gate a Daoist priest—crowned with a kingfisher-blue lotus coronet, clad in a purple crane-feather cloak, and holding a crystal ruyi scepter. The priest stepped forward, bowed, and said, “Your servant has received the August Thearch’s command to subdue this malevolence.”

After a long while, he summoned a warrior in golden armor, who seized the spirit and tore it apart to devour it. The emperor asked, “Who is this warrior?”

The Daoist replied, “This is Lord Guan Yu, the *Chongning* Perfected Lord whom Your Majesty has enfeoffed.” The emperor repeatedly expressed his gratitude. He then asked, “Where is Zhang Fei?” Guan Yu answered, “Fei is my brother through countless kalpas. Now he has been reborn in Your Majesty’s realm to the family of Yue in Xiangzhou. In days to come, he will aid the restoration of the dynasty, and Fei shall render great merit.” The emperor inquired after the Daoist’s name. The Daoist said, “Your servant’s surname is Yang, and I was born on the fourteenth day of the fourth month.” When the emperor awoke from his dream, his attendants identified the Daoist, saying, “This is Master Lü.” From that time onward, the palace disturbances ceased entirely. The emperor then issued an edict to all under heaven, ordering that wherever incense was offered to Master Lü, his title be corrected to “Perfected Lord of Wondrous Communication.”

The imperial decree read: “We delight in joining the people in reverence for the Great Dao. All those immortals and recluses are recorded in the registers. Moreover, those who silently respond to prayers deserve to be shown favor and honor. The Perfected Lord Lü has concealed his radiance and hidden his traces, wandering near and far. When he arrived at the Palace of Established Felicity, he found a temporary abode. Moved by this karmic affinity, We bestow upon him a title and name. Though his numinous presence is solemn and majestic, may he deign to witness this act. Let him be enfeoffed as *Perfected Lord of Wondrous Communication*.” A statue was sculpted in the Palace of Illustrious Spirits, where seasonal sacrifices were offered.

His wondrous spiritual efficacy, as recorded in various biographies, cannot be fully described in words. The Yuan Emperor Shizu enfeoffed him as *Perfected Lord of Pure Yang, Who Warns and Transforms with Orthodox Teachings*. Emperor Wuzong of Yuan later elevated his title to *Perfected Lord of Pure Yang, Who Warns and Transforms with Orthodox Teachings, the Emperor Who Protects and Assists*. His collected poems and lyrics, titled *The Anthology of Effortless Mastery*, circulated in the world. Later, through planchette revelations, he expounded the *Eight Preceding Grades* at Wuling, the *Five Grades* at Qizhen in Ezhu, the *Three Grades* and *Triple Concordance* at Hansan, and the *Scriptures on Sagely Virtue* at the Thatched Hut in Hunan. Earlier works such as the *Treatise on the Pointing Staff*, the *Edict on Loyalty and Filial Piety*, the *Anthology of Cultivating the True and Transmitting the Dao*, and the *Eulogies on the Jade Pivot Scripture* were also transmitted. Now, all these have been compiled into a complete collection.

The following passage, absent in the original Yuan Shizu biography, has been added here:

The Venerable Wuwozi respectfully eulogized: “The Daoist tradition’s *Emperor Who Protects and Assists* is like the Buddhist tradition’s *Great Bodhisattva Avalokiteśvara*. The World-Honored One abides in non-action, yet his Dharma flourishes through the *Great Bodhisattva*. The Most High abides in non-action, yet his Dharma flourishes through the *Emperor*. Though they have attained celestial ranks, they still move among humankind, delivering countless beings. This is akin to the sages’ desire that all things attain their proper place. Thus, for ten thousand generations, all who hear of them are inspired, for their vow-power is vast and far-reaching. Formerly, at the *Śūraṅgama* assembly, the World-Honored One selected the *Great Bodhisattva* as foremost in perfect penetration among all buddhas. As for Ancestor Lü, is he not also foremost in perfect penetration?”

**Brief Preface to the First Eight Chapters of the Scripture**
Since the Blue Ox departed and the studies of *xuan* flourished, and the White Horse arrived and the Buddhist teachings arose, beyond the Confucian canon, there have also been Buddhist scriptures and alchemical classics—all intended to guide and uplift this world, to guard the mind of the Dao with vigilance, and to cleanse the hearts of humankind.

Yet the texts of Buddhism and Daoist immortality each establish their own schools and doctrines, diverging into a thousand paths and ten thousand streams from the Way of the Two Emperors and Three Kings. Who, then, has traced the source to its root and returned to the One?

Only Lüzu harmonized the essences of the Three Teachings and expounded them as various scriptures. The *Eight Chapters* mark their first emergence:
- The first and second chapters were revealed in Guangling,
- The third and fourth in Jinling,
- The fifth in Piling,
- The sixth and seventh in Xinzhou,
- The eighth in Linjiang.

Spanning five regions and several years, one can well imagine the arduousness of their transmission! Yet through his compassionate heart, vast vows, and resolute determination, he ultimately brought them to completion.

This scripture is often profound and solemn, unlike the more expansive later revelations. Yet it truly encompasses all scriptures, gestating myriad chapters—like a spring emerging from the mountains, its momentum bound for the sea; like bamboo shoots breaking through their sheaths, their vitality already piercing the heavens.

In essence, the principle is one and unbroken, the intent fundamentally the same. The Three Teachings need not follow separate paths, nor do the scriptures differ in their ultimate aim. Yet those of shallow learning, inferior capacity, and heterodox schools each raise their crimson banners, mutually ridiculing one another—surely they may now desist and return to the source.

**Original Preface to the Reprinted *Eight Chapters of the Immortal Scripture***
I, by nature, am serene and simple, with a steadfast aspiration for the Dao. In my daily life, I reverently venerate Lüzu. In all my undertakings, I first report to him, and the Master, perceiving my sincerity, often descends through the planchette to bestow guidance, admonitions, and poetic verses. Though his words initially seem cryptic, when events unfold, they invariably align with perfect clarity.

Upon my transfer to govern Yunnan, one day the planchette suddenly conveyed a command: “The immortal scriptures I composed in the past—eight chapters in total—were once printed in Guangling, but their transmission remains limited. You now govern Yunnan, an ancient land of the Six Zhaos, where barbarians and Han intermingle. The people’s nature is harsh, their speech guttural and coarse, ignorant of ritual propriety and royal transformation. Daily they take up arms, slaughtering one another, their rotting bones and putrid flesh reeking of blood and filth, thereby provoking the celestial punishments of the Emperor on High. You shall preface this scripture and widely disseminate it—its benefits will be profoundly far-reaching.” I respectfully assented at the time.

The Dao finds its fullest expression in the *Book of Changes*, while its meaning is exhausted in yin and yang. Later, the Yellow Emperor battled Chiyou at Zhuolu, where the Nine Heavens’ Mystic Woman bestowed upon him the *Classic of the Yin Talisman*, composed by the Supreme Dao Lord—just as in the time of the Dragon Duke, when he crossed Hangu Pass and was urged by Magistrate Xi to compose the *Classic of the Dao and Virtue*. These two scriptures, though their style may seem abstruse, lead to profound clarity; though their words may appear partial, their store of meaning is complete. Thereafter came the *Triplex Unity*, rooted in the *Book of Changes*, expanding upon the intent of the two sages in recondite terms, boundless in its depths! Still later appeared the *Awakening to Reality*, which earnestly expounds the theories of lead and mercury, dragon and tiger, infant and maiden. Those who awaken to it perceive the kan and li within the body; those who remain deluded drift into the arts of alchemical refinement. Such offshoots, myriad and rootless, exaggerate beyond truth—how could the Dao be thus?

This present *Eight Chapters* takes the Dao as its core, supplemented by Confucian and Buddhist teachings. In its essence and function, it accords well with the *Doctrine of the Mean*; its ultimate aim differs not from the *Śūraṅgama* or *Perfect Enlightenment*. Proceeding from shallow to deep, from outer to inner, from manifest to subtle, from the five phases to the myriad things, from daily ethical conduct to the nature of body and mind—nothing is left unaddressed, nothing left obscure. Lofty beyond measure, profound beyond fathoming, when expounded it illumines the Three Luminaries; when unfolded it pervades the Six Directions. Follow it and its end cannot be seen; meet it and its beginning cannot be perceived. Vast indeed, great indeed! Dimly, vaguely, its images and things cannot be exhausted, nor its abstruse subtleties plumbed. Compared to the *Awakening to Reality*, it swiftly treads in the footsteps of the *Triplex Unity*, rivaling its excellence.

Those who wander within the world, if they study and grasp its meaning, will be moved to loyalty to their lord, filial piety to their parents, observance of ritual and law, rejection of violence, and earnest self-cultivation to nurture their reputation. Those who wander beyond the world, if they study and grasp its meaning, will still their thoughts, extinguish desires, refine essence and qi, diligently practice breath circulation, and focus on inner preservation to nurture their spirit. This is called not living in vain; this is called long life; this is called non-arising. The Three Teachings merge as one, and the myriad principles suffer no deficiency.

The Dao does not choose its ground, nor does the ground choose its people. Whether among those clad in robes and caps, versed in culture, or those in feathered speech and floral garments, it appears as if the Eastern Flowery One and the Trustworthy Protector descended in paired chariots upon the clouds to teach them, fully spreading the mystic wind and thoroughly washing away vulgar customs—how could this be but a great aid?

Yet one must grasp the root before aligning the branches, trace the origin before comprehending the end. Thus, in today’s publication and circulation, special attention must be paid to those within the world, for they are the foundation of those beyond it. As the *Master Embracing Simplicity* says: “To seek immortality, one must first take loyalty, filial piety, harmony, compliance, benevolence, and trust as the foundation. If virtue is not cultivated and one merely pursues arts and techniques, one will never attain long life.”

A guest at my side laughed and said: “Sir, you speak eloquently—surely you do not intend to employ the numinous Dao as a means of instruction?” I withdrew, not daring to presume.

In the winter month of the Jia-Yin year of the Wanli reign (1594), the Returned-to-Yang Daoist Zhao Xingcui inscribed this at the Clear-Heart Studio in central Yunnan.

**Original Preface to the *Eightfold Scripture of Immortality***
*(This preface was composed when the eight ranks were first compiled, before their definitive classification)*

The *Eightfold Scripture of Immortality* is the posthumous work of the Pure Yang Patriarch, Master Lü. The first and second ranks were transmitted in Guangling, the third and fourth in Jinling, the fifth in Piyin Pilin, the sixth and seventh in Xinzhou, and the eighth in Linjiang. The master instructed that the scripture be preserved for those worthy of its reception. Later, he commanded Tong Qixuan of Guangling to widely carve and disseminate it, and Disciple Li was tasked with composing this preface.

When the scripture arrived, Qixuan compiled and recorded it, further entreating the Immortal Maiden He and the Purple Yang Patriarch Zhang to proofread and collate it. It was then printed at the Immortal Tower of Wan Dian, and Yang subsequently undertook a thorough revision.

Kneeling in reverence, I bow and compose this preface:

How vast is this *Ranked Scripture*! It encompasses the alchemical canons, dissects profound mysteries, elucidates imperial governance, and serves as a raft for the Dao. It traces origins and conclusions, unifying Heaven and humanity—nothing is left unaddressed. Truly, it is the authentic sign of deliverance from the world and the essential path of immortal cultivation.

In surveying its outline, one may:
—Verify the numinosity of its teachings,
—Discern the flourishing of its aid to governance,
—Gauge the magnitude of its merit and virtue,
—Comprehend the convergence of the Three Teachings,
—Distinguish the rectification of heterodoxy, and
—Confirm the secrets of spiritual refinement.

Why is this so?

The numinous cannot be measured by place; thus, its response grows ever more manifest from the slightest stimulus. Trust cannot be obstructed by distance; thus, its sincerity spreads universally, and its transformation shines ever brighter. Therefore, the Patriarch’s *Ranked Scripture* was not bestowed upon a single person or place. That it was granted to the many scholars of the Five Mounds is precisely to manifest the impartiality of the Great Dao and to instill the mechanism of sincerity that engenders faith. Hence, it is said: *“One may verify the numinosity of its teachings.”*

Of old, Fuxi, the Yellow Emperor, Yao, and Shun transformed the people through spiritual means, governing effortlessly. Thus, the *“Primordial Supreme Ultimate and Five Agents Rank”* begins by exalting the sacred edicts of our Great Ancestor, the August Emperor, aligning them with the Jade Emperor and Heavenly Worthy, and expounding the wondrous principles of transformation. It enables people to clearly understand how migrating toward goodness averts calamity, how accumulating virtue brings fortune, how nurturing one’s nature aligns with the Real, and how to aid the state and bless the people—silently assisting the flourishing of non-action. Hence, it is said: *“One may discern the flourishing of its aid to governance.”*

Of old, the sages of antiquity transformed their forms to expound scriptures, and bodhisattvas manifested in myriad bodies to preach the Dharma. Thus, the Patriarch, grieving for the benighted and blind, bent low to guide them—sometimes through dreams, sometimes through apparitions, sometimes through planchette writings—yet records cannot exhaust his deeds. In this *Ranked Scripture*, he rivals the *Cloud Satchel* and the *Universal Gateway*, his merit and virtue boundless. Hence, it is said: *“One may gauge the magnitude of its merit and virtue.”*

The Dao is one and undivided; there was never a distinction among the Three Teachings. Of old, our Old Master was likened to a dragon, the Profound Sage compared himself to a unicorn, the Elephant Teaching had not yet come east, and Liezi foretold it—yet how could their followers cling to their own traditions and refuse to yield? This was mistaken! Thus, the *Ranked Scripture* broadly draws upon the subtleties of Confucianism and Buddhism, unfolding the profound mysteries of the Dao’s source, making ever clearer the principle that diverse paths converge as one. Hence, it is said: *“One may comprehend the convergence of the Three Teachings.”*

Moreover, the Dao has its orthodox lineage, its lineage has its secrets, and its secrets have their true exegesis. Since heterodox schools arose, the false has mingled with the true, and delusion has disordered the Real. Thus, the *Ranked Scripture* sweeps away falsehood to reveal truth, establishes orthodoxy to dispel heterodoxy—its clarity is strict, its detail precise. Scholars who rely on its ranks to examine exegesis, follow exegesis to explore secrets, and grasp secrets to return to the lineage—how could heterodox schools delude them? Hence, it is said: *“One may distinguish the rectification of heterodoxy.”*

The Great Dao is not easily expressed in plain words, and perfected beings are seldom encountered. Moreover, the mechanisms of cinnabar and lead, the abundance of metaphors, the profusion of names, the concealment of oral instructions in cryptic language—these make comprehension arduous. Yet in reciting and practicing the *Ranked Scripture*, one naturally grasps its meaning, connects its categories, and achieves sudden enlightenment, as if bolts were drawn and doors flung open to grant direct access to the inner sanctum. Hence, it is said: *“One may confirm the secrets of spiritual refinement.”*

Nevertheless, the scripture bears the Dao, while people expound it. The Patriarch composed the scripture to instruct the world, yet if people fail to model themselves upon it to cultivate immortality, will they not betray the benevolent intent of universal deliverance? If every person were to faithfully receive it—not merely reciting and perusing but practicing and embodying its teachings—then each would escape the sea of suffering, ascend the shore of the Dao, and transcend into the realm of immortals, fulfilling the Patriarch’s earnest and compassionate hopes.

How excellent is Disciple Tong! His merit in defending the Dao is as vast and enduring as the scripture itself, and his blessings and posterity will surely flourish in kind. Sun Defu, who preserved the planchette methods, and Zhu Ni, who embraced the Dao and received the scripture, both contributed to this endeavor—thus, they too are mentioned. As for the many faithful recipients of the scripture, their names are recorded within its ranks and need not be repeated here.

Respectfully composed in the third month of the Ji-Chou year of the Wanli reign (1589) by Disciple Li Yingyang of Guangling, who has broadly investigated the subtle and profound.

**Postscript to the *Eightfold Scripture of Immortality***
*(Composed later during the repeated proofreading, this postscript recounts the process of collating the scripture, rather than serving as a dedicated preface to its exposition)*

The *Scripture of Immortality* was composed in the Five Mounds long ago. Its great purpose unifies the Three Teachings, converging the myriad principles. It instructs in loyalty and filial piety, exhorts to virtuous deeds—ever aiding royal transformation and harmonizing with Heaven’s work. From the self to the family, from the family to the state, its extension proceeds from the broad to the refined, from the manifest to the esoteric. Its application attains the utmost of spiritual transformation, yet it does not transcend the return to investigation, sincerity, integrity, and rectification. Such is the meaning of composing the scripture in the Five Mounds!

The Great Dao shines resplendently, its path level and unobstructed—it is no book of hidden wonders or strange anomalies, nor a manual of fortune-telling or exorcism. Those who fathom its subtleties exhaust essence and penetrate transformation, ascending to the Celestial Capital.

Its governance attains order through effortless rule—hands folded in repose, punishments set aside in non-action. Its nurturing of the latent proceeds through cultivating the self, quieting the mind, withdrawing the will, and embracing tranquility. How could it be reduced to burning incense and reciting scriptures, or bowing to canons, blindly trusted by the ignorant and the simple? Thus the superior person awakens to it through subtle spirit, the middling person cultivates it to enter the Dao, and the lesser person gains it to prolong life. Its principles merge into boundlessness, its qi and spirit vast and expansive—how could one not thereby endure as long as Heaven and Earth?

After the scripture was transmitted, errors crept in amid the carving of words and the chiseling of sounds, such as "bird" (鳥) rendered as "crow" (烏), or "fox" (狐) nearing "lonely" (孤). These were once corrected by the two Perfected Ones, He and Zhang, whose emendations were themselves laborious and exacting; now, a thorough revision has been made. Though the Five Mounds’ texts diverged in place and interpretation, they were but rough drafts. What was unordered in scrolls has now been ordered; what was unranked in categories has now been ranked. Yet one still fears that as ages grow distant, errors will be passed down in turn, and the printed text will again become as confused as before: "lord and king" (君王) written as "lord and parent" (君親); "spirit’s decay" (神敗) as "spirit’s nourishment" (神沃); "Great King" (太王) as "Civil King" (文王); "Martial Village" (武鄉) as "Martial Minister" (武卿); "resolving the heart’s unclarity" (任心不了) as "abiding in the heart’s unclarity" (在心不了); "why not cultivate and uphold" (何匪修持) as "why must one cultivate and uphold" (何必修持). Such instances are not merely ten or a hundred—all are errors that arose *after* the corrections of He and Zhang.

What is most troubling is this: the followers of miscellaneous and crooked schools, with their tangled words, imitate our scripture; the clever and eccentric, with their false doctrines, adulterate our canon. The crimson sun wheels through the sky, illuminating all peoples. Heaven and Earth are vast, embracing the ten thousand things—how could one compete with them? Yet can one remain unafraid?

The patterns of Heaven are the sun, moon, and stars; dew, thunder, wind, and rain; clouds, rosy dawn, rainbows, and lightning. The patterns of Earth are mountains and peaks, seas and rivers; flying and walking creatures, hidden and growing things; dwellings and the wilds. The patterns of humanity are benevolence, righteousness, propriety, and wisdom; loyalty, filial piety, trustworthiness, and sincerity; clothing and food. The reason the Three Powers endure so long is their constancy. Beyond the supreme principle, there is no other principle. At the end of verbose speech, what superfluous words remain!

Thus, after Confucius and Mencius, no more books of Confucius and Mencius appeared; after Laozi and Zhuangzi passed, no more words of Laozi and Zhuangzi were heard. Why then, in revising this immortal scripture, should I compile heaps of bamboo slips, repeatedly engaging in mundane discourse? Even after He and Zhang’s corrections, some suddenly claim one must wait for the tenth month, the tenth day, the tenth hour to begin entering the chamber. I can only laugh and say:
*"How many live a hundred years—
The swift return lies right before your eyes!"*

"Love’s river, desire’s sea—boundless suffering;
How could one bear to wait idly for the tenth year?"

These are truly the galloping strides of heterodox paths, recklessly trespassing the celestial precincts, where wandering spirits and numinous essences roam, tongues wagging like winnowing baskets, disrupting my sacred canons. Such acts merit the punishment of betraying the Dao and forsaking the teachings. Though they may evade manifest judgment, how can they escape the unseen retribution?

By chance, I encountered a devoted disciple in his youth who, to save his mother’s life, cut flesh from his thigh. Later, his father suffered misfortune, and in his overwhelming grief, the son lost his sight. Moved by this, I descended to restore his vision and bestowed upon him a collection of recorded sayings, a scroll of *The Immortal’s Repentance After Snow*, and a fascicle of *The Great Divine Mantra of the Dipper’s Light for Deliverance and Lifesaving*. The immortal scriptures were thereby firmly established.

After the transmission, I no longer returned. This scroll’s sequence is now fixed, radiant as the sun and stars; its ranks are distinguished, steadfast as Mount Tai’s balance. Should anyone alter my words or destroy the scriptures and teachings, this text declares: *"If there be those who destroy the scriptures and teachings: the city gods and village spirits shall report them; the thunder and fire departments shall swiftly mete out retribution."* How could this promise fail?

Receive and uphold these teachings, guarding them without loss. Practice ritual recitation and contemplative insight, cultivating without negligence.

Expanding the propagation of the Dharma and teachings, greatly reviving the winds of the *xuan* tradition. Thus, those who enter the Dao/Way remain unwavering in their resolve, and my strength in defending the Dao/Way is not solitary. These words should also be transmitted alongside *The Eight Ranks*, to admonish those who compile scriptures in later ages.

In the *bingyin* year of the Tianqi reign, on the fifteenth day of the first lunar month, the Lord of Trust and Protection composed this preface.

We bow our heads in homage to the Three Teachings’ Founders,
The Heavenly-Thunder Prime Minister, styled Pure Yang,
Whose meritorious deeds are complete throughout the Three Realms,
Whose vast vows deeply pervade the Ten Directions.
The precious sword’s majestic radiance vanquishes and humbles,
The Golden Elixir’s supreme Dao/Way subdues gods and spirits.
Ascending transcendents’ true canon and satchel,

**Supreme Sutra of the Heavenly Emperor’s Verification of Reality, Opened by the Most High Lord Lü**
**Volume One**

**Chapter One: The Transformation and Nurturance of the Supreme Ultimate**
(All chapter titles were rectified by Lord Lü.)

At that time, two meanings were implied: first, it recounts the reason for receiving the mandate to expound the teachings, as in "at that time"; second, it directly indicates the moment of sutra-recitation, as in the later phrase "At that time, the Perfected One said," and the like.

At that time, the August Jade Emperor, residing in the Lingxiao Heavenly Palace of the Yü rate Star, together with the Holy Mother of the Jasper Pool, expounded the *Wondrous Dharma of the Heavenly Emperor’s Opening of the Supreme Ultimate for Universal Salvation*. The Five Elderly Thearchs, accompanied by the immortals of the Ten Continents, Three Islands, Five Peaks, Four Waterways, and the Three Realms, all gathered at His side to listen to the wondrous Dharma.

Then, the Thearch of the Eastern Peak stepped forth from the assembly and addressed the throne, saying: "Formerly, a celestial decree descended, for the reason that sentient beings had turned their backs on their sovereigns, bullied their parents, and become defiled by the dust of greed, craving the clamor of profit and fame, engaging in deceit, theft, depravity, and licentiousness. Their impurity and chaos bred mutual contention between self and others, and strife among kin. Thus, retribution was specially ordained to afflict their descendants, and calamities to plague the land. In obedience to the decree, the continents were surveyed: epidemics of premature death and pestilence spread across hundreds of thousands of myriads of beings; drought and flood ravaged the crops, ruining seven or eight parts out of ten. Those with grave offenses were cut off from their posterity, while those with lighter sins suffered from plagues and pestilence. Their souls filled the courts of the Underworld, and none could be delivered."

Amidst famine and starvation, the roads were filled, and daily life became unbearable. Such was the retribution for their sins, yet beings still failed to repent, ensnared in the web of karmic transgressions. Humbly we beseech the Merciful One to take pity on their ignorance, deliver them from great suffering and distress, and bestow a decree of grace to transform misfortune into fortune. May they return to the true Dao, cast off all obstacles, and no longer suffer untimely death; may the realm know peace and the years bring abundance. Thus, the lingering souls may ascend, and pestilence, by this, be purified into tranquility. May heaven be clear and earth serene, all things prosper in harmony.”

The Jade Emperor replied, “Excellent! Excellent! The mortal realm is defiled, evil pervades heaven and earth, and the wheel of retribution turns, visiting obstruction and karma upon them. For they have strayed from the true Dao and thus committed transgressions. Let it be decreed that the Immortal Ministry dispatch the Perfected One Lü to descend to the world, broadly reveal the subtle and profound, awaken the blind and deaf, and expound the Great Dao of Supreme Strength. Let him purge the world of its dust and miasma, that all may turn from evil and return to rectitude!”

“I, in obedience to the Supreme and Non-Action Wondrous Decree, shall deliver living beings. Those in the world who read and recite this may release deep-seated grievances and past suffering, resolve the transgressions of this life, and transform all into just rulers and upright ministers, loving fathers and filial sons, harmonious brothers, mutual affection among the six relations, unerring propriety and righteousness, and households of purity and peace. All of you, with reverence and sincerity, heed my teaching:

The Supreme Ultimate was formless, born before heaven and earth. Qi and spirit merged as one in the primordial chaos.”

One qi then stirred—stirring, it trod the yang, and its hexagram answered as Qian. Stirring to its utmost, it returned to stillness—still, it gave birth to yin, and its hexagram answered as Kun. Light and pure, it floated upward, and the Qian Dao became Heaven; heavy and turbid, it congealed below, and the Kun Dao became Earth.

Now Heaven—its motion ceaseless, its qi whirling like a ring. Now Earth—firm and still, its winds fierce yet sustaining. Heaven and Earth interdepend, their substance and function complete: Heaven rests upon Earth, Earth upon Heaven.

The sun is yang qi accumulated, its essence shining outward; the moon is yin qi accumulated, its po containing radiance. The principles of yin and yang are all bound to the *Yi*; the pivot of the celestial sphere holds its warp and weft—such are the transformations of Heaven and Earth’s creative work.

The sixty-four hexagrams, each inverted or upright, each descending or ascending—ascending, they unite with yang; descending, they align with yin. Those who cultivate the elixir expound the hexagrams *Zhun* and *Meng*: *Zhun* ascends yang, *Meng* aligns with yin. Fire has its upper and lower, reversal and uprightness must be clear.

The mystery of yin and yang, the division of dark and new moons—at the first exchange of *zi* and *hai*, the numinous essence of the elixir coalesces. The *Ren* and *Du* meridians, the essence of yin and yang, flow unimpeded through the hundred channels, circulating through the body, naturally and of itself, not by any contrived spirit.

Water and fire, the division of above and below: the *Yongquan* at the soles of the feet, the root of the two qi. Rising into the *Weilu*, they meet the two sovereigns—one water, one fire, right as life, left as essence. Ascending the spine, the double gates open. Reaching the *Niwan*, they return to the *Mingtang*, silently irrigating the five palaces. Descending through the *Chonglou*, straight into the *Jiangting*, they flow back to the elixir府, ceaseless day and night, impossible to dam or halt.

True fire has no season, the great medicine no weight. With spirit driving qi, the supreme Dao is accomplished.

Man embodies the Three Powers, his body complete with the Supreme Ultimate. The heart precedes Heaven and Earth, vast and penetratingly round. Its original nature is empty and limpid, its function harmonious and balanced. Spirit transforms naturally, endlessly and without attachment.

*“Observe the Dao of Heaven, grasp the conduct of Heaven.”*
Essence transforms into qi, qi into spirit; refining spirit to return to emptiness is called longevity.

Yet beings do not awaken—they are deluded by the seven emotions: joy, anger, sorrow, and pleasure scatter spirit in form. They rebel against the moral order, violate the constant norms. Drowning in the waves of desire, they commit countless acts of unkindness: sons disobey fathers, ministers betray rulers, elder brothers do not love younger, younger do not respect elder, wives do not submit to husbands, friends do not trust companions. Benevolence and righteousness are perverted, form and spirit unsettled. They are vain, deceitful, and false; tame yet fierce, self-aggrandizing; proud, arrogant, self-protective, and belittling of others.

Thus the Supreme Lord shakes with anger, and transgressions bring calamity: crops fail, kin scatter, untimely deaths and violent ends, floods, fires, plagues, and punishments. Yet they do not reflect—instead, they resent the gods, foolish and stubborn in their heavy transgressions.

Therefore I descend, expounding the teaching and founding the school, preaching the Dharma to deliver beings. Each of you should examine and rectify yourself, unite sincerely in heart, be loyal, filial, righteous, and compassionate, accumulate virtue and merit, painfully repent past wrongs, and reform to begin anew. In stillness, awaken to the Dao; in silence, nurture spirit.

I transmit the supreme principle, broadly revealing it to Heaven and humanity. If you can fathom it, you will instantly transcend the wheel of suffering. I pity those drowning in delusion, repeatedly manifesting forms, traversing the cosmos, universally delivering all beings.

This first chapter of the scripture briefly expounds the causes of cultivation; the seven subsequent chapters serve as the great bridge of guidance. Those who faithfully receive and take refuge will have their names recorded in the celestial court. Those who awaken will be numinous; those who slander will be struck down. Those who realize it will attain fruition in the registers of immortals; those who transmit it will benefit across three lifetimes.

The Sagely Dao of the August Ultimate must not be treated lightly. Those who aid it will increase blessings and prolong life; those who destroy it will forever sink into the dark netherworld. Heavenly spirits observe and examine—retribution is clear and bright. With purification, reverence, and recitation, the myriad spirits all revere it. City gods and village altars follow the teaching and practice it.

The assembly at the altar rejoiced, believed, and received it, then bowed and withdrew.

**Chapter Two: The Five Phases and the Root of Filial Piety**

At that time, the Perfected Lü of Pure Yang said: “In past lives, my heart abided in the Dao. Following form and entrusting transformation, I never lost my root or pursued nature, thus never straying from my original source. Though the supreme secret was hard to encounter, my body and life floated and sank. Repeatedly receiving, repeatedly cultivating, I accumulated merit and virtue, vowing to practice filial piety, fraternal duty, loyalty, righteousness, benevolence, and compassion.

Later, I met the Lord Emperor of Eastern Florescence and thus heard the great Dao. I ascended to the Golden Gates and attained sagehood, becoming a perfected one. Pitying the afflicted, I roam the Three Realms, universally saving all beings.

Recently, a celestial decree has commanded me to deliver those blind and deaf in the sea of karma. Yet many chase fame and profit, while few attain sagehood and cultivate perfection. They scorn others and think only of themselves, their natures like wolves and tigers, their venom even more poisonous. Their words and hearts diverge, their schemes myriad. Countless are those stained by desire, but how few cherish life!

I have heard the Supreme Lord say: *‘I have three treasures, which I hold and preserve: the first is compassion, the second is frugality, the third is not daring to put oneself before the world.’* Thus compassion engenders courage; frugality engenders abundance; not daring to put oneself before the world enables one to perfect one’s vessel.”

What is called *"the Real"*? It is to empty the heart and sever thoughts, preserve *qi* and nurture essence. Respond to things without being ensnared by them; cultivate emptiness and embody the void. Clarity of intent and emotion—thus begins primordial cultivation. The six gates are strictly guarded; a single breath is ever present. *Qi* and spirit do not deplete; spirit and *qi* merge as one.

Subdue *qi* beneath the navel; guard the spirit within the body. When spirit and *qi* harmonize, the gates and pivots open smoothly. You speak of the Dao—where does the Dao reside? If the heart does not forget the Dao, the Dao is already attained! Embody the heart of sages and sages’ deeds—only then is it the Dao!

I have received the grace of a mandate to guide all beings. With wisdom, I illuminate you, yet you still do not believe and accept, recklessly wielding cunning and deceit, stirring up treachery and obstinacy. You conceal falsehood amid truth, making the Real difficult to grasp. Clearly, in this floating life, there is no benevolence or virtue!

My heart is the heart of Heaven and Earth. I only wish that all the deluded will universally cultivate kindness and goodness, silently focusing spirit so that spirit and *qi* align. Subdue and embrace primordial *qi*; do not lose these three treasures.

Now, for the sake of all beings, I expound the principles of the *Yi*, drawing analogies from former sages to illustrate subtle truths. I show that the *Yi* encompasses the Dao, and the Dao encompasses the *Yi*. Gather and practice it; cultivate it in seclusion; guard it in silence; refine it with diligence. Then the spirit ascends to the Purple Palace, and one takes one’s place among the immortals.

When Qian and Kun merge, the images of the *Yi* are thus. Once the singular *qi* divides, it becomes the source of the Two Modes. To fathom the spirit and know transformation, to encompass all in an unbroken cycle—knowing the subtle and the manifest, the hidden and the revealed, which are indescribable, continuous, and boundless, their radiance illuminating the vast primordial.

Pride does not endure; only humility can preserve the whole. Guard the Dao with reticence; indulging in cleverness will surely lead to error. Hold to the center and embrace the One; walk in harmony and humility. Accumulate through lowliness; strengthen through softness.

When the heart stirs, it becomes intent; when intent turns, it becomes emotion; when emotion clings, it becomes delusion; delusion leads to manifold transgressions. Human emotion, upon seeing things, is like a tiger in pursuit; human intent, upon seeing things, is like a dragon’s coils. If the stirring heart is not extinguished, the illuminating heart cannot be perfected. Life resides in the kidneys; nature belongs to Qian.

When the heart congeals, it becomes spirit; when spirit is still, it becomes nature. To exhaust principle and fulfill nature is to merge with the boundless. When spirit returns to non-action, refining and tempering the Three Origins, seeing yet not perceiving, hearing yet not clamoring, speaking yet voiceless—all thoughts are cast aside.

In the Dao of the Five Phases, water and fire transform. Water and fire harmonize; water and fire intermingle. Within fire is earth; within water is flame. Since fire generates earth, the three natures are complete. Use earth to restrain water; when water overflows, it must be turned back. Guide water to aid fire; when water and fire rejoice together, metal and wood unite, *qi* and spirit connect. The nature of metal and the essence of wood are driven and refined until they adhere. Through the long night, light pierces heavy curtains. Nurturing with warmth, ascending mercury and descending lead—metal floats, wood sinks, the red sun stands at midheaven.

Fire requires water to aid it; water relies on fire to blaze. Use softness to restrain hardness; hardness and softness intertwine. Refined into one mass, neither mercury nor lead, it can ascend and descend—this is called the Embryonic Immortal.

Circulate fire to refine the elixir; spirit and *qi* entwine. Use fire as an analogy for spirit; use the *qi*-vessel as an analogy for the elixir. Unite spirit with *qi*; when *qi* is sufficient, spirit is complete. The river chariot’s count: circulate *qi* through the celestial cycle. Heart and breath depend on each other; the abdomen stores, the eyes are clear.

Wu-earth follows Kan, advancing with yang fire; Ji-earth follows Li, retreating with yin tally. Advancing and retreating, merging and parting—abandon them to the Great Primordial. The aperture of the Primordial Sea follows the Mud Pill Palace. The Five *Qi*-Vessels merge; all phenomena pay homage to Heaven.

Yet people do not recognize this and cling to distorted transmissions. Before the human Dao is complete, the immortal Dao is difficult to fulfill. To cultivate the Real Dao, the human Dao must merge with the immortal. Practice and walk this path, and immortals and sages will stand side by side.

Born of father and mother, the body unites with karmic conditions. Shift spirit and shed *qi*; waxing and waning like the moon’s beauty. The two *qi* assist each other; tortoise and snake coil together. Gathered and congealed, the embryo is complete. Nurtured for ten months, the body accords with the prenatal. Splitting open the primordial chaos, the image appears resplendent.

Nurtured in the womb and suckled, the mother’s form is emaciated and tormented. Gradually, the child is reared, the body firm and spirit complete. Shedding *qi* and transforming through nurture—boundless is the vast Heaven. What is called "transformation" is a profound and subtle principle.

The Dao of the Embryonic Origin accords with Kun and Qian. Yang bestows; yin receives. Emotion and nature intertwine.

In this world, those lost on the path doubt and misinterpret the teachings. They scatter internally and drown externally, clinging to the seven emotions and spoiling the six roots. Losing their original nature and forgetting the Real, they know no warning. Fire scorches; water collapses; *qi* departs; spirit decays.

Cherishing children and pitying wives, they hold pearls in their palms. Yet the great kindness of parents becomes dust in their eyes. Disobedient and unfilial, their sins are vast. If you cherish your child, you should cherish your parents. If you are filial to your parents, your child will also be filial to you. If you do not respect your parents, your child will also defy you.
