Each organ possesses both yin and yang: yin flourishes at eight and doubles at two, so when qi reaches the liver, the residual yin of the kidneys is exhausted; when qi reaches the heart, the Supreme Ultimate generates yin, for two resides in the heart while eight resides in the liver. Yang is exhausted at nine and flourishes at one, so when fluid reaches the lungs, the residual yang of the heart is exhausted; when fluid reaches the kidneys, the Supreme Ultimate generates yang, for one resides in the kidneys while nine resides in the lungs. Those who uphold the Dao first conjoin dragon and tiger, gathering the heart’s true yang qi—the true yang qi is the heart’s seven. Seven returns to the middle origin and enters the lower elixir field, nurturing the immortal embryo, then returns to the heart—this is called the Sevenfold Returned Elixir. When the two and eight of yin are dissolved, true qi is generated and the heart is without yin, thus severing two; when the Great Medicine is complete, the liver is without yin, thus severing eight. Once the two and eight of yin are dissolved, the three and nine of yang may flourish. The liver, having severed yang, assists the heart, so the liver’s qi of three flourishes. Seven having returned to the heart to sever the lung’s fluid, the lung’s nine turns to assist the heart, so the three and nine of yang flourish—this is the Ninefold Cyclic Elixir.

Master Lü said: The Sevenfold Return refers to the heart’s yang returning to the heart and residing in the middle elixir; the Ninefold Cycle refers to the lung’s yang, originally born from the heart, turning and returning to the heart, also residing in the middle elixir. The Sevenfold Return and Ninefold Cycle are now understood. What, then, is the mutual exchange of golden fluid and jade fluid, the upper, middle, and lower fields interacting, yin and yang reciprocating to return the elixir?

Master Zhong said: Former worthies and ancient sages often spoke of lung fluid entering the lower elixir field as the Golden Fluid Returned Elixir, and heart fluid entering the lower elixir field as the Jade Fluid Returned Elixir. This discourse is not without subtlety, yet it does not fully reveal the profound mechanism. The lungs generate the kidneys through metal generating water, but when metal enters water, how can this be called a returned elixir? The kidneys restrain the heart through water restraining fire, but when water enters fire, how can this be called a returned elixir? Golden fluid is lung fluid; lung fluid forms the embryonic sac, containing dragon and tiger, safeguarding and conveying them within the Yellow Court. As the Great Medicine nears completion, it is drawn from behind the elbow, and the lung fluid soars to enter the upper palace, then descends to return to the middle elixir, from the middle elixir returning to the lower elixir field—thus it is called the Golden Fluid Returned Elixir. Jade fluid is kidney fluid; kidney fluid ascends with original qi to pay homage at the heart, accumulating to become metal-water, raising to fill the Jade Pool, dispersing as jasper blossoms, refining into white snow. If it is received from the middle field to enter the lower elixir field, when medicine is present, it bathes the immortal embryo. If it is ascended from the middle field to enter the four limbs, refining the form transmutes the mortal bones. Neither ascending nor receiving, it circulates endlessly—thus it is called the Jade Fluid Returned Elixir. When yin reaches its extreme, yang is born; within yang resides the true one of water, and this water ascends with yang—this is the elixir of yin returning to yang. When yang reaches its extreme, yin is born; within yin resides the true yang of qi, and this qi descends with yin—this is the elixir of yang returning to yin. Nourishing the brain and refining the crown returns the lower to the upper; achieving balance and irrigation returns the upper to the middle; firing the elixir and advancing the flame returns the middle to the lower; refining the body and incinerating the form returns the lower to the middle. The Five Phases are inverted, the three fields return and repeat, mutually exchanging until the form is refined into qi, qi is refined into spirit. From the lower elixir field it transmutes to the middle, from the middle to the upper, from the upper it transmutes to exit the Heavenly Gate, discarding the mortal frame to enter the ranks of sages and immortals—only then is the work of three transmutations complete, ascending from below without further return.

**On Refining the Form, Fourteenth**

Master Lü said: The returned elixir is now understood. May I hear the principle of "refining the form"?

Master Zhong said: In human life, form and spirit are exterior and interior. Spirit is the master of form, and form is the dwelling of spirit. The essence within form generates qi, and qi generates spirit; fluid generates qi, and within qi fluid is generated—these are the mother and child within form. Water generates wood, wood generates fire, fire generates earth, earth generates metal, metal generates water; qi transmits between mother and child, and fluid flows between husband and wife—these are the yin and yang within form.

Water transforms into fluid, fluid into blood, blood into essence—this is yin receiving yang to generate life. Should yin and yang fall out of harmony, then tears, mucus, saliva, and sweat issue uncontrollably, and yin loses its generative power. Qi transforms into essence, essence into pearl, pearl into mercury, mercury into cinnabar—this is yang receiving yin to achieve completion. Should yin and yang fall out of harmony, then sickness, aging, death, and suffering arise, and yang cannot be generated.

Without yin, yang cannot be generated; without yang, yin cannot be completed. Can a follower of the Dao cultivate yang without cultivating yin, refine the self without refining the substance? At the moment one’s form receives qi, it is the balanced union of father’s and mother’s true qi, where essence and blood coalesce into the embryo, lodged within the mother’s pure yin. Within yin, yin is generated; through form, form is shaped. Once the fetus is complete and qi is full, this stately six-foot frame is entirely yin—all but a single point of original yang.

If one desires long life without death, one must refine the form to abide in the world, enduring kalpa after kalpa. If one desires to transcend the mundane and enter sagehood, one must refine the form to transform into qi, so that a body exists beyond the body.

Master Lü said: Form is the image of yin, and yin possesses substance. To make the substantial into the insubstantial, to transform form into qi and transcend the mortal frame to enter the rank of sages—this is the supreme method of refinement. By preserving qi within form and nourishing form with qi, one may achieve minor blessings of peace and longevity, or greater ones of preserving form to abide in the world. The aged return to youth, the youthful maintain their countenance for eternity. Three hundred and sixty years become a single year, thirty-six thousand years a single kalpa, thirty-six thousand kalpas a single great kalpa. In this vast expanse of kalpas, the passage of years becomes immeasurable, yet one endures as long as heaven and earth—this is the verification of refining the form.

May I hear of the workings of this alchemical mechanism that yields such verification?

Master Zhong said: The human form is completed in three hundred days within the womb. After birth, qi is full in five thousand days. Five feet and five inches constitute the fundamental frame, corresponding to the generative numbers of the Five Phases. Should there be variations in size, they are measured proportionally to ensure harmony. Above the heart lies the Nine Heavens; below the kidneys, the Nine Earths. From the kidneys to the heart is eight inches and four fen; from the heart to the first ring of the *chonglou* is eight inches and four fen; from the first ring of the *chonglou* to the crown is eight inches and four fen. From the kidneys to the crown spans two feet, five inches, and two fen. The original qi fills this measure in a single day and night, cycling three hundred and twenty times. Each cycle traverses two feet, five inches, and two fen, totaling eighty-one zhang of original qi—corresponding to the pure yang number of nine nines.

The distance between heart and kidneys aligns with the celestial and terrestrial proportions. From the kidneys to the crown spans two feet and five inches, further conforming to the pure yang number of five fives in the Five Phases. Thus, original qi follows the breath outward: when exhaled, the constructive and defensive qi circulate freely. The upright qi of heaven and earth responds to the seasons and nodes, now uniting, now parting, extending without limit. When inhaled, the qi enters, and the channels and collaterals open wide. Each exhalation and inhalation embodies the true qi of heaven, earth, and humanity, coursing before the Twelve Stories. One departure and one return constitute a single breath. In a day and night, a person takes thirteen thousand five hundred breaths.

Dividing them: thirteen thousand five hundred exhalations, each expelling one’s own original qi from within; thirteen thousand five hundred inhalations, each drawing in the upright qi of heaven and earth from without. If the root is firm and original qi unharmed, then between exhalation and inhalation, one may seize the upright qi of heaven and earth. Refining qi with qi, it disperses to fill the Four Great Elements. The clear becomes constructive, the turbid defensive, all flowing unimpeded. The vertical channels and horizontal collaterals all attain ease. Cold and heat cannot harm, toil and hardship cannot trouble. The body is light, the bones strong, the qi fresh, the spirit clear—eternal life is preserved, and one remains forever unaging.

Should the root be unstable, essence exhausted, and qi weakened, then above, original qi leaks away; below, the foundational palace is unnourished. The qi of heaven and earth that is inhaled flows out in abundance. The eighty-one zhang of original qi dwindles through nine nines, no longer belonging to oneself but instead seized by heaven and earth. How then can one seize the upright qi of heaven and earth? As yin accumulates and yang wanes, qi weakens and illness arises; when qi is spent, death follows, and one falls into the cycle of rebirth.

Master Lü said: How can original qi be prevented from dissipating, so that by refining the form, one may seize the upright qi of heaven and earth and endure through great kalpas?

Master Zhong said: To achieve victory in war, one’s troops must be strong; to ensure the people’s peace, the nation must be prosperous. The "troops" are the original qi. When deployed internally, they dissolve the yin of form and substance; when deployed externally, they seize the qi of heaven and earth. The "nation" is one’s own body. The tangible aspects of the body are abundant and ever-sufficient; the intangible aspects are firm and never lacking. Though ten thousand gates stand open, not a single loss is feared; should a single horse stray, many losses may befall. Whether advancing or retreating, one refines the substance and burns the body; whether ascending or descending, one nourishes yang and dissolves yin. The time to scorch heaven and earth arrives in due course—how can the refinement of qi and fluid lack daily vigilance?

Refining the form with *jade fluid*, riding the armored dragon to ascend and soar, white snow fills the dusty flesh. Refining the form with *golden fluid*, pursuing the thunder chariot to descend, golden light fills the chamber. Master Lü said: The principle of refining the form is now roughly understood. What are the *golden fluid* and *jade fluid*?

Master Zhong said: Refining the form with *golden fluid* causes the bones to glow golden, the body to radiate golden light, and golden petals to manifest spontaneously in the void. This is the Five Qi converging at the origin, the Three Yangs gathering at the crown—the moment one transcends the mortal frame, the day the Golden Elixir is fully realized.

When refining the form with *jade fluid*, the flesh becomes suffused with *yang*-butter, the body resembling jade trees, jasper blossoms, and jade buds—transforming the mortal frame so that radiance shines upon others. Riding the wind, one soars freely, the form becoming qi. For those who uphold the Dao, though they may know the method of the Returned Elixir, the work of refining the form is no small matter.

When the *jade fluid* returns as the Elixir, the Embryonic Immortal ascends in the upward movement, while the River Chariot transports it through the Four Great Elements. It begins with the liver: when the liver receives it, light fills the eyes, and the eyes become dark as lacquer. Next, the heart receives it, and the *spirit-fluid* is born daily, the fluid becoming white snow. Then the spleen receives it, and the flesh becomes smooth as congealed fat, all scars vanishing. Next, the lungs receive it, and the nose detects celestial fragrance, the complexion restored to youth. Finally, the kidneys receive it, returning once more to their original palace: within the ears, the sound of strings and pipes is ever heard, and at the temples, the color of gray hair is forever banished. Such is the refining of the form with *jade fluid*.

As for refining the form with *golden fluid*, it begins with the Returned Elixir yet unreturned, meeting the *Lord Fire*—this is called *Completion*. Once the Elixir has returned and rises again, it contends with true *yin*—this is called *Refining the Substance*. Earth inherently overcomes water, but when the *golden fluid* resides in earth, it causes the Yellow Emperor to turn his light back, uniting with the Great Yin. Fire inherently overcomes metal, but when the *golden fluid* resides in fire, it causes the Red Child to share the furnace, spontaneously generating within purple qi. Fire arises within water, *yin* dissolves within *yang*, the Golden Elixir transforms within the Yellow Court, and the *yang*-spirit is refined amid the Five Qi: in the liver, green qi surges; in the lungs, white light emerges; in the heart, red radiance appears; in the kidneys, black qi ascends; in the spleen, yellow light gathers. The Five Qi converge at the Middle Origin, ascending from the *Lord Fire* to transcend the Inner Sanctum.

The *yang* within the *yin* of the Lower Origin—its *yang* without *yin*—ascends and gathers in the Spirit Palace. The *yang* within the *yang* of the Middle Origin—its *yang* without birth—ascends and gathers in the Spirit Palace. The great medicine of the Yellow Court, with *yin* exhausted and pure *yang* remaining, ascends and gathers in the Spirit Palace. The Five Fluids converge at the Lower Origin, the Five Qi converge at the Middle Origin, and the Three Yangs converge at the Upper Origin. Once the convergence is complete, the merit of three thousand is fulfilled: now cranes dance atop the crown, or dragons soar within the body. Only the resounding music of pipes is heard, and immortal blossoms scatter in profusion. The Purple Court lingers, true fragrance is richly redolent, and the three thousand merits fulfilled—one is no longer a mortal of the dusty world. As a single stick of incense burns away, one becomes a guest of Penglai and Yingzhou, transcending the ordinary to enter sagehood, shedding the mortal frame to ascend as an immortal.

**Discourse on the Convergence at the Origin, Fifteenth***
Master Lü said: The principle of refining the form is now understood.

What is meant by "Convergence at the Origin"? Might I be permitted to hear of it?

Master Zhong said: When the Great Elixir nears completion, the Jade Fluid returns as the Cinnabar, and one bathes the Embryonic Immortal. Once true qi is born, it carries the Jade Fluid upward to transform the mortal bones—this is called "refining the form with Jade Fluid." Later, when the Golden Radiance flies up from behind the elbow and the River Chariot enters the Inner Court, ascending from above to the middle, then descending from the middle to below, the Golden Fluid returns as the Cinnabar. Refining the Golden Sand with this, the Five Qi converge at the Origin, and the Three Yangs gather at the crown—this is "refining qi to become spirit," not merely "refining the form to abide in the world."

The Convergence at the Origin is known to few, past or present. Should one know of it, sages and worthies do not speak of it. For this is the method of true immortals’ great accomplishment, the subtle mechanism hidden by Heaven and Earth, the esoteric matter of the Three Clarities, the profound principle beyond words and images, the wondrous truth of no-question and no-response. I fear that if your resolve is not steadfast, your study not single-minded, your heart not tranquil, and your inquiry not earnest, careless speech may instead increase my transgression of leaking sacred secrets, to the mutual benefit of none.

Master Lü said: First, one awakens to the true immortals and recognizes the great Dao. Next, one knows the seasons and comprehends the celestial mechanism. One distinguishes the true origins of Water and Fire, knows that Dragon and Tiger do not arise from liver and lungs, examines the great principle of withdrawal and addition, and discerns that Lead and Mercury are not Kan and Li. The art of inverting the Five Phases has already been instructed; the mechanism of the Three Fields’ reversal has again been expounded. One thoroughly understands the principle of returning the Cinnabar and refining the form, and deeply knows the art of longevity and deathlessness. Yet the origin of transcending the ordinary to enter sagehood, the Dao of shedding the mortal frame to ascend as an immortal, lies in refining qi to converge at the Origin. As for the Convergence at the Origin, I dare to offer a brief explanation of its essentials.

Master Zhong said: The Dao is originally formless. The Great Primal reveals simplicity; the Upper Clarity and Lower Turbidity merge as one. Once the Great Primal divides, the primordial chaos first separates into Heaven and Earth. Within Heaven and Earth, the five directions—east, west, south, north, and center—are arrayed. Each direction has its own Emperor, and each Emperor has two children: one Yang and one Yin. The two qi generate and complete each other, dividing into the Five Phases; the Five Phases generate and complete each other, establishing the Six Qi, thus forming the Three Yins and Three Yangs.

Extending this principle to human conception: at first, essence and qi are one. Once essence and qi separate, the two kidneys are born first. The left kidney is the Yang Kidney, which ascends qi and transmits it upward to the liver. The right kidney is the Yin Kidney, which receives fluid and transmits it downward to the bladder. The Yang and Yin Kidneys arise from Nothingness, transforming Nonbeing into Being. They are the true qi of father and mother, received in the realm of pure Yin. Thus it is said, "The Valley Spirit does not die; this is called the Yang and Yin Kidneys." The Gate of the Yang and Yin Kidneys may be compared to the root of Heaven and Earth. The Yang and Yin Kidneys are the two kidneys; from them arise the Five Viscera and Six Bowels in their entirety.

Among them:
- The liver is Wood, called Jia and Yi, comparable to the Azure Emperor of the East.
- The heart is Fire, called Bing and Ding, comparable to the Vermilion Emperor of the South.
- The lungs are Metal, called Geng and Xin, comparable to the White Emperor of the West.
- The spleen is Earth, called Wu and Ji, comparable to the Yellow Emperor of the Center.
- The kidneys are Water, called Ren and Gui, comparable to the Black Emperor of the North.

At the beginning of human life, there is no form or image, only one Yin and one Yang. Once the fetus is complete and the intestines and stomach form, the Six Qi divide, merely the Three Males and Three Females. One qi moves the Five Phases, and the Five Phases move the Six Qi.

First, one recognizes Yin and Yang: within Yang there is Yang within Yin, and within Yin there is Yin within Yang. Next, one recognizes Metal, Wood, Water, Fire, and Earth, each containing Water within Fire, Fire within Water, Water within Metal, Metal within Wood, Wood within Fire, and Fire within Earth. These five interact and unite, so the two qi divide into the Six Qi, and the great Dao scatters into the Five Phases.

After the Winter Solstice, when one Yang arises in the earth of the five directions, all Yangs are born. One Emperor presides over its seasonal command, while the other four Emperors assist. For example, when the command of spring has been issued, if the Black Emperor does not withdraw its command, cold cannot transform into warmth; if the Vermilion Emperor does not prepare its command, warmth cannot transform into heat.

After the Summer Solstice, when one Yin arises in the heavens of the five directions, all Yins descend. One Emperor presides over its seasonal command, while the other four Emperors assist. For example, when the command of autumn has been issued, if the Vermilion Emperor does not withdraw its command, heat cannot transform into coolness; if the Black Emperor does not prepare its command, coolness cannot transform into cold.

At the Winter Solstice, Yang arises from the earth to converge qi at Heaven. At the Summer Solstice, Yin arises from Heaven to converge qi at earth. Those who uphold the Dao must deeply investigate this principle.

Between the sun and moon, when one Yang first arises, the qi of the Five Viscera converge at the Middle Origin. When one Yin first arises, the fluids of the Five Viscera converge at the Lower Origin. The Yang within Yin, the Yang within Yang, and the Yang within the midst of Yin and Yang—these Three Yangs ascend to converge at the Inner Court of the Heart Spirit, returning to the Heavenly Palace. All these are the Convergence at the Origin.

Master Lü said: When Yang arises, the Five Qi converge at the Middle Origin; when Yin arises, the Five Fluids converge at the Lower Origin. If the Yang within Yang, the Yang within Yin, and the Yang within the midst of Yin and Yang converge at the Upper Origin—though some know of this practice, how can one transcend and escape the dusty world?

Master Zhong said: If the primordial Yang qi, at the time when one Yang first arises, ascends to converge at the Middle Origin, all people are like this. If accumulated qi generates fluid, and at the time when one Yin first arises, descends to converge at the Lower Origin, all people are like this. If one practices in this manner, few can achieve transcendence.

If one wishes to transcend the mortal and enter the sacred, to shed the physical form and ascend as an immortal, one must first achieve the union of Dragon and Tiger to form the Great Elixir. Once the Great Elixir is formed, true qi is born. When true qi is born, one employs the months within the year to determine waxing and waning; the days within the month to fix the affairs of the celestial stems; and the hours within the day to establish the count of breaths. Nurture Yang with Yang, ensuring no Yin lingers within Yang; refine Yin with Yang, ensuring no Yang scatters within Yin.

In general: in spring, the liver flourishes while the spleen weakens; in summer, the heart flourishes while the lungs weaken; in autumn, the lungs flourish while the liver weakens; in winter, the kidneys flourish while the heart weakens. For humans, the kidneys are the root, and in every season, the spleen flourishes while the kidneys weaken—only the kidneys suffer depletion across the four seasons, which is why people often fall ill. In general: when Jia and Yi govern the liver, guard against the spleen’s qi failing to circulate; when Bing and Ding govern the heart, guard against the lungs’ qi failing to circulate; when Wu and Ji govern the spleen, guard against the kidneys’ qi failing to circulate; when Geng and Xin govern the lungs, guard against the liver’s qi failing to circulate; when Ren and Gui govern the kidneys, guard against the heart’s qi failing to circulate. When one qi flourishes, another weakens; when one organ waxes, another wanes—this is why people often fall ill.

In general: the heart’s qi sprouts in Hai and is born in Yin, flourishes in Si, and weakens in Shen; the liver’s qi sprouts in Shen and is born in Hai, flourishes in Yin, and weakens in Si; the lungs’ qi sprouts in Yin and is born in Si, flourishes in Shen, and weakens in Hai; the kidneys’ qi sprouts in Si and is born in Shen, flourishes in Hai, and weakens in Yin. The spleen’s qi follows the liver in spring, the heart in summer, the lungs in autumn, and the kidneys in winter. People, unaware of daily practice, do not comprehend the times of flourishing and weakening—this is why they often fall ill.

When the three Yangs of the day, month, and hour converge, refine Yang to prevent Yin from arising; when the three Yins converge, nurture Yang to prevent it from scattering. Moreover, once true qi is born, use the pure Yang qi to refine the qi of the five viscera, exhaling without ceasing, and in one movement of the original nature, ascend to the Heavenly Pool. First, with the kidneys free of Yin, the Nine Rivers are without waves; next, with the liver free of Yin, the Eight Passes are forever sealed; next, with the lungs free of Yin, metal and fire share the same furnace; next, with the spleen free of Yin, the Jade Gate does not open; finally, as true qi ascends, the four qi converge into one. Even if the Golden Fluid descends, a cup of water cannot overcome the fire of kindling. Water and fire envelop each other, merging into one, entering the Spirit Palace. Settle the breath, gaze inward, focus the mind without distraction—spirit and consciousness become wondrous. In stillness, one constantly hears music, as if in a dream yet not a dream, as if in a realm of emptiness and nothingness. The scenery and landscapes are unlike the dusty world, their splendor and beauty surpassing the mortal realm—pavilions and palaces, jade-green tiles wreathed in mist, pearls and silks, fragrant incense forming ranks.

At this time, one transcends the Inner Court, and the Yang spirit gathers to return to the Upper Cinnabar, refining the spirit into immortality to merge with the Great Dao. With one strike at the Gate of Heaven, the Dharma Body appears enveloped in golden light. Amidst the depths of blossoming flowers, seated in the mortal form, one traverses the void as if walking on level ground, a thousand miles no farther than an outstretched arm. If one chooses to return, re-entering the original body, spirit and form unite, and one’s longevity equals that of heaven and earth. If one wearies of the mortal world and lodges in a mortal womb, returning to the Ten Isles, at the Purple Mansion of the Supreme Subtle True Lord, one verifies one’s origins, confronts one’s name and surname, and assesses the depth of one’s merit and conduct. Attaining residence on the Three Isles, one roams forever beyond the wind and dust—this is called transcending the mortal and shedding the mundane.

Master Lü said: Refining the form only preserves one’s life in the world; refining qi is what enables ascension as an immortal. People who fail to grasp the profound mechanism, practicing fetal breathing without the Elixir, forcibly retaining it in the abdomen, may accumulate cold qi and fall ill or stir false Yang and invite disease. Though they cultivate in hopes of longevity, such delusion only leads to illness. They do not realize that once the Fetal Immortal is achieved, true qi is born; true qi is born, and fetal breathing arises naturally; fetal breathing refines qi, and refining qi gives birth to spirit.

Yet in refining qi, one must examine the months within the year, the days within the month, and the hours within the day. Sit upright in a quiet chamber, free from scheming and distractions. At this time, all lingering thoughts and attachments must be dispelled. If idle thoughts persist unceasingly, wisdom leaks, and the will to ascend as an immortal remains unsettled—what is to be done?

Master Zhong said: The union of Dragon and Tiger has its proper time, and practice has its proper method. Follow the time, practice the method, seek the Dao through the method—success will come swiftly, as easy as turning one’s palm. From ancient times to the present, those who have attained understanding close their eyes and still their minds, entering the realm of the subtle and imperceptible, relying on inner contemplation to stabilize the spirit and consciousness.

**On Inner Contemplation, Sixteenth**
Master Lü said: May I hear the principle of "inner contemplation"?
Master Zhong said: The methods of inner contemplation and sitting in forgetfulness, of visualization and concentration, have been adopted by some sages and rejected by others. One fears the mind-monkey and intent-horse, ceaselessly restless, lest external things erode one’s resolve, and no image arises from the void. Thus, one makes the ears unhearing, the eyes unseeing, the mind unconfused, and the intent undisturbed—visualization, inner contemplation, and sitting in forgetfulness are indispensable!

Alas, the ignorant and unlearned do not know the time of union, nor the method of practice. They merely hope for success through visualization, forming the Elixir within intent, extracting medicine from thought, snorting and swallowing, yearning for the tangible sun and moon or the formless heaven and earth, retaining them in the abdomen and mouth—this is truly child’s play!

Thus, the enlightened adepts and extraordinary individuals, upon abandoning sitting in forgetfulness and visualization, declare: "Wealth gained in dreams cannot sustain use! Drawing cakes on the ground cannot sate hunger!" Empty within emptiness, like flowers in a mirror or the moon in water—ultimately, no achievement is possible.

Yet there is merit to be found, for the heart is easily stirred, and intent is difficult to subdue. On auspicious days and favorable hours, one may gather and refine. Though one knows the realm of clarity and stillness, the heart is enslaved by affairs, and resolve is swayed by emotions. Even the slightest deviation separates one from heaven and earth; though years and months accumulate, no progress is seen—this failure lies in a chaotic heart and a reckless intent.

The keen observer focuses on the beauty of paintings and fails to see Mount Tai or Hua. The attentive listener attends to the sounds of strings and bamboo but does not hear thunder. If even the minor functions of the ears and eyes are thus, how much more so when the singular heart roams the six directions, encompassing all things? At the moment of seizing the time and applying the method, can one do without visualization and inner contemplation to bring it to fruition?

Lü Zu asked: "What, in broad terms, is meant by 'visualization and inner contemplation'?"
Zhong Zu replied: "When yang ascends, one visualizes many things: as man, as dragon, as fire, as heaven, as clouds, as cranes, as the sun, as horses, as chariots, as mist, as carriages, as flowers, as qi—all such inner contemplations and visualizations correspond to the image of yang’s ascent.

When yin descends, one visualizes many things: as woman, as tiger, as water, as earth, as rain, as tortoises, as the moon, as oxen, as springs, as mud, as lead, as leaves—all such inner contemplations and visualizations correspond to the image of yin’s descent.

The Azure Dragon, White Tiger, Vermilion Bird, and Dark Warrior—since these names exist, their images must also exist. The Five Peaks and Nine Provinces, the Four Seas and Three Isles, the Golden Boy and Jade Maiden, the river chariot and layered towers—calling forth their names and comparing their categories cannot be fully described. All are established as images within the void to stabilize the spirit and consciousness.

Before the fish is caught, the trap must not be discarded; before the hare is captured, the snare must not be absent."

The rear carriage moves only after treading the tracks of the one before; the great vessel once completed must serve as the model for those to follow. Thus, the method of inner contemplation must never be abandoned in practice. It cannot be clung to indefinitely, nor can it be severed even for a moment. If thoughts are cut off and no images arise, this is true thought; true thought is true emptiness. In this realm of true emptiness, one gradually ascends toward the real and departs from the dim crossroads—this is the path of transcendence.

When laying the foundation and beginning anew, progress can be made day by day. Then, visualization may be employed. Moreover, as one daily diminishes for the Dao, entering the realm of the subtle and formless, the method naturally simplifies, relying entirely on inner contemplation.

Master Lü said: "When the Dragon and Tiger unite in mating to pair yin and yang, what is the visualization like?"
Master Zhong replied: "At first, in their union, yin and yang are paired to stabilize Kan and Li. The visualization is this: the Nine August True Men lead a small boy in red robes upward; the Nine August True Mothers lead a small girl in black robes downward. They meet before the Yellow Chamber, where an old woman in yellow receives them, following the rites of a mortal couple, joyful at their union. The girl descends, the boy ascends, as in mortal partings. When this is complete, the old woman holds an object shaped like a red tangerine and casts it into the Yellow Chamber, where it is caught in a golden vessel. This boy is Qian seeking from Kun, his yang returning to its original place, yang carrying yin to rejoin its homeland. This girl is Kun seeking from Qian, her yin returning to its original place, yin embracing yang to rejoin its homeland. This is Kan and Li exchanging, yin and yang paired in union.

If in raging flames, one sees a black tiger ascending; if in surging waves, one sees a red dragon descending. The two beasts meet and battle before a towering pavilion. The vermilion gates swing open, and within swirling mists, a king gestures amid a sky ablaze with fire, above which towering waves rise. Fire surges and falls, mists fill heaven and earth. The dragon and tiger coil and entwine, entering a golden vessel, descending into the Yellow Chamber, as if placed within a casket.

This is the visualization of the Dragon and Tiger mating to transform into the yellow sprout.

Master Lü said: "Pairing yin and yang through the Dragon and Tiger’s union in inner contemplation is now understood. But what of the visualization for ‘advancing the fire to refine the elixir’?"
Master Zhong replied: "The visualization is this: a vessel like a tripod or cauldron, yellow or black, shaped like a wheel, with the Azure Dragon to the left and the White Tiger to the right, the Vermilion Bird before and the Dark Warrior behind. Beside it stand two ministers in purple robes, bowing and holding jade tablets; attendants stoke the fire beneath the vessel. Then a king in red robes rides a red horse, driving fiery clouds from the sky, raising his whip and shouting, fearing the fire is too small or the flames too weak. The flames blaze fiercely, pressing against the heavens, but the celestial gates do not open. The mists descend again, swirling fourfold. The people, vessels, cauldron, king, and ministers are all enveloped in crimson flames, gesturing and calling to one another, competing to advance the fire. The water in the vessel, though without vapor, seems congealed; the pearl within the water, though without light, seems radiant.

This is the visualization of advancing the fire to refine the elixir.

Master Lü said: "Does inner contemplation and visualization end with gathering the medicine and advancing the fire, or does it follow each method and each stage?"
Master Zhong replied: "Clouds and thunder descend, mists and vapors rise. Sometimes heavenly flowers rain down, auspicious winds and propitious qi arise beneath the palace halls; sometimes immortal maidens and jade women ride colorful phoenixes and auspicious simurghs, descending from the azure heavens. In golden platters, they offer jade dew and rosy nectar to the king.

This is the visualization of the Golden Liquid Returning Elixir reaching completion.

If the Dragon and Tiger drag a chariot through fire, surging upward through the Three Passes—each pass guarded by countless soldiers and officials in armor, fearful of the intruder—first the Dragon and Tiger charge but cannot break through; then the great fire burns them open. They ascend Kunlun without pause, halting only at the Heavenly Pool. Or three cranes soar through the Three Heavens, or a pair of butterflies enter the Three Palaces. Or within five-colored clouds, a small boy in red robes is borne past the Celestial Gate; or a golden chariot and jade carriage carry a king beyond the Three Realms.

This is the visualization of the ‘Flying Golden Essence behind the Elbow’ and the ‘Great River Chariot.’

Then a red-robed messenger rides a chariot, traveling in sequence: from Ji Province to Yan Province, from Yan to Qing, from Qing to Xu, from Xu to Yang, from Yang to Jing, from Jing to Liang, from Liang to Yong, and from Yong back to Ji. East, west, south, and north—all converge at Yu Province, where they pause before continuing. The treasures gathered are gold and jade; the tasks accomplished are solidification and stagnation. A single official transmits the decree, and the Nine Provinces are harmonized. Cycling endlessly, the movement never ceases.

Or journeying through the Five Peaks, beginning with Mount Heng; or sailing the Five Lakes, beginning with the Northern Lake. Or heavenly decrees summon the Five Emperors, or royal commands appoint the Five Lords.

This is the visualization of the returning elixir.

Then pearls and jades scatter upon the earth; or rain and dew nourish all things; or the sea tide fills the hundred rivers; or yang arises and stirs the ten thousand beings; or fire blazes across heaven and earth; or mists and dew fill the cosmos.

This is the visualization of refining the form.

Then, like a crane leaving its nest, or a dragon emerging from its cave; or the Five Emperors ascending to heaven, or five-colored clouds rising; or riding a cinnabar phoenix through the azure void; or in dreams ascending the celestial thoroughfares; or as heavenly flowers fall in profusion, immortal music resounds, golden light swirls, and one enters the splendor of palaces and halls."

Such are the visualizations of audience at the Origin.

After audience at the Origin, one no longer engages in visualization—this is called "inner contemplation."

Master Lü said: "Inner contemplation of the mysterious principle differs from the previous methods. May I hear of it?"

Master Zhong said: "Those who cultivate the Dao from ancient times to the present have not grasped the celestial mechanism. At the outset, they fail to follow the method in practice, seeking swift liberation. They take in much and expel little, practicing embryonic breathing, stilling the mind, closing the eyes, and engaging in inner contemplation. Yet they only attain quiescence and manifest a yin spirit, becoming a clear and numinous ghost rather than a pure yang immortal.

True immortals and sagely beings, in gathering the medicine and advancing the fire, in withdrawing lead and adding mercury, in returning the elixir and refining the form, in audience at the Origin and merging the qi, have spoken in earnest and in detail, fearing only that the world would not awaken. Yet they have paid little heed to inner contemplation. Little do they know that the method of inner contemplation is the method of yin-yang transformation, the moment of change between immortality and mortality. Those who uphold the Dao must not slight or underestimate it.

Moreover, the preceding matters—union occurs at set times, practice follows established rules. If one can carefully observe discipline and steadfastly adhere to the timing and method without the slightest deviation, success will be seen in due course. But this inner contemplation has no fixed time, no set rules. Secluded in a profoundly quiet chamber, day and night one sits upright in reverent stillness, recognizing the yang spirit and driving out the yin ghosts.

Bodhidharma faced the wall for nine years before transcending the inner court; the World-Honored One stilled his mind for six years before emerging from the cage of the mundane. Thus, inner contemplation is truly a difficult matter.

At first, from above to below, the purple river chariot is carried into the celestial palace. Who would not admire the wealth and honor of the celestial palace? Coming and going, one encounters splendor and extravagance—things unseen by ordinary people—all of which become manifest. Those who uphold the Dao, having long maintained purity and ease in solitude, when their merit is complete, readily accept such pleasures: towers and pavilions adorned with pearls and jade, female musicians playing sheng and huang, rare delicacies and fine foods, exotic grasses and wondrous flowers, scenes and vistas bright as day. If one does not awaken, one may mistake this for truly having arrived at the celestial palace, unaware that it is one’s own inner court, taking the illusory for the real. Lingering without exit or entry, one becomes trapped in the gloomy thoroughfare, the form abides in the world, and one cannot shed the body to become a spirit immortal. Before reaching the celestial palace, one remains in inner contemplation.

Yin ghosts and external demons arise from thought, and from thought arise illusory realms, forming demonic armies. Those who uphold the Dao may thus become wild and dissolute, falling into heterodoxy, or even losing their bodies to external paths, ultimately failing to achieve immortality. For the three corpses and seven poisons desire a person’s death to indulge in their own pleasures, while the nine worms and six thieves torment a person’s peace, leaving no place of refuge.

**On the Seventeenth Difficulty: Demonic Obstacles**

Master Lü said: "Through inner contemplation, the yang spirit is gathered; through refining the spirit, one transcends the inner court; by leaping upward, one exits through the celestial gate, directly ascending to the sagely ranks. Having exited and entered, coming and going without error; whether near or far, all is precise. If one wishes to remain in the world, spirit and form unite; if one wishes to ascend as an immortal, one roams afar to Penglai and the Isles of the Blessed. All this is achieved through inner contemplation to attain liberation. But how are yin ghosts and demonic obstacles to be subdued, so that those who uphold the Dao may ascend as immortals?"

Master Zhong said: "Those who uphold the Dao must first establish steadfast resolve. Matters of affection, profit, fame, and all worldly toils must not sway their great aspiration. Next, they must arouse a bitter resolve, enduring hardship and solitude. All realms of emptiness and purity must not alter their original intent. If one is determined to achieve great completion, one may only attain middling completion; if one is determined to achieve middling completion, one may only attain lesser completion. Moreover, those who do not recognize the great Dao find it difficult to fathom the celestial mechanism. Practicing minor methods, they often favor heterodox paths. Years and months pass in vain, no merit is seen, and in old age, they re-enter the cycle of rebirth. This leads later seekers of the Dao to regard longevity as a delusion and liberation as empty words. Often they hear the Dao but do not awaken, encountering circumstances that stir the mind, losing their resolve to external things, and ultimately failing to escape the nine difficulties and ten demonic obstacles."

Master Lü said: "What are the 'nine difficulties'?"

Master Zhong said: "Before the great medicine is complete, one struggles to endure cold and heat—throughout the year, one needs clothing. Before true qi is born, hunger and thirst remain—each day, one requires three meals. Those who uphold the Dao suffer from the pressing need for clothing and food—this is the first difficulty.

Furthermore, with heavy karmic conditions from past lives, one must repay them in this existence. Even when stealing moments in the floating world, one fears the constraints of high halls and the reluctance to abandon revered parents. Those who uphold the Dao suffer from the hindrance of elders—this is the second difficulty.

Moreover, those one loves—parents—and those one cherishes—wife and children—impose the shackles of affection and the fetters of emotion, increasing daily. The fiery household and the cart of sorrow never cease. Even with a mind of purity, one struggles to resist the clamor of the world. Those who uphold the Dao suffer from the entanglements of love and affection—this is the third difficulty.

Furthermore, possessing the wealth of ten thousand households or the rank of the three highest ministers, the restless mind refuses to rest, and the greedy heart fears insufficiency. Those who uphold the Dao suffer from the entanglements of fame and profit—this is the fourth difficulty.

Moreover, in youth, one refuses to cultivate, and in old age, one laments in vain. Qi weakens and illness arises, yet the stubborn heart does not awaken. Fate is thin and calamity strikes, suffering already endured in this life. Those who uphold the Dao suffer from misfortunes arising on all sides—this is the fifth difficulty.

Furthermore, eager to seek a teacher, one fails to discern the true from the false. Some may have eloquent speech, others an ancient and virtuous appearance. At first, one believes they have encountered a lineage of immortals, only to later realize they are mere opportunists. Those who uphold the Dao suffer from the constraints of blind teachers—this is the sixth difficulty."

Moreover, blind teachers and reckless companions falsely point to side doors, plucking branches and leaves, never achieving true accord. Petty techniques and heterodox teachings vie in mutual instruction. They know not: the sun and moon do not emerge, but when they do, their great radiance allows all with eyes to see; thunder does not rumble, but when it does, its mighty crash allows all with ears to hear. Yet they, with the dim glow of a firefly’s light and the croaking of well-frogs, flicker and chirp—how could they ever align? Those who uphold the Dao suffer from the divergence of doctrines—this is the seventh difficulty.

Furthermore, what is done in the morning is abandoned by evening; what is sat for is forgotten when standing. Delighted for a moment, they grow weary of perseverance; beginning with diligence, they end in indolence. Those who uphold the Dao suffer from the slackening of will and intent—this is the eighth difficulty.

Moreover, within the body, years are lost; within the year, months are lost; within the month, days are lost; within the day, hours are lost. In youth, fame and profit remain unforgotten in the heart; in old age, children and grandchildren constantly occupy the mind. The span of years is limited—do not say, "This year has passed, so I shall wait for the next"; the affairs of life are boundless—do not say, "Today has passed, so I shall wait for tomorrow." Today does not guarantee tomorrow, and old age will never regain youth. Those who uphold the Dao suffer from the wasting of years and months—this is the ninth difficulty.

Only by avoiding these nine difficulties can one truly uphold the Dao. If even one or two remain, all effort is in vain and success unattainable.

Lü Zu asked: "Now that the nine difficulties are known, may I hear of the so-called 'ten demons'?"
Zhong Zu replied: "The ten demons fall into three categories: first, 'external and present'; second, 'dreams and sleep'; third, 'inner vision.'

When the eyes behold a profusion of blossoms, the ears hear the strains of reed pipes and strings, the tongue savors sweet flavors, the nose delights in rare fragrances, the emotions feel at ease, and the spirit soars—if such sights are not recognized for what they are, these are the demons of the six thieves.

When jade towers and jeweled pavilions, painted beams and carved rafters, pearl curtains and embroidered drapes, orchid chambers and aloeswood canopies, coral strewn upon the ground, and halls filled with gold and jade appear—if such sights are not recognized for what they are, this is the demon of wealth.

When golden saddles and jeweled steeds, lofty canopies, lordships of ten thousand households, envoys bearing banners and flags, households clad in purple, and boots and tablets filling the hall appear—if such sights are not recognized for what they are, this is the demon of nobility.

When drifting mists, warm and languid sunlight, violent winds and heavy rains, thunderclaps and lightning flashes, the resounding strains of pipes and strings, or weeping and sorrow appear—if such sights are not recognized for what they are, these are the demons of the six emotions.

When relatives face hardship, family members suffer calamity, children fall ill, parents pass away, brothers scatter, or wives and concubines part—if such sights are not recognized for what they are, this is the demon of love and attachment.

When one is cast into boiling cauldrons, falls from high ridges, is harmed by venomous creatures, poisoned by toxins, encounters insurmountable perils on the road, or dies by legal decree—if such sights are not recognized for what they are, this is the demon of suffering and adversity.

When the Ten Grounds stand in radiance, the Three Pure Ones and the Jade Emperor, the Four Spirits and Seven Luminaries, the Five Peaks and Eight Kings appear in solemn dignity, circling and soaring—if such sights are not recognized for what they are, these are the demons of sages and worthies.

When clouds gather with troops and horses, blades gleam like frost, spears and halberds clash, bows and arrows are drawn, and fierce battles erupt—if such sights are not recognized for what they are, this is the demon of blades and warfare.

When immortal maidens and jade women array themselves in rows, pipes and strings resound, rainbow skirts are raised in unison, and pairs of crimson sleeves vie to offer golden goblets—if such sights are not recognized for what they are, this is the demon of female musicians.

When many beauties of dazzling charm, adorned in rich attire, feast by night in orchid pavilions, their jade forms clad in light silks, their alluring and haughty demeanors vying to pair—if such sights are not recognized for what they are, this is the demon of female beauty.

Though these ten demons arise, it is the failure to recognize them that matters. Once recognized, they take hold; once they take hold, they are grasped. This is why the Dao is not attained. For those who uphold the Dao, if external and present phenomena are neither recognized nor grasped, the heart does not retreat and the will does not waver. In dreams and sleep, if such visions are neither recognized nor clung to, the spirit does not stray and the soul does not scatter. During inner vision, when such sights appear, one must discern their emptiness or reality, distinguish truth from falsehood, and not drift with the waves or mistake thieves for one’s own kin. Then, igniting the true fire of samadhi to burn the body, with a single sweep, the demons scatter. Employing the Purple River Vehicle, one transports one’s own yang spirit, ascending from the inner court to the celestial palace—only then may liberation be sought.

From ancient times to the present, those who love the Dao, though their hearts may be pure, often falter before external circumstances, rarely escaping the ten demons and nine difficulties. They bear only the empty name of loving the Dao, never witnessing its true fruition. Some may renounce worldly toil, dwell in seclusion, and aspire to the Mystery Gate, yet if they cannot fully overcome the nine difficulties or may succumb to one or two of the ten demons, they do not fail to attain the Dao entirely. Within the Dao, they may achieve middling or minor success; among immortals, they may become human or earthbound immortals. But if all demons and difficulties are eradicated, step by step ascending through verified signs, uniting inner vision with the yang spirit, they may swiftly return to the Three Isles.

**On Verification, Eighteenth**
Lü Zu said: "Aversion is illness, yet those who love the Dao seek freedom from illness and enduring peace. Fear is death, yet those who love the Dao seek immortality and eternal life. While the world’s people dwell in the mundane, those who love the Dao aspire to ascend as immortals and wander beyond the material. While the world’s people remain on earth, those who love the Dao seek to transcend the elixir and enter the grotto heavens. Thus, they willingly endure hardship, endure poverty and lowliness, roam their minds in the carefree and unadorned, and conceal their traces in the wilderness and desolate places. Persisting in their practice, they know not the depth of their merit, the exchange of methods, or the timing of transformation and change."

**On Verification, Eighteenth (continued)**

Lü Zu asked: "After commencing cultivation, what is the sequence of verification?"

Zhong Zu replied: "Those who苦心志行持 yet see no fruition do not suffer the Dao’s betrayal—rather, they who follow the Dao without a luminous teacher receive no true method. Those who依法行持 yet see no fruition do not suffer the Dao’s betrayal—rather, they who follow the Dao know not the proper timing, and thus fail to succeed.

If one meets a luminous teacher and obtains the method, practicing the great method in accord with the time, how could verification not manifest?"

Lü Zu asked: "Does the 'method' have a fixed number? Does the 'time' have a fixed number?"

Zhong Zu replied: "The method comprises twelve divisions:
1. Harmonizing yin and yang,
2. Gathering and dispersing water and fire,
3. Conjoining dragon and tiger,
4. Refining the elixir,
5. Flying golden essence behind the elbow,
6. Returning the jade liquid elixir,
7. Refining the form with jade liquid,
8. Returning the golden liquid elixir,
9. Refining the form with golden liquid,
10. Facing the origin to refine qi,
11. Inner contemplation and exchange,
12. Transcending and parting the form.

As for the 'time,' it follows the yearly ascent and descent of heaven and earth’s yin and yang, the monthly cycles of the sun and moon’s movements, and the daily divisions of the four cardinal directions, eight trigrams, ten heavenly stems, twelve earthly branches, one hundred ke, and six thousand fen. When these are apportioned according to the method, from the first day onward, the sequence of verification proceeds without the slightest deviation until one sheds the mortal form and ascends as an immortal.

At first, lewd and deviant thoughts cease entirely; external conduct is cultivated alongside practice. During the gathering of medicine, golden essence fills the body, the mind’s illusions vanish, and yin ghosts are slain.
Next, the heart channel surges upward, and sweet liquid fills the mouth.
Next, yin and yang strike and clash, and at times, the sound of wind and thunder is heard within the abdomen.
Next, the hun and po are unsettled, and dreams are often filled with fearful and startling visions.
Next, the six bowels and four limbs may develop minor ailments, which heal without treatment.
Next, the cinnabar field grows warm, and one’s appearance becomes refined and elegant.
Next, in a dark room, the eyes emit a divine radiance.
Next, in dreams, one is mighty and brave, untouched by harm, uncheated by others, or as if embracing a returned infant.
Next, the golden gate and jade lock seal firmly, ending nocturnal emissions and leakage.
Next, a thunderous roar sounds, the joints connect, and startled sweat flows in all directions.
Next, the jade liquid is simmered and rinsed, congealing into su.
Next, the numinous liquid forms a paste, gradually repelling foul odors, filling the mouth and belly.
Next, the dusty bones grow light, the spirit chamber transforms, and one outpaces galloping horses, moving as if in flight.
Next, facing circumstances without attachment, all cravings cease.
Next, true qi enters things, enabling the cure of others’ illnesses.
Next, inner contemplation becomes luminous, free from obscurity.
Next, both eyes become as dark and bright as lacquer dots, wrinkled skin smooths, and black hair regrows; even the aged retain a youthful countenance.
Next, true qi gradually fills the body, and one feels perpetually sated, eating little yet drinking wine without limit, never appearing drunk.
Next, the body glows with radiance, the spirit and qi become refined and graceful, the sacred elixir generates flavor, the numinous liquid emits fragrance, and true fragrance and rare tastes linger between mouth and nose, perceptible to others.
Next, the eyes see autumn down at a hundred paces.
Next, old scars and blemishes on the body naturally fade, and tears, saliva, and sweat no longer appear.
Next, the embryo is complete and qi is full, ending the need for food and drink.
Next, the inner will is pure and lofty, merging with the Great Void; worldly passions and attachments vanish, the nine worms are eradicated below, and the three corpses die above.
Next, the hun and po no longer wander, ending dreams; the spirit’s brilliance and clarity transcend day and night.
Next, yang essence forms the body, the spirit’s abode is fortified, and the four limbs are unharmed by cold or heat.
Next, life and death can no longer interfere; sitting in forgetfulness and inner contemplation, one roams the divine immortal realm of Huaxu, where towers of jade maidens and resplendent beauty surpass anything in the mortal world.
Next, when merit is complete and conduct is fulfilled, karmic retribution manifests; the Three Clarities secretly bestow the true register, and one comprehends the transformations of yin and yang, foresees human affairs, and perceives disasters and blessings in advance.
Next, the eyes grow weary of worldly dust and refuse further entanglement; dwelling in purity and stillness, the embryonic immortal appears, and a body exists outside the body—this is the divine sage.
Next, true qi becomes pure yang, and exhalations can dry external mercury.
Next, the embryonic immortal constantly desires to soar, and auspicious light arises in the bedchamber.
Next, in stillness, music is heard at times.
Next, when facing ordinary people—even the wealthy and noble—their bones and vulgar bodies emit a foul stench.
Next, the spirit’s radiance can transform, and one’s bearing becomes as graceful as a jade tree; rare fragrance emanates, suffusing the golden hue.
Next, wherever one goes, divine spirits naturally appear to pay homage, obeying commands as if by one’s own will.
Next, in stillness, gazing outward, purple mist fills the eyes, and golden light envelops the body.
Next, within the body, a fire dragon suddenly flies or a dark crane arises—these are the numinous spirits shedding the mortal bones and transcending the vulgar, called *transcendence*.
Next, after transcendence, colored clouds swirl, auspicious qi abounds, heaven rains rare flowers, dark cranes fly in pairs, rare fragrance scatters, and jade maidens descend to bestow celestial scriptures and purple decrees. Once complete, the attire of an immortal—crown, robes, and all—is fully prepared; the dignity of the regalia, the attendants before and behind, are beyond enumeration. Welcomed and guided, one returns to Penglai, where in the Purple Palace, one pays homage to the True Lord of the Grand Tenuity. After verifying one’s native village, name, and assessing the merit of one’s conduct, one resides in the Three Isles as a *True Person and Immortal*.

Lü Zu said: "Today, I have been specially favored by the venerable teacher, who has revealed the profound principles of the abstruse and the celestial mysteries—far beyond mere clarity of ears and eyes or refinement of spirit. This decrepit body now has a refuge and will not share the fate of the dust and earth."

Yet to know is not necessarily to practice, and to practice is not necessarily to attain. Considering the gravity of life and death and the swift passage of time, though one may grasp the wondrous principles, without cultivation and adherence, one will ultimately fail—no different from one who remains ignorant. I humbly ask: at the moment of transmission and convergence, what is the method of practice? How does one begin? How does one apply effort?

Zhong Zu replied: I possess the *Lingbao Bifa*, comprising ten scrolls and twelve divisions, which contains six essential teachings: first, the *Golden Edicts*; second, the *Jade Scriptures*; third, the *True Origin*; fourth, the *Analogies*; fifth, the *True Instructions*; and sixth, the *Essentials of the Dao*. It encompasses the great Dao, drawing parallels to the Three Clarities. It takes the ascent and descent of Heaven and Earth’s yin and yang as its model, and the ebb and flow of the sun and moon’s essence as its standard—truly the purport of the Five Immortals and the paradigm of the Three Perfections. I shall select an auspicious day to transmit it to you.

*Commentary on the "Qiaoyao Song" and "Qinyuan Chun" (Scroll Thirty-One)*

**Preface to the *Complete Works of Patriarch Lü’s "Qiaoyao Song" and "Qinyuan Chun" Annotations***

The Dao of Patriarch Lü is that of "dual cultivation of *xing* (nature) and *ming* (life)." All his poetic works expound this principle, yet the two chapters—*"Qiaoyao Song"* and *"Qinyuan Chun"*—particularly grasp the essential framework, concise yet luminous, succinct yet comprehensive. They speak more of *ming* and less of *xing*, and later generations have followed this emphasis, thus labeling it the "Southern School." Yet *xing* precedes *ming*; I say that "nurturing *xing* to extend *ming*" is one and the same. Once *xing* is realized, *ming* naturally follows—how can *ming* be realized without first realizing *xing*? The *"Qiaoyao Song"* concludes by revealing the dual cultivation of *xing* and *ming*, while the *"Qinyuan Chun"* opens with refining the self to await the proper moment—its intent is thus evident. Yet those who annotate the *"Qiaoyao Song"* elaborate on *ming* while neglecting *xing*, and those who annotate the *"Qinyuan Chun"* variously interpret it as pertaining to *xing* or *ming*, much like the saying: "The benevolent see benevolence; the wise see wisdom." In truth, the text encompasses all without omission—one need not exalt one while suppressing the other, nor should one embrace one while discarding the other.

Having surveyed the complete corpus of Daoist texts, I found one commentary on the *"Qiaoyao Song"* and two on the *"Qinyuan Chun"*, and thus compiled them into a single scroll. Compiled by Liu Tishu of Yiling, styled Wuwozi; edited by his son Liu Yincheng, styled Qinghui, and nephew Liu Yuncheng, styled Qingxu; collated by Huang Chengshu of Shaxian, styled Yixingzi.

**Preface to the Annotations on the "Qiaoyao Song"**

The *"Qiaoyao Song"* expounds the great Dao of the union of yin and yang. The Dao originally has no name, yet our patriarch Laozi forcibly named it the Dao. This Dao is the Dao of the "Golden Elixir and Returned Cinnabar." Humans are born endowed with the essence and blood of Heaven and Earth; in infancy, their original essence (*yuanjing*), original qi (*yuanqi*), and original spirit (*yuanshen*) are undivided and wholly pure. As they mature, the four gates—eyes, ears, nose, and tongue—lead them astray, and their singular true nature is deeply stained by form, sound, fragrance, flavor, touch, and dharmas. Day after day, year after year, original essence transforms into generative essence, original qi into breath, and original spirit into discursive thought. The original qi disperses, making it difficult to recover primordial purity.

The patriarchs of past ages, moved by compassion, bequeathed teachings and established doctrines, recording in alchemical classics the methods for repair and restoration. When essence is depleted, it is replenished with essence; when qi is depleted, it is replenished with qi; when spirit is depleted, it is replenished with spirit. Thus, when humans decline, they are restored by humans, just as when trees wither, they are revived by earth. Therefore, the method of repair and restoration returns to the root and recovers *ming*. What is recovery? When essence is not leaked, it becomes a deep root; when qi is whole, it becomes a firm stem; when spirit is complete, it achieves wondrous union. If one can preserve these three, they become the lifelong medicine.

Yet in this world, those who are ignorant of the Dao are many, while those who understand it are few. Even among those who know, few grasp it in full. Instead, they become self-important, clinging to their own abilities, discoursing on Heaven and Earth, and setting themselves up as teachers. Such people ruin themselves. Thus, the *"Wuzhen Pian"* states: *"Though you recognize cinnabar and black lead, without knowing the fire times, it is all in vain. All depends on the power of cultivation; the slightest deviation prevents the elixir from forming."* It also says: *"The true essence of scriptures and songs is expounded, yet the fire times are not committed to writing. To know the oral instructions that reveal the mysterious, you must discuss them in detail with immortals."* And again: *"All things return to their roots; returning to the root and recovering ming ensures longevity. Few comprehend the constancy of returning to the root; reckless actions often invite misfortune."*

Therefore, the patriarchs earnestly exhort later learners: do not be reckless, nor waste time. When a single breath fails to come, regret is too late! It is better to turn back early and seek the oral instructions of an enlightened teacher. Without doubt, accept them directly, and cultivate this matter with a firm foundation. Obtain the medicine, obtain the elixir, temper it for ten months, shed the mortal coil, and undergo spiritual transformation. The ten kinds of elixirs are indispensable—not one can be lacking.

The above are but general remarks, earnestly admonishing the wise to awaken. Having seen Patriarch Lü Chunyang’s *"Qiaoyao Song"*—its meaning profound, its words incisive, encompassing the great Dao of the Golden Elixir, the three vehicles of the great Dharma, and the ten kinds of returned cinnabar—I could not put it aside, sighing without end. Though I have not yet attained the Dao, I do not conceal Heaven’s treasure. Thus, I have taken the oral instructions on the Golden Elixir personally transmitted by our patriarch and annotated the *"Qiaoyao Song"* verse by verse, clarifying its beginning and end. Though my words are shallow and my scholarship crude, the principle remains unblemished. This is not for the wise alone, nor is it beyond the grasp of the unlearned. I place this preface at the start of the scroll—heed it well and be cautious.

In the eighth year of the Zhengtong era, the cyclical year *guihai*, on the fifteenth day of the first lunar month, this was inscribed by Qian Daohua, the Master Without Blemish of Jade Peak in Gusu.

*Annotations on the "Qiaoyao Song"*
Composed by Qian Daohua, the Master Without Flaw of Jade Peak in Gusu

A drifting wanderer at the end of Han, in the Tang realm—
Thus the *"Qiaoyao"* defies all measure.
Through the unbounded—vertical and horizontal, inverse and direct—
In stillness, non-action; in motion, form.

The Master’s surname was Lü, given name Yan, style Dongbin, with the Daoist name Pure Yang. His ancestral home was in Yongle Town, Zhaoxian Village, Pucheng County, Hejing Prefecture of the Western Capital (present-day Pucheng County, Pu Prefecture). Born into an official family, he entered the world in the fourteenth year of the Tianbao era of the Tang, on the fourteenth day of the fourth month, at the *si* hour. At twenty, he remained unmarried. After passing the imperial examinations, he encountered the Perfected Lord Zhongli of True Yang, who transmitted to him the great Dao. Having completed his cultivation, he composed this *"Qiaoyao Song"*, declaring himself *"a drifting wanderer at the end of Han, in the Tang realm."*

*"Qiao"* means to deliberate—if one’s conduct is not straightforward, it may be *"qiao-ed."* *"Yao"* refers to the lines of the hexagrams, the principle of yin and yang intermingling, the dynamics of stillness and motion, advance and retreat. The worldly, deluded and ignorant, find it difficult to fathom.

*"Vertical and horizontal, inverse and direct"*—whether proceeding vertically or horizontally, in reverse or forward cultivation, all lies within one’s grasp, freely directed. *"Inverse"* refers to the sevenfold-returned elixir, the later-arising method; *"direct"* denotes the way of obtaining the medicine, the great elixir of dragon and tiger, the earlier-gathering method. *"Unbounded"* means that when one’s refinement is perfected, there is no constraint, nor any carelessness or error.

*"In stillness, non-action"*—when entering samadhi, the inner medicine and inner elixir coalesce as the spirit is stabilized and the mind fixed. All entanglements dissolve; the heart guards the elixir field within, the body like withered wood, the mind like dead ashes. One awaits only the first stirring of yang within the body, the union of heart and kidney, the inner husband and wife, when essence and nature merge as if in the great void. Thus it is said: *"A thousand sages seek his traces in vain—his whole being hides within the great void."* Upon emerging from samadhi, heart and kidney return to their places, and one feels two or three drops of clear spring water descending into the Yellow Court. As the ancients said: *"When yin and yang have consummated their union, a single drop falls into the Yellow Court."*

*"In motion, form"*—this is the principle of yin and yang, inverse and direct. One guards against danger, weighs risks, knows when to advance or retreat, discerns ascent and descent, distinguishes host and guest, ensuring no error in either. Without disturbance in motion, without desiccation in stillness—this is the foremost task in elixir refinement, hence it is stated first.

He drinks wine, he eats meat—
Yet holds fast to rouge and flowers, cutting off lust.
He practices Chan, sings lewd songs of rouge and powder—
While upholding precepts, his belly ever full of wine and meat.

The true cultivator values not the fasting of the mouth, but the fasting of the heart. *"Fasting of the mouth"* means abstaining from wine and meat; *"fasting of the heart"* means cutting off lust. If one’s nature and life are clear, and lust is severed without transgressing the precepts, what need is there to abstain from wine and meat? Thus the Patriarch said: *"He drinks wine, he eats meat."*

Rouge and flowers are the domain of lust—how much more to *"hold fast"* to them! Yet the adept, though beautiful sights may appear before his eyes, remains undisturbed in heart. Moreover, in the refinement of the returned elixir, there is the joy of the union of infant and maiden—how could he still crave the filth of rouge and flowers? Thus the Perfected Master, refining within, forever severs the dust of desire. His pure and tranquil heart abides in desire yet is not desirous, dwells in the world yet is not stained by it. Temporarily resting in the ground of freedom from defilement, he shall realize the body of the Dharma King.

*"Practicing Chan, singing lewd songs of rouge and powder"*—Chan is the practice of purity, while rouge and powder are the words of lust; the two are incompatible. Yet he who practices Chan while singing such songs—scripture says: *"A lotus blooms in fire—how rare! To practice Chan amid desire is equally rare."* Thus the Immortal Master, practicing Chan and singing lewd songs, forgets all appearances. Moreover, he wishes the world to recognize that his resolve is firm, his footing steady. There is no harm in blending with the world’s radiance.

Concealing his actions, silently refining, strictly guarding the root of life, meticulously upholding the precepts of his nature—what need is there to abstain from wine and meat?

Form is medicine, wine is emolument—
Amid wine and form, unbound.
Only through flowers and wine did he awaken to longevity—
Drinking wine, wearing flowers, gods and ghosts weep.

*"Form is medicine"*—within the maiden of sixteen, there lies the treasure of true gold, the medicinal substances of hun and po. *"Wine is emolument"*—destined by past causes, it also aids the flourishing of the Dao. *"Drinking wine all day without intoxication, wearing flowers without losing them"*—thus amid wine and form, there is no constraint.

The Master said: *"Now that I have attained the Dao and become an immortal, it is through flowers and wine that I achieved long life and enduring vision."* By drinking wine and wearing flowers, refining the self and upholding the heart, he committed no error. The six thieves and the three corpses’ ghosts naturally vanished, no longer able to run rampant—hence *"gods and ghosts weep."*

Do not break precepts, do not transgress lust—
Breaking precepts sinks the true suchness of nature.
Transgressing lust destroys the treasure of long life—
Only those who attain it are men of the Dao’s power.

*"Do not break precepts, do not transgress lust"* echoes the earlier *"holding fast to rouge and flowers, cutting off lust."* The foolish and deluded of the world, unaware of refining their own bodies, break precepts and transgress lust. Like a lamp extinguished when its oil is spent, or a man perishing when his marrow is exhausted, many have harmed their bodies and lost their lives. They know only to abstain from killing and stealing, unaware that the true theft and murder occur within—stealing the original yang qi, killing one’s own nature and life. Yet they remain unguarded, sinking into the river of love, their true nature obscured, mired in lust and desire, destroying the treasure of long life—how can they become immortals?

To grasp the method of cultivation, one must rely on the oral instructions of an enlightened master—refining the self, stabilizing the mind, obtaining the medicine, and securing the elixir. Thus attaining long life and enduring vision, the power of the Dao grows firm and strong. Hence it is said: *"Only those who attain it are men of the Dao’s power."*

**Men of the Dao’s power—**
**True idlers—**
*Wine is a fine friend, flowers a companion.*
*Seeking the true man in the willow lanes and flower streets—*
*The true man is but playing in the flower streets.*

Men of the Dao’s power are those who have completed the cycles of elixir-refinement, attained the Dao, and gained its strength—great beings of virtue. *"Wine is a fine friend"* refers to the earth of Kun, the southwest where companions gather, allowing one to drink the immortal wine of no-rice. *"Flowers are companions"* denotes the paired numbers of seven-six, two-seven, nine-two, nine-six—kindred spirits who may join as companions.

Thus, those of great practice enter without hesitation into brothels, taverns, flower streets, and willow chambers, performing the work of refining the self. Hence it is said: *In the willow lanes and flower streets, one may seek the true man.* The true man is indeed found playing in the flower streets.

*Plucking flowers, wearing them, drinking the wine of long life—*
*In the scene of non-action, the Dao naturally flourishes.*
*Let the deluded masses mock and scorn—*
*The immortal flowers and immortal wine are the immortal realm.*

*Plucking flowers, wearing them, drinking the wine of long life*—for the Dao cultivator, having received the master’s oral instructions and begun the work, the furnace must be precisely calibrated in weight and measure, without the slightest error. One must proceed in proper sequence: first, on the third day, the moon emerges at Geng; next, on the eighth day, the moon reaches Ding.

Afterward, on the fifteenth day, the moon reaches Jia. During the work, first use the yang sword to sever the flower’s stem, then with the yin sword drink the wine of long life. One must also know that at the time of the full moon, the water source is clear or turbid, the metal and water arrive in season, and the true man is precisely in position. Plunge into the Yellow Chamber’s earthen crucible, where in the ordinary scene, all entanglements are shed, and one enters non-action—then the true Dao naturally flourishes. The deluded masses of the world, hearing of using the cauldron to refine the great elixir, all mock and slander, deeming it unworthy of pursuit. Thus the immortal master said: *“Let the deluded masses mock and scorn—the immortal flowers and immortal wine are my immortal realm.”* Let the scholar ponder this.

*To this realm, no common guest—*
*Within the joyous cave, boy and girl gather flowers of all seasons,*
*Flower upon flower, the elixir of long life is formed.*

For the Dao cultivator, having gathered the elixir and entered the Central Palace, arriving at this true realm, one is no ordinary worldly guest but truly a seed of immortality. Within the Yellow Chamber, the boy and girl unite in joyous union. One must then temper the fire for ten months, followed by one month of total refinement and one month of spirit emergence—hence the year-long work of the four seasons, *“constantly gathering flowers of all seasons within the cave.”* The internal and external fire-work and qi-cycles must be flawless, so that the embryo of spirit may congeal and transform, called *“flower upon flower, the elixir of long life is formed.”*

*The elixir of long life—pluck the heart of the flower,*
*Layer upon layer, the flower’s pistils bloom in spring splendor.*
*Men do not grasp the principle within the flower—*
*A single secret of heaven’s mechanism is worth ten thousand gold.*

Fearing later students might not understand, the immortal master reiterated emphatically: The elixir of long life must be gathered from the three treasures of the upper crescent within the jade crucible, where jade pistils and golden blossoms unfold in orderly, layered spring radiance. Many in the world blindly cultivate without grasping the principle within the flower, making attainment of the Dao difficult. If by past good fortune one encounters a true master who reveals the celestial mechanism step by step, it is like a pauper gaining treasure, like the sick obtaining medicine, like a prisoner granted pardon, like the dead restored to life—worth more than ten thousand taels of gold. Even if one possessed ten thousand taels, they would eventually be spent, but having obtained this true method, its wondrous use is inexhaustible.

*Give thanks to heaven and earth, feel gratitude for the empty void—*
*To have met the immortal master is to meet one’s ancestors.*
*Whispered in the ear, the profound and wondrous instruction,*
*Raised to the first peak of Penglai.*

After attaining the Dao, the immortal master sighed in gratitude for the protection of yin and yang, heaven and earth, and the empty void, having met the True Yang Emperor Lord, who was like an ancestor.
