Gradually ascend the body to enter the *Niwan* palace, from *si* to *wei* to fill the *li* trigram. *(One thousand breaths or more is especially excellent; the method is as described above.)*

In autumn’s three months, the lung’s qi flourishes. When the lung’s qi flourishes, the parents’ true qi, following the celestial movements, resides in the lung. If encountering a Metal day (*geng-xin*) or a Wood day (*jia-yi*), during the *zhen* trigram hours, kindle fire in accordance with the method to refine the liver’s qi. On other days, during the *li* trigram hours, diminish Fire to deplete the heart’s qi—at this time, one must not engage in practice. During the *xun* trigram hours, kindle fire in accordance with the method to refine the spleen’s qi. During the *dui* trigram hours, enter the chamber and practice as before—white light will naturally appear. Gradually ascend the body to enter the *Niwan* palace, from *shen* to *xu* to fill the *dui* trigram.

In winter’s three months, the kidney’s qi flourishes. When the kidney’s qi flourishes, the parents’ true qi, following the celestial movements, resides in the kidney. If encountering a Water day (*ren-gui*) or a Fire day (*bing-ding*), during the *li* trigram hours, kindle fire in accordance with the method to refine the heart’s qi. On other days, during the *chen-xu-chou-wei* hours, diminish Earth to deplete the spleen’s qi—at this time, one must not engage in practice. During the *dui* trigram hours, kindle fire in accordance with the method to refine the lung’s qi. During the *kan* trigram hours, enter the chamber and practice as before—black light will naturally appear. Gradually ascend the body to enter the *Niwan* palace, from *hai* to *chou* to fill the *kan* trigram.

Explanation: In spring, refine the liver for a thousand breaths, and blue-green qi will emerge. During the last eighteen days of spring, one need not practice as before; simply abide by the method of settled breathing, sitting in stillness all day to nurture the spleen and refine one’s true qi. Only then, during the *kan* trigram hours, kindle fire to refine the kidney, lest the true qi be depleted. In summer, refine the heart for a thousand breaths, and crimson qi will emerge. During the last eighteen days of summer, one need not practice as before; simply abide by the method of settled breathing, sitting in stillness all day, refining as before. Only then, during the *zhen* trigram hours, kindle fire as before. In autumn, refine the liver for a thousand breaths, and white qi will emerge. During the last eighteen days of autumn, one need not practice as before; simply abide by the method of settled breathing, sitting in stillness all day, nurturing and refining as before. Only then, during the *xun* trigram hours, kindle fire as before. In winter, refine the kidney for a thousand breaths, and black qi will emerge. During the last eighteen days of winter, one need not practice as before; simply abide by the method of settled breathing, sitting in stillness all day, nurturing and refining as before. Only then, during the *dui* trigram hours, kindle fire as before, until yellow qi forms a radiance, and one silently observes myriad Daoist paths encircling the body.

The method of settled breathing does not lie in forcefully holding or tightly closing the breath. Rather, it should be continuous as if present, employed without strain. From existence, one enters non-existence, allowing it to abide naturally. The method of gathering the medicine involves holding the saliva and clasping the hands to press the heart, ensuring the true qi does not scatter.

When entering the chamber, one must close the door in a secluded and quiet dwelling, far from chickens, dogs, women, and all disturbing influences. The eyes should be slightly open, just enough to discern objects. Avoid drafts and direct sunlight, and ensure no sounds intrude from either side. One should empty the heart and still all thoughts, casting aside all worldly concerns. Both internally and externally, one must be utterly serene, allowing nothing to disturb the mind. For the yang spirit is newly gathered and the true qi only just congealed, one must tend to it as a newborn, not yet mature. Morning and evening, burn incense, kneel, and bow in reverence: first to Heaven, second to the Heavenly Immortals, and third to the Earthly Immortals. After completing these three bows, sit in stillness, forgetting all scheming, and proceed with this method. One must also follow the preceding method step by step to witness its effects. If one mistakes this for the Dao itself, one may labor in vain and never achieve success, merely allowing the yin po to leave the body and become a ghostly immortal.

The essential teaching of the Dao states: In practicing this method, one is not bound by years, months, days, or hours. Simply follow the preceding method until signs of verification appear, and then cease. The qi will manifest naturally, but one must be diligent and unwavering, forsaking all external affairs. Remain in the chamber, focus the mind, and gauge the proper times. Employ two pure yang youths or cultivate a bond with disciples, engaging in mutual exchange and support for a thousand days to complete one cycle of qi. One gains tenfold in one hundred days, and in five hundred days, the qi is complete. One may then practice inner observation, gather the yang spirit, and merge with the celestial spirits. Refining the spirit to unite with the Dao, one enters sagehood and transcends the mundane.

The verification of refining qi lies in feeling the body utterly at ease, often ascending as if borne aloft. The elixir’s light penetrates the bones, and an extraordinary fragrance fills the chamber. Next, in stillness, one gazes outward to see purple clouds filling the eyes. Looking downward from the crown of the head, a golden light envelops the body—strange and wondrous signs of verification are too numerous to record.

**Inner Observation and Transformation (Ninth Section: Gathering the Yang Spirit, Heaven-Scaling Fire, Exchanging Mortal for Immortal, True Emptiness, the Celestial Realm of Huaxu)**

The *Golden Edict* states: The Great Dao has no form; it dwells within qi. The Dao is vast beyond all bounds, containing nothing. The Great Dao has no function; it operates through things. Its depth is unfathomable, and its principles are beyond investigation. Speaking of the Dao in terms of form, it begins to have distinctions of inner and outer. Speaking of the Dao in terms of function, it establishes the foundation for observation and perception. Observing the inner without observing the outer, nothing external remains unexamined, and the inner becomes clear. Observing the spirit without observing the form, no aspect of form is left unperfected, and the spirit becomes visible.

The *True Source* states: With one heart, observe the myriad things, and the myriad things are not said to be excessive. With the myriad things disturbing the one qi, the one qi is not said to be insufficient. When the one qi returns to the one heart, the heart cannot be seized by things. When the one heart moves the one qi, the qi cannot be enslaved by methods. When the heart’s source is clear and penetrating, one illumination shatters ten thousand illusions, and one forgets the existence of things. When the qi’s struggle is firm and strong, ten thousand stimuli are stilled in a single breath, and one forgets the existence of methods. Thing after thing, no thing remains—thus returning to the original image. Method after method, no method remains—thus preserving the true self-attained reality.

This analogy states: From images, forms arise; from forms, names are established. With names, one infers their numbers; with numbers, one grasps their principles. Yet the loftiest and most empty is beyond all things and cannot be compared. The only possible comparison is to one who cultivates and refines. The seasons proceed without error, and accomplishments follow in order.

The qi of harmony congeals and does not disperse. The true nature of utmost emptiness is tranquil and free from striving. The spirit unites with the Dao, returning to spontaneity. At this moment, taking non-mind as mind—how then can one speak of responding to things? Taking non-thing as thing—how then can one speak of employing methods? True joy abounds, and one forgets the existence of one’s own body. Gradually entering the Dao of non-action, one reaches the realm of the imperceptible and inaudible, becoming a guest who enters sagehood and transcends the mundane.

The true formula states: This method accords with the Dao, resembling the principle of visualization as commonly described, or like the moment when a Chan monk enters samādhi. One should choose an auspicious site to establish a chamber, kneel in reverence, burn incense, sit upright with legs crossed, let the hair down and robes loose, clench the fists to retain spirit, and close the eyes to still the mind. Before noon, gently raise the body to kindle the fire and refine the qi. After noon, slightly gather the body to gather the fire and forge the elixir. Regardless of day or night, with spirit clear and qi harmonious, joy arises naturally. If sounds are heard during meditation, do not listen; if visions appear, do not acknowledge them, and the external phenomena will disperse of their own accord. Should one acknowledge these phenomena, demonic obstacles will only intensify. If demonic obstacles do not recede, swiftly lean the body slightly forward, then straighten the waist; afterward, slightly arch the chest without straightening the waist. After a brief pause, the fire will rise high before and behind—do not move the body. This is called "firing the body." When the fire subsides, demonic obstacles will disperse beyond the frame, and yin evil will not enter the shell. Repeat this two or three times.

One should visualize all between heaven and earth as a blazing fire. Once the fire subsides, all is cool and clear, leaving nothing behind. Yet one sees carriages and horses, song and dance, canopies and silken banners, wealth and splendor, crowds of joyous people forming ranks and processions. Five-colored clouds ascend, as if ascending to the celestial realm. Upon arrival, one beholds towering pavilions amid verdant peaks, courtyards stretching endlessly, pearls and gold scattered ungathered upon the ground, gardens and pavilions, flowers and fruits, pools and terraces beyond count. Suddenly, rare fragrances arise on all sides, and the sounds of music and revelry fill the air. Guests and friends fill the seats, a feast of land and sea is laid out, laughter and conversation abound, all celebrating great peace. Precious treasures are exchanged as gifts. At this moment, though these are not the armies of yin ghosts or demons, one must not regard them as auspicious events.

For those who cultivate the true, having renounced worldly affairs and willingly embraced solitude—whether concealing themselves by rivers and lakes or withdrawing to secluded corners—all thoughts and emotions are severed, and every action is governed by precepts. After enduring hardship and experiencing freedom, once the work is accomplished and the method established, one may witness such splendor. Yet if one does not recognize these as demonic illusions but instead believes they have truly arrived in the celestial palace, unaware that shedding the mortal form occurs within the celestial palace atop one’s own head, and thus becomes attached, taking these visions as reality, failing to apply the method of transcendence—then the yang spirit will remain trapped within the body, and the immortal embryo will not transform. One may emerge above the dark paths to become a terrestrial immortal, merely attaining longevity without death, yet unable to shed the mortal frame and ascend as an immortal, returning to the Three Isles to become a celestial being. This is truly lamentable.

Disciples must consider that though transcendence is difficult, it cannot be neglected. The essential teaching states: There is no inexhaustible method, for it has already been reduced to its essence.

**Chapter Ten: Transcending and Shedding the Form**
*(Emerging and Entering the Form, Immortal Shedding the Mortal Frame, Transcending the Mundane and Entering Sagehood)*

The *Golden Edict* states: The Dao is fundamentally non-being; to speak of it as being is not the Dao. The Dao is fundamentally empty; to speak of it as substantial is not the Dao. Since it is formless, neither questioning nor responding can reach it; since it is imageless, neither seeing nor hearing can grasp it. If one takes the mysterious and subtle as the Dao, the mysterious and subtle still cannot escape the burden of question and answer. If one takes the imperceptible and inaudible as the Dao, the imperceptible and inaudible still cannot avoid the burden of seeing and hearing. If even the imperceptible and inaudible, the mysterious and subtle, are not the Dao, then the Dao is beyond all knowing.

The *Jade Scripture* states: Its coming has a beginning, yet who knows the beginning of the great Dao? Its going has an end, yet who knows the end of the great Dao? Though there is an "above" beyond the highest, who knows that the great Dao’s above has no limit? Though there is a "below" beneath the deepest, who knows that the great Dao’s below has no end? The Dao, unfathomable and nameless, arranges ranks and distinctions according to what beings attain. The Dao of non-action cannot be fully explored.

The true formula states: To *transcend* is to rise beyond the mortal frame and enter the rank of sages. To *shed* is to cast off the mundane embryo and become an immortal. It is the spirit entering the qi-embryo, the qi completing the true nature. Only when prior efforts have borne verification at every step should one reside in a chamber of purity to enter the realm of the imperceptible and inaudible. Inwardly observe and recognize the yang spirit, then kindle the fire to subdue demons, firing the body to gather qi. The true qi ascends to the celestial palace, and the shell becomes utterly pure, leaving nothing behind.

One should choose a secluded dwelling, abide by inward observation, and after the three bows are completed, sit upright without rising or adjusting the posture. Close the eyes and still the mind. When stillness reaches its utmost, the body seems to float in empty space. Spirit and qi drift freely, difficult to restrain. In silent inward observation, clarity shines unobscured. Mountains and rivers appear resplendent, pavilions faintly discernible, purple qi and crimson light swirling in formation, auspicious simurghs and colorful phoenixes singing like reed pipes. The wondrous scenes and splendor may be called the true delight of the pot, the separate realm of the grotto-heaven—carefree and at ease, utterly unaware of the burdens of the dusty world.

At this moment of true emptiness, the qi transforms of its own accord, without need for methods or adherence to time. If one sees green qi emerging from the east, with the sounds of reed pipes and drums, banners, carriages, and horses appearing left and right, front and back, in countless numbers—then suddenly, red qi emerges from the south, white qi from the west, black qi from the north, and yellow qi from the center.

The five qi converge and coalesce into iridescent clouds, while joyous music resounds in a clamor, and blissful qi radiates warmth. Golden lads and jade maidens support and escort one’s self, or one rides a fiery dragon, mounts a dark crane, straddles a colorful simurgh, or bestrides a fierce tiger, ascending into the void. From below to above, wherever one passes, pavilions and temples stretch beyond description, while divine officials and spirits defy enumeration. Arriving at another place, ten thousand rows of female musicians stand in array, and officials form ranks like the court of an earthly emperor, with sages and worthies all in attendance.

At this moment, one sees all as if no one else exists, riding upward until reaching a gate where guards stand solemn and inviolable. On all sides, officials and female musicians linger with reluctance, yet ultimately, one cannot pass through the gate. Canopies cover one’s face as one descends from above, returning to the former dwelling. Such ascents and descents occur countless times without weariness—this is the method of harmonizing the spirit to exit the shell. With days of accumulated practice, one ascends in a single bound to the celestial palace and descends in one motion to the original place. Up and down, there is no obstruction, as if ascending from below to above. It may resemble climbing a seven-tiered pagoda or ascending a three-story jade tower: at first, one climbs step by step, and upon reaching the seventh tier, one must not look down, lest the spirit be startled and cling to the body, refusing to depart. Once atop the seventh tier, one closes the eyes and leaps as if in sleep or waking—there is a body beyond the body. Its form resembles an infant, with fresh and radiant skin, its spirit luminous and bright. Looking back at the former body, one sees nothing of it, only what appears as a dung heap or withered wood, evoking endless shame and disgust. Yet one cannot immediately abandon it and wander far, for the spirit’s departure is not yet perfected, and the sagely qi has congealed to form it. One must re-enter the original body, coming and going freely, roaming at will. At first, one may take but one or two steps, then two or three *li*. With days of accumulated practice, one may stretch forth like a warrior, traversing a thousand or ten thousand *li*. The form and spirit grow robust, and courage becomes unshakable. Only then may one entrust the mortal frame to the great mountains and rivers, dwelling beyond the comings and goings of the world, no longer equaling the common folk. When one’s conduct is complete, one receives the celestial writ, riding simurghs and phoenixes, straddling tigers and mounting dragons, traveling east and west to enter the Purple Palace. First, one meets the True Lord of the Grand Tenuity, then resides on the lower isles. To ascend to the grotto-heaven, one must transmit the Dao and accumulate merit among mortals, receive the celestial writ, and ascend to the grotto-heaven as a celestial immortal.

Few in ancient or modern times have succeeded in this practice. Some, lacking sufficient merit, seek swift attainment and thus pursue this path; others, though their merits remain unproven, merely engage in quiet sitting, hoping for transcendence. If residual yin spirits do not disperse, they may become ghostly immortals, unseen by others, coming and going without fixed abode, ultimately forced to seize mortal bodies and be reborn as humans. Or, if one’s comings and goings are unskilled and without method, departing and returning without means to re-enter the original body, the spirit may wander without destination—this is the sitting transformation of Buddhist monks or the corpse liberation of Daoist adepts. Thus, in practicing this path, one must first ensure that prior merits are verified and appropriate, then select a secluded place to build a chamber, far from all foul and putrid things, noxious vapors, passing sounds, and the allure of women. Not only do these disturb the true qi, but the spirit itself grows weary of them. If one exits and re-enters, entering without exiting, then form and spirit become wondrous, attaining the lifespan of heaven and earth, enduring through eons without death. If one enters and exits, exiting without re-entering, it is like the cicada shedding its husk, transforming the spirit to attain sageliness. This is transcending the mundane and shedding the vulgar, becoming a true person and immortal, dwelling beyond the dusty world on the isles of the Three Mountains.

The essential Dao states: "The inexhaustible Dharma has already ceased and stilled."

The above are the secrets of transcending the mundane and entering sageliness, belonging to the Great Vehicle’s three gates of celestial immortality.

*Scripture of the Nine Grades of Immortals* (Scroll Nine)

**Preface to the *Collected Scriptures: Scripture of the Nine Grades of Immortals***

I am a *jinshi* of the Tang dynasty. From past lives, I have been devoted to the Dao, and by the grace of Master Zhengyang, I was led into the Zhongnan Mountains and initiated into the Mystery Gate. From that moment, I vowed to ferry all sentient beings across. Once this great vow was uttered, regret came too late.

I have heard that the highest mysteries of Heaven and Earth are boundless in their wondrous workings. Heaven is lofty, Earth profound—mystery begets mystery. The Three Teachings share a single principle, yet deluded mortals fail to grasp it. The Void gives birth to the formless, and from there, one returns to the origin.

By the grace of Master Zhengyang, I was transmitted the Golden Elixir. After twelve years, I ascended and paid homage before the August Emperor. Moved by compassion, the Emperor commanded me to descend to the mortal realm and universally deliver the deluded. Yet the deluded remained unmoved, so I manifested in person and left behind the *Scripture of the Eight Grades of Immortals*: two scrolls in Guangling, two in Jinling, two in Piling, and one each in Linjiang and Xinzhou—eight in total.

Later, by imperial decree, I descended again to the Jishui River to open the hearts of mortals. Still, they remained ignorant, so I bestowed upon them the oracle of the planchette. In the year *wuzǐ*, I was commanded to compile the *Scripture of the Nine Grades of Immortals* and the *Precious Repentance Sutra for Extracting the Heart*. Though five regions had received the eight scrolls, one was missing. Later, Pan Yanjǐ of Huaiyang completed the ninth, along with the *Precious Repentance*.

The Jade Writ was bestowed upon the Azure Spirit Perfected, who retrieved it from the Jishui River to guide sentient beings into the Dao. One must revere Heaven and Earth, sovereign and parents, and teachers, and uphold benevolence, righteousness, propriety, wisdom, and trust.

To disrespect Heaven invites thunder, lightning, and torrential rains that drown all in chaos. To disrespect Earth brings corpses to the waters, their bodies manifesting as ducks and geese. To be unfilial to parents ensures that neither Heaven nor Earth will tolerate you, and you shall suffer for ten thousand kalpas. To be disloyal to the sovereign brings ruin to the state and deceit to the ruler, and you shall later sink into the depths. To disregard the teachings of your master is to invite the cycles of Heaven and Earth, from which awakening is nearly impossible to escape.

That which Heaven decrees as human nature cannot depart from principle. To depart from principle is to stray from the Dao. Only when principle and the Dao are practiced in harmony does one fulfill human propriety!

Righteousness (*yì*) is to revere Heaven and Earth, honor one’s superiors, and avoid the Five Transgressions. Propriety (*lǐ*) is to uphold integrity, shame, modesty, and a sense of honor—neither losing respect among one’s village nor among the common folk—revering Heaven, honoring Earth, being filial to parents, and compassionate to the young. Wisdom (*zhì*) is the highest wisdom of the formless and unified *qi*, the middle wisdom of serving the state, and the lower wisdom of human relations. Trust (*xìn*) is to be true to Heaven and Earth, true to the state, true to one’s kin, and never break faith with the young. These are the bonds of human relations.

Benevolence, righteousness, propriety, wisdom, and trust—I open the eyes of the deluded, lead them out of the mundane, and guide sentient beings into the Mystery Gate. First, revere Heaven, and Heaven will send down auspiciousness, for Heaven is pure. Revere Earth, and Earth will bring forth the myriad things, for Earth is at peace. Naturally, a hundred plants will sprout, and the five grains will flourish.

In human relations, one must cultivate good thoughts, avoid the gates of hell, escape the paths of delusion, depart the mundane, ascend the path of awakening, penetrate the Great Dao, emerge from the sea of suffering, and illuminate the formless. Through gradual refinement, one may transcend and join the ranks of immortals.

This preface to the *Scripture of the Nine Grades of Immortals* was left by me personally. The disciples of the Returning to Truth Assembly, Zhen Zhang, Zhao Shan, and others, in the year *jiǎwǔ*, vowed at the White Crane Abbey to carve and publish the immortal scriptures.

If mortals seek the Dao, let them not speak of the distance of a thousand miles—with sincere hearts, how can the ten thousand *li* to Zhongnan be called far? Those who request my immortal scriptures shall see all their endeavors succeed and all their fortunes align.

The nine numinous talismans sweep away demons, eradicate the roots of calamity in the human realm, and guide one into the wondrous gate of Heaven and Earth. Uphold human relations with benevolence, righteousness, propriety, wisdom, and trust. Have faith in the Dao, and above, refine your essence and spirit.

The Three Teachings all possess these truths—there is no room for doubt or hesitation. To print the scriptures is to print the heart; to carve the scriptures is to carve the Dao. Once the human Dao is accomplished, the immortal Dao may be achieved! How could one not find contentment between Heaven and Earth, preserving this for the deluded of later generations?

Above, it is unfathomable in its literary grace; below, it does not stray from propriety. To have one’s name inscribed in the immortal register, to have nine generations ascend to Heaven—how could this not be joyous!

I, now ranked among the immortals, have personally penned this.

**The Ninth Scroll of the *Scriptures of the Mysterious Origin of the Most High***

At that time, the Great Emperor of Pure Yang was in the Heaven of Tuṣita, the Palace of Pure Emptiness. Seated in full-lotus, holding a *rúyì*, he sat in serene silence. The divine immortals of the myriad heavens, the thunder and fire departments, the city gods and village altars—all stood in solemn attendance.

The Great Emperor spoke: "By the decree of the August Emperor, I have traversed the nine continents to universally deliver the deluded, propagate the Great Dao, and lead all to right awakening. Yet for the sake of sentient beings, who remain deluded and unenlightened, I have now proclaimed the eight scrolls of the immortal scriptures: one in Guangling, two in Jinling, three in Piling, four in Xinzhou, and five in Linjiang—eight in total, serving as a bridge for the world.

Of the multitude of sentient beings, only one or two in a hundred believe, while those who slander are beyond counting. By the Emperor’s command, embodying the virtue of cherishing life and the benevolence of universal salvation, I earnestly admonish and clearly expound. Yet sentient beings are as deaf and blind, provoking the wrath of the August Emperor. Disasters of flood, fire, blade, and warfare, plagues and locusts, have left people with no means to live. Fathers and sons, brothers, husbands and wives, flesh and blood—all are scattered and lost.

The deluded remain unrepentant, instead harboring resentment. Witnessing such obstinacy, I am deeply moved with pity. Thus, I tirelessly descend into the dusty mortal realm, manifesting in countless forms to expound the Dao and deliver beings from the roots of suffering. Yet sentient beings, ignorant of the profound mysteries, speak and act recklessly, slandering the Dao and its teachings.

Though I do not reproach them, I redouble my efforts to awaken them. But sentient beings, ensnared by profit, desire, and emotional attachments, have forgotten their original nature. They are disloyal, unfilial, unkind, undutiful, unjust, deceitful, untrustworthy, and unrighteous."

Only seeking advantage for oneself, heedless of the harm left for others; ever pursuing warmth and fullness for oneself, unmindful of lord, kin, or brothers. The widowed, orphaned, solitary, and bereft—one callously poisons and harms them. Defying the sages and worthies, scorning the people of heaven. Major transgressions go uncorrected; minor virtues remain undone. Idle chatter, seductive speech, harsh words, and double tongues. Such manifold karmic obstructions cast one into pits and snares, yet still one fails to awaken to the gravity of life and death, to the swiftness of impermanence. Once fallen into the wheel of rebirth, the human form is hard to regain. The three evil destinies and six paths lead to the Avīci hell—though one may seek to repent and reform, to whom can one turn for deliverance?

In the boundless realm of suffering, only the Dao can uplift. Pure and true, empty and luminous, it abides in the vastness of the great void, free from the distinctions of self and other—only then can one perceive the Primordial Ultimate. Yet sentient beings remain benighted, as if dreaming, as if drunk. Drunkenness may yet pass, dreams may yet be awakened from—why then do sentient beings remain so utterly oblivious? The Dao is before their very eyes.

The Three Teachings share one insight: the Confucians call it "holding to the center," the Buddhists call it "emptiness within," while in our Dao, it is simply "guarding the center." Thus, the Confucians "preserve the heart and nurture nature"; the Buddhists, "illumine the heart and perceive nature"; while in our Dao, we "cultivate the heart and refine nature." In cultivating the heart, loyalty and filial piety are perfected, and none—lord, kin, or brothers—are left unsuited. In refining nature, one abides in contentment and endures humiliation, neither exposing others' faults nor flaunting one's own strengths.

In governing the state and ordering the family, only impartiality and uprightness prevail. Reverence moves the Lord on High, and water and fire cannot encroach. Bandits and thieves vanish; illness and plague do not arise. The sword is forever stilled; fathers and sons reunite, flesh and blood remain unsevered. Precious grains and fine ears flourish; timely winds and seasonable rains come. Blessings and prosperity abound; calamities and omens dissolve. The nation enjoys eternal peace; the people dwell in constant joy.

Heed my words: cultivate truth and enter the Dao, that together we may ascend the other shore and transcend life and death. Once, in Guangling, they slandered our great Dao, mocked the Lord on High, reviled immortals and cursed buddhas, disparaged sages and rejected worthies—thus bringing down destruction. Though I could not save them, I deeply pitied their fate. Therefore, I journeyed to the Huai and the sea to ferry those lost in the ford of delusion.

Let sentient beings take heed: strive to do good, lest you err to your own ruin. The sins you amass will be as mountains—beware, beware! Turn from evil and practice the Way.

The Master of Pure Emptiness knelt and kowtowed, saying: "By what name is the Dao known? I humbly beseech Your illumination, that all sentient beings may awaken and find the path to the gate."

The Great Emperor replied: "A profound question indeed! Listen with utmost attention, purify your heart and still your thoughts."

All the celestial immortals and divine spirits bowed in reverence before the vermilion court. The Great Emperor radiated a great light, the Three Flowers gathering at his crown, the Five Qi returning to their origin. For the celestial palaces, the thunder-fire citadels, and the earthly altars, he expounded the Dao, saying:

"That which establishes Heaven and Earth and nurtures the myriad things is called the Dao.
That which illumines the sun and moon and generates the Five Phases is called the Dao.
That which is more numerous than the sands of the Ganges is called the Dao.
That which alone shines, solitary and without peer, is called the Dao.
That which opens the primordial chaos and returns to the primordial vastness is called the Dao.
That which seizes the workings of creation and transcends life and death is called the Dao.
That which abides in the lowly and filthy yet is supremely noble is called the Dao.
That which dwells in darkness yet attains the utmost brilliance is called the Dao.
That which enters the tiniest speck of dust is called the Dao.
That which encompasses Heaven and Earth is called the Dao.
That which moves from being into non-being is called the Dao.
That which enables one to become a buddha or an immortal is called the Dao.

*'The Dao that can be spoken is not the eternal Dao; the name that can be named is not the eternal name.'*

Every word of my scriptures conveys the profound truth. You must contemplate them carefully, proclaim them widely to the world, and awaken the deluded multitudes."

Then he spoke this gatha:

Great indeed, most wondrous is the Dao,
Giving birth to Heaven, Earth, and the myriad things.
Filial piety, fraternal duty, loyalty, and trust—
These are the great canons for humanity.
Strive in practice, never grow lax,
For when the root is firm, the Dao is born.
Swords and weapons shall never bring calamity,
Water and fire shall never assail.
Tigers shall slumber in the southern mountains,
Dragons shall return to the northern seas.
You must master the spirit and guide the qi,
Refine the qi to cultivate the true essence.
Essence transforms into spirit, returning to emptiness,
And leads you to worship the Supreme Clarity.
Transcending the Three Realms,
Beyond the Five Phases of the world,
Each step summons wind and clouds,
Each word startles ghosts and spirits.
When the heart is pure and limpid,
Nine generations of ancestors ascend.
Heed well my words—
Within this lies the Great Dao."

When the Great Emperor finished speaking the gatha, all the celestial generals, divine marshals, and immortal disciples rose in reverence, filled with boundless joy.

The Great Emperor said: "My scripture in eight fascicles has been transmitted in the world for ages, yet few have widely believed in it. Now, Pan Yangji of Shanggu wishes to propagate its profound mysteries, to widely transmit the Great Dao, and to receive and circulate the scripture. Wherever this scripture resides, all the celestial immortals, divine generals, the thunder and fire departments, city gods, and village altars shall naturally provide protection."

All the celestial generals bowed in assent and withdrew.

Praise says:
To save the kalpa and prolong the sun and moon’s days,
To return the soul and restore life to the Purple Cloud Realm—
The floating net’s precious canopy joins with the vast primordial harmony,
The wondrous Dharma’s radiance defies all measure.

The Boundless Great Dao,
The Primordial Dharma King—
A single pearl of treasure lies at the center,
Expounding the Dharma and emitting auspicious light.
Universally unfolding the golden scriptures,
All sages bow to the Void Sovereign—*(repeated line)*

**The Complete Works of Patriarch Lü**
**Volume 1: The Original Biography of Patriarch Lü**

*Preface to the Original Biography in The Complete Works of Patriarch Lü*

Patriarch Lü, in response to the Supreme Yang Emperor, declared, "Only when all sentient beings are delivered shall I ascend." Yet even after his ascension, he continued to transform and deliver the world. Thus, from the Tang dynasty to the present, his manifestations and transformations have been myriad. The world calls him "Immortal Lü," while he refers to himself as "The Returning Daoist" or "Lord of the Supreme Palace." Having ultimately realized the rank of Supreme Sage and Teacher, his numinous traces are too numerous to record in full.

This biography follows the original account in sequence, with occasional additions and annotations for reference.

As for the divergent accounts in circulation: some claim he was originally of the Tang imperial clan, surnamed Li, and named either *Huan* or *Qiong*, entering the mountains with his wife to cultivate together and changing his surname to Lü; others say he passed the imperial examinations and became a magistrate, or that he failed the examinations; some assert that at sixty-four he traveled to Chang’an and encountered the Supreme Yang Emperor, while others claim he ascended at sixty-four to pay homage to the Jade Emperor of Primordial Beginning; some hold that he was born on the fourteenth day of the fourth month, others on the fourth day of the eighth month. As for the year of his birth, some say it was during the *Zhen’guan* era, others the *Tianbao* or *Zhenyuan* eras—such variations abound.

Patriarch Lü once remarked, "Call me an ox, and I respond as an ox; call me a horse, and I respond as a horse. The world’s errors may be true or false—what did I have to do with anything before the Tang?" His words were truly enlightened.

When the Most High descended to be born, he took Li as his surname; when the snow-clad mountain first bore him, he emerged from a *qi*-womb. Dragons coiled around the chamber, and the five stars shone in the courtyard—such divine portents were precise and unerring. The births of immortals, buddhas, sages, and worthies have always been extraordinary. How, then, could I presume to fathom Patriarch Lü?

Compiled by Liu Tishu, styled *Wuwuzi*, of Yiling
Collated by his son Liu Yincheng, styled *Qinghui*, and nephew Liu Yuncheng, styled *Qingxu*
Revised by Huang Chengshu, styled *Yixingzi*, of Shaxian

*Eulogy*

The greatest divine power
Lies in loyalty and filial piety;
Benefiting self and others—
The grand Dao of a thousand autumns.

From ancient times to the present,
Karmic conditions are not trifling;
Freely brushed onto the page,
A portrait before one’s eyes.

Again—
A sword slashes through autumn,
Pure wind fills both sleeves;
The Dao resides in the Three-in-One,
The elixir perfected, cycling through the Nine.

Cangwu and the Northern Sea,
The imperial homeland of white clouds;
A single drop from the Gan River—
Its source distant, its flow long.

*The Original Biography of Patriarch Lü*
*(Collated from the *Complete Writings on the Dao*, *Marvelous Traces of Immortals and Buddhas*, *Comprehensive Mirror of Divine Immortals*, and *Complete Tang Poems*. Discrepancies are annotated beneath the text for reference.)*

Patriarch Lü’s personal name was Yan, his courtesy name Dongbin. His family had long been natives of Yongle County, Hezhong Prefecture. His great-grandfather, Yanzhi, served the Tang as Military Commissioner of Hedong; his grandfather, Wei, ended his career as Vice Minister of Rites; his father, Rang, was Prefect of Haizhou.

Born on the fourteenth day of the fourth month of the fourteenth year of the Zhenyuan era (at the *si* hour), his mother, as she lay in childbed, was enveloped in a strange fragrance, while celestial music drifted through the air. A white crane descended from the heavens and vanished into the bed curtains. At birth, his form was golden, his essence wooden—crane’s crown, tortoise’s back, tiger’s body, dragon’s jowls, kingfisher brows, phoenix eyes, a long neck with prominent cheekbones, a broad forehead and rounded frame, a straight and towering nose bridge, a face of pale yellow hue. A black mole marked the corner of his left brow, another beneath his left eye. His head was large, his feet bore hidden patterns like tortoise-shell creases.

From childhood, he was keen and quick-witted, memorizing ten thousand words a day and composing essays extemporaneously. In adulthood, he stood five *chi* and two *cun* tall, fond of wearing a Huayang cap, a pale yellow *lan* robe, and a black sash, his bearing reminiscent of Zhang Zifang.

At twenty, he remained unmarried, still in swaddling clothes. Master Ma saw him and remarked, *"This child’s bone structure is extraordinary—naturally a figure beyond the dust of the world. When you encounter a hut, dwell there; when you see a bell, strike it. Keep this in mind."* Later, all came to pass as foretold.

He later traveled to Mount Lu, where he met the Fire Dragon Perfected and received the *Celestial Concealment Sword Technique*. Thereafter, he wandered the world selling ink among the common folk, styling himself *Master Pure Yang*.

During the Xiantong era, he passed the imperial examinations at the age of sixty-four. Later, while visiting a wineshop in Chang’an, he saw a Daoist—green turban, white robe, long whiskers, and bright eyes—carrying a purple bamboo staff and a large gourd at his waist. The Daoist inscribed three quatrains on the wall:

*Seated or reclining, I always carry a jug of wine,
Lest my eyes ever recognize the imperial capital.
Vast as heaven and earth, yet nameless—
A carefree man of the world, a true husband.*

*True immortals who have attained the Dao are not easily met;
When shall I return? I wish you would follow.
I say my dwelling adjoins the azure sea—
It is the first peak of Penglai, apart from all.*

*Do not weary of chasing joy and laughter,
For pondering separation and chaos grieves the spirit.
Leisurely, I count on my fingers—
How many have known true peace in this world?*

Struck by the Daoist’s archaic and extraordinary appearance and the soaring spirit of his verses, Patriarch Lü bowed and inquired after his name. The Daoist replied, *"My compound surname is Zhongli, my given name Quan, my courtesy name Yunfang."* Patriarch Lü bowed again and invited him to sit.

Zhong said, *"Might you recite a quatrain? I would fain observe it."* Patriarch Lü thereupon presented a quatrain:

*Born to the Confucian path in times of peace—
The weight of office hangs heavy, while coarse cloth feels light.
Who in this world would vie for fame and gain?
I serve the Jade Emperor, returning to the Upper Clarity.*

Zhongli beheld the poem and rejoiced inwardly. They then rested together in a tavern. Zhongli himself rose to tend the stove, while Patriarch Lü, overcome by weariness, pillowed his head upon the table and dozed. In his dream, he journeyed to the capital as an examination candidate, passed the imperial exams, and began his career in local posts before ascending to the ranks of ministerial secretary, remonstrator, academician, and custodian of the imperial archives—every eminent office he traversed in turn. Promoted, then demoted; demoted, then promoted again. Two wives, daughters of wealthy families, were wed in his youth; sons and grandsons flourished, the household brimming with capped and gowned officials. For nearly forty years he served, then a decade more as sole minister, his power and influence scorching all. Suddenly, he was charged with grave crimes: his family’s wealth confiscated, his wives and children scattered, himself exiled to the southern frontier, left alone, destitute, and gaunt. As he stood astride his horse amid wind and snow, a deep sigh arose—

Then, in a start, he awoke. Zhongli was beside him, the millet still uncooked, and laughed, saying:
*"The millet is not yet done—
A dream has carried you to the land of Hua Xu."*

Patriarch Lü exclaimed, *"Master, did you know my dream?"*
Zhong replied, *"The dream you just dreamed—its rises and falls, its countless glories and sorrows—all spanned fifty years in but a moment. What is there to rejoice in gain, or grieve in loss? Only when one awakens to the Great Dao does one realize this world is but a vast dream."*

Patriarch Lü, moved to sudden enlightenment, understood that the path of officialdom was not worth clinging to. He bowed again and said, *"Master, you are no ordinary man. I beg you to teach me the art of transcending the world."*

Zhong declined, saying: *"Your bones are not yet whole, your will and conduct not yet settled. If you seek to transcend the world, you must pass through several more lifetimes."* With that, he departed in a flutter.

Patriarch Lü, disheartened and lost, resigned his office and withdrew into seclusion. Thereafter, Zhongli tested Patriarch Lü ten times:

1. One day, returning from outside, he saw that all his family had fallen ill and died. His heart held no grief—he simply prepared coffins with care. Soon after, the dead all revived.

2. Once, selling goods in the market, he agreed on a price. The buyer suddenly paid only half, yet he made no dispute. He did not even take the half, but left the goods behind and departed.

3. On New Year’s Day, a beggar leaned against his door, seeking alms. He gave money and goods. The beggar demanded more, hurling abuse. He bowed again and again in apology, until the beggar laughed and left.

4. Herding sheep in the mountains, he encountered a tiger chasing the flock. He pushed the sheep down a steep slope and stood alone before the beast. The tiger then turned and left.

5. Alone in a thatched hut in the mountains, reading, a girl of seventeen or eighteen appeared—her radiance dazzling, her adornments and voice pure and lovely. She claimed to be returning to her mother’s home, weary from travel, and asked to rest a while. Soon, she began to tease and entice him in every way, pressing him to share her bed through the night. Yet he remained unmoved.

6. One day, traveling in the countryside, he returned to find his household possessions plundered by bandits, leaving almost nothing for his daily needs.

He showed no sign of resentment, supporting himself by tilling the soil. One day, while hoeing, he uncovered several dozen cakes of gold. He quickly covered them again and took not a single piece.

7. Once, in the marketplace, he purchased several copper vessels and took them home, only to find they had turned to gold. He immediately sought out the owner and returned them.

8. A mad Daoist priest wandered the streets selling medicine, proclaiming, “Whoever takes this will die at once, but in the next life will attain the Dao.” After ten days with no buyers, he bought the medicine himself and consumed it without ill effect.

9. In spring, floodwaters surged, and his small boat was swept into the current. Waves tossed and churned, yet he sat unmoving, and in the end, he came to no harm.

10. One day, sitting alone in his room, he suddenly saw countless grotesque spirits and demons: some sought to strike him, others to kill him, yet he felt no fear. In the Crystal Palace atop the Hall of Primordial Containment,

Today I compose this song anew for you,

When Patriarch Lü had heard this, the dust and filth of the world fell away entirely, and he pressed further, asking of the teachings on the "Three Origins, Three Purities, Three Treasures, and Three Realms." Master Zhong replied:

"The first is the Primordial Chaos of Supreme Non-Being, from which the Heavenly Treasure Lord is transformed. He governs the Jade Pure Realm, the Heaven of Subtle Clarity, its qi beginning as azure.

The second is the Crimson Chaos of Supreme Non-Being, from which the Numinous Treasure Lord is transformed. He governs the High Pure Realm, the Heaven of Yu-Yu, its qi verging on yellow.

Last night, Zhongli spoke a single word:
The six celestial palaces would crumble to dust.

This poem was inscribed later, as he blended into the marketplace in remembrance.

On his first journey to the Jiang-Huai region, he tested the magic sword, slaying the great flood-dragon’s harm. Arriving at Dongting Lake, he ascended Yueyang Tower and drank alone. Suddenly, Ancestral Master Zhong descended, saying, “I have come to fulfill our former pact. The Supreme Emperor commands that your kin all dwell in the Jing Mountain grotto-palace, and your name has already been inscribed in the Jade Clarity Register.”

On the eighteenth day of the third month, he was led to pay homage to True Lord Ku Zhu and received the method of the sun and moon’s conjoined radiance. At fifty-three, he returned to Mount Lu to take refuge in the ancestral teachings. At sixty-four, he ascended to pay homage to the Primordial Celestial Worthy and the Jade Emperor. From then on, his appearances and transformations were manifold.

Only because his vows were vast did he drift through the turbid world, practicing transformation and delivering people. Even the most ignorant men and women, hearing his name, could not help but rise in reverence. He once said, “People vie to see me, yet cannot follow my words. Though they dwell with me day and night, what benefit is there? If a person can be loyal to their country, filial and kind to their family, faithful to friends, benevolent to those below, neither negligent of their own heart nor deceitful in secret, using skillful means to aid others and accumulating hidden merit to move Heaven—then people will love them, and ghosts and spirits will revere them. For the nature of humanity is this:
When the mind turns to goodness, it belongs to luminous yang, its nature entering the light and pure—this is the path to Heaven.
When the mind turns to evil, it belongs to turbid yin, sinking into coarseness and heaviness—this is the stairway to Hell.
Heaven and Hell are not ruled by any sovereign master; they are merely self-created by the human heart!”

The Daoist replied, “This is Lord Guan Yu, the *Chongning* Perfected Lord whom Your Majesty has enfeoffed.” The emperor repeatedly expressed his gratitude. He then asked, “Where is Zhang Fei?” Guan Yu answered, “Fei is my brother through countless kalpas. Now he has been reborn in Your Majesty’s realm to the family of Yue in Xiangzhou. In days to come, he will aid the restoration of the dynasty, and Fei shall render great merit.” The emperor inquired after the Daoist’s name. The Daoist said, “Your servant’s surname is Yang, and I was born on the fourteenth day of the fourth month.” When the emperor awoke from his dream, his attendants identified the Daoist, saying, “This is Master Lü.” From that time onward, the palace disturbances ceased entirely. The emperor then issued an edict to all under heaven, ordering that wherever incense was offered to Master Lü, his title be corrected to “Perfected Lord of Wondrous Communication.”

The imperial decree read: “We delight in joining the people in reverence for the Great Dao. All those immortals and recluses are recorded in the registers. Moreover, those who silently respond to prayers deserve to be shown favor and honor. The Perfected Lord Lü has concealed his radiance and hidden his traces, wandering near and far. When he arrived at the Palace of Established Felicity, he found a temporary abode. Moved by this karmic affinity, We bestow upon him a title and name. Though his numinous presence is solemn and majestic, may he deign to witness this act. Let him be enfeoffed as *Perfected Lord of Wondrous Communication*.” A statue was sculpted in the Palace of Illustrious Spirits, where seasonal sacrifices were offered.

His wondrous spiritual efficacy, as recorded in various biographies, cannot be fully described in words. The Yuan Emperor Shizu enfeoffed him as *Perfected Lord of Pure Yang, Who Warns and Transforms with Orthodox Teachings*. Emperor Wuzong of Yuan later elevated his title to *Perfected Lord of Pure Yang, Who Warns and Transforms with Orthodox Teachings, the Emperor Who Protects and Assists*. His collected poems and lyrics, titled *The Anthology of Effortless Mastery*, circulated in the world. Later, through planchette revelations, he expounded the *Eight Preceding Grades* at Wuling, the *Five Grades* at Qizhen in Ezhu, the *Three Grades* and *Triple Concordance* at Hansan, and the *Scriptures on Sagely Virtue* at the Thatched Hut in Hunan. Earlier works such as the *Treatise on the Pointing Staff*, the *Edict on Loyalty and Filial Piety*, the *Anthology of Cultivating the True and Transmitting the Dao*, and the *Eulogies on the Jade Pivot Scripture* were also transmitted. Now, all these have been compiled into a complete collection.

The following passage, absent in the original Yuan Shizu biography, has been added here:

The Venerable Wuwozi respectfully eulogized: “The Daoist tradition’s *Emperor Who Protects and Assists* is like the Buddhist tradition’s *Great Bodhisattva Avalokiteśvara*. The World-Honored One abides in non-action, yet his Dharma flourishes through the *Great Bodhisattva*. The Most High abides in non-action, yet his Dharma flourishes through the *Emperor*. Though they have attained celestial ranks, they still move among humankind, delivering countless beings. This is akin to the sages’ desire that all things attain their proper place. Thus, for ten thousand generations, all who hear of them are inspired, for their vow-power is vast and far-reaching. Formerly, at the *Śūraṅgama* assembly, the World-Honored One selected the *Great Bodhisattva* as foremost in perfect penetration among all buddhas. As for Ancestor Lü, is he not also foremost in perfect penetration?”

[*Preceding Eight Grades of the Immortal Scriptures* (Scrolls 9–10)]

chunks.translated_text:
**Preface to the *Supreme Venerable Lüzu’s Scripture of Opening the Celestial Pole, Verifying the True, and Revealing the Mysteries of the Cosmic Cycle***

**Upper Scroll**
1. The *Chapter on the Supreme Ultimate’s Transformative Nurturance*
2. The *Chapter on the Five Phases’ Filial Piety*
3. The *Chapter on Sincerity, Fraternal Duty, and Guiding Qi*
4. The *Chapter on Upright Loyalty and Exhortative Teachings*

**Lower Scroll**
5. The *Chapter on Faith, Integrity, and Attaining the Dao*
6. The *Chapter on Preserving Essence and Securing Life*
7. The *Chapter on Qi Harmonizing with the Primordial Origin*

**Brief Preface to the First Eight Chapters of the Scripture**
Since the Blue Ox departed and the studies of *xuan* flourished, and the White Horse arrived and the Buddhist teachings arose, beyond the Confucian canon, there have also been Buddhist scriptures and alchemical classics—all intended to guide and uplift this world, to guard the mind of the Dao with vigilance, and to cleanse the hearts of humankind.

Yet the texts of Buddhism and Daoist immortality each establish their own schools and doctrines, diverging into a thousand paths and ten thousand streams from the Way of the Two Emperors and Three Kings. Who, then, has traced the source to its root and returned to the One?

Only Lüzu harmonized the essences of the Three Teachings and expounded them as various scriptures. The *Eight Chapters* mark their first emergence:
- The first and second chapters were revealed in Guangling,
- The third and fourth in Jinling,
- The fifth in Piling,
- The sixth and seventh in Xinzhou,
- The eighth in Linjiang.

Spanning five regions and several years, one can well imagine the arduousness of their transmission! Yet through his compassionate heart, vast vows, and resolute determination, he ultimately brought them to completion.

This scripture is often profound and solemn, unlike the more expansive later revelations. Yet it truly encompasses all scriptures, gestating myriad chapters—like a spring emerging from the mountains, its momentum bound for the sea; like bamboo shoots breaking through their sheaths, their vitality already piercing the heavens.

In essence, the principle is one and unbroken, the intent fundamentally the same. The Three Teachings need not follow separate paths, nor do the scriptures differ in their ultimate aim. Yet those of shallow learning, inferior capacity, and heterodox schools each raise their crimson banners, mutually ridiculing one another—surely they may now desist and return to the source.

**Original Preface to the Reprinted *Eight Chapters of the Immortal Scripture***
I, by nature, am serene and simple, with a steadfast aspiration for the Dao. In my daily life, I reverently venerate Lüzu. In all my undertakings, I first report to him, and the Master, perceiving my sincerity, often descends through the planchette to bestow guidance, admonitions, and poetic verses. Though his words initially seem cryptic, when events unfold, they invariably align with perfect clarity.

Upon my transfer to govern Yunnan, one day the planchette suddenly conveyed a command: “The immortal scriptures I composed in the past—eight chapters in total—were once printed in Guangling, but their transmission remains limited. You now govern Yunnan, an ancient land of the Six Zhaos, where barbarians and Han intermingle. The people’s nature is harsh, their speech guttural and coarse, ignorant of ritual propriety and royal transformation. Daily they take up arms, slaughtering one another, their rotting bones and putrid flesh reeking of blood and filth, thereby provoking the celestial punishments of the Emperor on High. You shall preface this scripture and widely disseminate it—its benefits will be profoundly far-reaching.” I respectfully assented at the time.

The Dao finds its fullest expression in the *Book of Changes*, while its meaning is exhausted in yin and yang. Later, the Yellow Emperor battled Chiyou at Zhuolu, where the Nine Heavens’ Mystic Woman bestowed upon him the *Classic of the Yin Talisman*, composed by the Supreme Dao Lord—just as in the time of the Dragon Duke, when he crossed Hangu Pass and was urged by Magistrate Xi to compose the *Classic of the Dao and Virtue*. These two scriptures, though their style may seem abstruse, lead to profound clarity; though their words may appear partial, their store of meaning is complete. Thereafter came the *Triplex Unity*, rooted in the *Book of Changes*, expanding upon the intent of the two sages in recondite terms, boundless in its depths! Still later appeared the *Awakening to Reality*, which earnestly expounds the theories of lead and mercury, dragon and tiger, infant and maiden. Those who awaken to it perceive the kan and li within the body; those who remain deluded drift into the arts of alchemical refinement. Such offshoots, myriad and rootless, exaggerate beyond truth—how could the Dao be thus?

This present *Eight Chapters* takes the Dao as its core, supplemented by Confucian and Buddhist teachings. In its essence and function, it accords well with the *Doctrine of the Mean*; its ultimate aim differs not from the *Śūraṅgama* or *Perfect Enlightenment*. Proceeding from shallow to deep, from outer to inner, from manifest to subtle, from the five phases to the myriad things, from daily ethical conduct to the nature of body and mind—nothing is left unaddressed, nothing left obscure. Lofty beyond measure, profound beyond fathoming, when expounded it illumines the Three Luminaries; when unfolded it pervades the Six Directions. Follow it and its end cannot be seen; meet it and its beginning cannot be perceived. Vast indeed, great indeed! Dimly, vaguely, its images and things cannot be exhausted, nor its abstruse subtleties plumbed. Compared to the *Awakening to Reality*, it swiftly treads in the footsteps of the *Triplex Unity*, rivaling its excellence.

Those who wander within the world, if they study and grasp its meaning, will be moved to loyalty to their lord, filial piety to their parents, observance of ritual and law, rejection of violence, and earnest self-cultivation to nurture their reputation. Those who wander beyond the world, if they study and grasp its meaning, will still their thoughts, extinguish desires, refine essence and qi, diligently practice breath circulation, and focus on inner preservation to nurture their spirit. This is called not living in vain; this is called long life; this is called non-arising. The Three Teachings merge as one, and the myriad principles suffer no deficiency.

The Dao does not choose its ground, nor does the ground choose its people. Whether among those clad in robes and caps, versed in culture, or those in feathered speech and floral garments, it appears as if the Eastern Flowery One and the Trustworthy Protector descended in paired chariots upon the clouds to teach them, fully spreading the mystic wind and thoroughly washing away vulgar customs—how could this be but a great aid?

Yet one must grasp the root before aligning the branches, trace the origin before comprehending the end. Thus, in today’s publication and circulation, special attention must be paid to those within the world, for they are the foundation of those beyond it. As the *Master Embracing Simplicity* says: “To seek immortality, one must first take loyalty, filial piety, harmony, compliance, benevolence, and trust as the foundation. If virtue is not cultivated and one merely pursues arts and techniques, one will never attain long life.”

A guest at my side laughed and said: “Sir, you speak eloquently—surely you do not intend to employ the numinous Dao as a means of instruction?” I withdrew, not daring to presume.

chunks.original_text: 万历甲寅岁冬月，还阳道人赵性粹书于滇中之澄怀轩。 八品仙经原序　(此序系初合刻八品，尚未分定品目时) 《八品仙经》，盖　纯阳吕祖师之箕着也。 其一、二品授于广陵，三、四品授于金陵，五品授于毗音皮陵，六、七品授于信州，八品授于临江。 仍谕授经众信，存以俟取。 至是乃命广陵童启伭子，普取梓布，李子序之。 经至，启伭汇录，更祈　仙姑何祖，紫阳张祖箕校，梓于万店筑仙楼，阳乃重加订。 稽首作礼而序曰： 「大哉品经乎！ 其括丹经，剖伭蕴，剔皇猷，舣音拟道筏，要原终始，宗贯天人，罔弗悉备！ 洵度世之贞符，修仙之要道也。 于稽其概：可以征设教之神焉，可以觇翊治之隆焉，可以功德之盛焉，可以三教之归焉，可以核音劾正邪之辨焉，可以证修炼之秘焉。 何也？ 盖神不可以方所测，故感自疾而应益显，信不可以遐迩窒，故孚自溥而化益光，是故祖师品经，不一人一方畀，而五陵多士畀者，正以彰大道为公之兆，寓中孚起信之机尔，故曰「可以征设教之神」； 昔羲黄尧舜，神化宜民，垂拱而治，是故《伭元太极五行品》，首表我太祖高皇帝圣谕，配扬 玉帝天尊，阐化妙旨，使人晓然知迁善以弭音米灾，积德以致福，养性以合真，而助国佑民，默赞无为之化莫茂焉。 故曰「可以觇翊治之隆」； 昔伭圣化形演经，大士分身说法，是故祖师痌瘝愚盲，曲垂接引，或以梦示，或以形谕，或以箕演，纪载不足以尽之，迨兹品经，则又媲休云笈普门，功德尤为罔极，故曰「可以功德之盛」； 夫道一而已矣。 初无有三教之分也。 昔我老犹龙，宣圣窃比，象教未东，列子预述，夫何其徒，各相护持不相下，非矣！ 是故品经，博援儒释之精微，发挥道源之奥妙，而殊途同归之义弥昭，故曰「可以会三教之归」； 且道有正宗，宗有伭秘，秘有真诠。 自旁门起，而邪淆正，妄紊真矣。 是故品经廓真辟妄，标正祛音区邪，明而严，详而确。 学者据品参诠，循诠探秘，握秘归宗，即旁门乌得而眩诸，故曰「可以核邪正之辨」； 夫大道未易以明言，至人兼难于遘识，况丹铅伭机，托譬既多称名转浩，口诀隐语，臆中为艰，是故诵法品经，自尔心领意会，触类通解，豁若关开键启而直达堂奥矣！ 故曰「可以证修炼之秘」。 虽然载道者经也，阐道者人也，祖师着经以训世，而人不能法经以修仙，宁不有负普度之德意哉！ 苟人人信受，不徒诵览而是训是行，则人人脱苦海，登道岸，超跻仙境，而祖师之惓惓轸望始慰。 善哉童子，卫道之功，与经同其广远，而寿祉允祚繁衍如之矣。 若孙得富侍箕藏法，朱霓奉道受经，咸与有功，故并及之，其诸受经善信，具在品中不更赘。 时万历己丑三月，广陵弟子启真博微李应阳谨撰。 八品仙经自序　(系后重复校正时，自序校经始末，非专序演经) 仙经着于五陵古矣！ 大旨宗贯三家，汇音毁归万理，谕教忠孝，勤勉德功，无不襄益王化，协赞天工，自身而家，自家而国。 斯之推也，由博而简，由显而密； 斯之用也，诣于神化之极，不越夫格致诚正为归。 此着经五陵之义也！ 大道烂然，周行坦率，本非隐怪谲异之书，不近祸福告禳之典。 其知微也，穷精达化，上升天京；

In the winter month of the Jia-Yin year of the Wanli reign (1594), the Returned-to-Yang Daoist Zhao Xingcui inscribed this at the Clear-Heart Studio in central Yunnan.

**Original Preface to the *Eightfold Scripture of Immortality***
*(This preface was composed when the eight ranks were first compiled, before their definitive classification)*

The *Eightfold Scripture of Immortality* is the posthumous work of the Pure Yang Patriarch, Master Lü. The first and second ranks were transmitted in Guangling, the third and fourth in Jinling, the fifth in Piyin Pilin, the sixth and seventh in Xinzhou, and the eighth in Linjiang. The master instructed that the scripture be preserved for those worthy of its reception. Later, he commanded Tong Qixuan of Guangling to widely carve and disseminate it, and Disciple Li was tasked with composing this preface.

When the scripture arrived, Qixuan compiled and recorded it, further entreating the Immortal Maiden He and the Purple Yang Patriarch Zhang to proofread and collate it. It was then printed at the Immortal Tower of Wan Dian, and Yang subsequently undertook a thorough revision.

Kneeling in reverence, I bow and compose this preface:

How vast is this *Ranked Scripture*! It encompasses the alchemical canons, dissects profound mysteries, elucidates imperial governance, and serves as a raft for the Dao. It traces origins and conclusions, unifying Heaven and humanity—nothing is left unaddressed. Truly, it is the authentic sign of deliverance from the world and the essential path of immortal cultivation.

In surveying its outline, one may:
—Verify the numinosity of its teachings,
—Discern the flourishing of its aid to governance,
—Gauge the magnitude of its merit and virtue,
—Comprehend the convergence of the Three Teachings,
—Distinguish the rectification of heterodoxy, and
—Confirm the secrets of spiritual refinement.

Why is this so?

The numinous cannot be measured by place; thus, its response grows ever more manifest from the slightest stimulus. Trust cannot be obstructed by distance; thus, its sincerity spreads universally, and its transformation shines ever brighter. Therefore, the Patriarch’s *Ranked Scripture* was not bestowed upon a single person or place. That it was granted to the many scholars of the Five Mounds is precisely to manifest the impartiality of the Great Dao and to instill the mechanism of sincerity that engenders faith. Hence, it is said: *“One may verify the numinosity of its teachings.”*

Of old, Fuxi, the Yellow Emperor, Yao, and Shun transformed the people through spiritual means, governing effortlessly. Thus, the *“Primordial Supreme Ultimate and Five Agents Rank”* begins by exalting the sacred edicts of our Great Ancestor, the August Emperor, aligning them with the Jade Emperor and Heavenly Worthy, and expounding the wondrous principles of transformation. It enables people to clearly understand how migrating toward goodness averts calamity, how accumulating virtue brings fortune, how nurturing one’s nature aligns with the Real, and how to aid the state and bless the people—silently assisting the flourishing of non-action. Hence, it is said: *“One may discern the flourishing of its aid to governance.”*

Of old, the sages of antiquity transformed their forms to expound scriptures, and bodhisattvas manifested in myriad bodies to preach the Dharma. Thus, the Patriarch, grieving for the benighted and blind, bent low to guide them—sometimes through dreams, sometimes through apparitions, sometimes through planchette writings—yet records cannot exhaust his deeds. In this *Ranked Scripture*, he rivals the *Cloud Satchel* and the *Universal Gateway*, his merit and virtue boundless. Hence, it is said: *“One may gauge the magnitude of its merit and virtue.”*

The Dao is one and undivided; there was never a distinction among the Three Teachings. Of old, our Old Master was likened to a dragon, the Profound Sage compared himself to a unicorn, the Elephant Teaching had not yet come east, and Liezi foretold it—yet how could their followers cling to their own traditions and refuse to yield? This was mistaken! Thus, the *Ranked Scripture* broadly draws upon the subtleties of Confucianism and Buddhism, unfolding the profound mysteries of the Dao’s source, making ever clearer the principle that diverse paths converge as one. Hence, it is said: *“One may comprehend the convergence of the Three Teachings.”*

Moreover, the Dao has its orthodox lineage, its lineage has its secrets, and its secrets have their true exegesis. Since heterodox schools arose, the false has mingled with the true, and delusion has disordered the Real. Thus, the *Ranked Scripture* sweeps away falsehood to reveal truth, establishes orthodoxy to dispel heterodoxy—its clarity is strict, its detail precise. Scholars who rely on its ranks to examine exegesis, follow exegesis to explore secrets, and grasp secrets to return to the lineage—how could heterodox schools delude them? Hence, it is said: *“One may distinguish the rectification of heterodoxy.”*

The Great Dao is not easily expressed in plain words, and perfected beings are seldom encountered. Moreover, the mechanisms of cinnabar and lead, the abundance of metaphors, the profusion of names, the concealment of oral instructions in cryptic language—these make comprehension arduous. Yet in reciting and practicing the *Ranked Scripture*, one naturally grasps its meaning, connects its categories, and achieves sudden enlightenment, as if bolts were drawn and doors flung open to grant direct access to the inner sanctum. Hence, it is said: *“One may confirm the secrets of spiritual refinement.”*

Nevertheless, the scripture bears the Dao, while people expound it. The Patriarch composed the scripture to instruct the world, yet if people fail to model themselves upon it to cultivate immortality, will they not betray the benevolent intent of universal deliverance? If every person were to faithfully receive it—not merely reciting and perusing but practicing and embodying its teachings—then each would escape the sea of suffering, ascend the shore of the Dao, and transcend into the realm of immortals, fulfilling the Patriarch’s earnest and compassionate hopes.

How excellent is Disciple Tong! His merit in defending the Dao is as vast and enduring as the scripture itself, and his blessings and posterity will surely flourish in kind. Sun Defu, who preserved the planchette methods, and Zhu Ni, who embraced the Dao and received the scripture, both contributed to this endeavor—thus, they too are mentioned. As for the many faithful recipients of the scripture, their names are recorded within its ranks and need not be repeated here.

Respectfully composed in the third month of the Ji-Chou year of the Wanli reign (1589) by Disciple Li Yingyang of Guangling, who has broadly investigated the subtle and profound.

**Postscript to the *Eightfold Scripture of Immortality***
*(Composed later during the repeated proofreading, this postscript recounts the process of collating the scripture, rather than serving as a dedicated preface to its exposition)*

The *Scripture of Immortality* was composed in the Five Mounds long ago. Its great purpose unifies the Three Teachings, converging the myriad principles. It instructs in loyalty and filial piety, exhorts to virtuous deeds—ever aiding royal transformation and harmonizing with Heaven’s work. From the self to the family, from the family to the state, its extension proceeds from the broad to the refined, from the manifest to the esoteric. Its application attains the utmost of spiritual transformation, yet it does not transcend the return to investigation, sincerity, integrity, and rectification. Such is the meaning of composing the scripture in the Five Mounds!

The Great Dao shines resplendently, its path level and unobstructed—it is no book of hidden wonders or strange anomalies, nor a manual of fortune-telling or exorcism. Those who fathom its subtleties exhaust essence and penetrate transformation, ascending to the Celestial Capital.

Its governance attains order through effortless rule—hands folded in repose, punishments set aside in non-action. Its nurturing of the latent proceeds through cultivating the self, quieting the mind, withdrawing the will, and embracing tranquility. How could it be reduced to burning incense and reciting scriptures, or bowing to canons, blindly trusted by the ignorant and the simple? Thus the superior person awakens to it through subtle spirit, the middling person cultivates it to enter the Dao, and the lesser person gains it to prolong life. Its principles merge into boundlessness, its qi and spirit vast and expansive—how could one not thereby endure as long as Heaven and Earth?

After the scripture was transmitted, errors crept in amid the carving of words and the chiseling of sounds, such as "bird" (鳥) rendered as "crow" (烏), or "fox" (狐) nearing "lonely" (孤). These were once corrected by the two Perfected Ones, He and Zhang, whose emendations were themselves laborious and exacting; now, a thorough revision has been made. Though the Five Mounds’ texts diverged in place and interpretation, they were but rough drafts. What was unordered in scrolls has now been ordered; what was unranked in categories has now been ranked. Yet one still fears that as ages grow distant, errors will be passed down in turn, and the printed text will again become as confused as before: "lord and king" (君王) written as "lord and parent" (君親); "spirit’s decay" (神敗) as "spirit’s nourishment" (神沃); "Great King" (太王) as "Civil King" (文王); "Martial Village" (武鄉) as "Martial Minister" (武卿); "resolving the heart’s unclarity" (任心不了) as "abiding in the heart’s unclarity" (在心不了); "why not cultivate and uphold" (何匪修持) as "why must one cultivate and uphold" (何必修持). Such instances are not merely ten or a hundred—all are errors that arose *after* the corrections of He and Zhang.

What is most troubling is this: the followers of miscellaneous and crooked schools, with their tangled words, imitate our scripture; the clever and eccentric, with their false doctrines, adulterate our canon. The crimson sun wheels through the sky, illuminating all peoples. Heaven and Earth are vast, embracing the ten thousand things—how could one compete with them? Yet can one remain unafraid?

The patterns of Heaven are the sun, moon, and stars; dew, thunder, wind, and rain; clouds, rosy dawn, rainbows, and lightning. The patterns of Earth are mountains and peaks, seas and rivers; flying and walking creatures, hidden and growing things; dwellings and the wilds. The patterns of humanity are benevolence, righteousness, propriety, and wisdom; loyalty, filial piety, trustworthiness, and sincerity; clothing and food. The reason the Three Powers endure so long is their constancy. Beyond the supreme principle, there is no other principle. At the end of verbose speech, what superfluous words remain!
