chunks.original_text: 一气既动，动而履阳，其卦应干； 动极复静，静而生阴，其卦应坤。 轻清上浮，干道曰天； 重浊下凝，坤道曰地。 夫天者，天运不息，气旋如环； 夫地者，地定以静，风劲而载。 天地互附，体用以全，天依于地，地依于天。 日者，阳气积而精外明也； 月者，阴气积而魄含景也。 阴阳之理，悉系于《易》，璇玑之要，经纬存焉，此天地化工之变也。 六十卦象，一倒一正，一降一升，升而合阳，降而符阴。 修丹之士，演卦屯音肫蒙：屯卦升阳，蒙卦符阴。 火有上下，反正须明。 阴阳之奥，晦朔之分，子亥初交，丹结之灵，任督二，阴阳之精，通畅百，流转一身，自然而然，非能之神。 水火二，上下之分，足底涌泉，二气之根。 升入尾闾音庐，符合两君，一水一火，右命左精。 上升夹脊，双关贯通。 达此泥丸，而返明堂，默灌五宫。 下重楼中，直往绛庭，复流丹府，昼夜不息，难以壅停。 真火无候，大药无斤，以神驭气，至道乃成。 人禀三才，体全太极。 心先天地，廓彻圆通。 本性虚湛，用运和。 神化自然，绵绵忘情。 『观天之道，执天之行。 』精化为气，气化为神，炼神还虚，号之长生。 众生不悟，迷乱七情，喜怒哀乐，神丧于形。 悖忤纲常，违逆彝伦。 因溺欲浪，种种不仁，子不孝父，臣不忠君，兄不爱弟，弟不敬兄，妇不顺夫，友不信朋。 仁义乖张，形神不宁，虚浮诈伪，驯狠自矜，贡高我慢，护己挫人。 以致上帝震怒，罪衅灾迍，稼穑不收，骨肉飘零，横亡夭死，水火瘟刑，尚不知省，怨恨神明，愚顽愆重。 　吾降临，阐教开宗，说法度生。 各宜修省，诚一于心，忠孝义慈，积德累功，痛返前非，改过自新。 静而悟道，默而养神。 吾传至理，宏示天人。 若能参觉，顿超苦轮。 吾怜众溺，屡化身形，遍巡宇宙，普度群生。 此经首品，略演修因，后着七品，为大梁津。 信受皈依，名列天庭。 觉之者灵，谤之者轰，悟之者证果于仙籍，传之者利益于三生。 皇极圣道，勿视以轻。 助之者增福延寿，灭之者永堕幽冥。 天神鉴察，报应昭明。 斋戒礼诵，万神咸钦。 城隍里社，遵教奉行。 」 在坛众生，欢喜信受，作礼而退。 五行端孝品第二 尔时　纯阳吕真人曰：「吾因往昔，心存于道，随形托化，未尝迷根逐性，固不失其本源。 难逢至诀，身世浮沉，累受累修，积功积德，誓行孝弟忠义仁慈。 后遇　东华帝君，遂闻大道，飞升金阙，证圣成真。 怜诸苦恼，游行三界，普济群生。 近有天旨，度业海盲音萌聋，但贪名逐利者多，证圣修真者少，邈视人轻，惟怀己胜，性如狼虎，噬毒尤加，心口置于两途，机谋于万种，染欲者万亿，惜命者几何。 吾闻　太上曰：『吾有三宝，保而持之：一曰慈、二曰俭、三曰不敢为天下先。 』故慈能勇； 以俭能广； 不敢为天下先，而能以成其器。
chunks.translated_text:
One qi then stirred—stirring, it trod the yang, and its hexagram answered as Qian. Stirring to its utmost, it returned to stillness—still, it gave birth to yin, and its hexagram answered as Kun. Light and pure, it floated upward, and the Qian Dao became Heaven; heavy and turbid, it congealed below, and the Kun Dao became Earth.

Now Heaven—its motion ceaseless, its qi whirling like a ring. Now Earth—firm and still, its winds fierce yet sustaining. Heaven and Earth interdepend, their substance and function complete: Heaven rests upon Earth, Earth upon Heaven.

The sun is yang qi accumulated, its essence shining outward; the moon is yin qi accumulated, its po containing radiance. The principles of yin and yang are all bound to the *Yi*; the pivot of the celestial sphere holds its warp and weft—such are the transformations of Heaven and Earth’s creative work.

The sixty-four hexagrams, each inverted or upright, each descending or ascending—ascending, they unite with yang; descending, they align with yin. Those who cultivate the elixir expound the hexagrams *Zhun* and *Meng*: *Zhun* ascends yang, *Meng* aligns with yin. Fire has its upper and lower, reversal and uprightness must be clear.

The mystery of yin and yang, the division of dark and new moons—at the first exchange of *zi* and *hai*, the numinous essence of the elixir coalesces. The *Ren* and *Du* meridians, the essence of yin and yang, flow unimpeded through the hundred channels, circulating through the body, naturally and of itself, not by any contrived spirit.

Water and fire, the division of above and below: the *Yongquan* at the soles of the feet, the root of the two qi. Rising into the *Weilu*, they meet the two sovereigns—one water, one fire, right as life, left as essence. Ascending the spine, the double gates open. Reaching the *Niwan*, they return to the *Mingtang*, silently irrigating the five palaces. Descending through the *Chonglou*, straight into the *Jiangting*, they flow back to the elixir府, ceaseless day and night, impossible to dam or halt.

True fire has no season, the great medicine no weight. With spirit driving qi, the supreme Dao is accomplished.

Man embodies the Three Powers, his body complete with the Supreme Ultimate. The heart precedes Heaven and Earth, vast and penetratingly round. Its original nature is empty and limpid, its function harmonious and balanced. Spirit transforms naturally, endlessly and without attachment.

*“Observe the Dao of Heaven, grasp the conduct of Heaven.”*
Essence transforms into qi, qi into spirit; refining spirit to return to emptiness is called longevity.

Yet beings do not awaken—they are deluded by the seven emotions: joy, anger, sorrow, and pleasure scatter spirit in form. They rebel against the moral order, violate the constant norms. Drowning in the waves of desire, they commit countless acts of unkindness: sons disobey fathers, ministers betray rulers, elder brothers do not love younger, younger do not respect elder, wives do not submit to husbands, friends do not trust companions. Benevolence and righteousness are perverted, form and spirit unsettled. They are vain, deceitful, and false; tame yet fierce, self-aggrandizing; proud, arrogant, self-protective, and belittling of others.

Thus the Supreme Lord shakes with anger, and transgressions bring calamity: crops fail, kin scatter, untimely deaths and violent ends, floods, fires, plagues, and punishments. Yet they do not reflect—instead, they resent the gods, foolish and stubborn in their heavy transgressions.

Therefore I descend, expounding the teaching and founding the school, preaching the Dharma to deliver beings. Each of you should examine and rectify yourself, unite sincerely in heart, be loyal, filial, righteous, and compassionate, accumulate virtue and merit, painfully repent past wrongs, and reform to begin anew. In stillness, awaken to the Dao; in silence, nurture spirit.

I transmit the supreme principle, broadly revealing it to Heaven and humanity. If you can fathom it, you will instantly transcend the wheel of suffering. I pity those drowning in delusion, repeatedly manifesting forms, traversing the cosmos, universally delivering all beings.

This first chapter of the scripture briefly expounds the causes of cultivation; the seven subsequent chapters serve as the great bridge of guidance. Those who faithfully receive and take refuge will have their names recorded in the celestial court. Those who awaken will be numinous; those who slander will be struck down. Those who realize it will attain fruition in the registers of immortals; those who transmit it will benefit across three lifetimes.

The Sagely Dao of the August Ultimate must not be treated lightly. Those who aid it will increase blessings and prolong life; those who destroy it will forever sink into the dark netherworld. Heavenly spirits observe and examine—retribution is clear and bright. With purification, reverence, and recitation, the myriad spirits all revere it. City gods and village altars follow the teaching and practice it.

The assembly at the altar rejoiced, believed, and received it, then bowed and withdrew.

**Chapter Two: The Five Phases and the Root of Filial Piety**

At that time, the Perfected Lü of Pure Yang said: “In past lives, my heart abided in the Dao. Following form and entrusting transformation, I never lost my root or pursued nature, thus never straying from my original source. Though the supreme secret was hard to encounter, my body and life floated and sank. Repeatedly receiving, repeatedly cultivating, I accumulated merit and virtue, vowing to practice filial piety, fraternal duty, loyalty, righteousness, benevolence, and compassion.

Later, I met the Lord Emperor of Eastern Florescence and thus heard the great Dao. I ascended to the Golden Gates and attained sagehood, becoming a perfected one. Pitying the afflicted, I roam the Three Realms, universally saving all beings.

Recently, a celestial decree has commanded me to deliver those blind and deaf in the sea of karma. Yet many chase fame and profit, while few attain sagehood and cultivate perfection. They scorn others and think only of themselves, their natures like wolves and tigers, their venom even more poisonous. Their words and hearts diverge, their schemes myriad. Countless are those stained by desire, but how few cherish life!

I have heard the Supreme Lord say: *‘I have three treasures, which I hold and preserve: the first is compassion, the second is frugality, the third is not daring to put oneself before the world.’* Thus compassion engenders courage; frugality engenders abundance; not daring to put oneself before the world enables one to perfect one’s vessel.”

All of you, with reverence and sincerity, heed my teaching:

The Supreme Ultimate was formless, born before heaven and earth. Qi and spirit merged as one in the primordial chaos.”

chunks.original_text: 所谓『真』者，虚心绝虑，保气养精，应物而不存于物，养虚而体于虚空，情意了然，厥修元始，六关严守，一息恒存，气神不竭，神气相溶。 伏其气于脐下，守其神于身中。 神气孚合，关捩音列开通。 尔口说道，道居何处？ 心不忘道，道已得焉！ 体圣贤心，行圣贤事，方为道矣！ 吾承恩命，接引众生，慧照汝等，尚不信受，妄行智巧，播弄奸顽，掩诈杂真，真难领悟，可见浮生，无有仁德！ 吾体天地之心为心，但愿群迷，普修慈善，冥心注神，神与气符，伏膺元气，勿丧三般。 今为众生，开演易理，喻以前圣，而譬晓伭微，见易包于道，道包于易，采而行之，潜而修之，默而守之，勤而炼之，则神升紫府，位列仙班。 乾坤混合，易象如斯，一气既判，两仪之源，穷神知化，周匝环绵，知微知彰，隐显难言，络绎不绝，光范太伭。 自矜不长，惟曲可全，守道以讷，任兑必愆，致中抱一，履和而谦，以卑而积，以柔而坚。 心动为意，意转情牵，情牵着妄，妄引多愆。 夫人之情也，见物如虎之逐； 人之意也，见物如龙之缠。 动心不灭，照心难圆，命在于肾，性属于干。 心凝为神，神静为性，穷理尽性，混茫无端。 神归无为，炼煅三元，视而不见，听而不喧，言而无声，万虑俱捐。 五行之道，水火化焉。 水火相洽，水火相兼。 火中有土，水中有焰，火既生土，三姓以全。 以土制水，水溢必旋，导水济火，水火交欢，金木合并，气神相连，金情木性，驱炼胶粘，中宵漏永，光透重帘，温和颐养，升汞降铅，金浮木坠，赤日当天。 火要水济，水赖火炎，以柔制刚，刚柔连绵，炼成一块，非汞非铅，能升能降，号曰胎仙。 运火炼药，神与气缠。 以火喻神，以喻药，以神合气，气足神全。 河车之数，运气周天，心息相依，腹存目蠲。 戊土从坎，进之阳火； 己土从离，退之阴符。 进合与退，舍之太伭。 元海之窍，循之泥丸，五混合，万象朝天。 时人不识，附会乱传。 人道未了，仙道难全。 欲修真道，人道合仙。 参而行之，仙圣同肩。 受形父母，体合情缘，移神脱气，朔晦婵娟，二气相资，龟蛇盘旋，混聚凝结，包胎是全。 温养十月，符体先天，劈开混沌，显象灿然。 怀育乳哺，母形羸煎，子渐养成，体固神完，脱气化育，罔极昊天，所云脱化，妙理幽伭。 胎元之道，符合坤干，阳施阴受，情性交连。 今世迷途疑徒字误，散内溺外，七情惜怜，六根顿坏，失本忘真，不知警戒，火燥水崩，气离神败。 顾子恤妻，掌中珠爱，父母洪恩，眼中尘碍，不孝悖逆，罪愆广大。 汝既惜子，当惜父母。 汝若孝亲，子亦孝汝； 汝不敬亲，子亦违忤。 父母哀颜，电光草露，感气受形，当思乳哺。 吾今垂经，首孝为务，五行之先，百行之路。 顺其志颜，天神拥护，活祖不参，岁月空度。 不孝之辈，身劈雷部，报应昭明，速当醒悟。 暗室可欺于心　　神明难以掩布　　欲学仙道长生　　先修人道为务 易曰：『憧音充憧往来，朋从尔思。 』气和乃神之衢，精化乃药之务。 还精补脑，如蒙如雾，以无生有，世罕修也。 天形何以长　　门枢何不蠹　　内照慧宝光　　灿灿明珠府 众生所以不能悉心领悟者，由乎情着于物，思迷于爱也。

What is called *"the Real"*? It is to empty the heart and sever thoughts, preserve *qi* and nurture essence. Respond to things without being ensnared by them; cultivate emptiness and embody the void. Clarity of intent and emotion—thus begins primordial cultivation. The six gates are strictly guarded; a single breath is ever present. *Qi* and spirit do not deplete; spirit and *qi* merge as one.

Subdue *qi* beneath the navel; guard the spirit within the body. When spirit and *qi* harmonize, the gates and pivots open smoothly. You speak of the Dao—where does the Dao reside? If the heart does not forget the Dao, the Dao is already attained! Embody the heart of sages and sages’ deeds—only then is it the Dao!

I have received the grace of a mandate to guide all beings. With wisdom, I illuminate you, yet you still do not believe and accept, recklessly wielding cunning and deceit, stirring up treachery and obstinacy. You conceal falsehood amid truth, making the Real difficult to grasp. Clearly, in this floating life, there is no benevolence or virtue!

My heart is the heart of Heaven and Earth. I only wish that all the deluded will universally cultivate kindness and goodness, silently focusing spirit so that spirit and *qi* align. Subdue and embrace primordial *qi*; do not lose these three treasures.

Now, for the sake of all beings, I expound the principles of the *Yi*, drawing analogies from former sages to illustrate subtle truths. I show that the *Yi* encompasses the Dao, and the Dao encompasses the *Yi*. Gather and practice it; cultivate it in seclusion; guard it in silence; refine it with diligence. Then the spirit ascends to the Purple Palace, and one takes one’s place among the immortals.

When Qian and Kun merge, the images of the *Yi* are thus. Once the singular *qi* divides, it becomes the source of the Two Modes. To fathom the spirit and know transformation, to encompass all in an unbroken cycle—knowing the subtle and the manifest, the hidden and the revealed, which are indescribable, continuous, and boundless, their radiance illuminating the vast primordial.

Pride does not endure; only humility can preserve the whole. Guard the Dao with reticence; indulging in cleverness will surely lead to error. Hold to the center and embrace the One; walk in harmony and humility. Accumulate through lowliness; strengthen through softness.

When the heart stirs, it becomes intent; when intent turns, it becomes emotion; when emotion clings, it becomes delusion; delusion leads to manifold transgressions. Human emotion, upon seeing things, is like a tiger in pursuit; human intent, upon seeing things, is like a dragon’s coils. If the stirring heart is not extinguished, the illuminating heart cannot be perfected. Life resides in the kidneys; nature belongs to Qian.

When the heart congeals, it becomes spirit; when spirit is still, it becomes nature. To exhaust principle and fulfill nature is to merge with the boundless. When spirit returns to non-action, refining and tempering the Three Origins, seeing yet not perceiving, hearing yet not clamoring, speaking yet voiceless—all thoughts are cast aside.

In the Dao of the Five Phases, water and fire transform. Water and fire harmonize; water and fire intermingle. Within fire is earth; within water is flame. Since fire generates earth, the three natures are complete. Use earth to restrain water; when water overflows, it must be turned back. Guide water to aid fire; when water and fire rejoice together, metal and wood unite, *qi* and spirit connect. The nature of metal and the essence of wood are driven and refined until they adhere. Through the long night, light pierces heavy curtains. Nurturing with warmth, ascending mercury and descending lead—metal floats, wood sinks, the red sun stands at midheaven.

Fire requires water to aid it; water relies on fire to blaze. Use softness to restrain hardness; hardness and softness intertwine. Refined into one mass, neither mercury nor lead, it can ascend and descend—this is called the Embryonic Immortal.

Circulate fire to refine the elixir; spirit and *qi* entwine. Use fire as an analogy for spirit; use the *qi*-vessel as an analogy for the elixir. Unite spirit with *qi*; when *qi* is sufficient, spirit is complete. The river chariot’s count: circulate *qi* through the celestial cycle. Heart and breath depend on each other; the abdomen stores, the eyes are clear.

Wu-earth follows Kan, advancing with yang fire; Ji-earth follows Li, retreating with yin tally. Advancing and retreating, merging and parting—abandon them to the Great Primordial. The aperture of the Primordial Sea follows the Mud Pill Palace. The Five *Qi*-Vessels merge; all phenomena pay homage to Heaven.

Yet people do not recognize this and cling to distorted transmissions. Before the human Dao is complete, the immortal Dao is difficult to fulfill. To cultivate the Real Dao, the human Dao must merge with the immortal. Practice and walk this path, and immortals and sages will stand side by side.

Born of father and mother, the body unites with karmic conditions. Shift spirit and shed *qi*; waxing and waning like the moon’s beauty. The two *qi* assist each other; tortoise and snake coil together. Gathered and congealed, the embryo is complete. Nurtured for ten months, the body accords with the prenatal. Splitting open the primordial chaos, the image appears resplendent.

Nurtured in the womb and suckled, the mother’s form is emaciated and tormented. Gradually, the child is reared, the body firm and spirit complete. Shedding *qi* and transforming through nurture—boundless is the vast Heaven. What is called "transformation" is a profound and subtle principle.

The Dao of the Embryonic Origin accords with Kun and Qian. Yang bestows; yin receives. Emotion and nature intertwine.

In this world, those lost on the path doubt and misinterpret the teachings. They scatter internally and drown externally, clinging to the seven emotions and spoiling the six roots. Losing their original nature and forgetting the Real, they know no warning. Fire scorches; water collapses; *qi* departs; spirit decays.

Cherishing children and pitying wives, they hold pearls in their palms. Yet the great kindness of parents becomes dust in their eyes. Disobedient and unfilial, their sins are vast. If you cherish your child, you should cherish your parents. If you are filial to your parents, your child will also be filial to you. If you do not respect your parents, your child will also defy you.

The sorrowful countenance of parents is like lightning or morning dew. Receiving *qi* and taking form, you should remember their nurturing. Now, as I transmit this scripture, filial piety is the foremost duty—the first of the Five Phases, the path of a hundred virtues. Follow their wishes and expressions; heavenly spirits will protect you. If you do not honor your ancestors, the years and months are spent in vain.

Those who are unfilial will be split by thunder; retribution is clear and swift—awaken now! In the dark room, you may deceive your heart, but the divine cannot be concealed. If you wish to learn the immortal Dao and attain longevity, first cultivate the human Dao as your duty.

The *Yi* says: *"Coming and going in confusion, friends follow your thoughts."* Harmony of *qi* is the thoroughfare of spirit; the transformation of essence is the task of the elixir. Returning essence to replenish the brain is like mist or fog—creating something from nothing, a practice rare in the world.

Why does Heaven’s form endure? Why does the door’s hinge not rot? Inwardly illuminating the jewel of wisdom, the resplendent Pearl Palace shines brightly.

The reason beings cannot fully comprehend with their hearts is that they are attached to things and deluded by love.

chunks.translated_text:
If you attain softness to nurture harmony, turn the body inward and reflect—then the Dao abides therein!

Guangchengzi said: *"See nothing, hear nothing, embrace the spirit in stillness."*
The *Odes* says: *"The workings of High Heaven bear no sound, no scent."*
The Western teachings say: *"No wisdom, no attainment—thus, nothing is attained."*
The Most High said: *"Reversion is the movement of the Dao; weakness is its function. The greatest sound is soundless; the greatest form is formless. The vulgar are ever bright; I alone seem dim. That by which Heaven and Earth endure is their non-self-existence."*

How grand the words of sages and worthies!

The *Analects* says: *"Hold to no certainty, cling to no rigidity."*
Mencius said: *"Neither forget nor force—both are steps to preserving spirit and guiding qi."*

Yet people today remain unaware!

The Dao of nurturing qi lies in unbroken continuity—like flowing water’s winding ease, like drifting clouds’ soaring flight, like a round pearl rolling on a plate, or an infant’s selfless state.

The *Doctrine of the Mean* says: *"Obscure yet ever more radiant."*
The *Wall Sutra* says: *"His heart rests in perfect repose."*

Are these not all truthful words? From ancient times to the present, the sages and worthies have followed the same track, like wheels sharing a single rut. Yet the ignorant世俗, blindly dividing the Three Teachings, fail to recognize that *"a thousand lamps in one room share the same light; ten thousand dharmas follow the same principle to sagehood."* Without plumbing the subtlest depths of the supreme principle, they cling obstinately to right and wrong, self and other, grasping at branches and plucking leaves, wagging their tongues and flaunting their lips. They flaunt their arms in delusion, practicing blind cultivation and aimless refinement. Later learners are all led astray by such clamor, never awakening.

May all beings advance diligently in the Dao, with sincere hearts and earnest devotion. Do not cling to the sounds of phenomena, nor become attached to mere words. Honor your teachers and draw near to virtuous friends; empty yourself in reverence. In silent realization, you may ascend to longevity!

Then was spoken the incantation:

*North unites Heaven and Earth’s essence,*
*Transforming all things with boundless spirit.*
*The axis of Qian and Kun turns,*
*Dragon and Tiger conceal true qi.*
*Six demons dissolve and scatter,*
*Three Primes shine with radiant splendor.*
*Crow and Hare meet in the central valley,*
*Tortoise and Serpent coil within the inner court.*
*Roaming beyond the cosmos,*
*Grasping life and death in hand.*
*Commanding lightning’s flashing might,*
*All ghosts and spirits vanish without trace.*
*Who dares defy this power?*
*Shattered like dust in the wind.*
*Where wisdom’s light shines forth,*
*All calamities and misfortunes turn to peace.*
*Receive and recite with reverence,*
*Your name recorded in the celestial palace.*

When the Perfected One finished expounding the sutra, auspicious clouds and fragrant mists swirled in the air, while propitious vapors coiled and ascended. Cranes bore his chariot through the azure sky. The master returned to his abode, and all present bowed deeply, prostrating themselves in homage. They received the teachings in faith and withdrew.

*(The above two chapters were inscribed at Guangling.)*

chunks.original_text: 尔时　纯阳仙师，告金陵大众曰：「吾因鹤城徐氏，久在空门，实践乐施，致身颠沛，年逾七十，道心不退，虽无举，亦有深功。 因承玉音，命度苍生，慧照乾坤，感诚降彼，已说　太上皇极一品、二品化育之机。 但彼处众生，贡高我慢，妒音豆嫉贪瞋，屡以善道化之。 群生执着不了，有二三阐法，皆不体　吾普济为念，各怀私窒，作逞高能，善言慈诲，不劝于人。 以教外虚浮，矜夸于己，未得仙地，妄绝人言，可叹可喟！ 行吾道者，积功修德，劝善化恶，讲教忠孝，励勉信诚，以气致柔，从容中道，明无人非，幽无鬼责，和乎众性，循理民情。 以道义行仁慈，利物济生，愍贫恤苦，慈悲恻隐，泽及昆虫，至于草木，不可伤残。 悯人凶、恤人苦，放生戒杀，舍大慈悲，行方便心，胜如斋戒，体天地德，何匪修持？ 行吾道者，如遇不善之人，以德以理化之； 苟弗依善而执者，必当和气怡颜以接。 所以宣圣循循然善诱人，娄师德唾面自干音干，何曾瞋怒？ 若克己泰而不骄，彼必化恶归善，乃阐教之功。 设使不教民战，是谓弃之，焉无罪哉？ 如遇敬道之人，以恩以善结之； 苟错行道而偏着者，亦当引解圣经以悟。

At that time, the Pure Yang Immortal Master addressed the great assembly of Jinling, saying: "Through the Xu family of Hecheng, I long dwelt in the gate of emptiness, practicing joyful almsgiving and enduring hardship. Though I have passed seventy years, my resolve for the Dao has never waned. Though I have not achieved sudden enlightenment, my merits run deep. By the command of the Jade Emperor’s voice, I was tasked to deliver sentient beings. My wisdom illumined heaven and earth, and my sincerity moved them to descend. I have already expounded the *Supreme August Ultimate’s* first and second chapters on the mechanisms of transformation and nurturance.

Yet the beings there were arrogant and self-important, envious and jealous, greedy and wrathful. I repeatedly taught them the virtuous Way, but the multitude clung to delusion and failed to awaken. Though two or three preachers of the Dharma emerged, none embodied my spirit of universal salvation. Each harbored private obstructions, flaunting their abilities, uttering kind admonitions yet failing to exhort others. They indulged in superficial displays outside the teachings, boasting of their own virtues. Before attaining the immortal realms, they rashly rejected others’ counsel—how lamentable, how pitiable!

Those who practice my Way must accumulate merit and cultivate virtue, exhorting goodness and transforming evil, teaching loyalty and filial piety, encouraging faith and sincerity. With *qi*, they achieve suppleness; in tranquility, they abide in the Middle Way. They discern no wrong in others, nor do they incur blame from hidden spirits. Harmonizing with the nature of the multitude, they follow the principles of the people. Through the Dao and righteousness, they enact benevolence and compassion, benefiting beings and aiding life. They pity the poor and relieve the suffering, their mercy extending even to insects and plants—nothing may be harmed or destroyed. They grieve for the wicked and succor the afflicted, practicing life-release and forbidding killing. To cultivate great compassion and act with a mind of expedient means surpasses even fasting and abstinence. To embody the virtue of heaven and earth—what practice could be excluded?

When encountering the unvirtuous, those who walk my Way transform them through virtue and reason. If they stubbornly refuse goodness, one must still meet them with harmonious countenance and cheerful demeanor. Thus did Confucius, step by step, skillfully guide others; thus did Lou Shide endure spittle drying on his face—when did he ever harbor anger? If one masters oneself and remains composed without arrogance, even the wicked will turn from evil to goodness—such is the merit of expounding the teachings. To abandon the people without instruction is to cast them aside—how could one be without blame?

When encountering those who revere the Dao, one should bind them with kindness and goodness. If they err in practice or cling to partiality, one must still guide them to awakening through the sacred scriptures."

chunks.original_text: 所以君子近者悦、远者来。 周太王从者如市，皆因德惠，若尽己和而不同，彼必皈正起敬，乃阐教之仁。 设使颠而不扶，心何忍哉？ 岂不愆欤！ 天下之人，有教无类，为师作傅，当以忠恕敬肃，顺气怡颜，义以为质，礼以行之，逊以接之，信以成之。 深则厉，厉则难从； 浅则揭，揭则生乱； 言不重，则不威。 至哉守一，心平气和，气和神畅，神畅体舒，浩然天地，俯仰无愧，翕音吸然性情，不离体用，存真一心，超真一道。 吾闻　太上曰：『先天而生，生而无形； 后天而存，存而无体。 静为之性，心在其中； 动为之心，性在其中。 心生性灭，心灭性现。 如空无相，湛然常满。 』夫大道无象，内存于有； 真性无外，不生其心。 居境忘境，无象以存。 守乎无体，固蒂深根，养于天真，若忘若存，精以合气，气以合神。 太上曰：『神以形生，精以气盈，知其神气，可以长生。 』 引先圣语，以合三教，非妄枝叶，以误群生。 若能顿悟，可保真形。 吾因传经，维扬诳傲，故示教于金陵，以忠信品，普化群生。 不愿持斋，惟愿信心，斋之谓斋，以斋于心，心不修持，斋胡为功？ 只知戒口，罔知戒心，即心是道，坚守勿轻。 尔等侍坛，各有宿因，得闻斯道，以静尘心，尘欲克尽，大道昭明。 仍取毗陵《五品》伭文，合品传扬，易换品经，敬而持之。 吾当降灵，语维扬众，各改瞋心，毋蹈前非，枉费修因。 若怀种子，必加罪惩； 信心敬受，必获超升。 道没穷富，劝勿择人，言有必无，知真未真。 修道之人，心无毫尘； 得道之士，行多隐贫。 道非财授，授传信人。 以利求　吾，吾何以闻？ 虚己觅道，圣必显灵。 勿作人师，将人视轻； 阻人参修，报殃灭门。 善言当喻，诬话休论，被褐怀玉，焉于虔反可量人？ 故　太上曰：『见小曰明，守柔曰刚。 用其刚而复其明，无遗身殃。 』夫无为故无败，无执故无失。 陶称舜，御众以宽； 仲虺赞汤，克宽克仁。 若矜然无乖戾，群然无阿比，躬自厚而薄责人，斯近道矣！ 故圣人修身以道，修道以仁，嘉善以矜不能，至道斯凝，柔于远人，天下归仁，以赞天地化育，而参三才。 今学伭者，外丹搬弄四黄，内丹止于功坐，不思五金非八石之母，幻身非先天之道，所以燕不生凤，狐不乳马，以幻身作养，以砒音批硵音鲁行持，非真父母。 气不相接，神不相投，安能炼外而养内也！ 夫六魔灭而六通存，三尸斩而三光现，不离乎身，非着于身。 今悟参者，以为坐得，夜坐日卧，何以炼形？ 十二时中，行而勿失。 以神驭气，以气运精，精不役形，不于情生，情不动移，精不溺崩。 精非有生，因情而生，以精合气，和翕天真，天真非真，真以强名。 怀人我念，岂为道心！ 行道之士，体天地心，曰儒曰释曰道，三教非离于心：儒以谦和，释以忍辱，伭以致柔。 『精气神』非柔莫得，『戒定慧』非忍莫守，『仁义德』非和莫涵，柔忍和厥中乃成。 中者性也，性本乎善。 进乎阳火，以情伏性； 退乎阴符，以性归情。 所谓性者，木也、汞也、神也、火也、龙也、蛇也； 所云情者，金也、铅也、精也、水也、虎也、龟也。 皆譬语也。 神运精，则精化气； 以金木，则木成材。 驱龙就虎，龙虎交欢，以心伏身，心身翕泰。
chunks.translated_text:
Thus does the noble person bring joy to those near and draw those far—like King Tai of Zhou, whose followers thronged like a marketplace, all through the power of virtue and kindness. If one exhausts one’s harmony without partiality, others will surely turn toward rectitude and rise in reverence—such is the benevolence of expounding the teachings. To see another stumble and not lift them—how could one bear it? Would this not be a grievous fault?

All under heaven are to be taught without distinction. As a teacher or mentor, one must act with loyalty, forbearance, respect, and solemnity; meet others with harmonious qi and cheerful countenance; take righteousness as one’s essence and ritual as one’s practice; receive them with humility and fulfill them with trust. Too profound, and one becomes severe—severity makes following difficult. Too shallow, and one becomes frivolous—frivolity breeds disorder. Words not weighty lack authority.

Ah, to guard the One! With mind at peace and qi harmonized, qi harmonized and spirit flowing, spirit flowing and body at ease—vast as heaven and earth, one moves without shame, inhaling and exhaling in accord with nature, never departing from substance and function. Preserve the true One-heart, transcend the true One-Way.

I have heard the Most High say: *"Before heaven it is born, born yet without form; after heaven it abides, abiding yet without body. Stillness is its nature, the heart within it; movement is its heart, nature within it. When the heart arises, nature vanishes; when the heart ceases, nature appears. Like empty space without form, it is serene and ever full."*

The Great Dao has no image, yet inwardly abides in being. True nature has no exterior, and does not give rise to the heart. Abiding in the realm, one forgets the realm—no image remains. Guarding the formless, one roots deeply, nurturing celestial authenticity, as if forgotten yet present. Essence unites with qi, qi unites with spirit.

The Most High said: *"Spirit is born from form, essence is filled by qi. Know spirit and qi, and you may attain long life."* I cite the words of the ancient sages to harmonize the Three Teachings—not idle branches or leaves to mislead the multitude. If one awakens suddenly, one may preserve the true form.

I transmit the scriptures, yet in Yangzhou, arrogance and deceit prevail. Thus I reveal these teachings in Jinling, with loyalty and trust as their measure, to transform all beings. I do not urge fasting, only sincere faith. Fasting is fasting of the heart—if the heart is not cultivated, what merit lies in fasting? To know only the restraint of the mouth and not the restraint of the heart—this heart is the Dao. Guard it firmly, lightly not.

You who attend this altar, each bears karmic causes from the past. Having heard this Way, still the dust of your hearts. When worldly desires are wholly overcome, the Great Dao shines clearly. Still, take the *Five Ranks* text from Piling, harmonize its ranks with transmission, and reverently uphold the *Rank-Changing Scripture*.

I shall descend in spirit to address the assembly of Yangzhou: each must reform your angry hearts, avoid repeating past errors, lest your cultivation be in vain. If you harbor seeds of wrongdoing, you will incur punishment; if you receive with sincere faith, you will surely ascend. The Dao makes no distinction between rich and poor—do not choose whom to exhort. Words may claim certainty, yet true knowing remains uncertain.

Those who cultivate the Dao have hearts without the slightest dust; those who attain the Dao often live in hidden poverty. The Dao is not conferred by wealth—it is transmitted only to those of trust. If you seek me for gain, how shall I hear you? Empty yourself to seek the Dao, and the sage will surely manifest.

Do not presume to be others’ teacher, nor look down upon them. To obstruct another’s practice invites calamity upon your house. Good words should be understood; false speech must not be spoken. Cloaked in coarse cloth yet holding jade—how could Fan Yu measure such a one?

Thus the Most High said: *"To see the small is called clarity; to guard the soft is called strength. Employing strength while returning to clarity, one leaves no misfortune for oneself."* Without action, there is no failure; without attachment, there is no loss.

Yao praised Shun for governing the people with leniency; Zhong Hui extolled Tang for his perfect kindness and benevolence. If one is haughty and without discord, if the multitude is free from favoritism, if one is strict with oneself and lenient toward others—one draws near the Dao.

Thus the sage cultivates the self through the Dao, and cultivates the Dao through benevolence. Praising the good while pitying the incapable, the perfect Dao coalesces. Gentle toward those afar, the world returns to benevolence—thus aiding heaven and earth in transformation, and partaking in the triad of heaven, earth, and humanity.

Now those who study external alchemy fiddle with the Four Yellows, while those of internal alchemy stop at seated practice. They do not consider that the Five Metals are not the mother of the Eight Stones, nor is the illusory body the precelestial Dao. Thus the swallow does not hatch a phoenix, nor does the fox give birth to a horse. To nurture with the illusory body, to practice with arsenic and sulfur—these are not one’s true parents. Qi does not connect, spirit does not commune—how can one refine the external to nourish the internal?

When the Six Demons are extinguished, the Six Penetrations arise; when the Three Corpses are severed, the Three Lights appear. They do not depart from the body, nor do they cling to it.

Now those who awaken to practice believe they have attained through sitting—sitting by night, lying by day—how can they refine the form? In all twelve hours, act without fail. With spirit drive qi, with qi move essence. Essence does not enslave the form, nor does it arise from emotion. If emotion does not shift, essence does not drown or collapse.

Essence is not inherently born—it arises from emotion. Unite essence with qi, harmonizing and gathering celestial authenticity. Celestial authenticity is not true—"true" is but a forced name. Harboring thoughts of self and others—how can this be the heart of the Dao?

Those who practice the Way embody the heart of heaven and earth. Whether called Confucian, Buddhist, or Daoist, the Three Teachings do not depart from the heart: Confucians with humility and harmony, Buddhists with forbearance, Daoists with yielding. *"Essence, qi, and spirit"* cannot be obtained without softness; *"precepts, concentration, and wisdom"* cannot be upheld without forbearance; *"benevolence, righteousness, and virtue"* cannot be contained without harmony. Softness, forbearance, and harmony—these are the mean, and therein lies completion.

The mean is nature, and nature is fundamentally good. Advancing with the yang fire, one subdues nature with emotion; retreating with the yin tally, one returns emotion to nature.

What is called *nature* is wood, mercury, spirit, fire, dragon, and snake. What is called *emotion* is metal, lead, essence, water, tiger, and turtle. These are all metaphors.

When spirit moves essence, essence transforms into qi. When metal smelts wood, wood becomes timber. Driving the dragon to the tiger, dragon and tiger rejoice in union. With the heart subduing the body, heart and body harmonize in peace.

chunks.translated_text:
By returning emotion to nature, emotion and nature blend in harmony;
By returning lead to mercury, mercury and lead fuse like lacquer;
By the turtle entwining the snake, turtle and snake coil in embrace.
Without oral transmission, all is but forced conjecture!

Confucianism is for *action*, Buddhism for *quiescence*, and the *Xian* path for *preservation*.
Quiescence means stilling birth, aging, sickness, suffering, and death—pointing to the quiescence of illusion.
Action means practicing benevolence, righteousness, propriety, wisdom, and trust—pointing to the governance of conduct.
Preservation means preserving metal, wood, water, fire, and earth—preserving the spirit within.

Birth, aging, sickness, suffering, and death are stilled;
Benevolence, righteousness, propriety, wisdom, and trust are practiced;
Metal, wood, water, fire, and earth are preserved.
Things arise from earth and perish in earth; humans arise from qi and perish in qi.
Those who purify earth and nurture qi may partake in the *Xian* path!

Then he spoke the gatha:
Great indeed is the true *Xian*!
Water and fire in balance,
Returning emotion to nature—
Not through greed or wrath.
The wondrous Dao of emptiness aligns with the celestial mind.
This celestial mind is not the fleshly heart;
It is singular in truth,
Never dual or inclined.
Enter through sincerity,
Achieve through silence.
Not that it lacks spirit,
But spirit resides in the inch of sincerity.

I reach with sincerity,
Not with wealth.
Disciples of the Dao,
First cultivate your hearts.
Do not indulge in arrogance,
Nor cling to stubborn emptiness.
Refrain from violence and anger,
Accumulate virtue and benevolence.
Encourage filial piety toward parents,
Loyalty to the sovereign,
Trust among friends,
Harmony with neighbors,
Compassion for all beings,
Relief for the poor.
Do not boast of your own merits,
Nor belittle others.
Wealth has no root—
Why pride yourself?
Poverty is not eternal—
Why harbor resentment?
The poor do not flatter,
The rich do not arrogantly display.
Good begets good with resounding voice,
Evil begets evil with departing tone—
Karmic retribution is clear and bright.
If you cultivate goodness,
Your descendants will flourish;
If you commit evil,
Your posterity will wither.
Relieve the orphaned, cherish the aged,
Refrain from killing, release the living.
Day by day, month by month,
You will surely attain merit.
With the Three Primes’ protection,
All sages will aid your success.
In years to come, when your practice is complete,
You will ascend with your entire household.

The master concluded the gatha.
Among the assembly, twenty people in unison voiced their praise,
bowed their heads to the dharma altar,
expressed gratitude to the celestial perfected,
and wholeheartedly accepted the teachings,
vowing to embody the precious scripture of the immortal master,
to practice impartiality,
to eliminate the Three Poisons,
to distance themselves from the Six Dusts,
to purify the heart and illuminate nature,
and to make their grand vows before the master.

At that moment, auspicious clouds gathered in gentle harmony,
immortal music filled the sky,
white cranes soared,
cinnabar clouds illuminated the chamber,
and the assembly bowed in reverence before withdrawing in solemnity.

**Chapter Four: Zhengzhong’s Teachings**

Then Lü Zu again addressed the assembly, saying:
"The world is an illusion of the blind multitude, who do not embody the formless and are utterly lost in existence.
Often seeking the Dao, they cling to delusion and stray from truth,
not knowing that the Dao resides within themselves, not in external manipulation.

The *Avataṃsaka Sūtra* states:
*'The mind is like a master painter, creating all pure conditions.'*
The *Śūraṅgama Sūtra* says:
*'When the mad nature ceases, cessation itself is bodhi.
Hearing is restored, the root of obstruction removed, dust vanishes, and awakening is perfectly pure.'*
The *Pan* scripture says:
*'From love arises sorrow, from sorrow arises fear.'*
All your fears stem from love.
Depart from this ocean of love, and it is called true awakening.

The *Vajracchedikā Prajñāpāramitā Sūtra* states:
*'All conditioned things are like dreams, illusions, bubbles, echoes, dew, and lightning—
contemplate them thus.'*
You have long erred in stubborn emptiness, entangled in multiplicity and delusion.
Can you awaken to such truths?
Can you practice and uphold them?

The *Buddha-nāma Sūtra* says:
*'With attachment, there is arising; with the exhaustion of attachment, there is cessation.
Comprehending this arising and cessation, one may speak of it.'*

It is not that I seek extensively among the sages for analogies,
but because the three teachings—Confucianism, Buddhism, and Daoism—
have been falsely divided by people.
Branches and leaves are used as metaphors,
creating a vast chasm,
yet when one investigates the root,
all return to the same principle.

A heart free from worldly dust is called *emptiness and tranquility*.
People attribute this to Buddhism as the path of quiescence and cessation,
yet they do not know themselves.

The *Śūraṅgama Sūtra* says:
*'Quiescence and cessation are called the One Mind—
not the cessation of movement, nor the extinction of what has already arisen.
Only when the locus of arising is known can the locus of cessation be understood.'*
The *Yuanjue Jing* states:
*'When the eye of wisdom is pure and clear,'*
it purifies the inner realm.
With no inner realm arising,
true samādhi and nature’s samādhi are realized.
When nature is settled, emotions are stilled,
and the primordial is illuminated.

The primordial is called *spirit*;
congealing spirit in *Kun* gives birth to the numinous medicine.
The postnatal is called *qi*;
circulating qi into *Qian* completes the elixir’s work.

The true nature is quiescent and unmoving,
yet responsive and unobstructed.
Refining medicine with spirit,
guiding qi to nurture spirit,
qi infuses spirit—
not bound by trigrams or forms,
fire and seed continue in succession,
the elixir crucible remains warm.

Thus, the ceaseless cycle of heaven and earth
awakens one to perfect quiescent awareness.
With a quiescently aware heart,
do not indulge in illusions or defiled appearances.
Understand that body and mind
are all hindrances.
Without knowing, awareness is bright,
not dependent on any obstruction.

The learning of the Western Paradise
takes departure from illusion as the Dao,
so heaven and earth accomplish without speech.
The primordial true nature
comes from emptiness and nothingness;
the postnatal true samādhi
arises from forbearance and clarity.

Abiding in silent preservation,
congealing essence to transform spirit,
obscuring things to lose intent,
dispersing qi to divide spirit—
do not be burdened by things.
Preserve essence with spirit,
essence depends on spirit to transform,
nature is still, spirit merges.

The Most High said:
*'Always observe the wondrous with desirelessness,
always observe the gateway with desire.'*
Gather the gateway of desire
to unite with the wondrous *Xian* path.

Thus, the Buddha, the World-Honored One, said:
*'With the power of quiescence and cessation, arise in perfect stillness,
abide in purity.'*

Now, as I expound the Dharma,
heavenly spirits gather in throngs,
thunder and fire oversee the altar,
golden youths burn incense and emit fragrance,
jade maidens scatter blossoms,
all sages assemble,
cleansing the dust and vapors.
If you do not believe and accept,
the officials will bind your souls.
All beings, take heed!

Purify your hearts with sincerity—
the spirits cannot be deceived.
Do not be deluded by karmic causes.
The path of loyalty and integrity
is revered by gods and ghosts alike."

What is called *nature* is wood, mercury, spirit, fire, dragon, and snake. What is called *emotion* is metal, lead, essence, water, tiger, and turtle. These are all metaphors.

When spirit moves essence, essence transforms into qi. When metal smelts wood, wood becomes timber. Driving the dragon to the tiger, dragon and tiger rejoice in union. With the heart subduing the body, heart and body harmonize in peace.

chunks.original_text: 以道事君，必慎必勤，勿恣怠傲，勿染贪瞋。 功德不修，虚湛难闻； 尘心未了，仙境难升。 芭蕉献瑞，是　吾阐灵，示尔京畿，以显功臣。 忠于君者，死节犯颜：殷之比干、楚之屈原、周之夷齐、夏之龙逢； 批鳞逆谏：汉之汲黯、朱云，唐之陆贽、魏征； 退隐达士，张良为韩报忠、范蠡去越全生； 守节继死：诸葛武乡、汉寿亭侯、张巡、许远，颜真杲卿。 往古忠烈，垂名丹青，光争日月，位列天庭此段叙述，已伏后演《忠孝诰》之案。 阿谀佞谄，事君逢迎； 贪酷于己，剥膏于民； 苟图荣富，为万世轻。 视乎诸公，辅国忘身，敢不汗颜，赧于衷！ 吾今劝世，为臣以忠，以忠事君，后裔云礽。 忠以尽己，非诬于人。 皇天无亲，亲于有德。 民罔常怀，怀于有仁。 君父之恩，万化原根，引贤勉励，以惩不忠。 参修之士，必先孝忠，信诚仁德，逊悌谦恭。 心正神明，心正慧灵。 自有仙师，度引成功。 虽明丹理，不积行功，损他利己，魔来堑音渐灵。 凡学修真，必炼乎心，博施普济，以本以仁，方便利益，援溺救焚，扶危拯困，乐道信心。 修如是功，名奏玉庭，虚皇有戒，伭帝有文，金科玉律，毫不容情。 救民疾苦，恤民饥穷。 昔汉天师，米谷收凝，遇缺乏时，价苦高腾，或以原价，或减济贫，分毫不增，粜之于民，民赖以济，腹得充荣； 成都黄公，紫府登名。 昔许真君，合药施病，救诸疾苦，获大深功。 昔葛仙翁，行祭炼法，拔度幽冥，一切有情，皆获超升。 今人富贵，自乐肥轻，有腴马，民有菜容。 孰能舍财，宏济于贫，历代师真，道得于心，三官考校，功过昭明：有功之人，保举仙成； 有过之人，罪缚幽魂。 上升之士，非一世功，历劫修来，天性方明。 吾取之人，侍立坛中，皆夙生庆，勿视以轻，当以敬爱。 阐吾法门，勿执一人，而将道闻，在坛之子，皆有道根。 今世愚人，妄言着魔，寸德不施，期步大罗，夸己若仙，嗜广贪多，贪嗜不净，焉出爱河？ 行吾道者，莫择贵贱，操心以仁，戒性以善，不染贪瞋，勿求己便。 损己潜修，天神眷恋； 依此炼修，皇君诏见。 吾今阐法，安执着伭，但绝尘心，道心坦然，广行阴德，回悟三元。 勿听朦师，妄行虚参，一朝气散，怎得符仙？ 此身不修，更待何年？ 离此不得，魂魄茫然； 没下手处，轮回乱穿。 为尔迷失，泪常暗潸，任心不了。 吾难训言，大丹之理，养气调元，但安神息，即是胎还。 所谓真人，潜乎深渊，情性为一，妙理自然。 勿闻渺渺，当信虔虔，信而行之，仙圣同肩。 」
chunks.translated_text:
To serve one's lord with the Dao,
one must be prudent and diligent,
never indulging in idleness or arrogance,
never stained by greed or wrath.
Without cultivating merit and virtue,
emptiness and stillness remain elusive;
with the dust-heart unresolved,
the immortal realms stay beyond reach.

The plantain offers its auspicious sign—
this is my manifestation of the numinous,
revealed to you in the capital,
to honor the meritorious ministers.
Those loyal to their lords,
who die for principle or defy authority:
such were Bi Gan of Yin,
Qu Yuan of Chu,
Bo Yi and Shu Qi of Zhou,
and Long Feng of Xia.
Those who remonstrated boldly,
plucking the dragon’s scales:
Ji An and Zhu Yun of Han,
Lu Zhi and Wei Zheng of Tang.
The reclusive scholars of insight:
Zhang Liang, who repaid loyalty to Han,
Fan Li, who left Yue to preserve his life.
Those who upheld fidelity unto death:
Zhuge, Marquis of Wuxiang,
Lord Guan of Hanshou,
Zhang Xun and Xu Yuan,
Yan Zhen and Gao Xing.
The loyal and steadfast of ancient times,
their names inscribed in crimson and azure,
their glory rivaling sun and moon,
their places secured in the celestial court—
this passage foreshadows the later *Exhortation on Loyalty and Filial Piety*.

Flatterers and sycophants,
who curry favor with their lords,
who enrich themselves through cruelty
and bleed the people of their fat;
who chase fleeting glory and wealth,
are scorned for ten thousand generations.
Behold these paragons,
who aided the state and forgot themselves—
how can one not blush with shame,
crimson to the core?

Now I exhort the world:
to be a minister is to be loyal,
to serve one’s lord with loyalty,
and one’s descendants shall flourish like clouds.
Loyalty is the fulfillment of one’s duty,
not the imposition of falsehood upon others.
Heaven is impartial,
yet favors those with virtue.
The people’s hearts are not constant,
but turn toward those with benevolence.
The grace of lord and father
is the root of all transformations.
I summon the worthy and urge them on,
to chastise disloyalty.

Those who cultivate the Dao
must first embrace filial piety and loyalty,
sincerity, benevolence, and virtue,
humility, deference, and reverence.
With a rectified heart, the spirit becomes luminous;
with a rectified heart, wisdom becomes numinous.
Then the immortal masters will appear,
guiding you to success.
Though one may understand the principles of the elixir,
without accumulating merit,
harming others to benefit oneself,
demons will come to obstruct the spirit.

All who study the true Dao
must refine the heart.
Practice universal generosity and relief,
rooted in benevolence.
Offer aid and benefit,
rescue the drowning and extinguish the burning,
uphold the endangered and succor the distressed,
rejoice in the Dao and hold fast to faith.
Those who cultivate such merit
shall have their names recorded in the Jade Court.
The August Emperor of Emptiness has decrees,
the *Xian* Emperor has texts,
golden precepts and jade statutes—
not a hair’s breadth of leniency.

Relieve the people’s suffering,
succor the hungry and destitute.
Of old, the Celestial Master of Han
condensed grains of rice.
When scarcity struck,
prices soared bitterly,
yet he sold at the original price,
or reduced it to aid the poor,
not raising it by even a fraction,
thus supplying the people.
The people relied on him for sustenance,
their bellies filled and bodies flourished—
Huang of Chengdu,
his name inscribed in the Purple Palace.

Of old, Lord Xu the Perfected
compounded medicines to heal the sick,
relieving all manner of suffering,
earning profound merit.
Of old, Master Ge the Immortal
performed rituals and alchemical rites,
liberating the suffering in the netherworld,
so that all sentient beings
might attain transcendence.

Now, the wealthy and noble
indulge in luxury and ease,
riding sleek horses,
while the people subsist on greens.
Who among them will relinquish wealth
to generously aid the poor?
The perfected masters of past ages
attained the Dao in their hearts.
The Three Officials examine and record,
merits and transgressions made clear:
those with merit
are recommended for immortal ascension;
those with transgressions
are bound in the netherworld as guilty souls.

Those who ascend to the heavens
have not achieved it in a single lifetime,
but through cultivation across kalpas,
their celestial nature at last revealed.
Those I have chosen,
who stand in attendance within the altar,
all bear blessings from past lives—
do not regard them lightly,
but treat them with reverence and love.

In expounding my Dharma-gate,
do not cling to a single person
and withhold the Dao from others.
All who stand within this altar
possess the root of the Dao.

Now, the foolish of this world
rashly speak of demonic possession.
Without even an inch of virtue,
they aspire to the Great Web of Heaven,
boasting of their own immortality,
indulging in excess and greed,
their cravings impure—
how can they escape the river of desire?

Those who practice my Dao
must not discriminate by high or low status,
but govern the heart with benevolence,
restrain the nature with goodness,
avoid the stains of greed and wrath,
and never seek personal convenience.
To diminish oneself in hidden cultivation
draws the affection of celestial spirits;
to refine and cultivate thus
will summon the imperial summons of the August Lord.

Now, as I expound the Dharma,
do not cling stubbornly to the *Xian* path,
but sever the dust-heart,
and the Dao-heart will lie open and serene.
Practice hidden virtue extensively,
awaken to the Three Origins.
Do not heed deluded masters
who engage in vain practices—
when the qi scatters in a single morning,
how can one become an immortal by talisman?

If this body is not cultivated now,
what other year shall one await?
Without departing from this,
the soul wanders in confusion;
without a starting point,
it drifts through the cycles of rebirth.
For your sake, lost in delusion,
my tears flow in secret—
heedless, the heart remains unresolved.

My teachings are difficult to convey:
the principle of the great elixir
is to nurture qi and harmonize the origin,
simply to settle the spirit and still the breath—
this is the return to the womb.
The true person
abides deep in the abyss,
emotion and nature as one,
the wondrous principle arising naturally.

Do not dismiss these words as distant and vague,
but believe with utmost sincerity.
Believe and practice,
and you shall stand shoulder to shoulder with the immortals and sages.

Upon hearing the Master’s discourse, the entire assembly at the altar bowed deeply. Daoist Yiyi then prostrated before the seat and offered this hymn of praise:

The Perfect Sage’s profound scroll
bestows teachings upon the altar,
illuminating the Three Teachings,
gathering the words of all sages.
Through Confucianism and Buddhism,
it clarifies our profound Way;
through loyalty and filial piety,
it opens the minds of the foolish.
Vast virtue reaches to heaven,
benevolence and mercy universally proclaimed,
rescuing all from distress and calamity.
The true essence of kindness,
greatly sagely, greatly merciful,
greatly compassionate, greatly vow-bound,
universally delivering all beings,
establishing karmic connections through scriptures.
Descending upon Jinling,
your numinous radiance shines brightly—
illness is instantly healed,
disaster is immediately dispelled,
surpassing even father and mother.
Vastly manifesting like Maudgalyāyana,
we, by karmic affinity of former lives,
have been granted to hear the Supreme Way.
Inspired by dreams, bestowed with the staff and carriage,
the subtleties of the whispered teachings
are wondrous beyond words.
Those who believe attain,
those who awaken become immortals.
With humble verses, I now extol you before the Master.
When my practice is complete in years to come,
I vow to attend your compassionate presence.

Then Daoist Yiyi, together with the assembly of disciples, bowed repeatedly before the altar, praising without end and expressing profound gratitude. They burned incense and paid homage together. Suddenly, auspicious clouds like a canopy descended before the altar, rare fragrances filled the air, and mist enveloped the earth. The Patriarch returned in his phoenix chariot, and throughout the village, all beings bowed in reverence. Each household turned toward virtue, every person engaged in cultivation. Wherever the rare fragrance reached, no illnesses arose. Every family obtained good fortune, every household manifested auspicious signs. The sagely power was resplendently revealed, and joy knew no bounds. All received the teachings with faith, paid their respects, and withdrew.

*(The above two chapters were first recorded in Jinling. Later, a child from Guangling named Tong Qi obtained them and combined them for wider circulation. Thus, the transmitted version consists of eight chapters divided into upper and lower volumes.)*

**The Supreme Lord Lǚzu’s Scripture of Opening the Celestial Pole and Verifying the True Mystery of the Closed and Open Gate**
**Lower Volume**

**Chapter Five: Faithfully Attaining the Dao**

At that time, the Immortal Master addressed the great assembly of Piling, saying: "I manifested signs across the Five Mounds and the Dragon Sands, responding to past virtues. Though my ascent and descent through the cycles of rebirth were not complete, the wondrous Dao of immortals was fully revealed. Thus, the female immortal of Tanyin in Tai Cang, Nanyang, whose original transmission traces to Tanluan, attained the immortal realm as proof of her Dao. The virtuous maiden Lian of Xiangshan County cultivated the causes and verified the fruit of Buddhahood. All achieved this by upholding faith, while those without intention attained realization.

I, by the mandate of the Supreme Emperor, descended into the mortal realm solely for the sake of sentient beings, who turn their backs on principle and violate virtue, cruelly harming others, bending the straight to crookedness, mixing flattery with benevolence, rebelling against rulers and parents above, and scorning their villages below. They fish for empty reputations, set traps to harm lives, and scheme to deceive others. As a result, the sagely ruler sends down calamities—floods, fires, plagues, and punishments—yet they do not repent or reform. Their karmic obstructions accumulate like clouds.

I have preached the scriptures in Yangzhou and Jinling. Among the assembly at the altar, barely one in a hundred believed, while countless others slandered. Unable to settle the spirit and establish destiny, they instead toy with cleverness and forget their true nature. The arts of flattery and deceit fill heaven and earth. They boast of their own abilities, delude their ancestors, and deceive the gods. Instead of quieting their minds, they indulge in karmic actions, unable to restrain themselves. They falsely depict emptiness, like a mantis brandishing its arms or a frog croaking in vain, obstructing the supreme Way. Though not without perception, they drift in the dark sea, ungrateful for the Emperor’s grace. Yangzhou was arrogant, Jinling lacked sincerity—compared to you, Piling, you must cultivate solemn reverence.

Having returned to my teachings, spread virtue and practice benevolence. Uphold filial piety, loyalty, and trust, and diminish the self to bring peace to others. All living beings, even the lowliest creatures, cherish life—do not harm them, but show compassion for all that heaven has created. Human nature is originally pure, yet obscured by external things. When the spirit is employed in the dust, it becomes dimmed by the dust.

The Way of Heaven follows its course without emotion, nurturing the myriad forms, embracing and sustaining all. The celestial body is round, with latitude and longitude. By day, it rotates from left to right; by night, from right to left. In harmony with the four seasons, it knows neither cold nor heat, creating and extinguishing the ten thousand things without awareness of creation or extinction. Existing without knowing, it endures; being without birth, it is luminous. Those who embody this may attain longevity.

The Way of longevity lies in its wondrous application by humans. Heaven relies on Earth, revolving through the great void without obstruction. Earth relies on Heaven, remaining still to adhere to qi, never falling or collapsing. Human essence is to Heaven as Earth is to Heaven, born in the Kan palace and residing within a single qi. Just as Earth revolves with Heaven to generate the myriad things, essence transforms through qi to govern the hundred bodily forms. If essence does not transform, emotional defilement causes collapse; if Earth does not revolve, extreme yin leads to ruin.

Advancing fire and retreating talisman follow Heaven’s left and right. Yin and yang grasp each other, the moon shifts within the sun. Nurture within and guard without, qi continues and spirit functions. Achieve harmony through emptiness, abiding in sincerity. The heart is not a heart—it is the spirit; qi is not breath—it is the numinous void.

Guard it like Penglai, shape it like an egg, visualize it as an unbroken ring—how dare one describe it? The Supreme Lord said: ‘Excessive speech exhausts the lunar cycle; better to abide in the center.’ Thus, one should constantly illuminate, neither scattered nor congealed. Practicing thus, the medicine circulates throughout the body. Warmly nurture the childlike pearl, and the hundred meridians flow freely. Preserve the original essence, refine the original form.

If essence is insufficient, supplement it with flavor; if form is insufficient, supplement it with qi. The southwest yields companions—this is the method for supplementing qi. Call the child with the mother, and like attracts like. Thoughts must not arise—arising brings the flame of fire; intention must not scatter—scattering brings the cold of fire.

Though the story of standing in snow at Cheng Yi’s gate pertains to events after Lǚzu’s verification of immortality, the perfected ones of the highest realms observe past and future without being bound by worldly eras. Moreover, the texts cited within this scripture, such as *Awakening to Reality* by Ziyang, are all from later times. *Entering the Medicine Realm* states: ‘Water fears drying, fire fears cold; deviate by a hair’s breadth, and the elixir will not form.’"

chunks.original_text: 』又曰：『水能流，火能，在身中，自可验。 黜聪明，绝视听，内照元真，外忘物用，兼修信诚，自然慧定，立信之源，非诚莫，以圮音夷桥进履为心，以程门立雪为教。 范张鸡黍，约期不忘； 管鲍交谊，与利无较； 季扎挂剑，事死如生； 郭伋竹马，儿童遮道。 以信于君必忠，以信于亲必孝，以信朋友必久，以信处必和，以信修道必昌，以信祀神必效。 修行以信为宗，若执狐疑必暴，若还失信于人，天神必加果报。 皇天岂谬于物，大道由诚而得，有德必有其言，有言未必有德，得道如痴如愚，岂可诳言削福？ 临财不恋于财，临色不贪于色。 超灵脱窍之功，致知而在格物。 仲尼问礼问官，宣圣尚然未足，知之可以为知，不知莫谈已得，忍辱必成至人，虚己自然受益。 传曰：『危者安其位，亡者保其存。 』大哉赞易之要！ 故坤以简能，干以易知。 易则易知，简则易从。 天下之理，贵乎其中！ 阴顺阳健，由简而成，所以易道，厥配丹功，知易变化，仙途可登。 所云『金丹』，竟是何物？ 金属坎水，丹属离火。 离火配心，非血肉心，乃云元神； 坎水配精，非交感精，乃先天金。 以神运精，精不飞腾，不飞不腾，名为元精。 此元精者，为命灵根。 所以还丹，谓还其心，外境不迷，内境自澄。 心即是丹，丹即是心，能悟之者，可保丹心，丹心即道，丹道即心。 息因胎住，胎因息存，息从心起，心静息融，调息之道，息息归根。 根非有根，由而生； 存无所存，存一于中。 贯乎伭牝，达运天庭。 尔不精通，休说道深！ 汝能行之，空谷传声，非谷得声，由空则宏，能空外境，六魔潜形。 」 即说咒曰：嗟彼红尘中　　尽溺利与名　　不知性保命　　妄谈死与生弗究生杀机　　枉将性命穷　　未死先学死　　逢生则杀生万物生复死　　元神死复生　　此生不尘了　　空诵万千经但把诸缘尽　　方能众虑空　　慧剑可戮妖　　妖平大道明九层台不登　　何以见虚空　　时人凭口讲　　口会心未能由心不由口　　由心道自成　　安得由心者　　吾将铅汞倾 仙师说经已毕。 复告大众曰：「若有众生，见闻是经，体而行之，即使三尸远退，众邪不干，万神加庇，但要远尘静事，守心定性，仙阶可步。 还有精气神经三品，乃秘奥伭文，归根要旨，共完八品，象易两仪六虚之义。 汝等积仁修德，　吾当普授于世，若各坛嫉矜傲，不能授此仙机。 判经之地，尚未择取，惟信心皈　吾者得之。 尔当信受，吾必孚灵。 遇后三经，蓬莱即诣。 」 师说经毕。

Moreover, it states: ‘Water flows, fire blazes—within the body, this can be verified for oneself. Dismiss cleverness, sever seeing and hearing; inwardly illuminate the original true, outwardly forget the use of things. Cultivate both trust and sincerity, and wisdom and stillness will naturally arise. The source of establishing trust lies in nothing but sincerity—take Yu the Great’s offering of shoes at the ruined bridge as your heart, and Cheng Yi’s standing in snow as your teaching.

Fan and Zhang’s shared meal, never forgetting their appointed time; Guan and Bao’s friendship, uncalculating of gain; Ji Zha’s hanging of his sword, serving the dead as if alive; Guo Ji’s bamboo horse, with children blocking the road—by being trustworthy to one’s lord, one must be loyal; by being trustworthy to one’s parents, one must be filial; by being trustworthy to friends, the bond must endure; by being trustworthy in affairs, harmony must prevail; by being trustworthy in Daoist cultivation, success must flourish; by being trustworthy in offering to the gods, efficacy must manifest.

Cultivation takes trust as its foundation. Clinging to doubt invites ruin; breaking trust with others brings karmic retribution from the heavenly spirits. How could the August Heaven be deceptive toward beings? The Great Dao is attained through sincerity. Those with virtue must have their words, but those with words do not necessarily have virtue. Those who attain the Dao appear foolish and dull—how could they deceive with words and diminish their fortune? Facing wealth, do not be attached to wealth; facing beauty, do not be greedy for beauty.

The work of transcending the spirit and liberating the aperture lies in extending knowledge through the investigation of things. Confucius inquired about ritual and offices, yet even the proclaimed sage found himself insufficient. Knowing is sufficient for knowledge; not knowing, do not claim attainment. Enduring humiliation will perfect the perfected one; emptying the self naturally brings benefit.

The *Transmission* says: ‘Those in peril secure their position; those on the verge of ruin preserve their existence.’ How great is the essence of the *Book of Changes*! Thus, *Kun* excels through simplicity, *Qian* through ease of understanding. Ease allows for understanding; simplicity allows for following. The principles of the world prize their mean!

Yin’s compliance and yang’s vigor arise from simplicity and achieve completion. Thus, the Dao of *Change* corresponds to the work of the elixir. Knowing the transformations of *Change*, the immortal’s path may be ascended. What, then, is this so-called ‘Golden Elixir’? Metal pertains to *Kan* Water, cinnabar pertains to *Li* Fire. *Li* Fire corresponds to the heart—not the heart of blood and flesh, but the original spirit; *Kan* Water corresponds to essence—not the essence of intercourse, but the prenatal metal.

With spirit moving essence, essence does not fly or soar—when it neither flies nor soars, it is called original essence. This original essence is the root of life’s numinous power. Thus, the Returned Elixir means returning to the heart. When external realms do not delude, internal realms naturally clarify. The heart is the elixir; the elixir is the heart. Those who awaken to this may preserve the cinnabar heart. The cinnabar heart is the Dao; the cinnabar Dao is the heart.

Breath rests in the womb; the womb persists through breath. Breath arises from the heart; when the heart is still, breath merges. The Dao of regulating breath lies in each breath returning to the root. The root is not a root—it arises from *qi*; to preserve is to preserve nothing, to preserve the One within.

It penetrates the Mysterious Female and reaches the Celestial Court. If you are not thoroughly versed, do not speak of profound depths! If you can practice this, the empty valley transmits sound—not that the valley gains sound, but that emptiness makes it vast. By emptying external realms, the Six Demons conceal their forms.”

Then he spoke the incantation, saying:
Alas, those in the red dust,
All drowned in profit and fame,
Unknowing of preserving life’s nature,
Idly debating death and life.
Failing to examine the mechanism of life and death,
Vainly exhausting life’s nature.
Learning death before death,
Encountering life, they kill life.
All things live and die,
The original spirit dies and lives again.
If this life is not resolved in the dust,
Reciting myriad scriptures is in vain.
Only by exhausting all conditions
Can the host of thoughts be emptied.
The sword of wisdom can slay demons;
When demons are pacified, the Great Dao shines.
Without ascending the nine-tiered terrace,
How can one see the empty sky?
People of this age rely on mouth to speak,
The mouth may speak, but the heart cannot.
Not from the mouth, but from the heart—
From the heart, the Dao naturally forms.
How can one act from the heart?
I shall pour forth lead and mercury.

When the Immortal Master finished expounding the scripture, he again addressed the assembly, saying: “If there are beings who see or hear this scripture and embody its practice, the Three Corpses will retreat afar, all demonic influences will not intrude, and the myriad spirits will grant their protection. Only by distancing oneself from worldly affairs and guarding the heart to stabilize the nature can one ascend the immortal’s ranks.

There are also the three treasures of essence, qi, and spirit—profound and arcane texts, the essentials of returning to the root, altogether completing eight grades, symbolizing the meaning of the *Changes*’ Two Modes and Six Voids. You have accumulated benevolence and cultivated virtue; I shall universally bestow this upon the world. If in each altar there is jealousy, arrogance, or pride, this immortal mechanism cannot be transmitted. The place for judging the scripture has not yet been selected; only those who sincerely take refuge in me may receive it. You must faithfully accept it, and I will surely manifest my numinous power. Upon encountering the subsequent three scriptures, Penglai will come to you.”

The Master finished expounding the scripture.

At that time, the Immortal Master spoke: “In a former kalpa, during the first year of the Tianbao era, on the ninth day of the first month, I ascended the Yu Luo Void Brahma Heavenly Palace and attended the *Xu Huang* Heavenly Worthy—*Xu Huang* being the Primordial Beginning—alongside the Ten Ultimate Perfected Ones, where the *Great Zhou Scripture of Cinnabar Alchemy for Subduing Fire* was expounded. At that time, boundless sacred assemblies from the ten directions, the Southern Asterism and Northern Dipper, the Three Officials and Four Saints, the Three Realms and Five Peaks, along with exalted perfected beings of wondrous conduct, all gathered in the Cloud Palace to hear the great Dharma.

Then the Heavenly Worthy addressed the assembled perfected ones, saying: ‘Because the people of the world, sunk in karmic delusion, drown in the sea of desire, I have repeatedly dispatched perfected beings of wondrous conduct, along with the host of immortals, to descend into the mortal realm and disseminate the *Great Vehicle Numinous Treasure Scripture of Salvation in All Its Chapters*, eighteen thousand scrolls in all, scattered across the four great divine continents of the world. Yet the blind multitudes of the four seas know only to chant its words, failing to awaken to its power. Their flattery lacks sincerity, their transgressions accumulate day by day, their hearts harbor the three poisons and their mouths the four faults. They fall into the turning wheel of retribution, their bones lost in the rushing torrent of suffering, ensnared by the hindrances of hell, cast into the destinies of beasts, and find it difficult to regain human form. Born from evil retribution, they clog the cosmos, beyond all hope of deliverance—deeply pitiable indeed.’”

At my great-grandfather’s time, he served as Military Commissioner of Zhejiang East; my grandfather was Vice Minister of Rites; and my father was Prefect of Haizhou. The Perfected One again instructed me, saying: ‘You have repeatedly cultivated the Dao and virtue, your name inscribed in the registers of immortality, your merit and conduct now complete, revered by all the Heavenly Worthies. Yet your worldly ties remain unsevered, and so in the future world of the Tang’s latter age, in the fourteenth year of the Zhenyuan reign, the wu-yin year, on the fourteenth day of the fourth month at the si hour, you shall be born a son in the Lü family of Henan. I command the Three Perfected—Kuzhu, Huolong, and Zhengyang—to transmit and confer the Dao upon you, that you may ascend the ranks of immortality. You shall incarnate in the world to propagate my teachings and guide all celestial and mortal beings back to the true teaching.’

I received the mandate and took birth in the Lü household. From childhood I was precocious, understanding filial piety and fraternal duty, careful in speech and action, moderating joy and anger, and urging my father to distribute grain to relieve famine. Later, when I set out for the examinations, I encountered the Perfected Master Zhengyang. In a dream of millet, I awoke to his teachings, abandoned office to cultivate the real, and my name was enrolled on Penglai, where I attend the Golden Gates of the Jade Emperor’s palace.

Again I received the August Emperor’s decree to rescue the deluded world, expound scriptures, and transform and deliver beings. I demonstrated the stages of nature and life, exhorted the roots of loyalty and filial piety, and with my fellow immortals compiled this scripture into eight chapters: the first and second chapters I left in Guangling; the third and fourth I entrusted to Jinling; the fifth I taught to the assemblies of Piling and others. Now I descend with the refined qi of the sixth and seventh chapters to Xinzhou, conferring them upon your assembly. The remaining eighth chapter, with its methods for refining spirit and returning to emptiness, its numinous talismans and true incantations, I shall transmit in Linjiang, keeping it secret and uncirculated. I instruct each locale to carve and print the complete scripture for exchange. Those of sincere faith shall find it efficacious; those who obscure its principles shall remain benighted. Yet I seal not the scripture but your heart—those who awaken shall attain it, those who comprehend shall achieve it.

Within these *Eight-Chapter Scriptures*, each passage soothes the numinous, refines form and preserves the body, stills qi and nurtures spirit. Though its phrases are plain and its principles unadorned, those who grasp its meaning shall propagate it widely. Essence, qi, and spirit are called the Three Numinous. Original essence and lustful essence are not two essences; original qi and the qi of respiration are fundamentally one qi. The heart is originally empty, yet nature has no dual substance. The great void is vast and bright—if you would transform essence, first guard your nature; if you would regulate qi, first empty your heart. In movement, nurture qi; in stillness, refine emptiness. Respond without acting, awaken without following.

Thus, through extreme emptiness and profound stillness, qi turns and spirit returns—not to be sought through merit and virtue, nor achieved through righteousness and ritual. If you practice righteousness, ritual, merit, and virtue, these are but embellishments of the dust. Embrace the origin, nurture simplicity, forget things and contain emptiness. In the midst of profound obscurity, true essence shall return of itself. Essence has no fixed abode; it dissipates through emotion. If essence does not follow desire, it fortifies the foundation of your numinous being. Through original essence it transforms into original mercury; through original qi it accumulates the bodily shell. The kidneys are the mansion where essence lodges; the heart contains the domain of original qi. Essence permeates the five viscera—if drowned in emotion, it becomes lustful; qi flows through the six bowels—if it departs the apertures, it is drawn in and exhaled.

If you do not know how to nurture qi, essence cannot be cultivated; if you do not know how to preserve essence, qi cannot return. When qi returns to the original sea, essence is preserved; when qi scatters through the six gates, essence flies away. Though the kidneys are the cavern where essence resides, it is spirit that moves essence. Thunder arises from the depths of water—yin harbors yang to form *zhun*; water moistens beneath the mountain—yang spreads through yin to form *meng*. Without knowing fermentation, fire dries and explodes; without understanding refinement, metal drowns and fails to ascend.

People of this world, blind and deaf, claim to see what they do not see, to hear what they do not hear. Deluded by fame and profit, they indulge in arrogance; dazzled by the five colors, they are ruined by the five sounds. Cultivate blood and refine essence to preserve your numinous root. The true marrow of the red tortoise transforms into *geng* and *xin*; the yellow sprout emerges from the earth to unite with *qian* and *kun*. The two qi of heart and kidney come and go, swallowing each other. The right kidney pertains to yin and is the seat of the *po*; the left kidney pertains to yang and is the seat of the *hun*. The lungs transmit the heart’s fluids to moisten the kidneys; the liver gathers original essence to nourish the heart. When the kidneys are cultivated, the tortoise retracts its head; when the heart is nurtured, the dragon conceals its scales. If spirit does not shift in countenance, essence is preserved; if essence does not scatter through desire, qi harmonizes.

Restrain the full belly to one, reveal the empty heart to the numinous. Refine it with gentle fire, nurture it with arid effort. Now soaring, now hidden; now forgotten, now preserved. Use it without exhaustion, guard it without congealing. Thus being and non-being give rise to each other, difficulty and ease complete each other. The tiger’s breast bears metal—when kidney qi is sufficient, liver qi is born. Through liver qi, the residual yin of the kidneys is severed, and kidney qi passing through the liver becomes pure yang. The dragon’s tally bears fire—when heart fluids prevail, lung fluids flourish. Through lung fluids, the residual yang of the heart is severed, and heart fluids passing through the lungs become pure yin. Within yin, refine yang; within yang, refine yin. Draw water from the kidneys, extract metal from qi. The nature of metal is heavy and fond of sinking—thus it moistens downward and readily leaks; the nature of fire is light and fond of rising—thus it flames upward and readily scorches. Use metal to restrain fire, the heavy to restrain the light.

After the winter solstice, yang ascends from the earth, and the earth withdraws its yin. Greater yin is withdrawn to become reverting yin; lesser yang is added to become yang brightness. Reverting yin is withdrawn to become lesser yin; yang brightness is added to become greater yang. After the summer solstice, yin descends from heaven, and heaven withdraws its yang. Greater yang is withdrawn to become yang brightness; lesser yin is added to become reverting yin. Yang brightness is withdrawn to become lesser yang; reverting yin is added to become greater yin. As the sun bestows its spirit upon the moon and the moon receives the sun’s essence, so too with withdrawal and addition—those of wisdom must understand. Use water to restrain fire, and fire shall have no fault of scorching wood; use fire to restrain water, and water shall have the merit of activating metal.

Still the heart and take seated meditation as your method—if the heart is not stilled, you shall be troubled by demons. Nurture qi and take reticence in speech as your duty—if reticence slackens, you shall be deluded by evil. Solidify your essence—not through the transformation of qi, or essence shall drown and bring harm...

Nurture your qi, yet without grasping the root of essence, and qi shall be difficult to manifest. Thus we know: essence governs qi, qi governs spirit, and spirit unites with emptiness—only then are the Three Powers accomplished.

Thereupon he spoke this gatha:
One is the root of Heaven and Earth,
All beings depend on its life-giving power.
From the One, the Three unfold all transformations.
Proclaimed as Heaven, Earth, and Human—
Human, the spirit among the ten thousand things.
The Three Powers reside within this body,
Yet what does this body treasure?
Its treasure is essence, qi, and spirit.

Earth was not yet split from yin,
Yet within it lay true yang.
Heaven was not yet split from yang,
Yet within it lay true yin.
Humans embody both yin and yang—
Why not refine your true nature?
The world, deluded, remains unawakened,
Abandoning the root to chase illusions.

I recall my own transformation in the womb,
Achieved through sudden severance.
Form merged with the body of emptiness,
Only then was I called "feather-transcended."

Pitying the world’s suffering,
I preach the Dao to the blind and deaf.
Yet the blind remain sightless,
The deaf still do not hear.
Living in vain, they die in vain,
Trapped in the wheel of karmic delusion.
If only they would trust and cultivate the heart,
I would guide them to ascend.

Soon the immortal writ shall descend,
Fish and dragons shall discern false from true.
Only when you awaken to Heaven and Earth’s principles
May you be called a true person.

The immortal master again addressed the assembly:
"This scripture I expound is the treasure of essence.
Whoever believes and receives it shall realize the true origin.
Where this scripture remains, those who cultivate the Dao in seclusion—
One thousand one hundred shall attain the fruit,
Five hundred more shall be summoned to verify immortal rank.
Each shall receive transmission
And ascend to the celestial capital,
All promoted in heavenly office.
Now still your hearts, regulate your qi,
Refine spirit, and nurture emptiness.
Based on your diligent practice,
I shall again memorialize on your behalf."

chunks.original_text: 众等稽首师真，作礼而退。 气合伭元品第七 尔时　仙师又曰：「黄帝训言：『观天之道，执天之行。 』二语即《阴符经》，人能礼之，可以长生。 天地随气而化，阴阳升降，有经有纬，寒暑相承。 试譬谕尔，尔当谛听： 日之所经，谓之『黄道』。 横络天腹，中分二极，谓之『赤道』，平分天体。 春夏之交，阳极生阴，天行速急，而其气清，故五日为候，三候为气，六气为时，四时为年。 一年之候，三百六十，真气结聚。 八万四千，和之气，在于中焉：四万二千，上为阳位； 四万二千，下为阴位。 天虽为阳，而存真阴； 地虽为阴，而发真阳。 冬至之节，气发乎阳，一气上升，至七千里，循之六气上升，四万二千里数，阳至阴位，故气常温。 应乎春分，再升六气，阳气已极，故气酷热而为夏至。 夏至之候，阴气出天，一气下降，至七千里，循之六气下降，四万二千里数，阴至阳位，故气爽凉，为之秋分。 再降六气，阴气已极，故气严寒，而为冬至。 阴阳互合，二气相承，阳中有阴，资之下降，降极至阳； 阴中有阳，资之上升，升极至阴。 阳阴两育，古长存。 人质两仪，气结父母，心环斗极，形合神存，天秉斗机，人秉心枢。 心有二穴，左伭右牝，下入契海，上通伭虚，阴阳之鼎，实心统之。 阳中之阴，纯圣驳愚。 心枢之上，天元主之； 心枢之下，地元主之。 流行运化，契合两仪。 天一生水，在人曰精； 地二生火，在人曰神； 天三生木，在人曰魂； 地四生金，在人曰魄； 天五生土，在人曰体。 五行混一，三极凝居，两仪化育，海产明珠。 肾为精府，阴中之阳。 精受于阳，聚而灵者曰『魄』，日以附月，譬之于人，以魂育魄； 气受于阳，散而神者曰『魂』，月质受日，譬之于人，以魄检魂。 阴阳化育，二气良能，天得气成，地得气荣，人得其气，可造长生。 守其真形，形神自灵，忘言息虑，卫血炼精，神以炼气，气以藏神。 火轮真主，坐镇中宫，心如自虚，气以自灵，黄芽出土，妙理须穷。 虚无尘色，道发干宫，息其神气，养其根灵。 肾有一百九十二根弦丝，炼铅归，化神滋，光明大海，飞出赤鸡。 肾气传肝，肝气传心，心下交，如日施德，月以舒光，阳秉阴受，雌雄相须。 恒顺地理，承天布宣。 心常驭气，气融精化； 心常顾息，神存气留。 上炼伭精，以补其脑； 中炼元精，以补其神； 下炼金精，以补其肾。 上调其神，中调其气，下调其精。 精非其精，精由气成； 气非其气，由气育神。 精气若隳音灰，神何以宁。 保精曰『命』，守神曰『性』。 气属黄婆，调神驭精，结为三友，水火平匀。 譬之媒媾，以谐婚姻。 伭珠产就，定意聚真，天精地髓，金浮木沉，火光烛金，金气浮空，上朝紫府，壁破山冲，河车上下，犬化鸡升，剥复否泰，弦望晦明，阴阳消长，坎水金精，血化白膏，变立乾坤。 丹田涌火，真气熏蒸，烹铅炼汞，木母金公。 二八会乎壬丙，一三炼乎甲庚。 性命关键，颠倒之功，鸾车凤辇，玉殿丹宫，种黍珠海底，起赤龙潭中，地雷震动，天雨滋生，龙潜虎伏，理寒温，无中生有，理妙机深，六洞尘无，三台景明，万神朝祖，一气归根。 太乙元君，栖泥丸官，挈其子气，摄灵光升，震霹雳而不知，临刀刃而不惊，吹之以无孔之笛，抚之以无弦之琴。
