s is true sacredness,
Sacredness beyond sacredness.
Dwelling within the heavens,
It is the root of heaven and earth;
Dwelling within humans,
It is the ancestor of the human body.

Those who cultivate nature and life,
Cultivators of the Dao,
Must cultivate this ancestral root.
When the ancestral root is complete,
The ten thousand qi congeal,
Qi returns to life,
Life governs nature,
Nature is qi, life is Dao,
Sacredness is truth, ancestor is root—
This is Yuanshi,
The wondrous Dao of Jade Clarity.

chunks.original_text: 其中复出，微妙异香，化为氤氲，和霭之气，布诸天诸地之处，一切天人，餐是伭气，皆各满足，无有厌者。 以斯胜概，集诸天人，咸至其下，俄见上清，圣境廓开，现诸楼阁，琪花珠宝，玉树琼枝，仙禽异兽，各各一名，罔可形状。 又现一切殿阁楼台，金碧辉煌，霞彩灿烂，一切真圣，伭宰高士，星冠剑履，环佩琚，往来出入，各显妙相。 复有天真玉女之辈，霞髻云鬟，琼佩彩裳，各捧摩尼宝珠一粒，环绕道前，忽现天尊神人之像，狰狞奇状，各执利刃，弓矢戈戟，现三首眼，各能言视，化六手臂，各有捧持，环立拱护，变化无端，是诸天人，远观遐瞩音竹，莫能相即，赞叹希有，无有异者。 夫此妙境，罕所觏闻，罕有能至，至伭至妙，几绝形容，岂知此中，更有伭奥，挹其伭奥，真为叵测，太极浑涵，万象具足。 以一黍米，藏诸世界； 以一芥子，纳诸须弥；
chunks.translated_text:
Within it arises again
a subtle, wondrous fragrance,
transforming into misty vapors—
an atmosphere of harmony and radiance—
that spreads throughout the heavens and the earth,
pervading all places.
All heavenly beings and humans
feast upon this ethereal qi,
each fully sated,
none growing weary.

By this sublime spectacle,
the hosts of heaven and humanity
gather beneath it.
Suddenly, the sacred realm of Shangqing unfolds,
revealing towers and pavilions,
flowers of jade and pearls,
trees of jasper with branches of coral,
celestial birds and rare beasts,
each bearing a singular name,
beyond all description.

Again appear halls and pavilions,
terraces and towers,
shimmering in gold and azure,
resplendent with rosy clouds,
where all true sages,
ethereal lords, and lofty adepts,
adorned in star-crowned headdresses and sword-girded sandals,
circlets and jade pendants,
come and go,
each displaying their wondrous forms.

There are also the jade maidens of the heavens,
their hair bound in rosy clouds,
adorned in rainbow-hued robes and jasper ornaments,
each bearing a single mani jewel,
encircling the Way before them.
Suddenly appears the image of the Heavenly Worthy,
a divine figure of fierce and wondrous form,
each wielding sharp blades,
bows and arrows, spears and halberds,
manifesting three heads and eyes,
each capable of speech and sight,
transforming six arms,
each holding something different,
standing in a ring to guard and protect,
their transformations boundless.

All heavenly beings and humans,
gazing from afar,
cannot draw near,
lost in praise and wonder,
none differing in their awe.

This wondrous realm,
rarely glimpsed or heard of,
few can ever reach.
Most subtle and marvelous,
nearly beyond all description—
who would know that within it
lies yet deeper mystery?
To fathom its depths
is truly unfathomable.
The Great Ultimate embraces all,
all phenomena complete within it.

A single grain of millet
holds all worlds;
a single mustard seed
contains Mount Sumeru.

chunks.original_text: 以一毫端，建诸梵剎； 以一微尘，现诸法像； 以一窍声，化亿万声； 以一孔气，变千万形。 俄而日月，任其盘旋； 俄而风雷，恣其怒号。 以有为无，原无而有，非真非幻，造化无方。 是诸灵宝，出大妙音，为诸真宰，启诸道藏，宣说灵妙无量之法，传以清静不二之仪，金符玉篆，科律森严，传授秘密，无上心印，金章玉质，丹黄妙色，无极伭文，转授天人，流布尘世，依科修奉，乃者天尊，慈悲度劫，各以所得，灵宝心印，妙法真传，金科玉律，下度人世，遇诸真人，道德崇高，可与授者。 遂设玉局，亲相指示，广被遐裔，流诸后世，罔敢不遵，缘是慈肠，遂各苦行，以衍无疆，历千万劫，保固天地，燮理阴阳，调和元气，养育群品，利赖幽明，超证神仙，安奠五岳，建宰五方，化及草木，莫有异者。 是此妙法，天子得之，建太平治； 诸候得之，立齐治本；
chunks.translated_text:
Within a single hair’s tip,
myriad Brahma-kingdoms stand;
within a single mote of dust,
all dharma-images appear.
From one aperture’s sound,
a hundred million voices arise;
from one pore’s qi,
a thousand myriad forms transform.

In an instant, sun and moon
wheel at will;
in an instant, wind and thunder
rage and roar unchecked.
Turning being into non-being,
tracing non-being back to being,
neither real nor illusory,
creation knows no fixed method.

These numinous treasures
emit the Great Wondrous Sound,
for all true lords,
opening the Daoist canon,
proclaiming boundless subtle dharmas,
transmitting the pure, non-dual rite.
Golden talismans and jade scripts,
precepts stern and strict,
secret transmissions,
the supreme mind-seal.
Golden writs and jade essence,
cinnabar and yellow wondrous hues,
the Limitless Profound Text,
passed on to gods and humans,
disseminated through the dusty world.
Following the precepts in cultivation and reverence—

Then the Heavenly Worthy,
in compassion, saves across kalpas.
Each, with what they have received—
the mind-seal of the Numinous Treasure,
the true transmission of the wondrous dharma,
the golden precepts and jade statutes—
descends to deliver the human realm,
encountering perfected beings,
of lofty virtue and power,
worthy of receiving it.

Thereupon, a jade altar is set,
with personal instruction given,
widely bestowed upon distant descendants,
flowing through later generations.
None dare disobey.
Moved by this compassionate heart,
each undertakes ascetic practice,
to propagate without end,
through thousands of myriad kalpas,
fortifying heaven and earth,
harmonizing yin and yang,
regulating primordial qi,
nurturing all beings,
benefiting both the hidden and the manifest,
transcending to attain immortality,
stabilizing the Five Peaks,
governing the Five Directions,
transforming even grasses and trees,
none differing in this.

This wondrous dharma—
when the Son of Heaven obtains it,
he establishes great peace and governance;
when the feudal lords obtain it,
they establish the foundation of harmonious rule.

chunks.original_text: 士庶得之，厥身以正； 鸟兽得之，厥性以灵； 昆虫得之，而全其命； 草木得之，而遂其生； 山川得之，而钟灵异； 湖海得之，而储其神； 修道之士，得此至要，正位天真； 儒流得之，而文明盛； 释氏得之，而见性真； 凡诸无情，无声无色，得此妙法，各悟原因； 幽明罪众得之，而永脱乎轮回。 故知妙法，无可思议，无可想象，无可言说，无可指示。 以我观物，以物观理，以理观数，以数观天，以天观道，以道观法，因法成象，因象成形，因形成质，因质成名，因名成物，因物成人，因人成教。 爰有　太上，宗灵宝法，垂范后人，故知上清真境妙法，开道德教，无穷无极，岂不微乎？ 岂不微乎？ 是此　太上，原于　元始，传于　灵宝，降生尘世，示诸灵异，圣躬诞育，须皓然，凡诸语言文字伭奥，无用师资，各体其要，各会其微。 浩劫之前，一切因缘，各各明了； 浩劫以后，一切道法，各各贯通。 上极于天，上天之载，一切伭微，各各彻悟； 下极于地，至于幽冥，一切秘密，各各了然； 中极人事，伦常道德，礼乐国政，度数文章，至理渊微，至道伭要，一切宏纲，细目端委，各各通达，心心印证。 至圣尼山，深相赞叹，古今希有，以斯绝伦，妙质殊才，帝观伭微，具大神通，无边法力，悯诸众生，罕闻大道，如聋如瞽，盲心昧志，爰阐灵章，极五千言，发扬道德，清静无为，至伭真要，奥理昌明，教法广备，罔有遗旨。 爰有至人，诞生其时，隐诸下吏，为关门尹，法讳曰喜。 生而灵异，聪慧超群，一瞬息间，千行俱透，博极群书，广参伭奥，惜乎无传，一间未达。 迩者　太上，放太毫光，烛照是处，产此异人，实为道器，可传斯旨，乃驾青牛，西度函关。 惟时至人，默坐伭眄音勉，知有真人，自东而来，爰伸积愫，长跽道旁，丐求伭秘。 是时　太上，知是传人，乃着《道德真经》授之。 是此至人，言下大悟，豁然了了，遂得天地不传妙宝，永垂至教，被于无疆，因着《文始真经》九篇，阐扬道德。 太上以斯妙道有传，至教已立，后世永赖，乃复一气，归于太清，大赤宫中，为道宗师。 是此天宫，在太清境，为诸天地，伭关至奥，一切天尊，帝释真宰，圣贤仙道，佛菩提祖，皆从此天，印证伭奥，得闻斯秘，乃可得入大罗仙班。 是兹天宫，为伭之键，一切有为，无为至圣，至神真人，如欲得观灵宝妙相，乃欲更进，仰窥玉清，圣境庄严，必从是天，经历伭妙，或幸得睹。 是此太清，为神仙都，凡诸境界，一切胜境，光景回异，是诸异卉奇葩音巴香艳，炫睛耀目，素所希见。 复有山陵溪谷，怪石异木，灵岩绝壑，藏诸珍禽异兽，虎文豹采，墨麟白鹤，青鸟赤凤之物，种种不同，变现灵异，各有殊观，又复各现云台方文，绮阁雕楹，朱薨音萌画槛，白玉为街，黄金甃音绉砌，五色宝石，布诸地。 其中复有上伭真宰，天尊大圣，羽士黄冠，金童玉女，各佩五色云霞之衣，从容雅步，出入逍遥，自然快乐。 内复有诸天神云将，或御音求龙，或驾赤虎，各执宝械，环卫诸天。 是时　太上默坐睇膝，无所宣示，尔乃　五帝长跽音忌几前，乞法垂教，俯恭恪，未敢遽起。 太上慈颜，忽尔开霁，乃为　五老指示精微，慨尔言曰：「吾之至教，久着一经，名曰道德，授于尹喜，传流人世，依教持行，登证仙道。
chunks.translated_text:
When scholars and commoners obtain it, their persons become upright;
when birds and beasts obtain it, their natures become numinous;
when insects obtain it, they preserve their lives;
when grasses and trees obtain it, they fulfill their growth;
when mountains and rivers obtain it, they gather wondrous essence;
when lakes and seas obtain it, they store their spirit.
Those who cultivate the Dao, obtaining this supreme essential,
rightly assume their place among the Celestial Perfected.
Confucians who obtain it flourish in civil brilliance;
Buddhists who obtain it perceive the true nature of existence.
Even the insentient—soundless and formless—
obtaining this wondrous dharma, each awakens to its original cause.
The hidden and the manifest, the sinful multitudes who obtain it,
forever escape the wheel of rebirth.

Thus it is known: this wondrous dharma
is beyond thought, beyond imagination,
beyond speech, beyond indication.
Through me one observes things,
through things one observes principle,
through principle one observes number,
through number one observes heaven,
through heaven one observes the Dao,
through the Dao one observes dharma.
By dharma forms arise,
by forms shapes take form,
by shapes substance is constituted,
by substance names are given,
by names things come to be,
by things humanity arises,
by humanity teachings emerge.

Herein lies the Supreme Venerable One,
who established the Lingbao dharma,
setting forth a model for later generations.
Thus it is known: the wondrous dharma of the Shangqing true realm
unfolds the teaching of Dao and virtue,
boundless and infinite—
how subtle! How subtle!

This Supreme Venerable One
originated with the Primordial Beginning,
was transmitted through the Lingbao,
descended into the dusty world,
manifesting numinous marvels.
At the sacred birth,
in an instant all became radiantly clear—
every arcane word and script,
without need of master or guide,
each embodied its essential,
each grasped its subtlety.
Before the kalpas of vast eons,
all causes and conditions were each distinctly understood;
after the kalpas of vast eons,
all Daoist methods were each thoroughly penetrated.
Above, it reaches to heaven—
all that heaven bears,
every subtle mystery,
was each fully comprehended.
Below, it extends to earth,
even to the hidden and obscure—
every secret was each made plain.
In the midst, it governs human affairs—
human relationships and virtue,
rites and music, state governance,
measures and literature,
profound principles and subtle truths,
the essentials of the supreme Dao,
all great principles,
every fine detail in sequence,
were each mastered,
mind to mind in perfect resonance.

Then the Most Sagely One of Ni Mountain
deeply praised it as rare in past and present,
peerless in excellence—
a marvelous essence, a singular talent.
The Emperor observed its subtleties,
possessing great spiritual power,
boundless dharmic might.
Moved by compassion for all beings,
who seldom hear the great Dao,
like the deaf and blind,
with hearts obscured and wills benighted,
he expounded the numinous scripture,
the five thousand words in full,
propagating Dao and virtue,
purity and non-action,
the supreme essential truth.
Profound principles flourished,
teachings were fully established,
no precept left unaddressed.

Thereupon, a perfected one
was born in that era,
concealing himself among minor officials,
serving as the Keeper of the Pass,
his dharma-name Xi.
From birth he was numinous and extraordinary,
his wisdom surpassing all.
In a single breath,
a thousand truths became clear.
He mastered all scriptures,
delved deeply into their mysteries—
yet alas, no transmission occurred,
a single gap remained unbridged.

Then the Supreme Venerable One
radiated a great millennial light,
illuminating that place,
giving rise to this extraordinary man,
truly a vessel of the Dao,
worthy to receive this teaching.
Thereupon, he rode a green ox,
westward across the Han Pass.
At that time, the perfected one
sat in silent contemplation,
aware that a true one
was approaching from the east.
He arose, his long-held reverence stirring,
knelt by the roadside,
begging for the secret transmission.

The Supreme Venerable One,
knowing him to be the rightful recipient,
thereupon composed the *Dao De Zhen Jing* and bestowed it upon him.
At these words, the perfected one
suddenly awakened,
fully enlightened.
He obtained the untransmitted wondrous treasure of heaven and earth,
eternally bequeathing the supreme teaching,
spreading it without bound.
Thereupon, he composed the *Wenshi Zhen Jing* in nine chapters,
elucidating Dao and virtue.

The Supreme Venerable One,
having ensured the transmission of this wondrous Dao
and the establishment of the eternal teaching,
thereafter returned in a single breath
to the Great Clarity,
within the Great Crimson Palace,
becoming the ancestral master of the Dao.

This celestial palace,
within the realm of the Great Clarity,
serves as the gateway to the subtlest mysteries
for all heavens and earths.
Every Heavenly Worthy,
Indra and true lords,
sages, immortals, and Daoist adepts,
Buddhas and bodhisattva ancestors—
all receive confirmation of its mysteries from this heaven,
hearing this secret,
thereby entering the ranks of the Great Luo immortals.

This celestial palace
is the key to all mysteries.
Every sentient being,
every non-actional and supremely sagely one,
every divine perfected one—
if they wish to behold the wondrous forms of the Lingbao,
or aspire to ascend further,
gazing upon the sacred and majestic realm of the Jade Clarity,
must pass through this heaven,
traversing its subtle wonders,
perhaps then meriting a glimpse.

This Great Clarity
is the capital of immortals.
Among all its realms,
every sublime landscape,
light and scenery shift and vary—
rare blossoms and exotic flowers,
fragrant and resplendent,
dazzling the eyes,
seldom seen before.
There are mountains and hills, streams and valleys,
strange rocks and wondrous trees,
sacred cliffs and precipitous ravines,
housing rare birds and extraordinary beasts—
tigers striped and leopards patterned,
black qilin and white cranes,
azure birds and vermilion phoenixes—
each distinct in kind,
manifesting numinous marvels,
each presenting a unique spectacle.
Again, there appear cloud terraces and square patterns,
carved pavilions and ornate pillars,
crimson railings and painted balustrades,
streets of white jade,
paved with yellow gold,
five-colored precious stones
scattered across the ground.

Within, there are supreme true lords,
Heavenly Worthies and great sages,
feathered transcendents and yellow-crowned adepts,
golden lads and jade maidens,
each adorned in robes of five-colored clouds and mist,
strolling leisurely,
coming and going in carefree ease,
naturally joyful.
Further within are the cloud generals of the various heavens,
some riding dragons,
some driving red tigers,
each wielding precious weapons,
encircling and guarding the heavens.

At that time, the Supreme Venerable One
sat in silent contemplation,
offering no instruction.
Then the Five Emperors
knelt before him,
begging for dharma and teaching,
bowing in reverence,
daring not rise hastily.
The Supreme Venerable One’s compassionate countenance
suddenly brightened,
and he expounded the subtleties to the Five Elders,
sighing as he spoke:
“My supreme teaching
has long been set forth in a single scripture,
called the *Daode*,
bestowed upon Yin Xi,
transmitted through the world.
Those who uphold and practice it
ascend to the immortal Dao.”

riad kalpas,
fortifying heaven and earth,
harmonizing yin and yang,
regulating primordial qi,
nurturing all beings,
benefiting both the hidden and the manifest,
transcending to attain immortality,
stabilizing the Five Peaks,
governing the Five Directions,
transforming even grasses and trees,
none differing in this.

This wondrous dharma—
when the Son of Heaven obtains it,
he establishes great peace and governance;
when the feudal lords obtain it,
they establish the foundation of harmonious rule.

chunks.original_text: 」是时　五帝，各白道前：「是此道德、清静真经，幽深伭远，下士修道，罕窥其密，伏愿圣慈，示以伭要。 」尔乃　太上，为　五帝言：「此至真妙，道之伭微，匪可口授，要诸心参。 若或求诸语言之间，人皆泛视，不由师承，妄为臆揣，多堕旁门，故第言其清静无为，收摄一切，客尘妄动，然后示以至道伭微之所端倪，俾其渐悟，默会真伭，今尔再四求指其要，我为言之，子宜静听。 盖此太清，居天之中，为天枢纽，名曰「伭关」，生天生地，生人生物，皆从此天，先地而生，有此一天，然后气通，无象之始，因无象中，一伭妙理，蕴酿元，乃获长保，先天后天，暨诸天地，山川人物，若非是天圜转生化，气机遂息。 故诸仙佛圣贤真宰，非通是天，无由会见玉清圣境，此固修士道德具足之时，所宜急讲者也。 吾昔于世，以我观天，因见我身，亦由大清至伭之境，其中伭关，统摄诸气，先天后天，咸于此判，分阴阳界，立水火门，上不于上，必通于下，下不于下，必通于上，上下相通，必经是关； 左而会右，右而会左，必通是关。 然后归一，引阴交阳，必度是关； 引阳济阴，必度是关。 是诸真水，度关济火，是诸真火，度关济水。 浑水火而共出一原，会阴阳而归于太极，判极为两，合两为一，总会此关，无有逾者。 然此伭关，居脐之中，非上非下，非左非右，非前非后，非浅非深，盼音畔睐音赉二气，嘿音默会神精，始由下被，终图上升，匪虚匪实，非形非声，形声俱泯，象态难名。 凡诸修士，趺坐屏息，澄清万虑，调伏元神，内无物扰，外无尘撄，任彼一切，有情无情，魔障相寻，中有所言，亦各无心，极彼分掷，不见不闻，如是清静，无所缘因，乃得默运，真元之精，由于气海，上至太清，自太清境，历周身，一切法界，至于上清，禹余宫中，经乎气机，至出纳司，上会玉清，还乃下济。 至于太清，大赤宫中，与诸一切三宝法物，融结成境，浑为太极，先天之妙，开基空阔，纳诸眷属，无有遗者，尔乃得以收摄元神，居处其中，各家眷属，环相围绕，如坐铁城，如入奥室，如登极顶，如入广渊，罔有见者，是诸天宫。 更现光景，供其娱玩，复献妙饮，琼浆玉液，供其啖食，复有祥光，四面缭绕，照烛一切，无为法界，是诸真宰，群相引导，香花满，供具各足，乃获登于大罗仙班。 是此至要，总极伭微，匪所易得。 尔诸五老，各以其身，保护斯人，得正妙果。

At that time, the Five Emperors each addressed the Dao before him: “This *Scripture of the Dao and Its Virtue, the Perfect and Tranquil*, is profound and far-reaching. Those of lesser capacity who cultivate the Dao rarely glimpse its mysteries. We humbly beseech your sagely compassion to reveal its essential subtleties.”

Thereupon, the Supreme Venerable One spoke to the Five Emperors: “This most true and wondrous subtlety of the Dao cannot be transmitted by speech; its essence must be grasped through the heart’s contemplation. If one seeks it merely in words, people will regard it superficially. Without proper transmission from a teacher, they will recklessly conjecture, often straying into side paths. Thus, I first speak of tranquility and non-action, gathering and withdrawing all that is stirred by the dust of delusion. Only then do I reveal the faintest traces of the Dao’s subtleties, guiding them toward gradual awakening and silent comprehension of the true mystery.

Now, as you repeatedly seek its essentials, I shall speak of it. Listen quietly, my children.

This Great Clarity dwells at the center of heaven, serving as its pivot, called the *Mysterious Pass*. From this heaven, heaven and earth are born, humans and all things arise. It existed before earth, and only with this heaven did qi begin to flow. In the beginning, when there were no forms, within this formless state, a single wondrous principle fermented primordial qi, thereby securing eternal preservation. Before and after heaven and earth, all heavens and earths, mountains and rivers, and living beings—without this heaven’s revolving transformations, the mechanism of qi would cease.

Thus, all immortals, buddhas, sages, and true lords, unless they penetrate this heaven, cannot perceive the sacred realm of Jade Clarity. This is what cultivators who have fulfilled the Dao and its virtue must urgently study.

In the past, while in the world, I observed heaven through myself and saw that my body, too, arose from the realm of the Great Clarity’s Mysterious Pass. This pass governs all qi, both prior to and following heaven and earth, dividing the boundaries of yin and yang, establishing the gates of water and fire. That which is not above must communicate with what is below; that which is not below must communicate with what is above. Only through this pass do above and below interconnect. Left unites with right, right with left—only through this pass. Then, returning to oneness, drawing yin to merge with yang, one must cross this pass; drawing yang to aid yin, one must cross this pass. All true waters cross the pass to aid fire; all true fires cross the pass to aid water. Water and fire, though distinct, emerge from a single source; yin and yang unite to return to the Supreme Ultimate. The ultimate divides into two, the two merge into one—all converge at this pass, with none surpassing it.

Yet this Mysterious Pass resides within the navel, neither above nor below, neither left nor right, neither front nor back, neither shallow nor deep. Gazing upon the interplay of the two qi, silently uniting spirit and essence, one begins from below and ultimately ascends above. It is neither empty nor solid, neither form nor sound. Form and sound both dissolve, its image and state defy description.

All cultivators should sit cross-legged, still their breath, calm their myriad thoughts, and subdue their primordial spirit. Internally, nothing disturbs; externally, no dust entangles. Let all—sentient and insentient, demonic obstacles that arise—be met with indifference. Even if words arise within, remain unmoved. Cast aside all distinctions, neither seeing nor hearing. In such tranquility, free from all conditions, one may silently move the essence of true primordiality. From the sea of qi, it ascends to the Great Clarity, and from the realm of the Great Clarity, it circulates throughout the body, all dharma realms, reaching the Upper Clarity within the Palace of Yu Yu. Passing through the mechanism of qi, it arrives at the Office of Inhalation and Exhalation, ascending to meet Jade Clarity, then descends again to the Great Clarity, within the Palace of Great Redness. There, it merges with all the Three Treasures and dharma objects, coalescing into a single realm, the Supreme Ultimate of primordial wonder. The foundation is laid in emptiness, embracing all retinues without omission.

Only then may one gather and withdraw the primordial spirit, dwelling within it. Each family’s retinue encircles and surrounds, like sitting within an iron citadel, entering a secluded chamber, ascending the highest peak, or plunging into a vast abyss—none can perceive it. These are the heavenly palaces. Further, radiant scenes appear for their delight, offering wondrous drinks of jade nectar and ambrosia for their nourishment. Auspicious light swirls on all sides, illuminating everything. In the realm of non-action, all true lords guide and escort, with fragrant flowers filling the path and all offerings in abundance. Thus, one ascends to the ranks of the Great Luo immortals.

This is the utmost essential, the ultimate subtlety, not easily attained. You, the Five Elders, must each protect those who cultivate, that they may attain the wondrous fruit of the true path.”

chunks.original_text: 」 我昔闻此至伭要道，以为此身此心此理，本之三清，还乃以所始得之身，仍从太清，诣玉清境，是则此身，与天无异，三清妙道，取之于己，各各具足，无或阙焉。 但此妙道，传于　太上，至精至微，至伭至奥，虽极显扬，初学之士，未获师承，无能致力。 我今于世，广施法乳，开方便门，示以快捷方式，为彼三教，各述良因，俾尔后学，按法习行，虽于至道，未悉伭微，然苟力行，亦或有得，是诸弟子，铲净异同，人我之见，详视审听，无生障碍，共证是因。 盖人一身，惟精气神，固精养气，心神安宁，藏其伭宰，无俾丧倾。 然此功要，先净六根，六贼既伏，七情无因，既无情识，乃无苦恼，以无苦恼，因无情想，以无情想，因无妄心，乃得此心，清净无为，若太虚然，无所不有，而如无有，无无有故，始无所障，无所障碍，乃无不灵，惟灵斯神，惟神斯通，通无弗通，遂明伭奥。 我示修士，先须主静，欲静须诚，欲诚须敬，欲敬须慎：慎无妄言，慎无妄动，慎无妄意，慎无妄因，至无妄因，虽历烦杂嘈沓之处，罔有妄者。 以无妄故，内斯宁谧，主一无适，以存其诚。 如是存诚，乃与归静，静之之极，明自生焉。 由其能明，是以能行：儒者敦行，一切伦常，罔有愧怍，则可入德，希圣希天； 释者能行，观空得空，而非顽空，求佛于心，以心印佛，即心即佛，即佛即心，相彼如来，如是如是； 道士志人，能敦厥行，始以其神，御诸元气，既以其气，收摄其精，精足则一切气皆足，气足则一切神皆足，神足其气，气足其精，精足其神，如是具足，大丹乃成。 是诸三教，分门别户，究所由来，皆从一极，寻原究委，则彼归宿，仍会极中，匪惟始终，归本太极，无二无三，即其功行，由知而行，由敬而诚，由诚而静，由静而明，由明而神。 其中次第，无所分更，惟彼儒者，多事格物，其教为实； 惟彼释氏，从事静参，止明性体，不修命元，其教为空； 若夫道流，性命双修，先固本根，后参伭要，虚不为空，实不徒实。 故其为教，合天地人，无有外者，至哉道乎！ 立于无始，生天生地，生人生物，运化古今，磅薄宇宙，入幽出显，拔度群伦，或儒或释，为圣为贤，为佛菩萨，皆于斯道，是二是一。 以至王侯将相宰臣，修此妙道，福禄尔昌，治国宁民； 圣明天子，修此妙道，运祚悠长，绵历无疆。 叹哉斯道！ 推运劫会，敦固坤舆，迁流时序，升沉二象，运行阴阳，体统太极，保固天根，视之不见，听之不闻，因应变化，神乎其神。 修道之士，克会伭微，炼精气神，立其命原，固其本真，徐悟本来，亲见自然，然后积累三千八百，深宏功行，以证金仙，复由太清，清静无为，受法灵宝，阐扬玉清，元始真一至道，积种种功，行种种行，愿尽累劫，立无量无等之功德，于是殊勋懋绩完足，乃始亲受玉皇诰命，为大罗天，无上无为，至真伭宰，号为　天尊，与天地俱。 微乎妙哉！ 尔诸弟子，谛听斯旨，各各明了至伭至道，微妙因缘，如法修持，生大智慧，无二无疑，乃有十方至真上宰，默为保护，一切魔王，咸为俯首，在世长年，或膺宠禄，位极人臣，或住名山，逍遥快乐，天爵尊荣，无与等者。
chunks.translated_text:
I once heard this most subtle and essential Dao, and understood that this body, this mind, this principle all originate from the Three Pure Ones. Thus, with the body one initially attains, one still follows the Great Purity to reach the Jade Purity realm. In this way, this body becomes no different from Heaven, and the wondrous Dao of the Three Pure Ones is drawn from within oneself, each fully possessed, with nothing lacking.

Yet this wondrous Dao was transmitted by the Most High, most refined and subtle, most profound and mysterious. Though widely proclaimed, beginners who lack a teacher’s guidance cannot apply themselves to it. Now, in this world, I broadly bestow the Dharma-milk, open the gate of expedient means, and reveal swift methods, expounding good causes for the Three Teachings, that later learners may practice according to the method. Though they may not fully grasp the subtleties of the utmost Dao, if they diligently practice, they may still attain something. Disciples, you must eliminate differences and the views of self and others, observe carefully, listen attentively, and generate no obstacles, that you may together realize this cause.

For within a person’s body, only essence, qi, and spirit are fundamental. Secure essence, nurture qi, and the mind and spirit will be at peace, preserving their subtle governance without loss or collapse. Yet the essential practice begins with purifying the six roots. Once the six thieves are subdued, the seven emotions have no cause. Without emotions or consciousness, there is no suffering; without suffering, there are no emotional thoughts; without emotional thoughts, there are no deluded minds. Only then does this mind become pure and non-active, like the great void—nothing is not present, yet it seems as if nothing exists. Because there is no "nothing," there is no obstruction; without obstruction, there is nothing not numinous. Only when numinous does it become spirit; only when spirit does it become penetrating. Penetrating without limit, one thus comprehends the profound and mysterious.

I instruct cultivators: first, one must master stillness. To attain stillness, one must be sincere; to be sincere, one must be reverent; to be reverent, one must be cautious. Be cautious of idle speech, idle movement, idle thoughts, and idle causes. When there are no idle causes, even amid chaos and clamor, there is no delusion. Without delusion, one is inwardly serene, focused on the One without distraction, thus preserving sincerity. By preserving sincerity, one returns to stillness; at the extreme of stillness, clarity naturally arises. Through clarity, one can act:

Confucians cultivate conduct, fulfilling all ethical norms without shame, thus entering virtue and aspiring to sagehood and Heaven.

Buddhists, through practice, contemplate emptiness and attain emptiness—not a dull emptiness—but seek the Buddha within the mind, using the mind to seal the Buddha. Mind is Buddha; Buddha is mind. Thus, they realize the Tathāgata, just so, just so.

Daoist adepts cultivate their conduct, first guiding their spirit to govern primordial qi, then using qi to gather essence. When essence is sufficient, all qi is sufficient; when qi is sufficient, all spirit is sufficient. When spirit suffices for qi, qi suffices for essence, and essence suffices for spirit, thus fully possessed, the Great Elixir is accomplished.

These Three Teachings, though distinct in approach, ultimately derive from the One Ultimate. Tracing their origins, they all return to the same source, not only beginning and ending in the Supreme Ultimate, but also in their practice: from knowledge to action, from reverence to sincerity, from sincerity to stillness, from stillness to clarity, from clarity to spirit. In this sequence, there is no division.

Yet Confucians often engage in the investigation of things, their teaching being substantive. Buddhists focus on still contemplation, illuminating the nature but not cultivating the life-force—thus their teaching is empty. Daoists, however, cultivate both nature and life, first securing the root, then exploring the profound essentials. They are not empty in their emptiness, nor merely substantive in their substance. Thus, their teaching unites Heaven, Earth, and Humanity, with nothing external to it. How supreme is the Dao! It stands from the beginningless, generates Heaven and Earth, humans and beings, governs the transformations of past and present, pervades the cosmos, enters the hidden and emerges in the manifest, delivers and elevates all beings. Whether Confucian or Buddhist, whether sage or worthy, whether Buddha or bodhisattva, all arise from this Dao, which is both two and one.

Even kings, dukes, generals, ministers, and rulers—if they cultivate this wondrous Dao, their fortune and prosperity flourish, governing the state and pacifying the people. If a sagely Son of Heaven cultivates this wondrous Dao, his reign endures long, extending boundlessly. How wondrous is this Dao! It propels the turning of kalpas, stabilizes the Earth, shifts the seasons, raises and lowers the two images, operates yin and yang, embodies the Supreme Ultimate, secures the Heavenly Root. It cannot be seen or heard, yet responds to changes and transformations—spiritlike in its spirit.

Cultivators who master the profound and subtle refine essence, qi, and spirit, establish their life’s origin, secure their original truth, and gradually awaken to their original nature, personally witnessing the natural. Then, accumulating three thousand eight hundred great and vast practices, they realize the Golden Immortal. Proceeding from the Great Purity, in purity and non-action, they receive the Dharma and sacred treasures, expounding the Jade Purity’s Primordial Beginning’s True One’s utmost Dao. Accumulating all manner of merits, performing all manner of practices, vowing to exhaust kalpas, establishing boundless and unequaled virtues—only when such meritorious deeds are complete do they personally receive the Jade Emperor’s decree, becoming a Great Luo Heaven’s supreme, non-active, utmost true subtle governor, titled Heavenly Venerable, coeval with Heaven and Earth.

How subtle and wondrous! Disciples, listen carefully to this decree, each clearly understanding the most subtle and profound Dao, its wondrous causes and conditions. Practice according to the method, generate great wisdom, without duality or doubt. Then, the ten directions’ utmost true supreme governors will silently protect you, all demon kings will bow their heads, and in the world, you will enjoy long life, or receive honor and emolument, attaining the highest ministerial rank, or dwell in famous mountains, carefree and joyful, with heavenly nobility and honor unmatched.

chunks.original_text: 海藏河沙　　　衍夫伭妙之义蕴 久矣玉局宏开　两间尽絪缊之气 聿哉贝书广译　三乘极梯筏之言 古今来圣贤心印，仙佛传灯，载诸金石，播诸行帛，虽五千四十八数而增益之，乌足计经典之旨归也哉！ 则是仙经伭范之昭垂于宇宙间者，朗朗然炳如日星，煌煌然光被上下，又乌可以烛照而数计也，尚何品之云乎！ 我　孚佑帝师，誓无量度人之愿，现身说法，普济群迷，一片婆心，随时方便，悯兹下土凡愚，汨没日甚，丧日深，更兼左道狂澜，肆行妄诞，愈见浸炽，而于三教本原，不特渺焉莫究，且复彼此交讥，互相攻击，正道之榛芜，圣言之阏音遏塞，非我　孚佑帝师，振臂一呼，大开觉路，几几乎坠地斯文，糜烂人心矣。 爰于壬午之岁，鹤驾临凡，降夫夏汭，集众弟子，结涵三坛，阐演灵章，恢宏正化，历十余载，至壬辰岁，始告竣天工，付厥镌印，其经典之透辟三教宗旨，理致渊深，分者合之，二者一之，晦者明之，疑者晰之，统发乾坤之秘，大彰今古之微，诚希有之真文，实至伭之宝箓，津梁末学，启迪后人，其功德力，岂棨之所能殚述哉！ 又岂棨之所敢仰赞也哉！ 第忆数十年来，凡经营典务，棨幸忝列侍从，得以稍伸赞勷，奔走后先，时亲优渥，含哺法乳，餐听妙音，见闻斯道之万一于圣侧，固属涵三诸弟子，因缘际遇，然皆我　孚佑帝师，惓惓不已，不厌不倦之训勉，而成斯懋续也。 于是大典镌印之后，我　师即证无上玉清之果，而诸子亦被利赖无穷之休。 独惜近念余年，沿习渐微，广布未几，甚有于斯典计虑者，乃得金陵孙子守恕，夙慕伭宗，久饴道位，获亲余泽，仰睹鸿文，欣然拜悦，矢力重梓，以广流通。 复虑经轴庄严，奉持者未免凛科律之戒，不能朝夕玩索，以期体行，似于圣心博施之功，有所闭碍，遂请易为简帙，装订成函，而其矢诚缮录者，则上元恪诚解子也，工竣乞志始末于经后，棨思至人穷神而达化，固无等伦，则其敷演至言，博探而旁搜，应无涯涘。 特是道之精湛，虽已泄于探幽隐之际，然而文之昭布，必有赖乎燮纲调纪之人，伭教藩篱，得斯诚信之子，可作东南半壁矣。 我　孚佑帝师，无量度人之愿，不几有所慰藉乎哉！ 将见是函之惠海隅，使众生咸闻道要，获睹真宗，则三品之一而二，二而三，三而穷之十百千万，俾人人心目中，皆有此三品一典，其功德力，真不可烛照而数计也。 孙子流衍之功，与解子临摹之力，其福荫又不与斯典常存欤棨幸叨见闻之荣，敢肆笔道其始末，以志册尾，将以为天下后世闻知者，勉修厥德云尔，是为记。 时旃蒙单阏孟上浣方山道士宏教真人弟子柳棨稽首拜撰。 参同经　(卷十六、十七、十八) 序
chunks.translated_text:
Within the ocean’s treasury lie river-sands—
they unfold the subtlest meanings of the *xuan*-mysteries.
Long has the Jade Bureau flung wide its gates;
between Heaven and Earth, *yinyun* qi suffuses all.
Behold! The Cowrie Scriptures are broadly translated,
the Three Vehicles’ words reach the utmost in raft and ferry.
From ancient times to now, the mind-seals of sages and worthies,
the lamp-transmissions of immortals and buddhas,
have been inscribed on metal and stone,
circulated on silk and bamboo.
Though they swell to five thousand forty-eight in number,
how could they ever exhaust the purport of the scriptures’ return?

Thus the immortal canons’ *xuan*-models,
radiant in the cosmos,
shine bright as sun and stars,
their luminous glory bathing above and below—
how could they be measured by candlelight or counted?
What need, then, to speak of grades?

Our Master, the Teacher of Emperors, Vouchsafing Blessing,
vowed the boundless vow to ferry all beings.
Manifesting a body, he expounded the Dharma,
universally saving the deluded multitudes.
With a heart of *prajñā*, he adapted to the times,
moved by the plight of the benighted below:
the common and foolish, daily more submerged,
daily deeper in perdition.
To this was added the raging torrent of heterodox ways,
wild and reckless fabrications,
ever more rampant.
As for the root-source of the Three Teachings,
not only was it left unplumbed,
but even mutual ridicule and attack arose.
The Way’s brambles grew rank,
the sages’ words were stifled and blocked.
Had not our Master, the Teacher of Emperors, Vouchsafing Blessing,
raised his arm and cried out,
throwing wide the path of awakening,
the culture of this world would have nearly fallen to ruin,
human hearts reduced to pulp.

In the year *renwu*, his crane-chariot descended to the mortal realm.
Alighting at the Xia Ford,
he gathered his disciples,
established the Three Altars,
and expounded the numinous chapters.
For over a decade he expanded the true transformation,
until the year *renchen*,
when he completed the celestial work
and entrusted its carving and printing.
These scriptures penetrate the Three Teachings’ essential purport,
their principles profound and far-reaching.
What was divided, he united;
what was dual, he made one;
what was obscure, he illumined;
what was doubtful, he clarified.
He revealed the secrets of Heaven and Earth,
greatly displayed the subtleties of past and present.
Truly a rare and wondrous text,
a most *xuan* treasure-talisman—
a bridge for late learners,
an awakening for posterity.
The power of its merit and virtue—
how could my brush ever exhaust its description?
How dare I presume to praise it!

Yet recalling these decades,
in all the affairs of the canon’s production,
I, Qiu, was humbly numbered among the attendants,
able to offer slight assistance,
running before and after,
ever graced with generous favor.
I drank the Dharma-milk,
feasted on the hearing of wondrous sounds,
and glimpsed but a ten-thousandth of this Way at the Master’s side.
This was the karmic opportunity of us disciples of the Three Altars.
Yet all was due to our Master, the Teacher of Emperors, Vouchsafing Blessing—
his tireless, unwearying exhortations—
that this great continuity came to be.

After the canon’s carving and printing,
our Master attained the supreme fruit of the Jade Clarity,
while his disciples received boundless blessings.
Only later did I come to regret:
in recent years, the practice has gradually waned.
Though widely disseminated, it was not for long.
There were those who, regarding this canon,
turned to Master Sun Shoushu of Jinling.
From early on, he had revered the *xuan* lineage,
long savoring the Dao’s station.
Having received my beneficence,
he gazed upon the vast scripture,
and joyfully bowed in delight.
He vowed to re-engrave it,
to broaden its circulation.
Yet he feared that the scripture’s solemnity,
with its strict precepts for reverent handling,
might prevent devotees from daily study and realization,
thus hindering the Master’s intent to universally bestow.
So he requested it be made into a simpler volume,
bound into fascicles.
The one who vowed to transcribe it with utmost sincerity
was Xie Kecheng of Shangyuan.
When the work was completed,
he entreated me to record its origins at the scripture’s end.

I reflect: the perfected one fathoms the divine and reaches transformation—
none can compare.
Thus his expounding of the ultimate words,
his vast exploration and wide-ranging search,
must be without limit.
Though the Dao’s profundity
has already been revealed in the depths of the hidden,
the text’s clear dissemination
still depends on those who harmonize the warp and weft,
who regulate and order.
For the *xuan* teaching’s fence and hedge,
this man of sincerity and faith
can stand for half the realm in the southeast.
Will not our Master, the Teacher of Emperors, Vouchsafing Blessing,
find some consolation in his boundless vow to ferry all beings?

We shall see these fascicles
spreading to the sea’s edge,
so that all beings may hear the essentials of the Way,
gaze upon the true source.
From the Three Grades’ one to two,
two to three,
three to ten, a hundred, a thousand, ten thousand—
until in every person’s heart and eye,
this Three Grades, one canon, resides.
The power of its merit and virtue—
truly beyond measure or count!

Master Sun’s merit in propagating it,
and Master Xie’s effort in transcribing it—
will their blessings not endure with this canon forever?
I, Qiu, humbly partook of the honor of witnessing these events,
and dare to set down their beginnings and ends with my brush,
inscribing this at the volume’s close.
May those who hear of this in the world and in posterity
be exhorted to cultivate their virtue.
This is the record.

Respectfully composed by Liu Qiu,
disciple of the Perfected One of Vast Teaching of Fangshan,
on the first washing of the *mengxia* month,
in the year *shanmeng danyan*.
*Preface to the* Cantong qi *(Scrolls Sixteen, Seventeen, Eighteen)*

**A Brief Preface to the *Cantong Jing***

The exposition of the *Cantong Jing* began in the *guichou* year and was completed in the *jiwei* year, spanning seven years in all. Originally planned to be held in southern Qian, the initial collaborators—Li Kexiu, who returned to Yu; Tu Jingcheng, who retired; and others like Yao, Sun, and Hong, who dispersed—left only myself and Deng Dongyan to shoulder the task. Yet Dongyan was far away in Yunnan, so the first plan came to naught. We then petitioned to complete it in Hubei instead of Qian.

Among those who contributed to its progress, my nephew Yun Cheng bore the greatest effort. The details have been thoroughly recounted in Mr. Huang’s preface to the *Wupin Jing*. The preface to the *Wupin Jing* states: “The Patriarch Lü took pity on the Three Chu regions, a hundredfold more than on the Five Mounds!” Yet the Patriarch’s compassion in delivering the world was impartial, without distinction. However, while the *Bapin Jing* was expounded in various places, the Chu region alone received it again and again—first the *Wupin Jing* at Qizhen, then the *Sanpin Jing* and *Cantong Jing* at Hansan—all within or near Ezhou. Was this not because the Peach Blossom Spring’s mouth, Yueyang Tower, Yellow Crane Jetty, and other sacred sites abound there, long famed as haunts of immortals? The eight hundred leagues of Dragon Sands await their time to respond—surely that time is not far off.

In southern Yunnan, Du Yujing held this canon in the highest esteem, deeming it purer than pure and a counterpart to the Six Classics. How true!

Does not the world’s work truly rest upon karmic conditions? Long ago, the First Patriarch Bodhidharma crossed the sea to come east, for karmic conditions brought him to the Land of the Sinitic Realm. Later, he encountered Shenguang and transmitted the Buddha-mind seal. To this day, people know of the intention behind the Western Patriarch’s coming.

When Patriarch Lü expounded the *Cantong Jing*, people from several provinces suddenly gathered by karmic conditions to bring this great canon into being. Tracing its origins, it truly began with the Guizhou scholar Liu Qingxu, who in his youth followed his father on official travels to Chu. There he studied under Song Shinan—Shinan being the first disciple of Hansan—who, in the intervals between lecturing on the arts, spoke of Hansan’s Patriarch Lü’s Dao-ground, where the *Three-Pin Qingwei Jing* and the *Essential Canon of the Chan School* had been expounded. Qingxu heard and grew admiring. One day, he accompanied his teacher to pay homage to the Patriarch, who perceived his deep karmic affinity and bestowed upon him a name.

Before long, Qingxu returned to Qian. In the year *gui-chou* of Yongzheng’s reign, he encountered Liu Wuwo of Yiling, Deng Dongyan of Quyang, and Tu Jingcheng of Huanchuan in Bo. At that time, Li Kexiu of Zhongzhou, advanced in years and skilled in external matters, had also come to Qian. Hearing of Hansan’s name, all rejoiced. They asked Qingxu to lead the way, bringing Li Licheng and Deng Xincheng, and in the year *jia-yin* of the she-ti month, they paid homage to the Patriarch to present their request for the composition and expounding of the canon.

Ah! How extraordinary!

chunks.original_text: 曩清虚随师诣宫时，不图有此因缘也。 及请制回南，不果开演。 首事各散去，惟无我坚志靡移，谋于东岩，复令清虚，恪请就鄂完黔，乃欣然就道，不避寒暑，往来跋涉十余次，由是李本恕、丁存恕、刘悟诚，附会不一其人。 己未春，积经始竣，旋即开演。 维时刘清惠始之，厥后清虚实终其事。 是冬信诚自滇至楚，《参同经》已告成功矣！ 方甲寅之初联会也，起经之日，瑞鹤舞于云端。 至演典时，亦复翔集。 诚信之所感召，固宜如是其速也。 余尝谓　吕祖道场在鄂城者不少，独涵三数十载罔替。 惟始事者诚信作之于前，而其子孙善继述于后，以致诸君子越数千里而联会，可不谓极盛欤？ 余不敏，幸侍法筵，谬承演务，深喜清虚初诚弗懈，而无我诸君，矢愿坚确，能相与以有成也。 嗟乎！ 人居各地，业有殊途，即善卜者亦不及料，洵莫之为而为者，讵非因缘有前定耶？ 兹因参订全书之暇，备叙演典始末，弁诸经首，辞俚不文，聊以志际会之非偶然云尔！ 沙羡一行子黄诚恕谨序。 梓潼帝君参同妙经序 稽自坟典肇兴，而经之名，遂灿然于世。 盖古先圣王，举人伦日用常行之道，着为训典，于以觉世牖民，使人日迁善改过，臻于上治。 后世因尊之为经世之典要云尔，非惟释、道两门，始创有经之名，以显异而骇俗也。 然梵帙琼编，亦皆佛仙启迪人心，补裨王化。 世儒不察，以为与圣道相左，每惑乎愚俗之辈，随流逐波，而轻肆讥谈也。 孚佑帝君之演斯典也，合三教以立言，会五典而垂训，辑四子之微言，集百家之绪论，引经据典，博采旁探，辨疑晰义，条贯参同，其旨显而深，其词该而备，发先圣未发之秘，阐佛仙未阐之精，固修证之法言，实训世之要典！ 其所以启迪人心，补裨王化者，岂浅鲜哉！ 览斯典者，务宜读其辞，玩其意，朝讽夕咏，日进于躬行，勿概视为梵帙琼编，与圣贤书相左也。 夫十室之邑，必有忠信！ 寰宇之大，岂无解人？ 世有深种善根，明达颖悟之士，能依斯典而力行之，广为流布，务使闾阎之内，家喻户晓，人人有向善之机，则不求福报，而福自骈臻。 其所以补益王化，羽翼圣贤者，正赖斯典维持不少也，奚第仙经云乎哉！ 如以为太上演之灵文，帝君开阐之法要，什袭珍藏，终岁不一览观，与但习为诵持，而于伦常日用之道，罔克实践者，岂帝君觉世之慈心也夫！ 后之览斯典者，亦当有省于予言。 义陵无我子刘体恕汇辑男刘荫诚清惠、侄刘允诚清虚仝校沙羡一行子黄诚恕参订 参同经赞偈 上卷赞

When Qingxu first followed his teacher to the palace, he never imagined such karmic affinity would arise. Upon returning south after the request for composition, the canon’s expounding did not come to fruition. The principal figures dispersed, save for Wuwo, whose resolve remained unshaken. He consulted Dongyan and once more dispatched Qingxu to earnestly invite the Patriarch to complete the work in Qian, journeying to Hubei. With joy, Qingxu set forth, undeterred by cold or heat, traversing back and forth over ten times. Thus, Li Benshu, Ding Cunshu, and Liu Wucheng, among others, joined in succession.

In the spring of *ji-wei*, the accumulated scriptures were finally completed, and the expounding commenced. At that time, Liu Qinghui initiated the work, while Qingxu ultimately brought it to fruition. That winter, Xincheng arrived from Yunnan to Hubei, and the *Cantong Jing* was already accomplished.

When the initial gathering took place in *jia-yin*, on the day the scriptures were begun, auspicious cranes danced in the clouds. By the time the canon was expounded, they once more soared and gathered. Such swift response was surely the result of sincere devotion.

I have often observed that while Lüzu’s Daoist sanctuaries in Ezhou are many, only Hansan’s has endured for decades without decline. This is because the founders’ sincerity laid the groundwork, and their descendants skillfully carried it forward, enabling these gentlemen to unite from thousands of miles away—could anything be more magnificent?

Though unworthy, I was fortunate to attend the Dharma assembly and was entrusted with the expounding. I rejoiced deeply that Qingxu’s initial sincerity never wavered, and that Wuwo and the others remained steadfast in their vows, achieving success together.

Alas! People dwell in different places, their paths diverging—even skilled diviners could not have foreseen this. Truly, what unfolds without deliberate design must be predestined by karma. Here, in the leisure of collating the complete work, I record the canon’s origins and conclusion, placing it at the scriptures’ outset. Though my words are coarse and unrefined, they serve to mark this gathering as no mere coincidence.

Respectfully inscribed by Huang Chengshu of Shayi, a humble practitioner.

---

**Preface to the *Cantong Jing* of the Divine Lord of Zitong**

Since the rise of the ancient classics, the term *jing* (scripture) has shone resplendently in the world. For the early sage-kings distilled the Way of human relations and daily conduct into teachings, awakening the world and guiding the people, so that all might daily progress in goodness and correction, attaining the highest order.

Later generations revered these as essential canons for governing the world. Yet it was not only the Buddhist and Daoist traditions that first coined the term *jing* to distinguish themselves and astonish the common folk. The scriptures of both schools, in fact, also enlighten the human heart and supplement royal governance.

Worldly scholars, failing to perceive this, assume they oppose the sagely Way and often mislead the ignorant masses, who drift with the current and recklessly mock them. When the Divine Lord Fuyou expounded this canon, he harmonized the Three Teachings in his words, united the Five Constants in his instructions, compiled the subtle sayings of the Four Masters, and gathered the threads of a hundred schools. Citing classics and drawing from broad inquiry, he clarified doubts and elucidated meanings, weaving them into a coherent whole. Its principles are both manifest and profound; its language, comprehensive and complete. It reveals secrets unspoken by the ancient sages and expounds truths unarticulated by buddhas and immortals. Truly, it is the Dharma-word of cultivation and realization, the essential canon for instructing the world!

How could its enlightenment of the human heart and supplementation of royal governance be insignificant? Those who study this canon must read its words, ponder its meanings, recite it morning and night, and daily advance in personal practice. Do not dismiss it as mere Buddhist or Daoist scripture, opposed to the books of sages and worthies.

Even in a village of ten households, there must be loyalty and trust! In this vast world, how could there be no discerning minds? If those deeply rooted in goodness, with keen insight and wisdom, practice this canon diligently and disseminate it widely, ensuring that every household understands and each person harbors the impulse toward virtue, then blessings will naturally abound without seeking. Its supplementation of royal governance and support of sages and worthies will rely significantly on this canon—how could it be merely a scripture of immortals?

Yet if one regards it as the sacred text revealed by the Most High or the essential Dharma expounded by the Divine Lord, treasures it without ever perusing it, or merely recites it mechanically while neglecting the Way of daily conduct and human relations, how could this fulfill the Divine Lord’s compassionate intent to awaken the world?

May those who read this canon reflect on my words.

Compiled by Liu Tishu of Yiling, styled Wuwo
Collated by his son Liu Yincheng (Qinghui) and nephew Liu Yuncheng (Qingxu)
Revised by Huang Chengshu of Shayi, styled Yixing

Unveiling subtleties and expounding mysteries,
Revealing the true and wondrous,
Converging the Three into One—words elucidate,
The Dao and virtue wholly encompassed.

**Eulogy Verses for the Opening of the Sutra’s Wondrous Gate**

The Great Dao is wondrously empty and nameless,
Dark and indistinct, yet possessing true essence.
The marvelous principle of the One Origin unites the Three Teachings;
At first, the primordial chaos divided, and images began to take form.
Solemn and profound, it proceeds directly from the nature of the heart-mind,
Where the roots of karma are cleansed, and the sprouts of goodness arise.
Through cultivation and realization, the meaning of the entire sutra is grasped,
And the Dharma-body, thus and unmoving, transcends the Supreme Vehicle.

Citing the sutra and drawing from the classics, we synthesize and compare,
Instructing and enlightening the deluded to awaken to their original school.
Know that the body’s forms and appearances belong to illusion;
The myriad dharmas are contained within a single word.
Once awakened, there is no need for excessive interpretation—
The turning of the sutra’s secret essentials is true mastery.
From this, the wondrous and wondrous is revealed,
And age after age, beings draw upon the Dao’s breeze.

The Most High revealed this to rescue the kalpa, dispel disasters,
Bestow blessings, resolve calamities, and safeguard destiny,
Enabling realization through the *Cantong Jing’s* wondrous sutra.

**Chapter One: The Origin of the Dharma Assembly**

In former times, the Vast Law Heavenly Worthy, having attained the Dao, before the Sacred Master of the True Yang, made a great vow to universally deliver all beings in Jambudvīpa. Thus, traversing the mortal realm, he composed the *Two Chapters on Pointing to the Wondrous*, elucidating the Way of refining mercury and lead. Yet the verses were profound and obscure, and worldly scholars failed to grasp the principle of inverting yin and yang or the work of "seeking heaven and digging earth." Therefore, he took the two chapters of wondrous text and concealed them in a stone chamber on Mount Qingcheng, awaiting those with true understanding.

Later, in Piling, he expounded the *Eightfold Scripture of Immortals*, which, compared to the *Pointing to the Wondrous*, was far clearer. However, the purport of "ascending and descending water and fire" and "infant boy and maiden girl," along with the discourse on "dragon and tiger, furnace and cauldron," were largely metaphorical. Unaware of this, people strayed into heterodox paths. Even the rare perceptive scholar often clung to the literal text, failing to comprehend the principle of "obtaining words while forgetting images" or "using intention to meet the intent."

The Heavenly Worthy, moved by compassion, often manifested in the region of Yi and Zhen, spreading transformation through flying phoenixes and broadly forming karmic connections. Whether the *Fivefold* or *Threefold* scriptures, he expounded them in succession, revealing the subtleties of the Great Vehicle, which never depart from the luminous awakening of one’s own nature. Thus, those who cultivate the truth could follow the text to practice the Dao—truly a compassionate and skillful means, fulfilling his original vow.

As the scripture’s circulation remained limited and few upheld it, while attending the Dharma-seat of the Primordial Beginning, he heard the discourse on the Most Wondrous, Supreme, Perfect, and True Dao. By chance, he observed that in the celestial division of Well and Ghost, baleful qi coiled in darkness. Thereupon, the Heavenly Worthy, surveying the kalpa’s fate, sighed deeply. Just as he considered petitioning the Primordial Beginning to preach the Dharma for salvation, a Dharma-heir from the Heavenly Worthy’s lineage entreated him to descend via flying phoenix to Luodian.

The Heavenly Worthy, deeply committed to delivering beings, was moved by compassion. He implored the Primordial Beginning Honored One and the Jade Emperor, beseeching them to universally proclaim the Great Transformation in the miasmic and pestilential lands of the southern barbarians. Upon closer examination of the karmic conditions, it still pertained to Ezhu.

Thus, the Heavenly Worthy bowed before the Primordial Beginning’s seat and addressed him: "Your servant once requested to expound the wondrous transformation in Luoshi to save the beings of the final kalpa. Now, having examined the celestial cycles and the convergence of karmic conditions, it should be in the celestial division of Yi and Zhen. Your servant now requests to shift to the land of Chu, to propagate the wondrous work. Humbly, I pray for your compassion and mercy to grant this request."

I shall command those who renew life and perpetuate destiny to assist and support the primordial transformation. You must clearly expound it, eschewing stale words, so that even the simplest men and women may know to cultivate and reflect, return to the true Dao, comprehend and transcend birth and death, and escape the realms of suffering—this shall be your merit."

The Heavenly Worthy bowed in gratitude for the grace bestowed. From the Golden Towers of the Jade Capital, he mounted a five-colored auspicious cloud, with white cranes leading the way and azure dragons bearing his chariot. Heavenly blossoms scattered in profusion, and auspicious mists swirled as he, accompanied by the hosts of heaven and the immortals, arrived before the Jade Emperor’s throne to present his petition. Once more, the Jade Emperor, moved by his compassionate vow, granted permission to commence the exposition. Thereupon, with the assembled perfected beings and sagely worthies, he descended in spirit to the Ezhu sanctuary, where the Three Ways converged. For the celestial beings, the assembled disciples, and all present, he proclaimed the *Thirty-Two Chapters of the Most High’s Wondrous Scripture for Saving the Kalpa*.

**Chapter Two: The Essential Teachings of the Wondrous Dao**

Then the Heavenly Worthy addressed the fourfold assembly: "What I now speak is solely of truth, unburdened by extraneous matters. Those who cultivate the Dao yet fail to grasp the root and merely pursue its branches—though they strive with utmost diligence—are like trees without roots; what benefit can there be? This root originates in the undifferentiated primordial *qi*: before heaven and earth divided, before sun and moon shone, in the chaos of Great Nothingness, there was no form, no name, no sound, no scent. Heaven received it and became heaven—where the four seasons proceed, cold and heat revolve, the sun ascends, and the moon waxes and wanes; clouds, mist, rain, dew, wind, thunder, lightning, and hail—all cycle through this *qi* without cease, day and night. Earth received it and became earth—where mountains stand firm, waters flow, bearing peaks without weight, containing seas without leakage. Without this singular *qi*, who would govern it?

Man, born of heaven and earth’s *qi*, inherits heaven’s *qi* as yang and earth’s *qi* as yin. Yang is vigorous, yin is compliant; the two *qi* alternate in motion, like a ring without end. The Confucians call it ‘the nature mandated by heaven,’ the Buddhists probe ‘the original face,’ and the Daoists inquire into ‘the state before father and mother were born’—all refer to this *qi*, wherein the principle resides.

The Most High said: ‘Before the image of the Lord.’ And again: ‘There is a thing formed in chaos, born before heaven and earth.’ From ancient times, buddhas, immortals, sages, and worthies cultivated body and destiny by this alone; in composing scriptures to bequeath to the world, they illuminated this alone. Yet in recent times, the common people, failing to return to the root, neglect personal practice and seek externally. Though they read all the sacred scriptures and exhaust the secret classics, they let their own single spark of primordial yang-true-*qi* dissipate unheeded, dying in ignorance—how deeply lamentable!

Now, for you gathered here, I shall reveal the essentials of cultivating the true: you must comprehend this pre-celestial singular *qi*, which is the ‘substance of the wondrous true.’ Yet this *qi* cannot be grasped through mere sitting in rigid stillness. Only in walking, standing, sitting, and lying—in every word and deed—must you subtly observe and recognize it. In every movement, its origin is unseen; in every stillness, its cessation is unseen. Vague and indistinct, its traces cannot be fathomed. By thus investigating its root and origin, you must strive for clarity. Then, suddenly, the original spark of yang-light will appear, naturally penetrating and purifying, illuminating the nature and heaven. The accumulated habits of ten thousand kalpas melt away in an instant; the great kalpa’s cataclysmic disasters cannot harm you. You shall share the years of heaven, consort with the sages, escape the wheel of rebirth, and roam freely at ease!

This *qi*, though without limit, becomes the Supreme Ultimate; it gives birth to heaven and earth, to man and all things. Within the human body, it resides in the Yellow Court, coursing through the hundred meridians. In its vastness, it encompasses the cosmos; in its minuteness, it is no different from a millet grain. Yet even a millet grain has form and shape, while this *qi* is so subtle as to be formless and traceless. Though the cosmos has bounds, this *qi* is so great as to pervade without gap. How profound! How ultimate! How exhaustive!

In my earlier *Treatise on Pointing to the Wondrous*, I already expounded this principle, yet few have grasped it. Now I reveal to the immortals and the true: the first step in cultivation must begin here. If you do not thoroughly comprehend this principle, even after kalpas of practice, it is but ‘having-activity’—and having-activity is having-leakage, far removed from the Dao. Only non-activity is without leakage, enabling you to unite in virtue with heaven and earth, and in brightness with sun and moon.

All you cultivators who aspire to comprehend the Dao and realize the true—without understanding this pre-celestial singular *qi*, how can you succeed?"

chunks.original_text: 天尊告曰：「学道之士，欲明心性，先须知得心性从出之原：盖人物始生，皆由天赋其性，地载其形，故天地谓之大父大母。 从古佛仙圣贤，莫不首敬天地。 虽人有贫富贵贱男女贤不肖之分，而其戴高履厚，则一也。 末俗不知性所从来，命由天定，肆意任心，逆天背理，以致天鉴其恶，或贫或贱，或疾或夭。 世愚不察，孽由自作： 谓天弗佑，横出怨谤，是谓『怼天』； 假饰己善，妄求非分，是谓『欺天』； 暗室作非，遇人掩着，是谓『昧天』； 口谈仁义，心多荆棘，谓天弗知，谓人罔觉，是谓『诳天』； 对诸三光，弗诚弗敬，威仪弗检，畏惧弗存，是谓『亵天』； 己命偶乖，嫉人富有，瞋天弗公，是谓『诬天』； 读书不明，诵经弗解，妄议前人，讥诽有道，是谓『藐天』； 即有一二修省之子，略知向善，无如善念未纯，善根未固，善果未深，遂希福报，妄延僧道，章奏屡陈，是谓『渎天』。 吾今告尔修士，务宜首敬天地。 然所谓敬，又非媚天以邀福也。 正直之人，尚不受媚，况天地乎！ 所谓敬者，盖从自己性天中，时时省察； 于自己心地上，刻刻检点。 一言而弗合于天地，弗言也； 一行而弗合于天地，弗行也。 以吾神明之性天，仰体乎于穆之天； 以吾静镇之心地，俯察乎安宁之地。 如子舆氏所云：『存心养性以事天』如礼所云：『闻雷而惧，中夜必兴。 』斯称敬畏，若末俗凡流，素无实行，矫举以祭，祗曰谩天，非敬畏也。 然心性难明，以敬畏入，虽暗室屋漏，常若天地神明，昭鉴在上，如此存心，则非僻无自而生。 非僻不生，则心君泰然，性天朗霁，身口意业，自然清净，三业清净，则六根六尘，俱可清净，而入圣之基，已有体段。 然又不可一刻放逸，加以时时洗涤之功。 及至阴符消尽，阳神脱现，浑浑默默，天真发光，端坐天廷，隐显莫测。 名之曰佛，佛亦强名； 名之曰仙，仙亦强称。 仙乎佛乎？ 圣耶贤耶？ 名虽多种，实由一心。 惟心与性，是二是一。 心性与天，同体不异，是谓三才，与道为一。 敬畏天地，功效最神； 不知敬畏，漫曰学道，祗是魔精，命终之后，必堕恶趣，永失真道。 」 清净身业章第四

The Heavenly Worthy declared: "Those who study the Dao and seek to understand mind and nature must first know the origin from which mind and nature arise. All beings—human and otherwise—begin their lives through heaven bestowing their nature and earth bearing their form; thus, heaven and earth are called the Great Father and Great Mother. From ancient times, buddhas, immortals, sages, and worthies have all revered heaven and earth first. Though people differ in wealth and poverty, nobility and lowliness, male and female, worthy and unworthy, all alike bear the high and tread the thick.

The degenerate customs of later ages fail to recognize that nature comes from heaven and life is ordained by fate. They indulge their minds at will, defy heaven, and violate principle, thereby incurring heaven’s judgment of their evil—some falling into poverty or lowliness, others into illness or early death. The foolish of the world do not examine themselves but blame their own karma on others: calling heaven unhelpful, they utter wanton complaints—this is called ‘resenting heaven.’ Feigning goodness, they covet what is not theirs—this is called ‘deceiving heaven.’ Acting wrongly in secret, they conceal it when discovered—this is called ‘obscuring heaven.’ Speaking of benevolence and righteousness, their hearts brim with thorns; believing heaven does not know and others do not perceive, they deceive—this is called ‘duping heaven.’ Facing the Three Luminaries, they lack sincerity and reverence, neglect dignity, and abandon awe—this is called ‘profaning heaven.’ When their own fate falters, they envy others’ wealth, resenting heaven as unjust—this is called ‘slandering heaven.’ Unenlightened in study, uncomprehending in scripture recitation, they recklessly criticize the ancients and mock the virtuous—this is called ‘belittling heaven.’ Even among the few who cultivate and reflect, who vaguely incline toward goodness, their good thoughts remain impure, their good roots unsteady, their good fruits shallow. Yet they crave blessings, recklessly summon monks and Daoists, repeatedly submitting memorials—this is called ‘defiling heaven.’

I now tell you cultivators: you must first revere heaven and earth. Yet this reverence is not flattering heaven to seek fortune. Upright people do not accept flattery—how much less heaven and earth! True reverence arises from constantly examining one’s own nature-heaven and ceaselessly scrutinizing one’s own mind-ground. If a word does not accord with heaven and earth, do not speak it; if an action does not accord with heaven and earth, do not perform it. With the luminous nature-heaven of our spirit, we look up to embody the profound heaven; with the tranquil mind-ground of our heart, we look down to observe the peaceful earth. As Master Ziyu said: ‘Preserve the mind and nurture nature to serve heaven.’ As the rites prescribe: ‘Hearing thunder, one fears; in the dead of night, one rises.’ This is called reverence and awe. But the vulgar of later ages, lacking true conduct, perform rituals with false gestures—this is merely ‘deceiving heaven,’ not reverence.

Yet mind and nature are difficult to understand; entering through reverence and awe, even in the darkest chamber, one feels as though heaven and earth’s divine luminosity shines above, ever observing. With such a mind, deviance cannot arise. When deviance does not arise, the mind’s sovereign is at peace, nature-heaven bright and clear. Body, speech, and thought naturally become pure. When the three karmas are pure, the six roots and six dusts can all be purified, and the foundation for entering sagehood is already established.

Yet one must not relax for even a moment, but constantly apply the work of cleansing. When the yin tally is fully dissolved and the yang spirit emerges, vast and silent, the celestial true radiates light. Seated in the heavenly court, hidden and manifest are unfathomable. This is called a buddha—though ‘buddha’ is but a forced name; this is called an immortal—though ‘immortal’ is but a forced term. Immortal or buddha? Sage or worthy? Though names vary, in truth they arise from one mind. Mind and nature—are they two or one? Mind, nature, and heaven share the same body, no different. This is called the Three Powers, united with the Dao as one.

Revering heaven and earth yields the most wondrous efficacy. Without reverence and awe, to speak of studying the Dao is mere demonic delusion. After the end of life, one will surely fall into evil destinies, forever losing the true Dao."

Having established reverence and awe in the heart, the Three Karmas may be purified. Yet these Three Karmas must be examined in each matter and scrutinized at all times to gradually achieve purity.

Take bodily karma, for instance: killing, stealing, and lust—regardless of wealth, status, or rank, all people possess these. What does "possess" mean? Consider the karma of *killing*: at its gravest, emperors wage war recklessly, generals slaughter surrendered cities, and civil officials treat lives as grass, executing the innocent without cause. Next, the powerful and wealthy indulge in unjust slaughter, butchers and brokers cruelly carve living beings. Even in small matters, such as harming insects at the start of spring or cutting down plants in their early growth—these are all readily visible forms of killing karma. Moreover, when common fools harbor grudges, they seek to annihilate their enemies. The moment hatred arises, the impulse to kill stirs, and Heaven records their sin in the ledger of slaughter, ensuring they receive the retribution of killing, with no escape. There are also those cunning clerks and officers who wield their pens to destroy lives, disregarding Heaven’s principles, perverting justice, and tormenting the innocent. Through such killing causes, killing effects are brewed, and karmic vengeance continues endlessly. The *Most High* said: "The Way of Heaven: it does not contend yet excels in victory, does not speak yet responds perfectly. Heaven’s net is vast and wide, loose yet never failing—how could there be no retribution?" Yet the ancient sages’ warnings against killing were but general admonitions; I now expound upon them in detail. You, all learners, if you purify the karma of killing, you embody the virtue of cherishing life, for all creatures, however humble, share the same body as we. From ancient times, sages and worthies have held compassion for all beings as their heart. To cherish life is to purify killing karma; when killing karma is purified, the primordial qi of Great Harmony resides within, and this heart communes with Heaven and Earth. What disaster would not vanish? What blessing would not increase?

Next is *stealing*. Even common men and women who retain a shred of shame would not willingly commit theft. It seems rare, yet what constitutes stealing? Must one rob in broad daylight or break in at night to be called a thief? Whenever officials embezzle state treasuries or take what belongs to others—be it a blade of grass, a flower, a sip of water, or a bite of food—it is called stealing! For if the thing is not one’s own and is secretly taken, deceiving others without their knowledge, it is theft. Thus, the sages of old took nothing not rightfully theirs, no matter how small, and were meticulous in caution—this was their principle. As for scholars and literati who plagiarize writings to seize empty fame and deceive the world, this is an even graver form of theft. Heaven detests such intent, and the spirits observe it. Eventually, exposure brings ridicule upon the scholarly community. This kind of stealing karma is widely committed yet seldom recognized, truly treacherous.

Next is *lust*. Lust is a transgression the world easily commits, and the powerful, wealthy, scholars, and literati are the worst offenders. From ancient scriptures and sagely teachings, warnings against lust are earnest and urgent. For lust’s evils are boundless: it ruins reputations, corrupts virtue, inflicts endless harm, and spreads the gravest poison. One need not engage in the act itself to be called lustful. Composing lewd words, crafting obscene tools, harboring a single lustful thought, or recounting a single lewd tale—all reveal that the root of lust remains unsevered. How many in the world, when faced with seductive beauty, can maintain an undisturbed heart, unstained by even a speck of dust? The Buddha once instructed his disciples: "When you see a woman of age, regard her as your elder sister; when you see a young woman, regard her as your daughter." By reverently guarding the heart and preventing its dissipation, even when the eyes encounter sensual forms, the heart remains detached from them. Mastering this, the root of desire is eradicated, and one avoids defilement.

Yet the root of these Three Karmas lies in the *heart*! The wealthy, powerful, scholars, and literati commit these transgressions most frequently. You, all learners, if you wish to purify bodily karma, must first purify the heart. Once the root of karma is removed, its sprouts will never grow again.

**Chapter Five: Severing Verbal Karma**

Having purified bodily karma, one must still guard against verbal karma. For verbal karma is more easily committed than bodily karma, and even lofty and enlightened individuals often fail to restrain it. "Speak not unless it accords with propriety"—this is the essence of self-mastery. Among the disciples of Confucius, only Yan Yuan, who thrice reflected on his faults like a flaw in a white jade scepter, earned the Sage’s singular praise. Even one as talented as Zilu, who excelled in eloquence, brought regret upon himself with a single ill-considered remark, damaging trust—how much more so for others? Once, the Tathāgata Śākyamuni led his disciples across the Ganges, where they saw fishermen hauling a massive fish with the heads of a hundred beasts. The disciples, unable to fathom the cause, asked the Buddha: "What vile creature is this, to bear such a form? Is it not strange?" The Buddha replied: "In a past kalpa, there was a monk who, relying on his eloquence, would argue with others, insisting on victory. If even slightly contradicted, he would fly into a rage, hurling insults and curses, calling others by the names of beasts. His maledictions harmed others but ultimately harmed himself, deepening his karmic debt and worsening his retribution. For ten thousand kalpas, he was trapped in icy hells, unable to escape—is this not tragic?" Hearing these words, the great disciples listened intently, admonishing one another, and vowed that all beings would forever sever verbal karma to avoid falling into evil destinies.

Verbal karma has four aspects: deceitful speech and frivolous talk are common among the clever, while divisive speech and harsh words prevail among the foolish and lowly. For example, scholars newly entered into the literati, monks barely versed in Chan teachings, Daoist priests with a smattering of breathwork—all boast and brag, indulging in arrogance, uttering grand words to deceive the world.

Those who study Confucianism declare, *"I have attained the essence of holding to the Mean!"* Those who follow Buddhism proclaim, *"I have realized the supreme One Vehicle!"* Those who practice the Dao boast, *"I have achieved the Golden Elixir and Returned Cinnabar!"*—all are gross delusions. Clinging to their own delusions, they further deceive others, remaining mired in perversity their whole lives, never awakening.

To hear their words, one might think them equal to buddhas and immortals, comparable to sages and worthies. Yet observing their conduct, one finds them steeped in obscurity, no different from the common rabble.

As for frivolous speech, men of letters are especially prone to it. Their poetry is lush and seductive, their literary flourishes exquisite, flaunting their talent while violating the gravest precepts. Some even compose heretical doctrines to bewilder the ignorant, corrupting virtue, ruining reputations, and undermining customs—all for the fleeting thrill of a sharp pen, heedless of the boundless calamities they unleash. Thus, the transgression of frivolous speech is deeply insidious, and its retribution most severe.

As for divisive speech, it is not only the province of petty rogues who wag their tongues, distorting right and wrong. Even foolish men and women engage in it, speaking of this to that one, and of that to this one, inverting truth and falsehood—this, too, is divisive speech. Scholars who wield sophistry to alter facts, court officials whose proposals shift with the wind, causing rightful discourse to be muddled and the worthy to be estranged—all engage in divisive speech. So, too, do false teachers who lack firm conviction, wavering between two sides, leading their disciples astray.

As for harsh speech, it belongs to the foolish who seize upon others’ faults, magnifying flaws, indulging in mockery and slander, flaunting their own strengths while exposing others’ weaknesses. Such acts provoke Heaven’s wrath, and the hidden punishments—like the karmic fish of the Ganges—are truly lamentable.

Yet these evil deeds are not merely warned against in the scriptures of buddhas and immortals, which vividly describe the retribution of hells and the tearing out of tongues. Even the Confucian classics admonish: *"Words may incite war,"* as recorded in the *Book of Documents*; *"Be cautious in speech,"* as taught in the *Odes*. *"What harm can the mouth do? It is the gate of disaster,"* inscribed in the *Three Seals*. The words of sages and worthies are most concise and direct, while the teachings of buddhas and immortals are exhaustive and clear.

Now, I shall further elucidate for you: all present here, and all future beings, must heed my words. Abide by the admonition of the *Three Seals*, restrain yourselves in silence, do not flaunt your talent or wield your tongue recklessly. Be reverent in speech, ever mindful of caution—exercising care before words are spoken, and reflection as they are uttered. Let no false speech arise, no frivolous words be spoken; guard against divisive speech and forever sever harsh words. Through such purification, you may cultivate your person, serve Heaven, and lay the foundation for advancing virtue—this is of utmost importance.

**Chapter Six: Guarding Against the Karma of Thought**

When the karma of speech is purified, yet all that issues from the mouth arises from the mind. All thoughts are born of the heart, and the heart is the master of the body—its restraint must be strict. If one does not habitually exercise caution, using righteousness to govern affairs and ritual to govern the mind, then wickedness will frequently sprout, and once arisen, it becomes difficult to subdue. Both the karma of body and speech will then fail to be purified.

The peril of the mind may be likened to a team of four horses—only through skillful control can they be prevented from running wild. Thus, the sages and worthies of old taught people to be vigilant in solitude. Only by being vigilant in solitude can the thoughts that arise be sincere and free from deceit, and the karma of greed, anger, and delusion find no opportunity to arise, thereby purifying the mind.

Yet what is called "greed" is not limited to those who abuse power to extort, crave profit insatiably, abandon the law for bribes, or indulge in endless corruption. Even merchants who ensnare profits in the marketplace through manifold monopolies, or the powerful who scheme to exploit others down to the last penny—all are called greedy. As the *Most High* says: *"Do not see what may be desired, lest the mind be disturbed; rare and precious goods hinder right conduct."* The *Book of Rites* states: *"In distribution, do not seek excess."* For once greed arises, one knows only self-interest and disregards others; good thoughts vanish, and evil karma takes root.

Yet greed takes many forms, which cannot all be enumerated. If what one covets is fame, the mind is ensnared, and one becomes obsessed with gain and loss, stopping at nothing. Should desires go unfulfilled, resentment flares against others, and greed transforms into anger. If what one covets is profit, the mind schemes to seize what others possess to sate its own desires, resorting to cunning and deceit worse than theft. As Master Ziyu said: *"Rising at cock’s crow, toiling ceaselessly for gain."* Even the followers of Robber Zhi—do they not become thieves?

If what one covets is sensual pleasure, beauty is pursued without restraint, indulgence knows no bounds, and shame and integrity are cast aside. The inner chambers fall into disorder, and greed transforms into lust. All such karmic acts of greed arise in the mind and manifest in action: some rely on power to intimidate others into submission, while others employ cunning schemes to bend others to their will. The karma of body and speech thus accumulates.

The harm of greedy karma unfolds endlessly across lives and transformations—how can one not fear it? Now, I shall dissect and clarify this for you, all you learners: you must vow to purify yourselves and cleanse your minds. Do not indulge in greed, lest you entangle yourselves in the realms of suffering.

The first is "anger." The harm of anger is like a raging fire—once ignited, its flames spread like a wildfire, impossible to extinguish or approach. The *Classic of Yin Convergence* says: *"Fire is born of wood, and disaster erupts swiftly."* Thus, the buddhas and immortals of old practiced forbearance to extinguish the fire of anger. The *Most High* says: *"The highest virtue is like water, which benefits all things without contention and thus approaches the Dao. The soft overcomes the hard; the weak overcomes the strong."* The *Book of Rites* states: *"Do not seek to prevail through cruelty. If one can be yielding and humble, not seeking to surpass others, how can anger arise?"* The worthies of the Confucian tradition—such as Yanzi, who did not contend, and Master Meng, who turned inward—all regarded anger as harmful to the Dao, obstructing merit and virtue. Thus, even when faced with unjust treatment or violent provocation, they accepted it calmly and did not engage in dispute.

The foolish of the world, when slighted by others, immediately plot revenge, often leading to feuds and attacks. At best, they exchange bitter words; at worst, they resort to blades and slaughter. A moment’s rage may bring ruin upon oneself and one’s kin. Thus, the karma of anger, lurking within, causes the karma of body and speech to rage outwardly. Yet the deluded, even unto death, remain unaware—how tragic!

The second is "delusion." Delusion does not mean utter ignorance or dull-witted obscurity. Rather, it refers to those who stubbornly cling to their own views, pursuing a single path without knowing the great Dao or comprehending true principle. Their minds are shrouded in perverse views, and they cannot awaken. Once delusion takes deep root, even if they encounter a perfected being who teaches them the true path, they refuse to repent. Such deluded ones are truly benighted.

There are also those of keen intellect who know full well that worldly affairs are illusory, that glory fades swiftly, and that all possessions ultimately return to emptiness. Yet their desires and attachments are difficult to sever. Though they strive to restrain themselves, they soon relapse into confusion, and right understanding cannot take hold. Like the bright sun obscured by clouds, their true nature remains hidden, and they wander in delusion their whole lives. Only when form dissolves and life ends do they regret their past—too late! Too late!

Of the karma of body, speech, and mind, purification varies in difficulty. The karma of body and speech manifests outwardly and is easier to examine. Those of clear principle may succeed in this. But the mind is hidden and not easily discerned, making it even harder to control.

To purify these three karmas is to fulfill the *Ten Virtues*. When the Ten Virtues are complete, one may ascend to heaven. To indulge in these three karmas is to commit the *Ten Evils*. When the Ten Evils prevail, one sinks into the realms of suffering. All you learners, be vigilant over these three karmas, that you may enter the Dao.

**Chapter Seven: Investigating the Nature of the Original Mind**
When the three karmas are purified, one must seek to understand the supreme Dao. The essence of the supreme Dao is difficult to express in words: it is formless yet gives form to all forms, imageless yet gives image to all images. It is voiced as sound yet is truly soundless; it is colored as hue yet is truly colorless. Vast and indistinct, it cannot be known by wisdom nor grasped by perception.

In its presence, nothing is without it; in its absence, even heaven and earth do not know it. If heaven itself does not know it, how much less can man?
