Only the sages of middle antiquity, perceiving that later generations could not embody the whole in its entirety, were compelled to divide it into the three teachings by name. Though their names differ, their principle is one and the same. Thus it is said: “A thousand or ten thousand generations ago, if a sage appeared, this heart and this principle were the same; a thousand or ten thousand generations hence, if a sage appears, this heart and this principle will still be the same.” Therefore, the Buddha, in the *Lotus Sutra*, declared: “After the Buddha Sun-Moon-Lamp-Light, there was yet another Sun-Moon-Lamp-Light; after the Buddha King of Majestic Sound, there was yet another King of Majestic Sound!” And not only this—even through endless future kalpas, the three teachings, though distinct in path, converge in return. This is not the private word of one man, but the common word of sages past and present.

Of old, the Supreme Sage, in calling Laozi “like a dragon,” honored him to the utmost—yet the Supreme Sage never rejected the Dao. The *Scripture of the Western Ascension* states: “My teacher, the ancient sage-kings of India, are there; I shall now depart.” Thus Laozi never rejected the Buddha. Moreover, Śākyamuni Tathāgata, in a past kalpa, served the Longevity Immortal as his teacher and, at the assembly on Vulture Peak, recounted hearing the *Lotus Sutra*, declaring it to his disciples—thus the Tathāgata never rejected the immortals. The sages of the three teachings, in this heart and this principle, were originally without difference. Precisely because they are without difference, there is no division.

In human learning, must one necessarily master all three teachings? If one awakens to the one source and thoroughly investigates and clarifies it within the nature of the heart, then whether one studies Confucianism, Buddhism, or the Dao, upon full awakening, one naturally grasps the principle of the three teachings as one source. Thus, the Confucian must be a true Confucian, the Buddhist a true Buddhist, the Daoist a true Daoist. What is “true”? It is to embody the principle of utmost sincerity with a heart of utmost sincerity, and to cultivate the practice of utmost sincerity—truly one, not two. Then the sage may be aspired to, the Buddha may be learned from, and the immortal may be approached.

The Buddhist scriptures say: “What is called ‘sentient beings’ is not sentient beings.” If one merely follows superficial traces, slandering one another, content to be a sinner among the three teachings, this is called “sentient beings.”

Thereupon, the assembled immortals, having heard this, bowed in reverence and praised it in verse:

The Heavenly Worthy, great in compassion,
Expounded the principle of the three teachings—
Heart and nature share one source,
Heaven and humanity accord with the wondrous intent.
Like a mirror reflecting the clear void,
Like the moon imprinted on still water,
It reveals and manifests the fundamental vehicle,
Providing roots for cultivation.
Whether Confucian, Buddhist, or Daoist,
What division is there between them?
Only when one attains the great perfect enlightenment
Can one comprehend these words.
May all sentient beings universally
Not allow doubts and obstacles to arise.

When the immortals finished reciting this verse, in that moment, heavenly flowers rained down, circling the seat thrice. They bowed and withdrew, receiving and upholding the teaching.

*Verses in Praise of the Scripture of Uniting the Three*

Having concluded the Dharma-seat, together with the assembly of immortals, they reverently proceeded to the Palace of the Pure Jade in the Heaven of Miro. "I shall not shrink from toil, but on Heaven’s behalf proclaim transformation and deliver the deluded masses."

Thereupon, the Heavenly Worthy once more mounted a five-colored auspicious cloud and descended in spirit to Ezhu. At that moment, the forests had just shed their leaves, the metallic wind blew chill, the bright sun shone in the sky, cinnabar clouds streamed across the scene, the mountains stood in silent majesty, purple qi surged with radiance, and the assembly of immortals rejoiced, attending the Dharma-seat, eager to hear the essential teaching.

The Heavenly Worthy spoke: "I observe that within the divine continent of Shenzhou, far and near across Yu’s domains, all manner of unbalanced qi arise—now drought, now flood, now water, now fire, now locusts, now plague. Wherever calamity strikes, people remain unaware of the karmic causes of their retribution; instead, they grow ever more perverse, so that day after day, they cannot escape it.

"According to the Daoist scriptures, from *zi* to *yin* marks one minor kalpa; the twelve cyclical signs together make four minor kalpas; the accumulation of these minor kalpas forms one great kalpa. Thereupon, famine and scarcity arise, pestilence and plague emerge, warfare erupts, drought and flood recur, and prodigies appear. Or again, the sun and moon deviate from their courses, the stars lose their proper measure, mountains collapse, waters overflow, and famine follows famine—all manner of inauspicious events. Though these are said to be the workings of qi and destiny, they are in truth the result of human affairs.

"Thus, the ancients, when faced with calamity, were filled with awe and turned to cultivation, from the sovereign above to the myriad commoners below—none dared be negligent. When the ruler cultivates virtue without transgression, comets do not appear, and the sun and moon, though due to be eclipsed, remain uneclipsed. When officials maintain purity and self-discipline, locusts do not enter their borders, tigers cross rivers, and winds reverse to extinguish fires—such events are recorded in the historical annals, most clearly evident.

"In former times, there was a city whose inhabitants had all accumulated deep karmic offenses, and their number was due for slaughter. After the report was submitted by the Mountain and River Offices, the Celestial Emperor could not bear it. Raising his dragon countenance to observe from amidst the clouds, he saw only black qi and poisonous clouds, dense and unyielding over the city. In an instant, a single ray of auspicious light arose from a corner of the city, piercing straight to the Emperor’s throne. The Emperor said: ‘Excellent! This is the light of a filial son.’"

Thereupon, the Celestial Emperor commanded the Star Lord of Greed and Wolf to take up his staff and go forth to protect it, and thus the entire city was spared from slaughter. This account is recorded in *The Record of Emperor Wen’s Exhortation to Filial Piety* and may be examined for verification.

Now, the slaughter of an entire city is the gravest of calamities, the most severe of disasters. Yet because of a single filial son, it was absolved—clearly, the power to avert disaster lies with man, not entirely with fate. As the Book says: *"Heaven-sent misfortune may yet be avoided; self-inflicted misfortune cannot be escaped."* This is its proof.

Today, when people encounter widespread celestial disasters, they fail to reflect and reform, fail to strive for goodness, and instead recklessly engage in perverse prayers. How misguided! Worse still, some indulge in extravagance and dissipation, pursuing what is of no benefit—this is defiance of Heaven! Master Ziyu said: *"Those who follow the Way of Heaven endure; those who defy it perish."* To follow is to align with the principle of Heaven, not to violate the Dao in pursuit of fortune.

The Book further states: *"Revere and emulate the August Heaven."* "Revere" denotes the utmost awe and reverence; "emulate" denotes steadfast trust and compliance. When disaster strikes, if one cultivates virtue and practices benevolence: a single household’s goodness may spare that household from calamity; a region’s goodness may resolve that region’s distress. If all sentient beings could deeply ponder and earnestly practice these words, advancing in goodness, then the Celestial Emperor may be moved, disasters may be averted, and distress may be lifted. Even long-accumulated transgressions and deep-seated impurities would disperse like clouds before a fierce wind or melt like frost beneath the blazing sun.

Beware of being deluded by malevolent shamans and perverse mediums, recklessly offering prayers beyond one’s proper station—not only will this bring no benefit, but it will only deepen one’s karmic offenses! Be vigilant in your conduct, steadfast in your good deeds, for this is the essential path to dispelling calamity and distress.

chunks.original_text: 天尊复告大众曰：「天有沴运，可以移之； 星有失度，可以转之。 是天道转移，在乎人事，则人之一生，或富或贵，或贱或贫，或穷或通，或寿或夭，亦无一定。 修德之至，则贱者可贵，贫者可富，夭者可寿，穷者可通； 若极恶之人，其获报反此。 故人之得失，主之于天，虽人定可以胜天，而天定更可胜人。 天人交感，其理一也。 夫『川』本流也，防之可以使止，其流也，畅于形体之通； 『渊』本渟也，决之可以使行，其渟也，拘于形器之隘。 惟人亦然。 方其未达，若一无所能，一无所为，故行则拂乱，而有空乏饥饿，困心衡虑之苦； 及其既达，则有经天纬地之功，惊世骇俗之事。 究之祇一人之身，非能于后，而弗能于前。 盖时命阨之也，然富贵贫贱，循环无端。 青门种瓜人，旧日东陵侯，富贵可常恃乎？ 居朝参知政事之人，即昔日被人讥之瞌睡汉，贫贱可以欺乎？ 是以圣人体天之道，执天之行，居富贵而不骄，处贫贱而不忧，乐天知命，心若太虚，真气贯四时，聪明并日月，其行事与天合德，故其序易也：否泰相循，剥复相乘。 盖天地之气，剥不终剥，剥极而复。 人事亦然，泰不常泰，泰过则否。 太上曰：『天之道，其犹张弓乎？ 高者抑之，下者举之，有余者损之，不足者补之。 』人之道亦然：福兮祸所倚，祸兮福所伏。 孰知其极，其无正耶？ 正复为奇，善复为妖。 故人之一身，与天道相表里。 《阴符经》云：『天性人也，人心机也。 立天之道，以定人也。 天人合发，万变定基。 』故凡希圣希仙，先须明此天人合一之旨。 则『宇宙在乎手，万化生乎身。 』可以弥纶天地之道，辅相天地之宜，是为最上一乘之理。 然此天人合一之旨，乃尽性之极功，至命之能事。 初学之士，如何能之？ 亦惟于自己心性中，时时体认。 盖人一心，本具有天理，人心即是天心。 天有太极，人心亦有太极； 天有中和； 人心亦有中和。 子思子曰：『道不远人，人之为道而远人，不可以为道。 』 盖人心外无道，道外无心。 凡人修道，即修心也，修心即修道也。 道有异乎？ 心有异乎？ 人人有此一心，即人人各具一天； 人人同此一心，即人人同此天，同此道也。 但世人汨于嗜欲，自蔽其天，自昧其心，不能于声臭俱泯中，求取帝载之天。 即吾心一念未动时，直与于穆之天，呼吸相通，非舍一心之外，别有所谓道理合之也。 若离此心以求合天，是即邪说诬民，非正道也。 昔　予曾谓『点金一术，恐误五百年后人』，正为此心，不敢自欺以欺天，故蒙　圣师接引成真。 即今之飞鸾演化，亦是运此慈心，代天行道。 若是众生心同　予心，天必佑之，予亦鉴之，至道可得矣。 」 持盛在德章第二十四

The Heavenly Worthy again addressed the great assembly, saying: "When Heaven’s qi is in disorder, it may yet be redirected; when stars deviate from their courses, they may yet be realigned. For the Dao of Heaven shifts in response to human affairs—thus in a person’s life, whether one is noble or base, wealthy or poor, obstructed or unobstructed, long-lived or short-lived, none is fixed. Through the utmost cultivation of virtue, the base may become noble, the poor may grow rich, the short-lived may attain longevity, and the obstructed may find passage. Yet for those steeped in extreme evil, the retribution is the reverse. Thus human gains and losses are governed by Heaven, for though human resolve may overcome Heaven’s decree, Heaven’s decree may yet overcome human resolve. Heaven and humanity interact and resonate—this principle is one.

The river is by nature flowing; by damming it, one may halt its course, yet its flow is the unimpeded passage of form and body. The abyss is by nature still; by breaching it, one may set it in motion, yet its stillness is the constraint of form and vessel. So too is it with humanity. When one has not yet attained enlightenment, one seems utterly incapable, utterly powerless—thus in action, one meets with disorder, suffering want, hunger, and the torment of a heart besieged by cares. Yet once enlightened, one may achieve deeds that order Heaven and Earth, startling the world and confounding custom. Yet this is still but one and the same person—no different in later days than in former. The obstruction lies in the constraints of time and fate. Yet wealth and nobility, poverty and baseness, cycle endlessly without cease.

The melon-grower at the Blue Gate was once the Marquis of Dongling—can wealth and nobility be relied upon forever? The man who attends court and assists in governance was once the drowsy lout mocked by others—can poverty and baseness be despised? Thus the sage embodies Heaven’s Dao and upholds Heaven’s workings: abiding in wealth and nobility without arrogance, dwelling in poverty and baseness without sorrow, delighting in Heaven and knowing fate, the heart vast as the Great Void. True qi courses through the four seasons, wisdom parallels the sun and moon. Such a one’s conduct harmonizes with Heaven’s virtue, and thus their destiny unfolds: adversity and prosperity follow in turn, decline and renewal alternate.

For the qi of Heaven and Earth does not remain in decline forever—when decline reaches its limit, renewal begins. So too with human affairs: prosperity does not endure unbroken, for when prosperity exceeds its measure, adversity follows. The Most High said: ‘The Dao of Heaven is like the drawing of a bow: what is high is pressed down, what is low is raised up; what is excessive is diminished, what is deficient is replenished.’ So too is it with the human Dao: fortune leans upon misfortune, misfortune harbors fortune. Who knows their ultimate end? Is there no constancy? The upright reverts to the strange, the good reverts to the ominous. Thus the human person and the Dao of Heaven are mutually reflective.

The *Yin Fu Jing* states: ‘Heaven’s nature is humanity’s nature; the human heart is the mechanism of change. Establishing Heaven’s Dao is to stabilize humanity. When Heaven and humanity act in unison, the foundation of all transformations is set.’ Therefore, those who aspire to sagehood or immortality must first grasp this principle of Heaven and humanity as one. Then ‘the cosmos rests in the palm of the hand, the myriad transformations arise from the body.’ One may thereby encompass the Dao of Heaven and Earth, assisting and harmonizing with their workings—this is the supreme principle of the highest vehicle.

Yet this principle of Heaven and humanity as one is the ultimate achievement of exhausting one’s nature and the consummate mastery of destiny. How can beginners attain it? They must only ceaselessly embody it within their own heart and nature. For the human heart inherently possesses Heaven’s principle: the human heart *is* the Heavenly heart. Heaven has the Great Ultimate; the human heart also has the Great Ultimate. Heaven has harmony; the human heart also has harmony.

Master Zisi said: ‘The Dao is not far from humanity. If one practices the Dao while distancing oneself from humanity, it cannot be called the Dao.’ For outside the human heart, there is no Dao; outside the Dao, there is no heart. Thus when one cultivates the Dao, one cultivates the heart; when one cultivates the heart, one cultivates the Dao. Is the Dao distinct? Is the heart distinct? Every person possesses this one heart—thus every person possesses their own Heaven. Every person shares this one heart—thus every person shares this Heaven, shares this Dao.

Yet worldly people, drowned in desires, obscure their Heaven and darken their hearts. They cannot seek the Heaven of the Imperial Chariot amid the extinction of sound and scent. Yet in the instant before a thought arises in our hearts, we are directly in communion with the profound and silent Heaven, breathing in unison—there is no separate principle of harmony beyond this heart. To seek union with Heaven apart from this heart is to propagate heretical teachings that deceive the people; it is not the true Dao.

Formerly, I once remarked, ‘A single alchemical technique may mislead people five hundred years hence.’ It was precisely for this heart that I dared not deceive myself to deceive Heaven, and thus I was guided by the sagely teacher to achieve perfection. Even now, in the flight of the phoenix and the transformations of the numinous, I am but employing this heart of compassion to act on Heaven’s behalf. If the hearts of all beings align with my heart, Heaven will surely bless them, and I too will witness it—then the supreme Dao may be attained."

The feathered kind numbers three hundred and sixty, with the phoenix as their chief; the furred kind numbers three hundred and sixty, with the qilin as their chief; the crawling kind numbers three hundred and sixty, with humans as their chief. Within the cosmos, the myriad beings are not uniform: flying and walking creatures differ, the numinous and the dull vary. Each follows its endowed nature, born and nurtured between Heaven and Earth. If one seeks to compare and make them the same, how could it be possible?

Not only among creatures—even the vastness of Heaven and Earth, the brilliance of the sun and moon, should cover and embrace all, should illuminate all. Yet Heaven does not fill the southeast, Earth does not fill the northwest; in the northernmost reaches of extreme yin, the sun and moon cannot shine. Thus Zisi said, *"Great as Heaven and Earth are, people still have regrets."* Qu Yuan asked, *"Where the sun does not reach, how does the Torch Dragon illuminate? Before Xihe has risen, how does Ruohua shine?"* Even with the vastness of Heaven and Earth, the brightness of the sun and moon, there are still insufficiencies—how much more so for humans?

Long ago, the Perfected King of Total Reality served as disciple to the Lady Ma Gu. The Lady told him, *"Since I began receiving guests, the blue seas have thrice turned to mulberry fields, and the waters of Penglai have grown shallow!"* Thus time passes in an instant, swift as a white colt flashing past a gap—no metaphor suffices. Wang Zhi’s axe-handle rotted while he watched, and a thousand years turned in a glance; the fisherman at the river’s mouth returned to find the ford lost. Within the Six Directions, all is illusion; every sentient being is but a phantom body. Through illusion one experiences illusion—strange transformations, wondrous changes. Since ancient times, none could exhaust their telling. If one pursues this to its ultimate end, even Heaven and Earth are but illusory transformations, destined for decay. Thus it is said: *"Sincerity is the beginning and end of things,"* and Heaven and Earth are but one thing among them. Only Heaven and Earth endure long—humans cannot match them! Yet even Heaven and Earth have no time of perfect flourishing.

Observe the sun and moon: the sun at noon begins to decline, the moon at full begins to wane. The Way of waxing and waning turns with the seasons. Observe the mountains and rivers: waters fill and overflow, earth fills and crumbles—the principle of collapse and overflow moves with things. Observe the hundred creatures: the morning mushroom knows not dusk or dawn, the cicada knows not spring or autumn—their natures, though subtle, differ. In the fourth month, a hundred plants flourish, grasses and trees luxuriate, yet the withered grasses die first—can this be explained? In the first month, thunder roars, and the fruits and grasses all split their husks, while peach and plum vie to bloom; when the warm south wind stirs, pomegranate flames grow more radiant, lotus fragrance fills the air, and peach and plum pale by comparison. At the first breath of the golden wind, white dew congeals, late chrysanthemums stir the reclusive heart, and water caltrop and lotus lose their scent. The clear pool’s green waters—where now are the lotuses of old?

Examine the four seasons: cold and heat alternate, flourishing and withering, growth and decay—none can be fully recorded! The inequality of things is the nature of things. One cannot force the walking to fly, nor compel the dull to be numinous—their natures are thus. When the Divine Lord of Nanhua spoke of making them equal, he did not mean to make things identical, but rather that in considering their beginning and end, their return to the root and restoration of fate, they are equal.

Thus the perfected person, taking lessons from afar in things and from near at hand in the self, knows that waxing and waning, growth and decay, are but the Way of cyclical replacement. Here abundance, there scarcity—there is no principle of perpetual flourishing. Therefore, one acts according to one’s station without desiring what lies beyond. Even in times of utmost flourishing, one must ever be wary of collapse. Thus, to occupy a high position without arrogance is to long preserve nobility; to dwell in abundance without extravagance is to long preserve wealth.

For this reason, the sages arranged the *Book of Changes*, placing *"Humility"* after *"Great Possession."* Only by being *"great"* and yet *"humble"* can one long preserve what one has—not only in times of perfect flourishing. Long ago, the Sage Confucius praised Wei Gongzi Jing for his skill in managing his household, simply because he knew contentment! The Most High said, *"Knowing contentment brings no disgrace; knowing when to stop brings no danger—this is how one endures."* The Buddhist scriptures say, *"The contented, though poor, are rich; the discontented, though rich, are poor, and are ever pitied by the contented."* The *Odes* say, *"Neither envious nor covetous—what use is not good?"* For once discontent arises, greed is born; with greed, envy and desire grow strong, and one loses the Way of meeting circumstances—how much more so in times of perfect flourishing!

Thus, in times of flourishing, joy arises, and with it arrogance and extravagance. If even one matter goes against one’s wishes, sorrow arises, and with it anger. This is the inevitable path of mutual succession. In the vastness of the cosmos, across the expanse of past and present, are there none who have known perfect flourishing? I need not recount them all—take the eight Xis of Jin, the three ministers and five great officials: they were truly flourishing! Yet in but a few generations, their descendants were plowing the fields. Or take Fengyang of Tang, who restored the imperial enterprise, whose name is recorded in history, who reached the pinnacle of ministerial rank, whose court was filled with officials—truly flourishing! Yet in but a few generations, the mansions bestowed upon him belonged to others. Where now is that perfect flourishing?

Thus, the Way of flourishing lies only in guarding it with humility, dwelling in restraint, and preserving it with virtue. As for the reckoning of rise and fall, leave it to Heaven, accept it as fate. To wish for perfect flourishing without a single loss—this has never existed since ancient times.

chunks.original_text: 「道之化也，虚化神，神化气，气化形，形生而万物塞焉！ 何以塞？ 塞于形气之碍也。 人之一身，目司视，耳司听。 其视也、明也、听也、聪也，其形各殊，其用别也。 今夫鸡羽类也，于昼则明，于夜则昏； 鸮亦羽类也，于昼则昏，于夜则明。 鸮之各为异也，滞于形气之碍也。 今试观之虚空，虚空非有也，而有道者，可以履虚空； 观之金石，金石非无也，而有道者，可以贯金石。 人之一身，五官四体，不能交相为用也，而　如来神力，目可为耳功德，耳可为目功德，其转塞为通者，何也？ 化也。 道无乎不化，亦无乎不神。 今夫五行，土本制水，而水滋复能伤土，土为之淤； 木本生火，而火烈复能毁木，木为之灰。 其生也、也、变也、化也。 其变也，自无而有，非无因而有也； 其化也，自有而无，非无因而无也，有因缘在焉。 昔　释迦说法，种种因缘譬喻，而憍陈如等，俱以因缘得悟，《法华》说因缘一周，而富楼那等，俱得授记。 不特古圣佛祖，即　予昔以妙行真人，降神吕氏，亦有因焉。 若无夙因，何以得降生于其家乎？ 即遇　正阳圣师，授以《度人经》一卷，亦由圣祖　少阳帝君，语以因缘，故得度也。 且　圣祖周人，于汉时始度　正阳，亦由　太上指令下山，于要路候之，度归仙洞。 圣祖以度　正阳功，证　东华紫府少阳帝君。 后　圣师亦以度　予之功，证　正阳传道垂极帝君。 若无因缘，则自周迄汉，历数百载； 自汉至唐，又数百载，何能不期而遇乎？ 故宇宙之大，若无前因，觌面失之； 若系夙因，虽千里万里，不为远也！ 昔东土　初祖，承西天　二十七祖命曰：『汝之因缘，在于震旦。 』遂航海而至，适梁武帝天监年中，因举帝论弗契，退归少室，面壁九载，后遇　神光，授以偈曰：『一花开五叶，结果自然成。 』传至　六祖，适符一花五叶之数，岂非因缘有前定乎？ 即　予阐演毗陵，及栖真各处，或因缘宜久则久，宜速则速，未有无因而得遇也！ 然　予奉　玉清灵宝之简命，弥罗金阙之灵符，于大千世界，普度有缘，慈悲之心，期无人弗度，故一日大赴三千场，又岂仅一方一处而已乎！ 然愿固洪深，因由夙植，譬之『雨露之养，不能滋无根之木。 』故因小缘小，因大缘大，未有善因而恶缘者，亦未有恶因而善缘者，即如楚中所建　予坛，不知凡几！ 况自唐至今，历有千载，海疆之大，予坛几千百万，然今之好　予道者，即前劫曾有奉　予之因。 其缘深者，因深也； 缘浅者，因浅也。 尔诸弟子，幸今聚此一坛，非偶然之因，宜各修省，即是善因，同结善缘。 若能修持不退，至于因深缘熟，了道成真，方可自信。 昔　舍利弗，于威音王时，即在　释迦佛往因中为弟子，劫劫相依，未尝少替，后于　释迦会中智慧第一。 尔诸弟子，但办诚心，深信因缘，善芽日新，善业斯懋，慎毋迷昧，自堕岐径。 」 罪福报应章第二十六

The Dao’s transformation moves thus: from emptiness it transforms into spirit, from spirit into qi, from qi into form, and with form’s arising, the myriad things fill all! Yet why do they fill all? They are obstructed by the hindrances of form and qi. Within the human body, the eyes govern sight, the ears govern hearing. Their sight is clarity, their hearing is acuity—yet their forms differ, and their functions are distinct. Consider the fowl, a creature of feathers: by day it sees clearly, by night it is dim; the owl, too, is a feathered creature, yet by day it is dim, by night it sees clearly. Why do owl and fowl differ thus? They are bound by the hindrances of form and qi. Now observe emptiness: emptiness is not *being*, yet those who possess the Dao may tread upon emptiness. Observe metal and stone: metal and stone are not *non-being*, yet those who possess the Dao may pierce through them. Within the human body, the five senses and four limbs cannot interchange their functions, yet through the Tathāgata’s divine power, the eyes may perform the ears’ merit, the ears may perform the eyes’ merit. How is it that obstruction is transformed into communication? Through transformation. The Dao transforms without ceasing, and its spirit moves without limit.

Now consider the five phases: earth by nature restrains water, yet water in abundance may harm earth, turning it to sludge; wood by nature generates fire, yet fire in its fury may destroy wood, reducing it to ash. Their arising, their decay, their change, their transformation—all unfold thus. In change, being arises from non-being, yet not without cause; in transformation, non-being arises from being, yet not without cause. There are always conditions at work.

Long ago, when Śākyamuni expounded the Dharma, he employed manifold conditions and parables, and Kauṇḍinya and the others all awakened through conditions. When the *Lotus Sutra* completed its exposition of conditions, Pūrṇa and the others all received predictions of buddhahood. Not only the ancient sages and buddha-ancestors—even I, in a former life as the Perfected One of Wondrous Conduct, descended in spirit to the Lü family, and this, too, had its conditions. Had there been no prior causes, how could I have been born into that household? Later, when I encountered the Sagely Master of Correct Yang, who transmitted to me a scroll of the *Scripture of Salvation*, this, too, came about because the Sagely Ancestor, the Imperial Lord of Lesser Yang, had spoken of the conditions, and thus I was delivered. Moreover, the Sagely Ancestor was a man of Zhou, and it was only in the Han dynasty that he delivered Correct Yang—this, too, was because the Most High had commanded him to descend the mountain and await him at a critical juncture, delivering him to the immortal caves. The Sagely Ancestor, by virtue of delivering Correct Yang, realized the title of Imperial Lord of Lesser Yang of the Eastern Florescence’s Purple Palace. Later, the Sagely Master, by virtue of delivering me, realized the title of Imperial Lord of the Transmission of the Dao and the Perpetuation of the Ultimate. Had there been no conditions, how could they have met by chance across hundreds of years from Zhou to Han, and again from Han to Tang? Thus, in the vastness of the cosmos, without prior causes, one may miss the encounter even face to face; yet with prior causes, though separated by thousands of miles, distance is no obstacle!

Long ago, the First Ancestor of the Eastern Land received the command of the twenty-seventh ancestor of the Western Heaven: “Your conditions lie in the Land of the Sinitic Realm.” He crossed the sea and arrived in the Tianjian era of Emperor Wu of Liang. When the emperor’s discourse failed to resonate, he withdrew to Shaoshi, where he sat in wall-gazing meditation for nine years. Later, he encountered Shenguang and transmitted to him the verse: “One flower opens into five leaves, and the fruit naturally ripens.” By the time of the Sixth Ancestor, the prophecy of one flower and five leaves was fulfilled—was this not the predetermination of conditions?

Even in my own propagation of the teachings in Piling and my retreat to various sacred sites, whether the conditions called for duration or haste, there was never an encounter without cause! Yet I, bearing the celestial mandate of the Jade Purity and Numinous Treasure, the divine tally of the Golden Towers of the Miro Realm, universally deliver those with conditions throughout the great thousandfold world. My heart of compassion aspires to deliver all beings, and thus in a single day I preside over three thousand assemblies—how could this be limited to one place alone? Yet though my vows are vast and deep, they depend upon prior cultivation. This is like “the nurturance of rain and dew, which cannot nourish a rootless tree.” Thus, minor conditions yield minor results, and major conditions yield major results. There has never been a good cause leading to evil conditions, nor an evil cause leading to good conditions.

Consider the altars I have established in the land of Chu—how many there have been! Moreover, from the Tang dynasty to the present, a thousand years have passed, and across the vastness of the maritime frontier, my altars number in the thousands and tens of thousands. Yet those who today favor my Dao are those who in former kalpas once upheld my causes. Those with deep conditions have deep causes; those with shallow conditions have shallow causes.

You, my disciples, are fortunate to gather here at this altar today—this is no accidental cause. Each of you should cultivate introspection, for this is the planting of good causes and the weaving of good conditions. If you can persevere in cultivation without retreat, until causes deepen and conditions ripen, you will realize the Dao and attain perfection—only then may you trust in yourselves.

Long ago, Śāriputra, in the time of King Brahmā Voice, was already a disciple in the former life of Śākyamuni Buddha. Through kalpa after kalpa, he never wavered in his devotion, and later, in Śākyamuni’s assembly, he became foremost in wisdom. You, my disciples, need only bring forth sincerity, deeply believe in conditions, and day by day nurture the sprout of goodness, that your virtuous karma may flourish. Take care not to be deluded, lest you stray onto deviant paths.

chunks.original_text: 「上古之世，淳气未漓，圣哲在上，化成天下，人皆有善而无恶； 中古之世，淳气既漓，为恶者多，作善者少，故圣人以神道设教，明善恶报应之趣，生死轮回之理，使人迁善而改过。 然世之儒者，不知天道好旋，惠迪吉，从逆凶，亳发不爽，闻佛仙所说报应神验之事，率以为荒渺无稽，至谓佛法未入中国以前，并无所谓『碓舂磨研』者。 不知地狱苦报，载诸仙经者，历历可考，岂但佛经已乎？ 况修善者生天，积恶者三途苦趣，圣有明训。 特事属幽渺，人未及见耳！ 太上曰：『天之道，不争而善胜，不言而善应。 』岂尽无稽乎？ 即佛经碓舂磨研，种种地狱变相，亦只为下根之人，难以理训，不得不明示三途苦趣，以儆惕之。 实佛氏慈悲，不得已耳！ 《维摩经》云：『此方之人，刚强难化，故佛为说刚强之语以调伏之。 』非谓修善之人，亦有碓舂磨研之苦报也！ 故于上中之资，则惟宣说明心见性之功，于罪福报应，祇戒其勿犯耳！ 然报应之理，不特佛仙谆谆诰诫，即载之儒书者，亦难枚举！ 如《春秋》一书，古圣垂训之大经大法。 然《春秋》事载于前，报应验之于后，二百四十二年之间，其为报应彰彰者何限？ 试举数事言之： 齐襄公实死鲁君，及鲁人问罪，而推其罪于公子彭生。 至崔杼之乱，公见豕人立而泣曰：『公子彭生也。 』因惊走，遂遇难。 郑国鬼祸，语兆于明年杀段之前，事验于次年杀段之际，讵非冤仇相报于死后者乎！ 齐桓公葵邱之会，初命曰：『无易树子，无以妾为妻。 』而内嬖如夫人者六人，以致死后，五子争立，不得殓，尸虫迸于寝门之外，此非背誓之惨报乎！ 晋献公假道灭虢，谋极阴险，而天亦以阴险报之。 献公纳骊姬，而生奚齐卓子，灭人之国而纳其女，仇人在侧，迷而弗知！ 以致杀申生，走重耳，怀惠出，几丧其国。 宁谓阴谋诡计，天弗知乎？ 若魏颗之结草退敌，感其从父治命嫁父妾，以恩报之于地下，谁谓鬼神尽渺茫乎？ 然昌黎韩子，大儒也，亦谓左氏浮夸； 柳子厚，才人也，于此种亦多不信，况下此者乎？ 古今来善恶报应亦不止此，如吕不韦，以孕妾献秦王，欲其子为天子，后为始皇，故秦帝以吕易嬴，然不韦卒死其子之手。 不韦可谓巧矣！ 而天之报施，尤为巧焉！ 春申君以娠妾进楚王，亦欲其子之为王也，而卒见杀于其妾。 是谋人者终被人谋，害人者卒为人害，祸不旋踵也。 然此犹为报复之在人类者。 至于秦将武安君，坑长平军四十万，至今身堕畜生道中，未有了期！ 夫以秦之暴虐，白起以暴虐佐之，视数十万苍生，不啻一犬豕！ 天道好生，宜其受斯苦报，万劫难复也！ 至于野史所载，与夫《功过》《劝善》诸书，或得之传闻，或得之目击，其事迹纵极怪异，俱属可信，非尽虚诞，荒渺无稽。 盖宇宙之大，理之所无，每为事之所有，焉可诬也。 诗曰：『神之格思，不可度思，矧可射思。 』又曰：『天维显思，陟降厥士，日鉴在兹。 』又曰：『上帝临汝，勿贰尔心。 』
chunks.translated_text:
In the age of high antiquity, when primordial qi had not yet dissipated, sagely and wise rulers governed above, transforming the world below. All people possessed goodness and knew no evil. In the middle antiquity, as primordial qi had already dissipated, those who did evil grew numerous while those who acted virtuously dwindled. Thus, the sages established teachings through the numinous Dao, clarifying the consequences of good and evil, the principles of karmic retribution, and the cycle of birth and death, guiding people to turn toward goodness and amend their faults.

Yet the Confucians of this world, unaware that the Dao of Heaven delights in cyclical return—rewarding those who follow the good and punishing those who defy it with unfailing precision—dismiss the karmic retributions and numinous verifications spoken of by Buddhas and immortals as absurd and baseless. Some even claim that before the advent of Buddhism in China, there were no such things as "pestles pounding, mills grinding" in the hells. They do not realize that the agonies of hellish retribution are recorded in the classics of immortals, clearly verifiable—how could this be found only in Buddhist scriptures? Moreover, the birth of the virtuous in heaven and the suffering of the wicked in the three evil destinies are teachings explicitly set forth by the sages. Only because such matters belong to the unseen do people fail to witness them!

The Most High has said: *"The Way of Heaven contends not, yet excels in victory; speaks not, yet excels in response."* Can this truly be groundless? Even the Buddhist depictions of pestles pounding, mills grinding, and the manifold transformations of hell are but expedient means for those of dull capacities, who cannot be instructed by principle alone. Thus, the three evil destinies must be vividly illustrated to warn and awaken them. This is the Buddha’s compassion, an unavoidable necessity.

The *Vimalakīrti Sutra* states: *"The people of this land are stubborn and difficult to transform, so the Buddha speaks in stern terms to subdue them."* It does not mean that those who cultivate goodness will suffer the torments of pestles and mills! Therefore, for those of superior and middling capacities, the teachings focus solely on illuminating the mind and perceiving the nature, while regarding karmic retribution, they are merely cautioned against transgression.

Yet the principle of retribution is not only earnestly expounded by Buddhas and immortals—even in the Confucian classics, such records are too numerous to count! Take the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, the great canon and law bequeathed by the ancient sages. The events it records occurred long ago, but their karmic consequences unfolded later. Within its span of two hundred and forty-two years, how boundless are the manifest retributions? Let us cite a few examples:

Duke Xiang of Qi murdered the ruler of Lu, yet when the people of Lu demanded justice, he shifted the blame onto Prince Pengsheng. Later, during the rebellion of Cui Zhu, the duke saw a boar standing upright and wept, crying, *"It is Prince Pengsheng!"* Terrified, he fled and met his doom. In Zheng, spectral omens foretold the killing of Duan the following year, and the event came to pass as predicted—was this not the settling of a grievance after death?

At the Assembly of Kuiqiu, Duke Huan of Qi first commanded: *"Do not replace the heir apparent; do not make a concubine your wife."* Yet he later favored six concubines as if they were proper wives. After his death, his five sons contended for the throne, his corpse lay unburied, and maggots swarmed beyond the palace gates—was this not the dire retribution for breaking his oath?

Duke Xian of Jin, in his cunning scheme to borrow a path to annihilate Guo, devised an utterly treacherous plot—yet Heaven repaid him with treachery in kind. He took Lady Li Ji as his consort, siring Xi Qi and Zhuo Zi; he destroyed a state and took its princess, harboring his enemy close, yet remained deluded and unaware! This led to the murder of Shensheng, the exile of Chong’er, and the flight of Huaihui, nearly bringing ruin to his kingdom. Could one truly claim that Heaven was oblivious to his scheming and deceit?

Yet when Wei Ke bound grass to repel the enemy, moved by his father’s dying command to marry off his father’s concubine, and repaid kindness in the netherworld—who could say that spirits and gods are entirely illusory? Nevertheless, Han Yu, the great Confucian, dismissed the *Zuozhuan* as exaggerated; Liu Zongyuan, a man of talent, also disbelieved many such accounts—how much more so those beneath them?

From ancient times to the present, examples of karmic retribution for good and evil abound. Lü Buwei, who presented his pregnant concubine to the King of Qin, scheming for his son to become emperor, saw his wish fulfilled when the First Emperor ascended the throne. Thus, the Qin dynasty bore the surname Lü instead of Ying—yet in the end, Buwei died by his son’s hand. Buwei’s cunning was great, but Heaven’s retribution was even more ingenious!

Chunshen Jun, who offered his pregnant concubine to the King of Chu, likewise desired her son to become king—yet he was ultimately murdered by that very concubine. Those who plot against others are in the end plotted against; those who harm others are in the end harmed. Disaster follows swiftly on their heels.

These are but retributions among humankind. As for the Qin general Bai Qi, who buried alive four hundred thousand soldiers at Changping, his soul has since fallen into the realm of beasts, with no end in sight! The Qin’s tyranny was matched by Bai Qi’s cruelty, who regarded hundreds of thousands of lives as no more than dogs and swine. The Dao of Heaven cherishes life—how fitting that he should endure such suffering, trapped for ten thousand kalpas without deliverance!

As for the accounts in unofficial histories and works like the *Ledgers of Merit and Demerit* and *Exhortations to Goodness*, whether derived from hearsay or witnessed firsthand, their events may be exceedingly strange, yet all are credible. They are not mere fabrications, absurd and baseless. For in the vastness of the cosmos, what is theoretically impossible often becomes reality—how could one dismiss it as false?

The *Book of Songs* says:
*"The thoughts of the divine are unfathomable,
How could one presume to mock them?"*
And again:
*"Heaven is ever manifest,
Ascending and descending, its officers ever watchful,
Its gaze fixed here daily."*
And again:
*"God is above you,
Let not your heart waver."*

All you disciples gathered here, when you hear of another receiving good reward for a virtuous deed, you should rejoice and think with admiration: *"Why am I not like this?"* Joy gives rise to emulation, emulation to the resolve to follow suit, and thus the heart of goodness arises. When you hear of another receiving ill reward for an unvirtuous deed, you should tremble with fear and ask: *"Might I too be like this?"* Apprehension leads to caution, caution to the dread of repeating such acts, and thus the heart of ungoodness is stilled.

As the saying goes: *"On seeing the worthy, think to equal them; on seeing the unworthy, turn inward and examine yourself."* If, upon witnessing goodness, you fail to encourage it; if, upon witnessing ungoodness, you fail to admonish it; if, upon hearing of good reward, you feel envy; or if, upon hearing of ill reward, you feel delight—such attitudes will only accumulate evil causes day by day, and the bitter retribution will fall upon yourself instead!

Beware of clinging to the one-sided views of pedantic scholars, dismissing the Buddha’s and immortals’ teachings on karmic retribution as untrustworthy, and regarding the sutras’ accounts of the cycle of birth and death, the hells, and the realms of suffering as mere fictions. To do so is to willingly plunge into ruin, and even in death, you will have no regrets!

In ancient times, when Kumārajīva was about to enter nirvana, he made a vow before the Buddha, saying: *"All the sutras and treatises I have translated faithfully follow the Sanskrit originals. If even a single word fails to accord with the Buddha’s intent, may my tongue be destroyed."* Thus, when his body was cremated, all who witnessed it saw his entire form consumed—only his tongue remained intact, radiant as a red lotus. To this day, the sutras and treatises he translated are revered by spirits and deities, cherished in the palaces of immortals and the peaks of the sea, guarded by dragons and heavenly beings, and offered incense and flowers. How could these be dismissed as deceptive falsehoods, bizarre theories, or unorthodox writings?

Yet the scholars of this world, confined by shallow and narrow views, raised in a single corner of the land, fail to grasp the principle that the Three Teachings share a common source. No sooner have their passions awakened than they drown in love and desire; before their marriages are even complete, their twilight years approach, and they do not recognize that the four great elements of their own bodies are empty—how then could they understand that all sentient beings before their eyes are but illusions? Deluded by falsehood and chasing after illusion, they recklessly mock and ridicule the scriptures of immortals and the teachings of the Buddha. They dismiss the Dao of good fortune for the virtuous and calamity for the wicked as unfounded, and scorn the doctrine of birth and death and the cycle of rebirth as unworthy of belief. In truth, their own nature remains obscured, their understanding clouded. Ask them to penetrate the mysteries of life and destiny, and they are utterly benighted; examine their devotion to ethical norms, and they are but perfunctory. Ashamed in the privacy of their chambers, abashed before the shadow of their own quilts—how then could they dare to call spirits and deities mere fictions and regard the Buddha and immortals as distant and unreal?

When Li Lu asked about *"serving the spirits,"* the Supreme Sage replied: *"If one cannot even serve men, how can one serve ghosts?"* This was meant as a practical admonition—nowhere did he deny the existence of spirits and deities. The Supreme Sage also said: *"Life and death are indeed matters of great weight!"* For though even the wise and sagely cannot escape the principle of life and death, the *Book of Changes* states: *"Tracing things to their beginning and returning to their end, one thus knows the Dao of life and death. Essence and qi become things; the wandering soul undergoes transformation—thus one knows the conditions of spirits and deities."* Essence and qi give rise to life when spirit arrives; the wandering soul brings death when the corporeal soul departs. Understanding these conditions, the principle of rebirth becomes clear.

Zhang Zai said: *"One who knows that death does not mean annihilation may be spoken to of nature."* The terms "life" and "death" derive from the physical body, not from the heart-mind or nature. For the body may decay, but nature does not. It is like the grasses and trees: though their branches and leaves wither, their roots remain in the earth, and when spring comes, they sprout anew. So too do humans: those who cultivate blessings are reborn in the heavens or among men, while those who commit evil deeds fall into the lower realms. If one claims that the principle of life and death leads to annihilation, then consider the words in the *Metal-Bound Coffer*: when the Duke of Zhou offered himself in place of the king, it is written: *"I, your filial and wise elder, am skilled in many arts and able to serve the spirits!"* If the Duke of Zhou’s prayers to the Three Kings were true, would they not contradict the annihilationist theories of worldly scholars? For if the Duke of Zhou had died in the king’s place, his form would have decayed and his spirit dispersed—even with his many talents, how could he still serve the spirits? And if the spirits themselves had already dispersed and perished, how could they have been served by the Duke of Zhou?

The rites of sacrifice were held in great esteem by the ancient sages. If one claims that spirits and deities are without substance, then the idea of *"offering humble food and drink to express filial piety to ghosts and spirits"* would be nothing but empty ritual. If one argues that sacrifice is merely descendants connecting with the qi of their ancestors, qi responding to qi to create resonance, then how does this explain the Son of Heaven’s sacrifices to the mountains, rivers, and great peaks, which are not his descendants? Could one say that Shun and Yu were the descendants of all the hundred spirits? Thus, though the Dao of spirits and deities is subtle and difficult to know, the principle of life and death is clear and readily apparent. The mechanism of their responsiveness is swifter than drum and drumstick; the retribution of rebirth turns like a wheel—most wondrously swift.

If there were no retribution for good and evil, no rebirth in hells or heavens, how would the Creator deal with the Most Sagely? Why would Heaven show partiality to Cao Cao alone? As for the *Declarations of the Perfected*, that book was a later forgery and is not to be trusted. If the principle of good fortune for the virtuous and calamity for the wicked were truly baseless, then those who cultivate themselves and strive diligently throughout their lives would fare worse than those who indulge their desires, pursue profit, and commit evil deeds, escaping punishment by mere luck. How could this be considered wise? The world’s customs grow ever more degenerate, and human hearts ever more insincere. Even when evil retribution is plainly visible before their eyes, they remain unmoved, unafraid of death—how much less would they believe in the hells and realms of suffering that await them after death! No wonder they live without knowing whence they came and die without knowing whither they go, drifting through life and death in vain, trapped in the cycle of rebirth without even realizing it.

Men of the world, cunning and calculating, assume that in the hidden depths of their hearts, when thoughts arise and intentions stir, the spirits and deities may not immediately know. Yet the Dharma-realm and the self-mind are not two separate things! The moment the self-mind stirs, even the ten directions and the three realms are fully aware. Thus, the *Doctrine of the Mean* begins by teaching the practice of vigilance and caution in solitude, instructing scholars that though spirits and deities may be subtle and invisible, unseen and unheard, the spirits and deities within our own minds cannot be deceived!

All you disciples gathered here must each arouse yourselves to diligent cultivation. Do not dismiss the cycle of birth and death as mere fiction, nor the retribution of spirits and deities as distant and unreal. Then the heart of vigilance will arise, good causes will gradually take root, and evil karma will gradually dissolve. Offering your bright virtue as incense, the spirits will surely receive it.

chunks.original_text: 「真常之道，各具于当人之身。 凡人之动静语默，皆此真常为之妙用，应事接物，曲当弗遗，儒谓『至诚无息』，道谓『真常得性』，释谓『常性真心』，其理一也。 然道本真，则宜以无伪体之； 道本常，则宜以有恒求之。 若无而为有，虚而为盈，妄念纷扰，则失其所以真。 一日暴之，十日寒之，见异而迁，则失其所以常。 故天地之道，恒久不已； 君子之道，立不易方。 然此真常之道，亦即《玉经》《清净》真一不二之道。 生出万法，故曰『法门』。 《易》曰：『成性存存，道义之门。 』盖许多道理，从兹而出，有门之义焉。 故曰『一生二，二生三，三生万物。 万物负阴而抱阳。 』一者何，诚也。 二仪于此分，三才于此定，万物于此生育。 故天地之道，为物不二。 是以生物不测，天地此一，人物此一，圣贤佛仙同此一，上帝亦此一也。 此真一不二法门，最为灵宝，最为清净。 元始位座说法，明此一也； 玉帝应身降诞，本此一也； 普明香岩山中修道，修此一也； 成佛成帝，全此一也。 以事论之，光严妙乐国土，系上帝示生之处； 普明山中，系修真之所。 以道言之，光严妙乐，即人庄严之身，普明香岩，亦即光明心地也。 上帝弃国修行，亦如　释迦，舍梵王太子不居，而于雪山修道。 雪山香岩，同一取其洁净也。 然上帝修行，何以每劫，皆云『八百』？ 吾试言之：初八百劫舍国，所以明八背舍，释门六度，亦以布施为先； 次八百劫，明转八识为大圆镜智，盖欲修道，非智慧无由入也； 再八百劫，所以表八正道，即六度万行，皆道之极正； 后八百劫，舍己血肉，所以表八解脱。 盖前之修行，尚执有人法，至舍己血肉，则人法两忘，故三千二百劫而证金仙。 然昔　释迦成佛，经亿万劫，岂上帝止三千二百劫乎！ 盖『三千』者，所以表超出三界，了达三乘； 『二百』者，二谛圆通也，此正成佛之因。 故果如其因，佛号大觉，又曰『法王』，而上帝亦称　『觉王如来』，但悲心广大，退佛不居，修菩萨行。 又经亿劫，始证玉帝，其功德力，不可思议！ 而玉女清净之身，亦与　帝同，何也？ 盖一阴一阳，同谓之道。 玉女修诸妙行，修此道也； 上帝普放神光，明此道也。 所以玉女身出微妙解脱之香，六道众生，普沾胜利。 昔　舍利弗疑龙女成佛，谓女身垢秽，尤有五障，而得成佛，此正色相未忘！ 盖大道不分男女，不可以色见音声求也。 然玉帝放光，遍照无极世界，而金仙菩萨，亦皆飞香散花而至，所以明仙佛同源，无二理也！ 昔　释迦说法，放光动地，诸天上帝，咸皆云集，亦复如是。 然上帝有无量光明，而止名十七光，何也？ 盖自古佛仙修道，先发慈悲喜舍、四无量心，而后至于圣神功化之极。 故帝之十七光，始于大慈悲光，而终之于无能胜光也。 然此光明众生中亦非尽无，特人有之，而自蔽之； 圣哲有之，而或未至其极； 惟上帝全之，为极大耳。 至高虚清明天主，乃九天生神之第八天，岂有不知玉帝之事？ 而　元始天尊，犹谓汝等，尚以结习，不睹是帝慈颜，盖为众生结习障重，不能见性，故假训天主之词，以教世人断障耳！ 断障之要，莫先于发大悲心，惟悲心方能度世，故菩萨于一切众生，皆思以无余盘而灭度之。

"The Dao of True Constancy resides within each person’s own body. In all human movement and stillness, speech and silence, this True Constancy manifests its wondrous function, responding to affairs and engaging with things without omission or error. The Confucians call it 'supreme sincerity without cease,' the Daoists call it 'attaining the nature of True Constancy,' and the Buddhists call it 'the true mind of constant nature'—their principle is one and the same.

Yet since the Dao is fundamentally true, it should be embodied without falsity; since the Dao is fundamentally constant, it should be sought with perseverance. If one fabricates existence from nothingness, fills emptiness with delusion, and allows false thoughts to scatter and disturb, one loses that which makes it true. If one acts intensely for a day and grows cold for ten, or shifts with every changing sight, one loses that which makes it constant. Thus, the Dao of Heaven and Earth endures without cease; the Dao of the noble person stands firm without altering its direction.

This Dao of True Constancy is none other than the non-dual Dao of True Oneness in the *Jade Scripture* and *Pure and Still*. It gives rise to the ten thousand dharmas, hence it is called the 'Dharma-gate.' The *Book of Changes* says: 'When the completed nature is preserved and maintained, it is the gate of Dao and virtue.' For from this arise all principles, and thus it bears the meaning of a gate. Hence it is said: 'The One gives rise to the Two, the Two give rise to the Three, and the Three give rise to the ten thousand things. The ten thousand things bear yin and embrace yang.' What is the One? It is sincerity. From this, the Two Modes divide; from this, the Three Powers are established; from this, the ten thousand things are born and nurtured. Thus, the Dao of Heaven and Earth is undivided in its creation of things. Therefore, the unfathomable generation of beings—Heaven and Earth share this One, humans share this One, sages, worthies, Buddhas, and immortals all share this One, and the Supreme Emperor shares this One as well.

This Dharma-gate of True Oneness and Non-Duality is most spiritually precious and most pure. When the Primordial Beginning took his seat to expound the Dharma, he elucidated this One; when the Jade Emperor manifested his incarnate birth, he was rooted in this One; when the Universal Illumination cultivated the Dao in Fragrant Rock Mountain, he cultivated this One; and in attaining Buddhahood or emperorship, he fully realized this One.

Examining it through events: the Land of Radiant Strictness and Wondrous Joy was where the Supreme Emperor demonstrated his birth; Fragrant Rock Mountain in Universal Illumination was the place of true cultivation. Speaking in terms of the Dao: Radiant Strictness and Wondrous Joy is the adorned body of the person, while Fragrant Rock Mountain is the luminous ground of the mind. The Supreme Emperor’s renunciation of his kingdom to cultivate the Dao was like Śākyamuni, who abandoned the throne of the Brahmā King’s son and practiced austerities on Snow Mountain. Snow Mountain and Fragrant Rock both share the quality of purity.

Yet why does the Supreme Emperor’s cultivation in each kalpa always number 'eight hundred'? Let me explain: The first eight hundred kalpas of relinquishing the kingdom illustrate the Eight Abandonments. In the Buddhist path of the Six Perfections, almsgiving comes first. The next eight hundred kalpas clarify the transformation of the Eight Consciousnesses into the Great Perfect Mirror Wisdom, for without wisdom, there is no way to enter the Dao. The following eight hundred kalpas represent the Eightfold Noble Path, which is the ultimate correctness of the Six Perfections and the ten thousand practices. The final eight hundred kalpas of offering his own flesh and blood represent the Eight Liberations. For in earlier cultivation, one still clings to the notions of person and dharma; only upon offering his own flesh and blood does one forget both person and dharma. Thus, after three thousand two hundred kalpas, he attained the rank of Golden Immortal.

Yet when Śākyamuni attained Buddhahood, he had practiced for countless kalpas—how could the Supreme Emperor have done so in only three thousand two hundred? The 'three thousand' signifies transcending the Three Realms and comprehending the Three Vehicles; the 'two hundred' signifies the perfect interpenetration of the Two Truths—this is precisely the cause of attaining Buddhahood. Thus, the fruit accords with the cause: the Buddha is called the Great Awakened One and the 'Dharma King,' while the Supreme Emperor is also titled the 'Tathāgata of Awakened Sovereignty.' Yet with boundless compassion, he declines the Buddha’s rank and practices the bodhisattva path. Only after countless kalpas does he attain the position of Jade Emperor, his merit and power beyond conception!

The Jade Maiden’s body of purity is also identical to the Emperor’s—why? For the unity of one yin and one yang is called the Dao. The Jade Maiden cultivates all wondrous practices, cultivating this Dao; the Supreme Emperor universally emits divine light, illuminating this Dao. Thus, from the Jade Maiden’s body arises the fragrance of subtle and wondrous liberation, and the six destinies of beings all partake of its excellence.

Formerly, Śāriputra doubted whether the Dragon Girl could attain Buddhahood, arguing that the female body is defiled and subject to the Five Hindrances. Yet to attain Buddhahood in such a form is precisely to remain attached to form! For the Great Dao makes no distinction between male and female—it cannot be sought through form, sound, or appearance.

When the Jade Emperor emits light, it pervades boundless worlds, and Golden Immortals and bodhisattvas all arrive, scattering flowers and emitting fragrance—this illustrates that immortals and Buddhas share the same source, with no duality in principle! When Śākyamuni expounded the Dharma, his light shook the earth, and all the gods and Supreme Emperors gathered—it was just the same.

Yet the Supreme Emperor possesses boundless radiance, so why is it named only the Seventeen Lights? From ancient times, Buddhas and immortals in cultivating the Dao first arouse the Four Immeasurable Minds of kindness, compassion, joy, and equanimity, and only then reach the ultimate in spiritual transformation. Thus, the Emperor’s Seventeen Lights begin with the Light of Great Compassion and conclude with the Light of Invincibility.

Yet this luminosity is not entirely absent among beings—people possess it but obscure it themselves; sages and worthies possess it but may not fully realize it; only the Supreme Emperor fully embodies it to its utmost.

The Lord of the Highest Void and Pure Brightness Heaven is the eighth heaven of the Nine Heavens of Spirit Generation—how could he be unaware of the Jade Emperor’s affairs? Yet the Primordial Beginning Honored One still said to you all: 'Due to residual habits, you have not beheld the compassionate countenance of this Emperor.' This is because the residual habits of beings create heavy obstructions, preventing them from seeing their nature. Thus, he borrowed the words of the Heavenly Lord to teach people to sever their obstructions!

The essential method for severing obstructions is none other than arousing the mind of great compassion, for only compassion can deliver the world. Therefore, bodhisattvas contemplate liberating all beings without remainder, extinguishing their suffering and guiding them to nirvāṇa."

All doubts and delusions, disputes between self and others, greed and anger, arrogance and lust—these manifold obstructions are the very roots of the cycle of birth and death. The scriptures speak of "severing obstructions," which is what the Buddha calls "delivering beings," and what the Confucians call "mastering the self." The method of cultivation takes this as its foremost task. If one upholds this scripture, one who severs obstructions to dispel self-interest, quiets the mind to preserve correctness, remains free from arrogance and deceit, fulfills loyalty and perfect filial piety, and reverently submits to the Supreme Dao—such a one may be called a "Perfected Person of Orthodox Unity." It is not that one may claim the title of Perfected Person merely by reciting the words with the mouth. All of you in this assembly constantly recite this scripture; if you can eliminate and sever each of the obstructions described within it, striving until no obstruction remains to be severed, this is the ultimate achievement of embodying the Dao, the essential key to entering sagehood and transcending the ordinary!

**Chapter Twenty-Nine: An Exegesis on the Meaning of the Scripture**

The teachings of the Buddhist and Immortal traditions differ in their canons, and their methods of cultivation also vary in many ways. Yet in my observation, the purport of the *Jade Scripture* often aligns with the Buddhist sūtras. For instance, the scripture states: *"The ten-direction transformation bodies of the Jade Emperor all gather beneath the Primordial Beginning’s assembly, like boundless bright mirrors."* This is akin to Śākyamuni manifesting bodies in the ten directions and, when about to open the stūpa of Many Jewels Buddha, transforming the pure land three times to accommodate the buddhas of the ten directions, all of whom open the stūpa together. Again, *"The Heavenly Treasures and wondrous flowers offered by the Lord of Pure Brightness Heaven spiral and coalesce into a canopy"* is like *"In Vaiśālī, five hundred sons of elders each hold a seven-jeweled canopy to offer to the Buddha, who causes all the jeweled canopies to merge into one."* For if there were oneness without division, the divine transformations of the myriad phenomena could not be seen; if there were division without oneness, the wondrousness of the One Origin could not be seen.

As for Śākyamuni’s responsive manifestation, descending from the Heaven of the Seed People, according to the Daoist canon, Śākyamuni is also an emanation of the Jade Emperor—only those who have not fully explored the canon remain unaware of this. Thus, his demonstrated traces of birth and the divine transformations of his cultivation and realization are largely the same. The sole difference lies in the Five Directions’ proclamations.

For the Supreme Lord administers transformation and governance, overseeing the pacification of water and earth—matters distinct from those of the Buddha. Yet the Five Directions’ proclamations and the *Crimson Writ of Numinous Script* are said by the Celestial Worthy of Primordial Beginning to have arisen before the vast kalpas, at the inception of primordial chaos. The Two Modes await them to divide, the sun and moon await them to illumine. Consider this: before the Two Modes had separated, before the sun and moon had shone, where did this numinous script arise? Only by awakening to this may one be called thoroughly enlightened.

Yet people know that the Five Venerable Lords implored the Celestial Worthy of Primordial Beginning to open the *Jade Casket* rituals and transmit the *Numinous Treasure* Dharma, without realizing that the scriptures refer to the Five Venerables to reveal that humans, endowed with the qi of the Five Phases, all return to the Origin. The *Jade Casket*’s numinous script resides within the nature of the human heart—who would claim the *Jade Scripture* merely recounts the deeds of the Supreme Lord and is not a text expounding the Dao?

All practitioners who, in accordance with the scriptures, first sever all obstacles and then follow the *Numinous Scripts of the Five Directions* to practice as prescribed, will, through prolonged devotion, naturally gain the protection of celestial perfected beings, with all demons restrained in form. The twelve bodies may thereby personally verify the thirty kinds of merit, which will arrive unbidden.

The only hindrance is that people fail to eliminate delusive conditions and purify karmic obstructions. If all thoughts truly cease and the myriad conditions suddenly still, then the dust-like evil karma will dissolve in accord with the mind. Merely reciting without cultivation remains a cause of leakage—this is not the meaning of the scriptures. Not only the *Jade Scripture*, but in reciting any scripture, one must comprehend it thus.

Today, those who revere the Dao are many, and those who gather to recite scriptures are not few. Some venerate the Three Primes, some worship the Northern Dipper, some follow Buddhist teachings, some admire the ways of immortals—varied as they are. Yet they know only the efficacy of averting calamities and transcending adversity, not the great fruit of learning the Dao and aspiring to immortality. Thus, those who recite scriptures are many, but those who understand them are few.

Let us now dissect and clarify the essential purport of the Three Primes. For instance, people know that on Cloud Terrace Mountain, there are these Three Emperor Lords who issue commands from their capital assembly. Judging by appearances, Cloud Terrace lies in the Northern Sea, and the capital assembly is where the Three Sages govern. Such an interpretation clings to the letter! The Three Sages’ intent to instruct the world is utterly lost.

Only by seeking the meaning does one realize that the Three Sages are one with the Supreme Ultimate, inseparable from the person’s own body. The so-called sea is the ocean of wisdom-nature; Cloud Terrace Mountain is the square inch of the heart-ground, and the clouds are the radiance of wisdom manifesting within the heart. The capital assembly is this body’s numinous and wondrous palace, the source of responsive adaptability. Master Ziyu said, *"All things are complete within me—what else could this be if not the capital assembly?"*

Moreover, the Upper Prime’s nine qi are the yang qi of nine: in conduct, they correspond to wood; in time, to spring. Thus, the Upper Prime’s birth in the first month rides the qi of spring. In constancy, they correspond to benevolence, and benevolence governs compassion and love—hence its function is to bestow blessings. In the human body’s generative spirits, they are the qi of the Embryonic Life Origin.

The Middle Prime’s seven qi are the yang qi of seven: in conduct, they correspond to metal; in time, to autumn. Thus, the Middle Prime’s birth in the seventh month rides the qi of autumn. In constancy, they correspond to righteousness, and righteousness governs decisiveness—hence its function is to pardon sins. In the human body’s generative spirits, they are the qi of the Ethereal Soul’s Life Origin.

The Lower Prime’s five qi are the yang qi of five: in conduct, they correspond to water; in time, to winter. Thus, the Lower Prime’s birth in the tenth month rides the qi of water. In constancy, they correspond to wisdom, and wisdom dispels obstructions—hence its function is to resolve adversities. In the human body’s generative spirits, they are the qi of the Corporeal Soul’s Life Origin.

These Three Primes, within the human body, govern the palaces of the Mud Pill, the Cinnabar Field, and the Cavern Chamber. Whenever a person conceives a thought, they immediately know it, for their numinous brightness is interpenetrating. Those who attain the Dao are all recommended by the Three Primes to serve as the Supreme Lord’s privy councilors, officials in charge of the retribution of good and evil, weighing the merits of cultivators, demoting or promoting immortals, and overseeing all spirits. Their merit is great, their authority weighty.

Yet though the immortal scriptures have long been transmitted in the world, and many uphold them, their purport has never been fully elucidated, leaving people unaware. Now, I do not begrudge revealing these secrets, offering earnest and incisive instruction, so that all may recite and uphold them according to the method. When my heart aligns with the Emperor’s heart, the Three Prime Emperor Lords respond in accord with the mind: prayers for blessings bring blessings, supplications to avert misfortune dissolve misfortune.

Formerly, Fada recited the *Lotus Sutra* until he had completed three thousand copies. One day, he visited the Sixth Patriarch, who asked him about the sutra’s meaning. Fada could not answer. The Patriarch said, *"Your name is Dharma-Penetrating, yet you have not penetrated the Dharma."* The Patriarch then expounded the Buddha’s insight, and Fada awakened on the spot. He presented a verse:

*"Three thousand copies of the sutra recited,
Yet Cao Stream’s single phrase was forgotten."*

The Patriarch said, *"Previously, your recitation was merely turned by the sutra; you did not turn the sutra. Only now may you be called a monk who recites the sutra!"*

All you disciples present here, and all sentient beings of the future, when reciting any scripture, must be able to turn the scripture and not be turned by it—then it will be well.

The ancients composed books and established teachings to instruct later generations. When their intent was not fully expressed and words could not make it manifest, they employed parables to elucidate their meaning, allowing people to grasp what lay beyond words and speech. The Buddhist sutras say, *"All those with wisdom must understand through parables."* Thus, the texts of the Three Teachings abound in analogies. Yet their implied meanings are profound and distant, and people often misconstrue them.

Take the *Book of Changes*, for instance: the sage established images to exhaust meaning, and the *Appended Judgments* clarified fortune and misfortune. But its analogies are subtle and far-reaching. For example:
- To warn against yang reaching its extreme above, where fullness cannot last, it says, *"The dragon soars on high—there will be regret."*
- To warn against yin reaching its extreme above, leading to conflict with yang, it says, *"Dragons battle in the wild."*
- Its blood is dark and yellow; to warn against indecision, it speaks of *"a cartload of ghosts."*
- To warn against failing to see things through to the end, where success is rare, it says, *"The fox wets its tail."*

The words of the sixty-four hexagrams are largely analogical. Had the supreme sage not composed the *Image Commentaries* to illuminate their meaning, how would later Confucians have understood them?

Long ago, Lord Wen Shi gazed upon a purple vapor moving from east to west and knew an extraordinary person was near. He then encountered the Most High, who composed the two chapters of the *Dao and Virtue*, unfolding its secret principles—embracing the vast and omitting nothing, however small. Yet much of what it says about governing states and deploying troops is couched in metaphor. Even the Buddhist sutras adorn the Buddha-land as the pure ground of the mind.

When the Most High speaks of governing the state, he refers to ordering this body and mind. Even his references to warfare are metaphors for battling and repelling the demons of yin, overcoming the harms of selfish desires. As the *Changes* says, *"In the shock of campaigning against Gui Fang, after three years, reward comes from a great state."* The *Classic of Yin Convergence* states, *"Cut off profit at its source, and military strength is tenfold; reverse the cycle of day and night, and it is a hundredfold."* The meaning is the same!

As for the passage in the sutra:
*"To gather it, first expand it;
To weaken it, first strengthen it;
To abolish it, first promote it;
To seize it, first give it."*

This is the natural workings of heaven’s movement—like the sun casting a final glow before setting, the year turning suddenly warm before the cold, a person rallying strength before death, or a lamp flaring before going out. There is no difference in principle! Yet this principle is the most difficult for people to grasp, hence it is called *"subtle illumination."* It urges people to foresee impending fortune or misfortune in such matters and to first examine their incipient signs.

Worldly Confucians, failing to perceive this, mistake it for the affairs of rival states and the tactics of vertical and horizontal alliances—is this not a gross error? It also says, *"To reconcile great resentment, there will inevitably remain residual resentment. How can this be considered good?"* This is a sharp rebuke for those who grow complacent in petty peace and forget long-term prudence. It aligns entirely with the *Changes*, which says, *"The noble person reflects on calamity and guards against it beforehand."* Take the case of Zhou and Zheng exchanging hostages, only to later become enemies—is this not clear proof?

Worldly Confucians attribute this to the affairs of Goujian and Wu, unaware that this sutra was composed before the enmity between Wu and Yue arose. To misinterpret its words on reconciling resentment as referring to Wu and Yue is a mistake!

Later, the teachings of the *Dao and Virtue* degenerated into the Legalist school, and the words of the Most High were misconstrued as schemes and deceit—is this not a slander? Long ago, the Supreme Sage inquired about ritual from the Most High. Upon leaving, he said to his disciples, *"I observe that Laozi is like a dragon!"* Even one as sagely as the Supreme Sage praised him as *"like a dragon."* Yet later Confucians, with their narrow views, disparage him—are they not inferior even to the Supreme Sage?

In the past, Shu Sun Wu Shu slandered Confucius, and Duanmu Ci reproached him for not knowing his own measure. Those who today attack the Most High and denigrate the *Dao and Virtue* are likewise merely ignorant of their own limits. In the end, this does no harm to the Most High.

Yet among the dozens of commentators on the *Dao and Virtue*—even the eminent Master Kumarajiva, whose talent and insight surpassed others—his commentary on the *Dao and Virtue* still faulted it for not discussing the mind. How much more so for the rest? However, the sutra’s words, *"Do not display what may be desired, so the mind will not be confused,"* precisely warn against the deluded mind and urge guarding the true mind.

*"The sage has no constant mind; he takes the people’s mind as his mind."* Does this differ from the ancient Buddha’s verse, *"The mind is fundamentally unborn; it arises due to conditions"*?

The Most High also said, *"Ritual is the thinning of loyalty and trust, and the beginning of chaos."* This does not refer to the essence of ritual as thin or chaotic. Loyalty and trust are the foundation of ritual; what the world calls ritual is merely the superficial trappings of form. The *Book of Documents* says, *"The offerings are abundant in ceremony, but the ceremony does not extend to the substance."* This is what is meant by the thinning of loyalty and trust.

Wang Mang was humble and deferential to scholars, yet he usurped the Han throne—is this not the beginning of chaos? The Most High’s words serve as a mirror for later generations! Yet worldly Confucians accuse him of abandoning ritual and righteousness—is this not excessive?

In the past, I read the *Dao and Virtue* and deeply lamented my inability to fully penetrate its meaning. Though there were many commentaries, from Master He Shang onward, each clung to a single perspective, and few could reveal its depths. Fortunately, since attaining the truth, I have daily discussed it with the assembled sages and only now have I grasped its wonders.

Today, in expounding this teaching, I have briefly explained a few points to you, my disciples here present. Do not imitate worldly Confucians, recklessly slandering without restraint. As for the sutra’s passages that remain unexhaustively clarified, each of you should comprehend them through their meaning, not being bound by words and letters.

**Chapter Thirty-One: Revering the Stars and the Dipper**

Within the cosmos, human life is endowed with the qi of Heaven and Earth’s yin and yang, formed from the essence and blood of father and mother. Regardless of wealth or poverty, nobility or lowliness, all possess a luminous, awakened nature—the seed of kalpas past—while their fate is truly bound to Heaven. Heaven’s seven luminaries govern all celestial bodies, ordering creation and serving as the master of the human body. Longevity or early death, prosperity or adversity, fortune or misfortune—none are beyond their measure.

Yet the seven luminaries depend on the Jade Pivot and Jade Balance to maintain their proper course, for the marvel of this pivot and balance turns the four seasons and governs the kalpas. Thus, the sage emperors of old first commanded Xi and He to observe the celestial patterns, scrutinize the Jade Pivot and Jade Balance, and align the seven luminaries. Later sages established divine teachings for transformation, giving rise to rites of revering the stars and worshipping the Dipper, as well as ceremonies to avert calamity and resolve misfortune. The *Jade Pivot Sutra* teaches: *"To escape the three disasters and nine perils, bow in stillness at night to the Northern Asterism."* The Most High, in the Shu capital, transmitted the *True Sutra of the Five Dippers* and the *Heart Sutra of the Dipper Mother*. Thereafter, those who devised rites for the Dipper’s altar numbered in the dozens. Yet each based their rules on where they perceived divine transformation and response, resulting in varying degrees of detail.

For instance, the method of *"Revering the Two Stars of the Three Primes"* is exceedingly concise, but people often find it too brief and few practice it. Works like the *Great Brahma Unifying Chapter* are overly verbose, lacking profound subtlety. The *Dipper Rites* expounded by Emperor Wen suit scholars but fail to benefit the common folk. Thus, the gates of Dipper reverence are many, and throughout the ages, those who cultivated reality and attained the Dao—ascending to immortality through Dipper rites—are beyond count.

Yet, surveying the treasuries of scriptures, the Buddhist rites of reverence surpass those of our tradition. Even the path of Sanskrit sounds is more esoteric than our own rituals. Thus, in the Chan school, there are those who practice and attain clarity of mind and vision of nature. As for the Dipper rites transmitted in the world, they consist only of bowing ceremonies, lacking secret oral instructions. I once composed a verse:

*Many are the gates to Dipper rites,*
*Yet all converge like a needle’s thread.*
*Silent and still, in profound quietude,*
*In darkness, one meets the Star Lords.*

*Within the altar’s hush,*
*Let no chaos intrude.*
*First from the Sea of Origin’s cavity,*
*Then ascend to Kunlun’s height.*

*The Dipper Mother’s and Jade Emperor’s decrees,*
*When fused, reach the supreme vehicle.*
*Thus is the Golden Elixir attained,*
*And the Infant formed in an instant.*

This Dipper formula has been transmitted for ages, yet none practice it. For people know only of the Northern Dipper in the Palace of the Jade Pivot, unaware that within their own bodies lies a Jade Dipper, which daily circulates through the entire form, flowing through the hundred vessels from midnight to the hour of the pig, never ceasing for a moment. Only those of superior insight first recognize their life-star’s Dipper, never departing from its movement within the body, and thus attain the Dao and achieve reality.

Yet this can only be spoken of to those of the highest capacity, for only they can practice it. Why is the Northern Dipper within the body? The White Jade Tortoise Terrace is the numinous terrace of the heart, and the divine Xiezhi’s precious seat is the heart’s spiritual transformation. The Jade Pivot’s treasury is the heart’s emptiness and numinosity, through which the five qi are mobilized! As the alchemical classics say: *"Why seek midnight at the edge of the sky? Within the body, the yang arises of itself!"* Thus, at midnight, when the first yang stirs, it is no different from the Dipper’s handle turning. At this hour, one who reverently worships the Dipper, riding the initial arising of yang, emulates Heaven’s ceaseless movement, and practices in accordance with meaning.

Now, for those who revere the Dipper, I proclaim a swift, essential, and secret method: Before the rite, fast and purify with utmost sincerity. At night, first enter the Dipper chamber, still all thoughts, and strike the teeth nine times. Stand upright, facing north, and bow in reverence. Envision the golden countenance of the Heavenly Mother descending from above, the Nine Emperors and Two Sovereigns standing to her left and right, and the assembled sages arrayed around. Empty all distractions and abide in silent concentration.

Then rise to perform the rites. The mind must be utterly focused, the spirit utterly still, the qi utterly solemn, the demeanor utterly dignified, the appearance utterly reverent, the voice utterly even, the tone utterly harmonious, the resonance utterly clear. Speed and slowness must follow measure, advance and retreat must follow rule, kneeling and bowing must follow rhythm, and rising and pausing must follow decorum. Whether at home, in a temple, alone, or in a communal gathering, all should proceed thus. Discipline body and mind, allowing no disturbance.

First bow to the august titles, then recite the Sanskrit sounds. Now, the Sanskrit sounds of the Dipper Mother, as found in the Buddhist and Daoist canons, number over a dozen, making them difficult to recite in full. Among those recorded in the treasuries, none are more essential than the *Heart Mantra*. You, my disciples, listen carefully, as I shall recite it:

The Most High proclaimed it to instruct those who cultivate the true Dao. If one recites it without ceasing, all demon hosts will submit in awe, the hundred evils will flee, malevolent ghosts will be annihilated, and no calamity shall arise.

This Sanskrit sound is most wondrous and subtle, capable of curing all chronic and stubborn illnesses, and of averting all baleful stars and malignant influences. Should one’s life palace or fate be in disarray—whether afflicted by yearly misfortune, monthly calamity, clashes, conflicts, or punitive encounters—recitation of this mantra may dissolve and dispel them. The key lies in sincerity and reverence, for then the marvel of resonance will be most efficacious and divine.

The human face and head possess seven apertures, which inwardly correspond to the heart. The seven *zhen*-spirits of the *po* receive their vitality from the Dipper. Thus, the apertures of the Dipper originally connect with the apertures of the heart, and the human heart is none other than the celestial heart. Above every person’s head shines the Three Terraces and the Northern Dipper, which record their transgressions. For above the crown of every person’s head, there exists an inherent luminosity of self-nature—whether red, purple, yellow, or white—its hue varying. Only those of the Dao possess a light that is lofty and vast. Those who do good emit red or yellow light, while evildoers reveal black qi above their crowns, their nature-light obscured and unable to manifest. Thus, the Northern Dipper, observing the presence or absence of this light above their heads, determines the goodness or wickedness of each person. Yet this crown-light is known only to the divine; mortals remain unaware of it.

The method of worshipping the Dipper, though not equal to the refinement of the Golden Elixir, may still—if practiced alongside it—lead to liberation from the cycle of rebirth and attainment of immortality. Thus, the *Heart Sutra of the Dipper Mother* states: *"For those who refine the Great Elixir of Nine Returns and Seven Reversions, recitation of this mantra brings sudden awakening to the subtle barrier, the numinous light appears before them, and vitality naturally flourishes."* This is akin to the Buddhist practice of reciting *"Amitābha Buddha"* to seek rebirth in the Pure Land, both yielding wondrous fruition.
