chunks.original_text: 凡秋三月肺气旺。 肺旺者，以父母真气，随天度运而在肺。 若遇金日，庚辛木。 于震卦时，依法起火炼肝气。 余日离卦时，损火以耗心气，是时不可下功也。 巽卦时，依法起火炼脾气。 兑卦时入室，依前行持，白色自见。 渐渐升身以入泥丸，自申至戌以满兑卦。 凡冬三月肾气旺。 肾旺者，以父母真气，随天度运而在肾。 若遇水日，壬癸火。 于离卦时，依法起火炼心气。 余日辰戌丑未时，损土以耗脾气，是时不可下功也。 兑卦时，依法起火炼肺气。 坎卦时入室，依前行持，黑色自见。 渐渐升身以入泥丸，自亥至丑以满坎卦。 解曰：春炼肝千息青气出。 春末十八日，不须依前行持，止于定息为法，终日静坐以养脾，而炼己之真气。 乃可坎卦，起火炼肾，恐耗其真气。 夏炼心千息赤气出。 夏末十八日，不须依前行持，止于定息为法，终日静坐，其炼如前。 乃可震卦时，起火如前。 秋炼肝千息白气出。 秋末十八日，不须依前行持，止于定息为法，终日静坐，养炼如前。 乃可巽卦时，起火如前。 冬炼肾千息黑气出。 冬末十八日，不须依前行持，止于定息为法，终日静坐，养炼如前。 乃可兑卦时，起火如前，以至黄气成光，默观万道，周匝围身。 凡定息之法，不在强留而紧闭。 但绵绵若存，用之不勤。 从有入无，使之自住。 采药之法，含津握固以压心，使真气不散。 凡入室，须闭户孤幽静馆，远鸡犬女子，一切厌触之物。 (双目)微开小窍，使明能辨物。 勿令风日透气，左右有声。 当灰心息虑，事累俱遣，内外凝寂，不以一物介其意。 盖以阳神初聚，真气方凝，看待如婴儿，尚未及老，日夕焚香跪拜稽首：一祝天，二祝天仙，三祝地仙。 三礼既毕，静坐忘机以行此法。 仍须前法，节节见效。 若以此便为道，但恐徒劳，终不见成。 止于阴魄出壳，而为鬼仙。 道要曰：凡行此法，不限年月日时。 一依前法，以至见验方止。 其气自见，须是谨节不倦，弃绝外事。 止于室中用意，测其时候，用二个纯阳小子，或结交门生，交翻往复，供过千日，可了一气。 一以夺十，一百日见功，五百日气全，可行内观，然后聚阳神，以入天神，炼神合道，入圣超凡。 炼气之验，但觉身体极畅，常仰升腾，丹光透骨，异香满室。 次静中外观紫霞满目，顶中下视，金光罩体，奇怪证验不可备纪。 内观交换第九(集阳神　摩天火　交换仙凡真空　人间天上华胥国) 金诰曰：大道本无体，寓于气也，道大无外，无物可容； 大道本无用，运于物也，其深莫测，无理可究。 以体言道，道始有内外之别； 以用言道，道始有观见之基。 观乎内，而不观乎外，外无不究，而内得明矣； 观乎神，而不观乎形，形无不备，而神得见矣。 真源曰：以一心观万物，万物不谓之有余； 以万物挠一气，一气不谓之不足。 一气归一心，心不可为物之所夺； 一心运一气，气不可为法之所役。 心源清彻，一照万破亦不知有物也； 气战刚强，万感一息亦不知有法也。 物物无物，以还本来之象； 法法无法，乃全自得之真。 此喻曰：以象生形，因形立名。 有名则推其数，有数则得其理。 盖高上虚无，无物可喻。 所可比者，如人之修炼。 节序无差，成就有次。
chunks.translated_text:
In autumn’s three months, the lung’s qi flourishes. When the lung’s qi flourishes, the parents’ true qi, following the celestial movements, resides in the lung. If encountering a Metal day (*geng-xin*) or a Wood day (*jia-yi*), during the *zhen* trigram hours, kindle fire in accordance with the method to refine the liver’s qi. On other days, during the *li* trigram hours, diminish Fire to deplete the heart’s qi—at this time, one must not engage in practice. During the *xun* trigram hours, kindle fire in accordance with the method to refine the spleen’s qi. During the *dui* trigram hours, enter the chamber and practice as before—white light will naturally appear. Gradually ascend the body to enter the *Niwan* palace, from *shen* to *xu* to fill the *dui* trigram.

In winter’s three months, the kidney’s qi flourishes. When the kidney’s qi flourishes, the parents’ true qi, following the celestial movements, resides in the kidney. If encountering a Water day (*ren-gui*) or a Fire day (*bing-ding*), during the *li* trigram hours, kindle fire in accordance with the method to refine the heart’s qi. On other days, during the *chen-xu-chou-wei* hours, diminish Earth to deplete the spleen’s qi—at this time, one must not engage in practice. During the *dui* trigram hours, kindle fire in accordance with the method to refine the lung’s qi. During the *kan* trigram hours, enter the chamber and practice as before—black light will naturally appear. Gradually ascend the body to enter the *Niwan* palace, from *hai* to *chou* to fill the *kan* trigram.

Explanation: In spring, refine the liver for a thousand breaths, and blue-green qi will emerge. During the last eighteen days of spring, one need not practice as before; simply abide by the method of settled breathing, sitting in stillness all day to nurture the spleen and refine one’s true qi. Only then, during the *kan* trigram hours, kindle fire to refine the kidney, lest the true qi be depleted. In summer, refine the heart for a thousand breaths, and crimson qi will emerge. During the last eighteen days of summer, one need not practice as before; simply abide by the method of settled breathing, sitting in stillness all day, refining as before. Only then, during the *zhen* trigram hours, kindle fire as before. In autumn, refine the liver for a thousand breaths, and white qi will emerge. During the last eighteen days of autumn, one need not practice as before; simply abide by the method of settled breathing, sitting in stillness all day, nurturing and refining as before. Only then, during the *xun* trigram hours, kindle fire as before. In winter, refine the kidney for a thousand breaths, and black qi will emerge. During the last eighteen days of winter, one need not practice as before; simply abide by the method of settled breathing, sitting in stillness all day, nurturing and refining as before. Only then, during the *dui* trigram hours, kindle fire as before, until yellow qi forms a radiance, and one silently observes myriad Daoist paths encircling the body.

The method of settled breathing does not lie in forcefully holding or tightly closing the breath. Rather, it should be continuous as if present, employed without strain. From existence, one enters non-existence, allowing it to abide naturally. The method of gathering the medicine involves holding the saliva and clasping the hands to press the heart, ensuring the true qi does not scatter.

When entering the chamber, one must close the door in a secluded and quiet dwelling, far from chickens, dogs, women, and all disturbing influences. The eyes should be slightly open, just enough to discern objects. Avoid drafts and direct sunlight, and ensure no sounds intrude from either side. One should empty the heart and still all thoughts, casting aside all worldly concerns. Both internally and externally, one must be utterly serene, allowing nothing to disturb the mind. For the yang spirit is newly gathered and the true qi only just congealed, one must tend to it as a newborn, not yet mature. Morning and evening, burn incense, kneel, and bow in reverence: first to Heaven, second to the Heavenly Immortals, and third to the Earthly Immortals. After completing these three bows, sit in stillness, forgetting all scheming, and proceed with this method. One must also follow the preceding method step by step to witness its effects. If one mistakes this for the Dao itself, one may labor in vain and never achieve success, merely allowing the yin po to leave the body and become a ghostly immortal.

The essential teaching of the Dao states: In practicing this method, one is not bound by years, months, days, or hours. Simply follow the preceding method until signs of verification appear, and then cease. The qi will manifest naturally, but one must be diligent and unwavering, forsaking all external affairs. Remain in the chamber, focus the mind, and gauge the proper times. Employ two pure yang youths or cultivate a bond with disciples, engaging in mutual exchange and support for a thousand days to complete one cycle of qi. One gains tenfold in one hundred days, and in five hundred days, the qi is complete. One may then practice inner observation, gather the yang spirit, and merge with the celestial spirits. Refining the spirit to unite with the Dao, one enters sagehood and transcends the mundane.

The verification of refining qi lies in feeling the body utterly at ease, often ascending as if borne aloft. The elixir’s light penetrates the bones, and an extraordinary fragrance fills the chamber. Next, in stillness, one gazes outward to see purple clouds filling the eyes. Looking downward from the crown of the head, a golden light envelops the body—strange and wondrous signs of verification are too numerous to record.

**Inner Observation and Transformation (Ninth Section: Gathering the Yang Spirit, Heaven-Scaling Fire, Exchanging Mortal for Immortal, True Emptiness, the Celestial Realm of Huaxu)**

The *Golden Edict* states: The Great Dao has no form; it dwells within qi. The Dao is vast beyond all bounds, containing nothing. The Great Dao has no function; it operates through things. Its depth is unfathomable, and its principles are beyond investigation. Speaking of the Dao in terms of form, it begins to have distinctions of inner and outer. Speaking of the Dao in terms of function, it establishes the foundation for observation and perception. Observing the inner without observing the outer, nothing external remains unexamined, and the inner becomes clear. Observing the spirit without observing the form, no aspect of form is left unperfected, and the spirit becomes visible.

The *True Source* states: With one heart, observe the myriad things, and the myriad things are not said to be excessive. With the myriad things disturbing the one qi, the one qi is not said to be insufficient. When the one qi returns to the one heart, the heart cannot be seized by things. When the one heart moves the one qi, the qi cannot be enslaved by methods. When the heart’s source is clear and penetrating, one illumination shatters ten thousand illusions, and one forgets the existence of things. When the qi’s struggle is firm and strong, ten thousand stimuli are stilled in a single breath, and one forgets the existence of methods. Thing after thing, no thing remains—thus returning to the original image. Method after method, no method remains—thus preserving the true self-attained reality.

This analogy states: From images, forms arise; from forms, names are established. With names, one infers their numbers; with numbers, one grasps their principles. Yet the loftiest and most empty is beyond all things and cannot be compared. The only possible comparison is to one who cultivates and refines. The seasons proceed without error, and accomplishments follow in order.

chunks.original_text: 和之气，凝而不散。 至虚真性，恬淡无为。 神合乎道，归于自然。 当此之际，以无心为心，如何谓之应物？ 以无物为物，如何谓之用法？ 真乐熙熙，不知己之有身。 渐入无为之道，以入希夷之域，斯为入圣超凡之客。 真诀曰：此法合道，有如常说存想之理，又如禅僧入定之时。 当择福地置室，跪礼焚香，正坐盘膝，散发披衣，握固存神，冥心闭目。 午时前微微升身，起火炼气。 午时后微微敛身，聚火烧丹。 不拘昼夜，神清气和，自然喜悦。 坐中或闻声莫听，见境勿认，物境自散。 若认物境，转加魔障。 魔障不退，急急向前以身微敛，敛而伸腰，后以胸微偃，偃不伸腰，少待前后火起高升，其身勿动，名曰「焚身」。 火退魔障自散于躯外，阴邪不入于壳中，如此三二次已。 当想遍天地之间，皆是炎炎之火，火毕清凉，了无一物。 但见车马歌舞，轩盖绮罗，富贵繁华，人物欢娱，成队成行。 五色云升，如登天界，及到彼中，又见楼台耸翠，院宇徘徊，珍珠金玉，满地不收，花果池亭，莫知其数。 须臾异香四起，妓乐之音，嘈嘈杂杂。 宾朋满座，水陆俱陈，且笑且语，共贺太平，珍玩之物，互相献受。 当此之际，虽然不是阴鬼魔军，亦不得认为好事。 盖修真之人，弃绝外事，甘受寂寞。 或潜迹江湖之地，或遁身隐僻之隅。 绝念忘情，举动有戒。 久受劬劳，而历潇洒。 一旦功成法立，遍见如此繁华，又不谓是阴魔，将谓实到天宫。 殊不知脱凡胎，在顶中自己天宫之内。 因而贪恋，认为实境，不用超脱之法，止于身中，阳神不出，而胎仙不化。 乃曰出昏衢之上，为陆地神仙，仅可长生不死而已，不能脱质升仙，而归三岛，以作仙子，到此可惜。 学人自当虑超脱虽难，不可不行也。 道要曰：不无尽法，已减省故也。 超脱分形第十　﹝出入分形　神仙脱质　超凡入圣﹞ 金诰曰：道本无也，以有言者非道也； 道本虚也，以实言者非道也。 既为无体，则问应俱不能矣； 既为无象，则视听俱不能矣。 以玄微为道，玄微亦不离问答之累； 以希夷为道，希夷亦未免视听之累。 希夷玄微，尚未为道，则道亦不知其所以然也。 玉书曰：其来有始，而不知大道之始何也？ 其去有尽，而不知大道之终何也？ 高高之上虽有上，而不知大道之上，无有穷也！ 深深之下虽有下，而不知大道之下，无有极也！ 杳杳莫测名道，随物所得而列等殊，无为之道，莫能穷究也。 真诀曰：超者，超出凡躯而入圣品； 脱者，脱去俗胎而为仙子。 是神入气胎，气全真性。 须是前功节节见验正当，方居清静之室，以入希夷之境。 内观认阳神，次起火降魔，焚身聚气，真气升在天官，壳中清净，了无一物。 当择幽居，一依内观，三礼既毕，平身不须高升，正坐不须敛伸。 闭目冥心，静极朝元之后，身躯如在空中。 神气飘然，难为制御。 默然内观，明朗不昧，山川秀丽，楼阁依稀，紫气红光，纷纭为阵，祥鸾彩凤，音语如簧。 异景繁华，可谓壶中真趣，而洞天别景，逍遥自在，冥然不知有尘世之累。 是真空之际，其气自转，不须用法依时。 若见青气出东方，笙簧嘹喨，旌节车马，左右前后，不知多少。 须臾南方赤气出，西方白气出，北方黑气出，中央黄气出。
chunks.translated_text:
The qi of harmony congeals and does not disperse. The true nature of utmost emptiness is tranquil and free from striving. The spirit unites with the Dao, returning to spontaneity. At this moment, taking non-mind as mind—how then can one speak of responding to things? Taking non-thing as thing—how then can one speak of employing methods? True joy abounds, and one forgets the existence of one’s own body. Gradually entering the Dao of non-action, one reaches the realm of the imperceptible and inaudible, becoming a guest who enters sagehood and transcends the mundane.

The true formula states: This method accords with the Dao, resembling the principle of visualization as commonly described, or like the moment when a Chan monk enters samādhi. One should choose an auspicious site to establish a chamber, kneel in reverence, burn incense, sit upright with legs crossed, let the hair down and robes loose, clench the fists to retain spirit, and close the eyes to still the mind. Before noon, gently raise the body to kindle the fire and refine the qi. After noon, slightly gather the body to gather the fire and forge the elixir. Regardless of day or night, with spirit clear and qi harmonious, joy arises naturally. If sounds are heard during meditation, do not listen; if visions appear, do not acknowledge them, and the external phenomena will disperse of their own accord. Should one acknowledge these phenomena, demonic obstacles will only intensify. If demonic obstacles do not recede, swiftly lean the body slightly forward, then straighten the waist; afterward, slightly arch the chest without straightening the waist. After a brief pause, the fire will rise high before and behind—do not move the body. This is called "firing the body." When the fire subsides, demonic obstacles will disperse beyond the frame, and yin evil will not enter the shell. Repeat this two or three times.

One should visualize all between heaven and earth as a blazing fire. Once the fire subsides, all is cool and clear, leaving nothing behind. Yet one sees carriages and horses, song and dance, canopies and silken banners, wealth and splendor, crowds of joyous people forming ranks and processions. Five-colored clouds ascend, as if ascending to the celestial realm. Upon arrival, one beholds towering pavilions amid verdant peaks, courtyards stretching endlessly, pearls and gold scattered ungathered upon the ground, gardens and pavilions, flowers and fruits, pools and terraces beyond count. Suddenly, rare fragrances arise on all sides, and the sounds of music and revelry fill the air. Guests and friends fill the seats, a feast of land and sea is laid out, laughter and conversation abound, all celebrating great peace. Precious treasures are exchanged as gifts. At this moment, though these are not the armies of yin ghosts or demons, one must not regard them as auspicious events.

For those who cultivate the true, having renounced worldly affairs and willingly embraced solitude—whether concealing themselves by rivers and lakes or withdrawing to secluded corners—all thoughts and emotions are severed, and every action is governed by precepts. After enduring hardship and experiencing freedom, once the work is accomplished and the method established, one may witness such splendor. Yet if one does not recognize these as demonic illusions but instead believes they have truly arrived in the celestial palace, unaware that shedding the mortal form occurs within the celestial palace atop one’s own head, and thus becomes attached, taking these visions as reality, failing to apply the method of transcendence—then the yang spirit will remain trapped within the body, and the immortal embryo will not transform. One may emerge above the dark paths to become a terrestrial immortal, merely attaining longevity without death, yet unable to shed the mortal frame and ascend as an immortal, returning to the Three Isles to become a celestial being. This is truly lamentable.

Disciples must consider that though transcendence is difficult, it cannot be neglected. The essential teaching states: There is no inexhaustible method, for it has already been reduced to its essence.

**Chapter Ten: Transcending and Shedding the Form**
*(Emerging and Entering the Form, Immortal Shedding the Mortal Frame, Transcending the Mundane and Entering Sagehood)*

The *Golden Edict* states: The Dao is fundamentally non-being; to speak of it as being is not the Dao. The Dao is fundamentally empty; to speak of it as substantial is not the Dao. Since it is formless, neither questioning nor responding can reach it; since it is imageless, neither seeing nor hearing can grasp it. If one takes the mysterious and subtle as the Dao, the mysterious and subtle still cannot escape the burden of question and answer. If one takes the imperceptible and inaudible as the Dao, the imperceptible and inaudible still cannot avoid the burden of seeing and hearing. If even the imperceptible and inaudible, the mysterious and subtle, are not the Dao, then the Dao is beyond all knowing.

The *Jade Scripture* states: Its coming has a beginning, yet who knows the beginning of the great Dao? Its going has an end, yet who knows the end of the great Dao? Though there is an "above" beyond the highest, who knows that the great Dao’s above has no limit? Though there is a "below" beneath the deepest, who knows that the great Dao’s below has no end? The Dao, unfathomable and nameless, arranges ranks and distinctions according to what beings attain. The Dao of non-action cannot be fully explored.

The true formula states: To *transcend* is to rise beyond the mortal frame and enter the rank of sages. To *shed* is to cast off the mundane embryo and become an immortal. It is the spirit entering the qi-embryo, the qi completing the true nature. Only when prior efforts have borne verification at every step should one reside in a chamber of purity to enter the realm of the imperceptible and inaudible. Inwardly observe and recognize the yang spirit, then kindle the fire to subdue demons, firing the body to gather qi. The true qi ascends to the celestial palace, and the shell becomes utterly pure, leaving nothing behind.

One should choose a secluded dwelling, abide by inward observation, and after the three bows are completed, sit upright without rising or adjusting the posture. Close the eyes and still the mind. When stillness reaches its utmost, the body seems to float in empty space. Spirit and qi drift freely, difficult to restrain. In silent inward observation, clarity shines unobscured. Mountains and rivers appear resplendent, pavilions faintly discernible, purple qi and crimson light swirling in formation, auspicious simurghs and colorful phoenixes singing like reed pipes. The wondrous scenes and splendor may be called the true delight of the pot, the separate realm of the grotto-heaven—carefree and at ease, utterly unaware of the burdens of the dusty world.

At this moment of true emptiness, the qi transforms of its own accord, without need for methods or adherence to time. If one sees green qi emerging from the east, with the sounds of reed pipes and drums, banners, carriages, and horses appearing left and right, front and back, in countless numbers—then suddenly, red qi emerges from the south, white qi from the west, black qi from the north, and yellow qi from the center.

chunks.original_text: 五气结聚而为彩云，乐气嘈杂，喜气熙熙。 金童玉女，扶拥自身或跨火龙，或乘玄鹤，或跨彩鸾，或骑猛虎，升于空中，自下而上，所遇之处，楼台观宇，不能尽陈，神祗官吏，不可备说。 又到一处，女乐万行，官僚班列，如人间帝王之仪，圣贤毕至。 当此之时，见之傍若无人，乘驾上升，以至一门，兵卫严肃，而不可犯。 左右前后，官僚女乐，留恋不已，终是过门不得。 轩盖覆面，自上而下，复入旧居之地。 如此上下不厌其数，是调神出壳之法也。 积日纯熟，一升而到天宫，一降而还旧处。 上下绝无滞碍，乃自下而上。 或如登七级宝塔，或如上三层琼楼，其始也，一级而复一级，七级上尽以至顶中，不得下视，恐神惊而恋躯不出。 既至七级之上，则闭目便跳，如寐如寤，身外有身。 形似婴儿，肌肤鲜洁，神采莹然。 回视故躯，亦不见有，所见之者，乃如粪堆，又如枯木，憎愧万端，不可顿弃而远游。 盖其神出未熟，圣气凝结而成。 须是再入本躯，往来出入，一任遨游。 始乎一步二步，次二里三里。 积日纯熟，乃如壮士展臂，可千里万里。 而形神壮大，勇气坚固。 然后寄凡骸于名山大川之中，从往来应世之外，不与俗类等伦。 或行满而受天书，骖鸾乘凤，跨虎乘龙，自东自西，以入紫府。 先见太微真君，次居下岛。 欲升洞天，当传道积行于人间，受天书而升洞天，以为天仙。 凡行此法，古今少有成者：盖以功不备而欲行之速，便为此道； 或功验未证，止事静坐，欲求超脱； 或阴灵不散，出为鬼仙，人不见形，来往去住，终无所归，止于投胎就舍，而夺人躯壳，复得为人； 或出入不熟，往来无法，一去一来，无由再入本身，神魂不知所在。 乃释子之坐化，道流之尸解也。 故行此道，要在前功见验正当，仍择地筑室，以远一切腥秽之物、臭恶之气、往来之声、女子之色。 不止于触其真气，而神亦厌之。 既出而复入，入而不出，则形神俱妙，与天地齐年，而浩劫不死。 既入而复出，出而不入，如蝉脱蜕，迁神入圣。 此乃超凡脱俗，以为真人仙子，而在风尘之外，寄居三岛之洲者也。 道要曰：不无尽法，已灭息矣。 以上超凡入圣之诀，右大乘三门系天仙。 补注：本单元之见金诰曰：乃指元始天尊说之意。 本单元　见玉书曰：乃指灵宝天尊说之意。 本单元　见真源曰：乃指太上老君说之意。 本单元之见真诀、道要、此喻曰：乃指正阳真人说之意。 （全篇完） 九品仙经　(卷九)

The five qi converge and coalesce into iridescent clouds, while joyous music resounds in a clamor, and blissful qi radiates warmth. Golden lads and jade maidens support and escort one’s self, or one rides a fiery dragon, mounts a dark crane, straddles a colorful simurgh, or bestrides a fierce tiger, ascending into the void. From below to above, wherever one passes, pavilions and temples stretch beyond description, while divine officials and spirits defy enumeration. Arriving at another place, ten thousand rows of female musicians stand in array, and officials form ranks like the court of an earthly emperor, with sages and worthies all in attendance.

At this moment, one sees all as if no one else exists, riding upward until reaching a gate where guards stand solemn and inviolable. On all sides, officials and female musicians linger with reluctance, yet ultimately, one cannot pass through the gate. Canopies cover one’s face as one descends from above, returning to the former dwelling. Such ascents and descents occur countless times without weariness—this is the method of harmonizing the spirit to exit the shell. With days of accumulated practice, one ascends in a single bound to the celestial palace and descends in one motion to the original place. Up and down, there is no obstruction, as if ascending from below to above. It may resemble climbing a seven-tiered pagoda or ascending a three-story jade tower: at first, one climbs step by step, and upon reaching the seventh tier, one must not look down, lest the spirit be startled and cling to the body, refusing to depart. Once atop the seventh tier, one closes the eyes and leaps as if in sleep or waking—there is a body beyond the body. Its form resembles an infant, with fresh and radiant skin, its spirit luminous and bright. Looking back at the former body, one sees nothing of it, only what appears as a dung heap or withered wood, evoking endless shame and disgust. Yet one cannot immediately abandon it and wander far, for the spirit’s departure is not yet perfected, and the sagely qi has congealed to form it. One must re-enter the original body, coming and going freely, roaming at will. At first, one may take but one or two steps, then two or three *li*. With days of accumulated practice, one may stretch forth like a warrior, traversing a thousand or ten thousand *li*. The form and spirit grow robust, and courage becomes unshakable. Only then may one entrust the mortal frame to the great mountains and rivers, dwelling beyond the comings and goings of the world, no longer equaling the common folk. When one’s conduct is complete, one receives the celestial writ, riding simurghs and phoenixes, straddling tigers and mounting dragons, traveling east and west to enter the Purple Palace. First, one meets the True Lord of the Grand Tenuity, then resides on the lower isles. To ascend to the grotto-heaven, one must transmit the Dao and accumulate merit among mortals, receive the celestial writ, and ascend to the grotto-heaven as a celestial immortal.

Few in ancient or modern times have succeeded in this practice. Some, lacking sufficient merit, seek swift attainment and thus pursue this path; others, though their merits remain unproven, merely engage in quiet sitting, hoping for transcendence. If residual yin spirits do not disperse, they may become ghostly immortals, unseen by others, coming and going without fixed abode, ultimately forced to seize mortal bodies and be reborn as humans. Or, if one’s comings and goings are unskilled and without method, departing and returning without means to re-enter the original body, the spirit may wander without destination—this is the sitting transformation of Buddhist monks or the corpse liberation of Daoist adepts. Thus, in practicing this path, one must first ensure that prior merits are verified and appropriate, then select a secluded place to build a chamber, far from all foul and putrid things, noxious vapors, passing sounds, and the allure of women. Not only do these disturb the true qi, but the spirit itself grows weary of them. If one exits and re-enters, entering without exiting, then form and spirit become wondrous, attaining the lifespan of heaven and earth, enduring through eons without death. If one enters and exits, exiting without re-entering, it is like the cicada shedding its husk, transforming the spirit to attain sageliness. This is transcending the mundane and shedding the vulgar, becoming a true person and immortal, dwelling beyond the dusty world on the isles of the Three Mountains.

The essential Dao states: "The inexhaustible Dharma has already ceased and stilled."

The above are the secrets of transcending the mundane and entering sageliness, belonging to the Great Vehicle’s three gates of celestial immortality.

chunks.original_text: 经集汇 九品仙经自序 吾乃唐朝进士。 夙世好道，感正阳师，引入终南，投进玄门。 自起弘愿，度尽众生。 大愿已出，追悔难及。 尝闻天地最高，玄妙用之无穷。 天高地奥，玄之生玄，三教一理，迷凡不参。 虚空生无，复本还原。 吾蒙正阳师立传金丹，一纪飞升，朝拜上帝，蒙　帝开怜，领旨下方，普度群迷。 迷夫不醒，显身留传《八品仙经》：广陵二品、金陵二品、毗陵二品，临江、信州共成八品。 又奉旨复下济水，开透凡心。 凡子不识，赐之乩鸾，戊子年命谕子，立求《九品仙经》，《拔心宝忏心经》。 五处留传八品，少传一品，后淮扬潘延吉，成九品，又有《拔心宝忏》。 玉文赐青灵真人，取回济水，指引众生入道： 遵天地君亲师，仁义礼智信： 不敬天地，雷震电随，暴雨混死； 不敬地，尸首落水，体现鸭； 不孝父母，天地难容，万劫不免； 不忠君王，败国欺君，后堕沈沦； 不遵师教，天地循环，后醒难逃。 夫天命之为性，不离理也。 离理非道，道理行，方成人礼！ 夫义者，敬重天地，尊事长上，莫犯五愆，义也； 夫礼者，礼义廉耻，上不失于乡党，下不失于庶民，敬其天，尊其地，孝其亲，慈其幼，礼也； 夫智者：上智之虚无一气，中智之于国家，下智之于人伦，智也； 夫信者：信之于天地，信之于国家，信之于亲党，下不失信于子幼，此是人伦。 仁义礼智信也，吾开迷愚，出凡界，引进众生入玄门。 先敬其天，天降吉祥，天清也； 敬其地，地生万物，地宁也。 自然百种生芽，五谷丰登。 夫人伦，必行善念，躲狱门，出迷途，离凡界，登觉路，通大道，出海岸，明虚无。 渐渐加工，超列仙班。 吾亲留传《九品仙经》之序，有还真会弟子，甄章赵等善，甲午年发愿，在白鹤观，立刊仙经。 世人若求道者，休论千万路遥，诚心进道，何言万里终南！ 世人请　吾仙经，所谋皆遂，利益皆顺。 灵符九道，荡荡除魔，扫尽人间之祸根，引进乾坤之妙门。 尊人伦，有仁义礼智信； 信参道，上有精神。 三教皆有，无所忐音毯忑音忒。 印经即印心，刊经即刊道。 人道既就，仙道可成！ 岂不恬于天地之间，存于后代之凡迷。 上不测于文，下不失于礼。 名登仙谱，九祖生天，岂不快哉！ 余身列仙班，亲笔而成。 太上玄元开化仙经品第九 尔时　纯阳大帝，在兜率之天，清虚之府，趺音夫跏音加蕉团，手执如意，晏然默坐。 诸天仙神，雷火二部，城隍里社，凛肃侍立。 大帝曰：「吾奉帝，遍历九洲，普度群迷，阐扬大道，咸登正觉，为因众生，迷而不悟，吾今弘宣经教八品，一在广陵，二在金陵，三在毗陵，四在信州，五在临江，共成八品，为世津梁。 众生信者，百中一二，谤者不可胜纪。 吾奉帝命，体好生之德，施广济之仁，谆谆告戒，明明敷说。 众生如聋如瞶，以致上帝震怒，水火刀兵，瘟疫蝗蝻，人不聊生，父子兄弟，夫妻骨肉，离散流亡。 众生不知儆悛，反起怨尤。 鉴兹冥顽，深加悯惜，故不厌滚滚尘凡，万亿化身，演说道法，超拔苦根。 众生不知玄妙，妄说妄行，谤道谤法。 吾愍不咎，益加提醒。 但众生为利欲情爱，迷却本来，不忠不孝，不友不悌，不公不直，不信不义。

**Preface to the *Collected Scriptures: Scripture of the Nine Grades of Immortals***

I am a *jinshi* of the Tang dynasty. From past lives, I have been devoted to the Dao, and by the grace of Master Zhengyang, I was led into the Zhongnan Mountains and initiated into the Mystery Gate. From that moment, I vowed to ferry all sentient beings across. Once this great vow was uttered, regret came too late.

I have heard that the highest mysteries of Heaven and Earth are boundless in their wondrous workings. Heaven is lofty, Earth profound—mystery begets mystery. The Three Teachings share a single principle, yet deluded mortals fail to grasp it. The Void gives birth to the formless, and from there, one returns to the origin.

By the grace of Master Zhengyang, I was transmitted the Golden Elixir. After twelve years, I ascended and paid homage before the August Emperor. Moved by compassion, the Emperor commanded me to descend to the mortal realm and universally deliver the deluded. Yet the deluded remained unmoved, so I manifested in person and left behind the *Scripture of the Eight Grades of Immortals*: two scrolls in Guangling, two in Jinling, two in Piling, and one each in Linjiang and Xinzhou—eight in total.

Later, by imperial decree, I descended again to the Jishui River to open the hearts of mortals. Still, they remained ignorant, so I bestowed upon them the oracle of the planchette. In the year *wuzǐ*, I was commanded to compile the *Scripture of the Nine Grades of Immortals* and the *Precious Repentance Sutra for Extracting the Heart*. Though five regions had received the eight scrolls, one was missing. Later, Pan Yanjǐ of Huaiyang completed the ninth, along with the *Precious Repentance*.

The Jade Writ was bestowed upon the Azure Spirit Perfected, who retrieved it from the Jishui River to guide sentient beings into the Dao. One must revere Heaven and Earth, sovereign and parents, and teachers, and uphold benevolence, righteousness, propriety, wisdom, and trust.

To disrespect Heaven invites thunder, lightning, and torrential rains that drown all in chaos. To disrespect Earth brings corpses to the waters, their bodies manifesting as ducks and geese. To be unfilial to parents ensures that neither Heaven nor Earth will tolerate you, and you shall suffer for ten thousand kalpas. To be disloyal to the sovereign brings ruin to the state and deceit to the ruler, and you shall later sink into the depths. To disregard the teachings of your master is to invite the cycles of Heaven and Earth, from which awakening is nearly impossible to escape.

That which Heaven decrees as human nature cannot depart from principle. To depart from principle is to stray from the Dao. Only when principle and the Dao are practiced in harmony does one fulfill human propriety!

Righteousness (*yì*) is to revere Heaven and Earth, honor one’s superiors, and avoid the Five Transgressions. Propriety (*lǐ*) is to uphold integrity, shame, modesty, and a sense of honor—neither losing respect among one’s village nor among the common folk—revering Heaven, honoring Earth, being filial to parents, and compassionate to the young. Wisdom (*zhì*) is the highest wisdom of the formless and unified *qi*, the middle wisdom of serving the state, and the lower wisdom of human relations. Trust (*xìn*) is to be true to Heaven and Earth, true to the state, true to one’s kin, and never break faith with the young. These are the bonds of human relations.

Benevolence, righteousness, propriety, wisdom, and trust—I open the eyes of the deluded, lead them out of the mundane, and guide sentient beings into the Mystery Gate. First, revere Heaven, and Heaven will send down auspiciousness, for Heaven is pure. Revere Earth, and Earth will bring forth the myriad things, for Earth is at peace. Naturally, a hundred plants will sprout, and the five grains will flourish.

In human relations, one must cultivate good thoughts, avoid the gates of hell, escape the paths of delusion, depart the mundane, ascend the path of awakening, penetrate the Great Dao, emerge from the sea of suffering, and illuminate the formless. Through gradual refinement, one may transcend and join the ranks of immortals.

This preface to the *Scripture of the Nine Grades of Immortals* was left by me personally. The disciples of the Returning to Truth Assembly, Zhen Zhang, Zhao Shan, and others, in the year *jiǎwǔ*, vowed at the White Crane Abbey to carve and publish the immortal scriptures.

If mortals seek the Dao, let them not speak of the distance of a thousand miles—with sincere hearts, how can the ten thousand *li* to Zhongnan be called far? Those who request my immortal scriptures shall see all their endeavors succeed and all their fortunes align.

The nine numinous talismans sweep away demons, eradicate the roots of calamity in the human realm, and guide one into the wondrous gate of Heaven and Earth. Uphold human relations with benevolence, righteousness, propriety, wisdom, and trust. Have faith in the Dao, and above, refine your essence and spirit.

The Three Teachings all possess these truths—there is no room for doubt or hesitation. To print the scriptures is to print the heart; to carve the scriptures is to carve the Dao. Once the human Dao is accomplished, the immortal Dao may be achieved! How could one not find contentment between Heaven and Earth, preserving this for the deluded of later generations?

Above, it is unfathomable in its literary grace; below, it does not stray from propriety. To have one’s name inscribed in the immortal register, to have nine generations ascend to Heaven—how could this not be joyous!

I, now ranked among the immortals, have personally penned this.

**The Ninth Scroll of the *Scriptures of the Mysterious Origin of the Most High***

At that time, the Great Emperor of Pure Yang was in the Heaven of Tuṣita, the Palace of Pure Emptiness. Seated in full-lotus, holding a *rúyì*, he sat in serene silence. The divine immortals of the myriad heavens, the thunder and fire departments, the city gods and village altars—all stood in solemn attendance.

The Great Emperor spoke: "By the decree of the August Emperor, I have traversed the nine continents to universally deliver the deluded, propagate the Great Dao, and lead all to right awakening. Yet for the sake of sentient beings, who remain deluded and unenlightened, I have now proclaimed the eight scrolls of the immortal scriptures: one in Guangling, two in Jinling, three in Piling, four in Xinzhou, and five in Linjiang—eight in total, serving as a bridge for the world.

Of the multitude of sentient beings, only one or two in a hundred believe, while those who slander are beyond counting. By the Emperor’s command, embodying the virtue of cherishing life and the benevolence of universal salvation, I earnestly admonish and clearly expound. Yet sentient beings are as deaf and blind, provoking the wrath of the August Emperor. Disasters of flood, fire, blade, and warfare, plagues and locusts, have left people with no means to live. Fathers and sons, brothers, husbands and wives, flesh and blood—all are scattered and lost.

The deluded remain unrepentant, instead harboring resentment. Witnessing such obstinacy, I am deeply moved with pity. Thus, I tirelessly descend into the dusty mortal realm, manifesting in countless forms to expound the Dao and deliver beings from the roots of suffering. Yet sentient beings, ignorant of the profound mysteries, speak and act recklessly, slandering the Dao and its teachings.

Though I do not reproach them, I redouble my efforts to awaken them. But sentient beings, ensnared by profit, desire, and emotional attachments, have forgotten their original nature. They are disloyal, unfilial, unkind, undutiful, unjust, deceitful, untrustworthy, and unrighteous."

chunks.original_text: 祇有剥利于己，不知贻害在人； 一味温饱自求，不念君亲兄弟； 鳏独孤寡，忍心毒害； 违背圣贤，轻蔑天民； 大过不改，小善不为； 妄言绮语，恶口两舌。 种种孽障，自堕坑，犹然不悟生死事大，无常迅速。 一入轮回，人身难再，三途六道，堕落阿鼻，虽欲改悔，望救何及！ 茫茫苦趣，惟道可提。 清真虚朗，湛然太空，无人我相，乃见元极。 众生蒙蒙，如梦如醉。 醉犹有醒，梦犹有觉。 何以众生，茫然不省？ 眼前皆道。 三教一识，儒曰『执中』，释曰『空中』，在　吾之道，惟曰『守中』。 所以儒者『存心养性』，若其释也，『明心见性』，惟吾之道，『修心炼性』。 惟心之修，忠孝以成，君亲兄弟，莫不咸宜； 惟性之炼，安分忍辱，不彰人短，不恃己长。 治国齐家，惟公惟正，敬感上帝，水火无侵，盗贼消弭，疾疫不生，刀兵永息，父子团圞，骨肉不离，珍禾嘉穗，五风十雨，福禄荐臻，灾祲消除，国祚永宁，民生常怡。 谛听吾言，修真入道，同登彼岸，超脱死生。 昔在广陵，谤　吾大道，欺侮上帝，毁仙詈佛，贬圣排贤，以致降戮。 吾救不能，深为垂怜。 特游淮海，渡人迷津。 众生其念，勉力为善，毋为自误，罪堕丘山，慎之慎之，改恶奉行。 」
chunks.translated_text:
Only seeking advantage for oneself, heedless of the harm left for others; ever pursuing warmth and fullness for oneself, unmindful of lord, kin, or brothers. The widowed, orphaned, solitary, and bereft—one callously poisons and harms them. Defying the sages and worthies, scorning the people of heaven. Major transgressions go uncorrected; minor virtues remain undone. Idle chatter, seductive speech, harsh words, and double tongues. Such manifold karmic obstructions cast one into pits and snares, yet still one fails to awaken to the gravity of life and death, to the swiftness of impermanence. Once fallen into the wheel of rebirth, the human form is hard to regain. The three evil destinies and six paths lead to the Avīci hell—though one may seek to repent and reform, to whom can one turn for deliverance?

In the boundless realm of suffering, only the Dao can uplift. Pure and true, empty and luminous, it abides in the vastness of the great void, free from the distinctions of self and other—only then can one perceive the Primordial Ultimate. Yet sentient beings remain benighted, as if dreaming, as if drunk. Drunkenness may yet pass, dreams may yet be awakened from—why then do sentient beings remain so utterly oblivious? The Dao is before their very eyes.

The Three Teachings share one insight: the Confucians call it "holding to the center," the Buddhists call it "emptiness within," while in our Dao, it is simply "guarding the center." Thus, the Confucians "preserve the heart and nurture nature"; the Buddhists, "illumine the heart and perceive nature"; while in our Dao, we "cultivate the heart and refine nature." In cultivating the heart, loyalty and filial piety are perfected, and none—lord, kin, or brothers—are left unsuited. In refining nature, one abides in contentment and endures humiliation, neither exposing others' faults nor flaunting one's own strengths.

In governing the state and ordering the family, only impartiality and uprightness prevail. Reverence moves the Lord on High, and water and fire cannot encroach. Bandits and thieves vanish; illness and plague do not arise. The sword is forever stilled; fathers and sons reunite, flesh and blood remain unsevered. Precious grains and fine ears flourish; timely winds and seasonable rains come. Blessings and prosperity abound; calamities and omens dissolve. The nation enjoys eternal peace; the people dwell in constant joy.

Heed my words: cultivate truth and enter the Dao, that together we may ascend the other shore and transcend life and death. Once, in Guangling, they slandered our great Dao, mocked the Lord on High, reviled immortals and cursed buddhas, disparaged sages and rejected worthies—thus bringing down destruction. Though I could not save them, I deeply pitied their fate. Therefore, I journeyed to the Huai and the sea to ferry those lost in the ford of delusion.

Let sentient beings take heed: strive to do good, lest you err to your own ruin. The sins you amass will be as mountains—beware, beware! Turn from evil and practice the Way.

chunks.original_text: 清虚子，长跪叩曰：「道何以名？ 愿指教明，使众生醒觉，为入门蹊径。 」 大帝曰：「大哉斯问！ 汝其倾听，洗心涤虑。 」 诸天仙神，咸礼彤庭。 大帝放大光明，三华聚顶，五朝元，为诸天雷火城社，而说道曰：「夫道也者：位天地，育万物，曰道； 揭日月，生五行，曰道； 多于恒河沙数，曰道； 独明孤然无侣，曰道； 开鸿蒙而归溟涬，曰道； 夺造化而超死生，曰道； 处卑污而大尊贵，曰道； 居幽暗而极高明，曰道； 细入微尘，曰道； 大包天地，曰道； 从有入无，曰道； 作佛成仙，曰道。 『道可道，非常道，名可名，非常名。 』吾经言言玄谛，汝当细细参求，普为世说，以悟群迷。 」 即说偈曰：大哉至哉道　　天地万物生孝弟及忠信　　为人之大经力行休自怠　　本立而道生刀兵永无劫　　水火总不攻虎入南山卧　　龙归北海瞑当使神驭气　　驭气炼真精精化神还虚　　引汝拜太清超然三界外　　不在世五行举步风云合　　言谈鬼魅惊自心清湛湛　　九祖尽超升慎哉吾所言　　大道此中寻 大帝说偈已毕，诸天神将仙子，咸起恭敬，发大欢喜。 大帝曰：「吾经八品，传世已久，人未广信，今上谷潘延吉，欲布扬玄妙，弘传大道，受经行世，凡经所在之处，诸天仙神，雷火二部，城隍里社，自加拥护。 」 诸天神将，作礼唯命而退。
chunks.translated_text:
The Master of Pure Emptiness knelt and kowtowed, saying: "By what name is the Dao known? I humbly beseech Your illumination, that all sentient beings may awaken and find the path to the gate."

The Great Emperor replied: "A profound question indeed! Listen with utmost attention, purify your heart and still your thoughts."

All the celestial immortals and divine spirits bowed in reverence before the vermilion court. The Great Emperor radiated a great light, the Three Flowers gathering at his crown, the Five Qi returning to their origin. For the celestial palaces, the thunder-fire citadels, and the earthly altars, he expounded the Dao, saying:

"That which establishes Heaven and Earth and nurtures the myriad things is called the Dao.
That which illumines the sun and moon and generates the Five Phases is called the Dao.
That which is more numerous than the sands of the Ganges is called the Dao.
That which alone shines, solitary and without peer, is called the Dao.
That which opens the primordial chaos and returns to the primordial vastness is called the Dao.
That which seizes the workings of creation and transcends life and death is called the Dao.
That which abides in the lowly and filthy yet is supremely noble is called the Dao.
That which dwells in darkness yet attains the utmost brilliance is called the Dao.
That which enters the tiniest speck of dust is called the Dao.
That which encompasses Heaven and Earth is called the Dao.
That which moves from being into non-being is called the Dao.
That which enables one to become a buddha or an immortal is called the Dao.

*'The Dao that can be spoken is not the eternal Dao; the name that can be named is not the eternal name.'*

Every word of my scriptures conveys the profound truth. You must contemplate them carefully, proclaim them widely to the world, and awaken the deluded multitudes."

Then he spoke this gatha:

Great indeed, most wondrous is the Dao,
Giving birth to Heaven, Earth, and the myriad things.
Filial piety, fraternal duty, loyalty, and trust—
These are the great canons for humanity.
Strive in practice, never grow lax,
For when the root is firm, the Dao is born.
Swords and weapons shall never bring calamity,
Water and fire shall never assail.
Tigers shall slumber in the southern mountains,
Dragons shall return to the northern seas.
You must master the spirit and guide the qi,
Refine the qi to cultivate the true essence.
Essence transforms into spirit, returning to emptiness,
And leads you to worship the Supreme Clarity.
Transcending the Three Realms,
Beyond the Five Phases of the world,
Each step summons wind and clouds,
Each word startles ghosts and spirits.
When the heart is pure and limpid,
Nine generations of ancestors ascend.
Heed well my words—
Within this lies the Great Dao."

When the Great Emperor finished speaking the gatha, all the celestial generals, divine marshals, and immortal disciples rose in reverence, filled with boundless joy.

The Great Emperor said: "My scripture in eight fascicles has been transmitted in the world for ages, yet few have widely believed in it. Now, Pan Yangji of Shanggu wishes to propagate its profound mysteries, to widely transmit the Great Dao, and to receive and circulate the scripture. Wherever this scripture resides, all the celestial immortals, divine generals, the thunder and fire departments, city gods, and village altars shall naturally provide protection."

All the celestial generals bowed in assent and withdrew.

Praise says:
To save the kalpa and prolong the sun and moon’s days,
To return the soul and restore life to the Purple Cloud Realm—
The floating net’s precious canopy joins with the vast primordial harmony,
The wondrous Dharma’s radiance defies all measure.

The Boundless Great Dao,
The Primordial Dharma King—
A single pearl of treasure lies at the center,
Expounding the Dharma and emitting auspicious light.
Universally unfolding the golden scriptures,
All sages bow to the Void Sovereign—*(repeated line)*
